(1) The Central Government may make rules regulating the construction, equipment and maintenance of motor vehicles and trailers with respect to all or any of the following matters: (a) width, height, length and overhang of vehicles and loads carried; (b) size, nature, maximum retail price and condition of tyres, including date/year of manufacture and maximum load capacity; (c) brakes and steering gear; (d) safety glasses including prohibition of tinted safety glasses; (e) signalling appliances, lamps and reflectors; (f) speed governors; (g) emission of smoke, visible vapour, sparks, ashes, grit, or oil; (h) noise reduction; (i) embossment of chassis number, engine number, and date of manufacture; (j) safety belts, motorcycle handlebars, auto-dippers, and other safety equipment; (k) standards of components including software used as inbuilt safety devices; (l) transport of dangerous or hazardous goods; (m) standards for air pollutant emissions; (n) catalytic converters in prescribed vehicle classes; (o) placement of audio-visual or radio/tape recorder devices in public vehicles; (p) warranty after sale of vehicle and related norms. Rules concerning environment protection shall be made after consultation with the Ministry handling environment matters.
(2) Rules may also provide for ensuring compliance, maintenance, investigation procedures, officers empowered, hearing procedures, and applicable penalties.
(2A) Empowered investigators have civil court powers to summon persons, require documents, receive affidavits, and other prescribed powers.
(3) Notwithstanding this section: (a) The Central Government may exempt any class of motor vehicles from this Chapter; (b) State Governments may exempt certain vehicles from these rules subject to Central Government conditions.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 110A - Recall of motor vehicles
content:
(1) The Central Government may direct a manufacturer to recall vehicles of a particular type or variant if: (a) a defect may cause harm to the environment, driver, occupants, or road users; and (b) the defect has been reported by a specified percentage of owners, a testing agency, or other sources.
(2) If the defect lies in a vehicle component, the recall shall apply to all vehicles containing that component.
(3) The manufacturer must: (a) reimburse buyers the full cost of the vehicle (subject to any agreements); or (b) replace with a similar or better compliant vehicle or repair it; and (c) pay fines and dues per subsection (6).
(4) If a manufacturer voluntarily reports and recalls defective vehicles, no fine under subsection (3) applies.
(5) The Central Government may authorise investigating officers with civil court powers to summon persons, require documents, receive affidavits, and do other prescribed acts.
(6) The Central Government may make rules for regulating vehicle recalls for defects causing potential harm.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 110B - Type approval certificate and testing agencies
content:
(1) No motor vehicle, trailer, semi-trailer, modular hydraulic trailer, or side car may be sold, delivered, or used in public in India without a type-approval certificate under subsection (2), unless exempted for export, display, testing, or other specified purposes.
(2) Manufacturers or importers must submit vehicle prototypes to a testing agency for type-approval certification.
(3) The Central Government shall make rules for accreditation, registration, and regulation of testing agencies.
(4) Testing agencies must test production vehicles to ensure compliance with this Act and related rules.
(5) If a vehicle with a type-approval certificate is recalled under section 110A, the issuing testing agency may have its accreditation and registration cancelled.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 111 - Power of State Government to make rules
content:
(1) A State Government may make rules regulating the construction, equipment, and maintenance of motor vehicles and trailers for matters not covered in section 110(1).
(2) Rules may address: (a) seating arrangements in public service vehicles and passenger protection from weather; (b) restrictions on audible signals at certain times/places; (c) prohibition on carrying appliances likely to cause annoyance or danger; (d) periodic testing and inspection of vehicles, including applicable fees; (e) particulars other than registration marks to be displayed and their manner; (f) use of trailers with motor vehicles.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 112 - Limits of speed
content: (1) No person shall drive or allow a motor vehicle to be driven in any public place at a speed exceeding the maximum speed or below the minimum speed fixed for the vehicle under this Act or any other law: Provided that such maximum speed shall not exceed that fixed by the Central Government by notification. (2) The State Government or authorized authority may, by notification and traffic signs, set maximum or minimum speed limits for motor vehicles or specified classes or vehicles with trailers, either generally or in certain areas or on specified roads, based on public safety or road conditions. Notification is not needed if the restriction is to remain in force for not more than one month. (3) This section does not apply to vehicles registered under section 60 when used in military manoeuvres as specified under the Manoeuvres, Field Firing and Artillery Practice Act, 1938.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 113 - Limits of weight and limitations on use
content: (1) The State Government may set conditions for issuing permits for transport vehicles and may prohibit or restrict use of such vehicles in any area or route. (2) Unless otherwise prescribed, no person shall drive or allow to be driven a motor vehicle without pneumatic tyres. (3) No person shall drive or allow to be driven any motor vehicle or trailer: (a) with an unladen weight exceeding that specified in the registration certificate, or (b) with a laden weight exceeding the gross vehicle weight specified in the registration certificate. (4) If a non-owner drives or is in charge of a vehicle in contravention of sub-section (2) or clause (a) of sub-section (3), a Court may presume the offence was committed with the knowledge or orders of the owner.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 114 - Power to have vehicle weighed
content: (1) Any officer of the Motor Vehicles Department or authorized person may, if he suspects a goods vehicle or trailer is being used in contravention of section 113, require the driver to take the vehicle to a weighing device within ten kilometres en route or twenty kilometres from destination for weighment. If found overloaded, he may order the driver to off-load excess weight and not move the vehicle until compliance, and the driver must follow these directions. (2) The officer must endorse details of overloading on the goods carriage permit and notify the issuing authority.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 115 - Power to restrict the use of vehicles
content: The State Government or authorized authority may, by notification, prohibit or restrict, with exceptions and conditions as specified, the driving of motor vehicles or particular classes or the use of trailers generally in a specified area or on specified roads if needed for public safety or convenience, or due to road or bridge conditions. Traffic signs must be placed accordingly under section 116. For restrictions under this section lasting not more than one month, notification in the Gazette is not necessary, but appropriate local publicity should be given.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 116 - Power to erect traffic signs
content: (1) The State Government or authorized authority may place or permit traffic signs in any public place to indicate speed limits, prohibitions or restrictions, or to regulate vehicle traffic. Roads may be designated main roads by notification or traffic signs. (1A) The National Highways Authority of India or authorized agency may place, erect, or remove traffic signs on national highways for regulating traffic and may order removal of signs or advertisements obscuring, resembling, or distracting from traffic signs, with assistance from State Government authorities as needed. (2) Such traffic signs must match the size, colour, and type specified in the Schedule, but transcriptions in other scripts may be allowed. (3) Except as above, no traffic sign may be placed after commencement of this Act except those legally placed before. (4) A State Government may empower police officers (Superintendent or higher) to remove signs or advertisements that obscure or resemble traffic signs or distract drivers. (5) No person shall wilfully remove, alter, deface, or tamper with any traffic sign placed under this section. (6) If a person accidentally damages a traffic sign so it becomes useless, he must report the occurrence to police as soon as possible, and within twenty-four hours. (7) The Central Government may modify any sign in the First Schedule by notification to conform with international conventions, and the Schedule will be amended accordingly.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 117 - Parking places and halting stations
content: The State Government or authorized authority may, in consultation with the local authority, determine places for vehicles to stand indefinitely or for set periods, and determine where public service vehicles may stop for longer than to pick up or set down passengers. Safety of road users and free flow of traffic must be prioritized. The National Highways Authority of India or authorized agency may also determine such places.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 118 - Driving regulations
content: The Central Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, make regulations for driving motor vehicles.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 119 - Duty to obey traffic signs
content: (1) Every motor vehicle driver must drive in conformity with mandatory traffic signs and regulations made by the Central Government and comply with instructions from police officers regulating traffic. (2) 'Mandatory traffic sign' means a sign included in Part A of the Schedule, or similarly formed signs (circular disc with device, word, or figure and red ground/border) placed to regulate traffic under section 116(1).

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 120 - Vehicles with left hand control
content: No person shall drive or allow to be driven a motor vehicle with left-hand steering control in any public place unless it is equipped with a prescribed mechanical or electrical signalling device in working order.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 121 - Signals and signalling devices
content: A driver must give prescribed signals on occasions as set out by the Central Government. To signal a turn or stop: (a) for right-hand steering control vehicles, signals may be given by an approved device; (b) for left-hand steering control vehicles, signals must be given by an approved device. The State Government may, for certain areas or routes, exempt vehicles or classes from this requirement by notification, subject to specified conditions.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 122 - Leaving vehicle in dangerous position
content: No person in charge of a motor vehicle shall cause or allow it or any trailer to be abandoned or left at rest in a public place in such a position, condition, or circumstances as to cause or be likely to cause danger, obstruction, or undue inconvenience to other public place users or passengers.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 123 - Riding on running board, etc.
content: (1) No driver or person in charge shall carry or allow any person to be carried on the running board or anywhere other than within the body of the vehicle. (2) No person shall travel on the running board, top, or bonnet of a motor vehicle.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 124 - Prohibition against travelling without pass or ticket
content: No person shall enter or remain in a stage carriage for travel unless he possesses a proper pass or ticket. Where tickets are supplied in the stage carriage, a person may enter but must pay the fare at the earliest and obtain a ticket. 'Pass' means a document allowing free or paid travel for a specified period; 'ticket' means a single, return, or season ticket.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 125 - Obstruction of driver
content: No driver shall allow any person to stand, sit, or place anything in any manner or position that hampers his control of the vehicle.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 126 - Stationary vehicles
content: No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall allow it to remain stationary in a public place unless there is a person duly licensed to drive in the driver's seat, or unless the mechanism is stopped and brakes or other measures have been taken so that the vehicle cannot be accidentally set in motion.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 127 - Removal of motor vehicles abandoned or left unattended on a public place
content: (1) If a motor vehicle is abandoned or left unattended for ten hours or more or parked where prohibited, its removal or immobilization may be authorized by a police officer in uniform. (2) If such a vehicle is creating a traffic hazard or impediment, immediate removal may be authorized. (3) The owner of a removed vehicle is responsible for towing costs and any penalty.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 128 - Safety measures for drivers and pillion riders
content: (1) The driver of a two-wheeled motorcycle shall not carry more than one additional person, and the pillion must sit on a proper seat with safety measures. (2) The Central Government may prescribe further safety measures for drivers and pillion riders.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 129 - Wearing of protective headgear
content: Every person above four years of age, driving or riding on a motorcycle in a public place, must wear protective headgear meeting standards prescribed by the Central Government. This does not apply to a Sikh wearing a turban. Measures for the safety of children below four riding or being carried may be specified. 'Protective headgear' means a helmet designed and fastened to provide injury protection.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 130 - Duty to produce licence and certificate of registration
content: (1) The driver of a motor vehicle shall, on demand by a police officer in uniform, produce his licence. If the licence has been submitted or seized under any law, a receipt or acknowledgment may be produced and the actual licence submitted within the prescribed period. (2) The conductor of a motor vehicle must, on demand, produce his licence for examination. (3) The owner or, in his absence, driver or person in charge shall, on demand, produce the certificate of insurance and, for transport vehicles, the certificate of fitness and permit. If not in possession, copies must be submitted within fifteen days. 'Certificate of insurance' means the certificate issued under section 147(3). (4) If the licence or certificates/permit are not available at the time of demand, production within the prescribed period and manner is sufficient, except as otherwise prescribed for certain certificates.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 131 - Duty of the driver to take certain precautions at unguarded railway level crossings
content: At an unguarded railway level crossing, every motor vehicle driver must stop the vehicle and have a conductor, cleaner, attendant, or other person walk to the crossing to ensure no train or trolley is approaching before crossing. If no such person is present, the driver must get down and check himself before crossing.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 132 - Duty of driver to stop in certain cases
content: (1) The driver must stop and remain stationary for reasonable time, not exceeding twenty-four hours, when required: (a) by a police officer (Sub-Inspector or above) in uniform in case of accident or damage to person, animal, vehicle, or property; (b) by a person in charge of an animal apprehending danger or alarm from the vehicle. The driver must give his name, address, and owner's details to any affected person who asks and furnishes theirs. (2) On demand by a person alleging offence under section 184, the driver must provide his name and address. (3) 'Animal' includes horse, cattle, elephant, camel, ass, mule, sheep, or goat.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 133 - Duty of owner of motor vehicle to give information
content: The owner of a motor vehicle whose driver or conductor is accused of an offence under this Act must, on demand by an authorized police officer, provide all available information regarding the name, address, and licence of the driver or conductor.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 134 - Duty of driver in case of accident and injury to a person
content: If any person is injured or property damaged in an accident involving a motor vehicle, the driver or person in charge must: (a) take reasonable steps to secure medical attention, by conveying the injured to the nearest medical practitioner or hospital, who must provide treatment without waiting for procedural formalities, unless the injured or guardian desires otherwise; (b) give any required information to police, or report circumstances to the nearest police station within twenty-four hours; (c) give written information to the insurer, including policy number, validity, date, time and place of accident, particulars of injured/killed, and driver's name and licence details. 'Driver' includes owner for this section.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 134A - Protection of Good Samaritans
content: (1) A Good Samaritan is not liable for civil or criminal action for any injury or death of an accident victim resulting from negligence while rendering emergency medical or non-medical care or assistance. (2) The Central Government may make rules regarding questioning and examination of Good Samaritans and disclosure of their personal information. 'Good Samaritan' means a person who voluntarily assists accident victims in good faith without expectation of reward.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 135 - Schemes to be framed for the investigation of accident cases and wayside amenities
content: (1) The State Government may make schemes for: (a) in-depth study of motor vehicle accidents; (b) wayside amenities on highways; (c) traffic aid posts; (d) truck parking complexes on highways; (e) other amenities for public safety and convenience. (2) Schemes by a State Government must be laid before the Legislature. (3) The Central Government may also make schemes for in-depth studies on road accident causes.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 136 - Inspection of vehicle involved in accident
content: When any accident involving a motor vehicle occurs, authorized persons may inspect the vehicle, enter premises where the vehicle is kept, and remove it for examination. The place where the vehicle is taken must be notified to the owner and the vehicle returned after completion of formalities within twenty-four hours.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 136A - Electronic monitoring and enforcement of road safety
content: (1) The State Government must ensure electronic monitoring and enforcement of road safety on highways, roads, or cities within limits prescribed by the Central Government. (2) The Central Government shall make rules for electronic monitoring and enforcement, including speed cameras, CCTV, speed guns, body wearable cameras, and related technology. 'Body wearable camera' means a mobile audio and video recording device worn on the body or uniform of authorized personnel.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 137 - Power of Central Government to make rules
content: The Central Government may make rules for: (a) occasions for drivers to signal under section 121; (aa) standards of protective headgear and safety measures for children under section 129; (b) manner of producing licences and certificates to police under section 130; (c) limits for urban cities under section 136A(1); and (d) electronic monitoring and enforcement under section 136A(2).

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 138 - Power of State Government to make rules
content: (1) The State Government may make rules to carry out this Chapter except matters in section 137. (1A) States may, for road safety, regulate activities and access of non-mechanically propelled vehicles and pedestrians to public places and national highways, in consultation with the National Highways Authority of India for national highways. (2) Rules may cover: (a) removal and custody of broken-down, abandoned, or stationary vehicles; (b) installation and use of weighing devices; (c) wayside amenities complex management; (d) exemption for fire brigade, ambulances, or other special vehicles; (e) parking place management and fees; (f) banning gearless driving downhill; (g) banning mounting or holding moving vehicles; (h) banning use of footpaths/pavements by vehicles; (i) preventing danger, injury, annoyance, or obstruction; (j) any other prescribed matter.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 139 - Power of Central Government to make rules
content: (1) The Central Government may, by notification, make rules for: (a) granting and authenticating travelling passes, certificates, or authorisations to persons temporarily taking vehicles out of India or proceeding abroad and wishing to drive during their absence; (b) prescribing conditions for possession and use in India of vehicles brought temporarily from abroad by persons on temporary stay; (c) prescribing conditions for persons entering India on a temporary stay to drive motor vehicles in India. (2) For facilitating and regulating motor vehicle services between India and other countries under reciprocal arrangements for carriage of passengers and/or goods for hire or reward, the Central Government may make rules on: (a) conditions for bringing such vehicles into India; (b) conditions for taking such vehicles out of India; (c) conditions for entry/exit of drivers and conductors of such vehicles; (d) granting/authenticating passes, certificates or authorisations for such staff; (e) display of particulars (other than registration marks) on such vehicles; (f) trailer use; (g) exemption from provisions of the Act or rules (except those in sub-section (4)); (h) identification of drivers and conductors; (i) replacement of lost/defaced documents on payment of prescribed fee; (j) exemption from certain customs, police or health laws to facilitate services; (k) any other prescribed matter. (3) No rule under this section confers immunity from State motor vehicle taxes. (4) Requirements on registration, construction, maintenance, equipment, and licensing/qualifications of drivers or conductors do not apply to vehicles/drivers/conductors covered by rules made under sub-sections (1)(b), (1)(c) or (2).

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 145 - Definitions
content: In this Chapter: (a) 'authorised insurer' means an insurer carrying on general insurance in India with a registration from IRDAI or any Government insurance fund authorised under the General Insurance Business (Nationalisation) Act, 1972; (b) 'certificate of insurance' means a certificate issued under section 147, including cover notes meeting prescribed requirements, and includes multiple certificates or copies issued; (c) 'grievous hurt' is as defined in section 320 IPC; (d) 'hit and run motor accident' means an accident caused by a motor vehicle whose identity cannot be ascertained despite reasonable efforts; (e) 'Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority' means the Authority established under the IRDA Act, 1999; (f) 'policy of insurance' includes a certificate of insurance; (g) 'property' includes roads, bridges, culverts, causeways, trees, posts, milestones, baggage, and goods carried; (h) 'reciprocating country' means a country notified by the Central Government for reciprocity under this Act; (i) 'third party' includes the Government, the driver and any co-worker on a transport vehicle.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 146 - Necessity for insurance against third party risks
content: (1) No person shall use or permit use of a motor vehicle in a public place without a policy of insurance complying with this Chapter, except as a passenger. Vehicles carrying hazardous goods must also have public liability insurance under the Public Liability Insurance Act, 1991. A paid driver without such a policy is not in contravention unless aware of its absence. (2) This rule does not apply to vehicles owned by the Central or State Government used for non-commercial purposes. (3) Appropriate Government may exempt vehicles owned by specified authorities, including Government, local authorities, and State Transport Undertakings, if a prescribed fund is established and maintained. 'Appropriate Government' is defined based on ownership/control of the authority or undertaking.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 147 - Requirement of policies and limits of liability
content: (1) A valid policy must: (a) be issued by an authorised insurer; (b) insure specified persons against: (i) liability for death or injury to any person (including owner of goods or representative) or damage to third party property from use of the vehicle; (ii) death or injury to any passenger of a transport vehicle, except gratuitous passengers in goods vehicles. Explanation: liability includes death/injury/property damage caused by an act/omission in a public place even if the injured/damaged party was not in a public place at the time. (2) For third party insurance for death or grievous hurt, the Central Government shall prescribe base premium and insurer liability in consultation with IRDAI. (3) A policy is ineffective unless accompanied by a certificate of insurance in prescribed form and particulars. (4) Policies issued before the 2019 Amendment continue under existing terms. (5) Where a cover note is not followed by a policy within the validity period, the insurer must notify the registering authority within 7 days. (6) The insurer is liable to indemnify persons specified in the policy for liabilities covered.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 148 - Validity of policies of insurance issued in reciprocating countries
content: Where a vehicle from a reciprocating country operates in a shared route/area under an arrangement between India and that country, and has a policy meeting that country's insurance law, that policy shall be effective in the shared area as if compliant with Indian insurance requirements, subject to rules under section 164B.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 149 - Settlement by insurance company and procedure therefor
content: (1) On receiving accident information, the insurer must designate an officer to settle claims. (2) The designated officer may offer settlement to the claimant within 30 days, following prescribed procedure. (3) If the claimant: (a) accepts the offer – the Tribunal records the settlement, and payment must be made within 30 days; (b) rejects the offer – the Tribunal sets a hearing date to decide the claim on merits.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 150 - Duty of insurers to satisfy judgments and awards against persons insured in respect of third party risks
content: (1) If a judgment/award is made against an insured person for liability covered by a policy under section 147(1)(b) or section 164, the insurer must pay the entitled person up to the policy limit, including costs and interest, even if entitled to cancel the policy. (2) Payment is not required unless the insurer had prior notice of proceedings and may defend the case on grounds including: (a) breach of specified policy conditions (e.g., unauthorised hire, racing, non-permitted use, missing side-car, unlicensed or disqualified driver, driving under influence, war/riot injury exclusion); (b) policy void for material nondisclosure or false representation; (c) non-receipt of premium. (3) Judgments from reciprocating countries are enforceable against Indian insurers if notice was given and defences available are similar to sub-section (2). (4) Policy terms restricting insurance beyond sub-section (2) conditions are ineffective. (5) Insurers with notice cannot avoid liability except as per sub-section (2) or applicable foreign law. (6) If claimant does not know the insurer, the vehicle owner must provide insurer details to the Tribunal or court. Explanation defines 'award', 'Claims Tribunal', 'liability covered by the terms of the policy', 'material fact', and 'material particular'.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 151 - Rights of third party against insurers on insolvency of insured
content: (1) If a person insured against third party liabilities becomes insolvent, makes composition with creditors, or if a company insured is wound up or placed under receivership, the third party's rights against the insurer for liabilities incurred vest in the third party. (2) If an order is made for administration of a deceased debtor’s estate, and any debt in insolvency is owing in respect of a liability covered by insurance, such rights vest in the creditor. (3) Any policy conditions seeking to avoid the policy or alter rights due to insolvency, winding up or administration order are void. (4) Upon such transfer, the insurer’s liability to the third party is as if to the insured, but excess insurer liability benefits the insured and any shortfall remains the third party's claim against the insured.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 152 - Duty to give information as to insurance
content: (1) A person against whom a third party claim is made must not refuse, on demand, to state if he was insured under this Chapter or would have been insured if policy not avoided, and must provide specified policy particulars. (2) In events of insolvency, winding up, or administration, the insolvent, personal representative, company, trustee, liquidator, receiver, or manager must provide information reasonably required to ascertain and enforce transferred rights. Any contract seeking to avoid or prohibit giving such information is void. (3) Persons receiving such information and suspecting transferred rights against an insurer have the same duty to provide information. (4) The duty includes allowing inspection and copying of insurance-related documents.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 153 - Settlement between insurers and insured persons
content: (1) Settlements by insurers of claims that may be made by third parties are invalid unless the third party is a party to the settlement. (2) The Claims Tribunal ensures settlements are bona fide without undue influence and compensation follows prescribed payment schedules. (3) Agreements, waivers, assignments, or payments made to insured persons after insolvency or winding up commencement are ineffective against third party rights transferred under this Chapter.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 154 - Saving in respect of sections 151, 152 and 153
content: (1) References to liabilities to third parties do not include liabilities owed by a person as insurer under another policy. (2) Sections 151, 152, and 153 do not apply when a company is voluntarily wound up for reconstruction or amalgamation.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 155 - Effect of death on certain causes of action
content: Death of a person in whose favour a certificate of insurance was issued, occurring after an event that gave rise to a claim under this Chapter, does not bar survival of any cause of action against the deceased’s estate or insurer.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 156 - Effect of certificate of insurance
content: (a) Where an insurer issues a certificate of insurance but not yet the policy, it is deemed to have issued a policy conforming to the certificate particulars as between the insurer and any other person except the insured. (b) Where the insurer has issued the policy but its terms are less favorable to claimants than the certificate particulars, the policy is deemed to conform to the certificate terms as between the insurer and such persons.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 157 - Transfer of certificate of insurance
content: (1) On transfer of vehicle ownership with insurance policy, the certificate and policy are deemed transferred to the transferee from transfer date, including all rights and liabilities. (2) The transferee must apply within 14 days in prescribed form to insurer for updating the certificate and policy details, and the insurer must make the changes accordingly.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 158 - Production of certain certificates, licence and permit in certain cases
content: (1) A person driving in public must produce on demand by authorized police: (a) certificate of insurance; (b) certificate of registration; (c) pollution control certificate; (d) driving licence; (e) in transport vehicles, certificate of fitness and permit; (f) any exemption certificate or authorization under this Act. (2) If an accident involving death or bodily injury occurs, and driver does not produce these at the time, driver or owner must produce them at the police station where reported. (3) Failure to produce on demand is excused if produced within 7 days at specified place, except as prescribed for transport vehicle drivers. (4) Owners must provide information demanded to determine compliance with insurance requirements. (5) 'Produce certificate of insurance' means production for examination or prescribed evidence proving compliance.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 159 - Information to be given regarding accident
content: During investigation of an accident, the police officer must prepare an accident information report in prescribed form and manner within three months, containing specified particulars, and submit it to the Claims Tribunal and other prescribed agencies to facilitate claim settlement.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 160 - Duty to furnish particulars of vehicle involved in accident
content: A registering authority or police officer must, on request and payment of prescribed fee, furnish to a claimant or insurer information available regarding identification marks and particulars of the vehicle involved in an accident, name and address of the user at the time, and damaged property, in prescribed form and time.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 161 - Special provisions as to compensation in case of hit and run motor accident
content: (1) The Central Government shall provide compensation for death or grievous hurt due to hit and run motor accidents in accordance with this Act and schemes. (2) Compensation amounts are: (a) fixed sum of two lakh rupees for death, or higher amount as prescribed; (b) fixed sum of fifty thousand rupees for grievous hurt, or higher amount as prescribed. (3) The Central Government may make schemes for scheme administration, application procedures, officers/authorities handling claims, procedures for order issuance, and related matters. (4) Schemes may provide for interim relief payments, penalties for contraventions (imprisonment or fines), and delegation of powers with Central Government approval.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 162 - Scheme for golden hour
content: (1) Insurance companies must provide treatment for road accident victims including during the golden hour in accordance with this Act and schemes. (2) The Central Government shall make a cashless treatment scheme for golden hour victims, which may include fund creation provisions.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 163 - Refund in certain cases of compensation paid under section 161
content: (1) Compensation paid under section 161 is subject to refund if any other compensation or amount satisfying the same claim is awarded or paid under other laws or provisions, equal to the amount paid under section 161. (2) Before awarding compensation except under section 161, the Claims Tribunal or other authority must verify if compensation under section 161 has been paid or application is pending. (a) If paid, the authority must direct refund of the corresponding amount to the insurer. (b) If application pending, forward particulars to insurer. Explanation clarifies when an application is considered pending.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 164 - Payment of compensation in case of death or grievous hurt
content: (1) Owners or authorised insurers must pay five lakh rupees for death or two and a half lakh rupees for grievous hurt due to motor vehicle accidents to legal heirs or victims. (2) Claimants need not establish wrongful act, neglect, or default for claims under this section. (3) Compensation paid under other laws is deductible from amounts payable under this section.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 164A - Scheme for interim relief for claimants
content: (1) The Central Government may make schemes to provide interim relief to claimants under this Chapter. (2) Such schemes shall provide for procedures to recover disbursed funds from motor vehicle owners or other prescribed sources.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 164B - Motor Vehicle Accident Fund
content: (1) The Central Government shall constitute the Motor Vehicle Accident Fund, credited with specified payments, grants, balances from previous schemes, and other prescribed income sources. (2) The Fund provides compulsory insurance cover for all road users in India. (3) The Fund is utilised for treatment of injured persons, compensation for hit and run accident victims, and other prescribed compensations. (4) Maximum liability amount per case is as prescribed by the Central Government. (5) Amounts paid from the Fund deduct from insurance company claims. (6) The Fund is managed by an authority/agency specified by the Central Government based on insurance knowledge, fund management capability, and other criteria. (7) The Central Government maintains proper accounts and prepares annual statements in consultation with the Comptroller and Auditor-General (CAG) of India. (8) The Fund's accounts are audited by the CAG at specified intervals. (9) The CAG or appointees have full rights and authority for audit including document demands and office inspections. (10) Audited accounts and reports are forwarded annually to the Central Government and laid before Parliament. (11) Previous schemes under section 161 before the 2019 amendment are discontinued and related rights and liabilities are met from this Fund.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 164C - Power of Central Government to make rules
content: (1) The Central Government may make rules to carry out this Chapter. (2) Rules may cover forms used, insurance policy particulars, certificate change procedures, accident report formats and submissions, information furnishing, forms for Fund statements, certificate issues and duplicates, records maintenance, exemptions identification, policy information furnishing, adaptations for temporary stay vehicles or reciprocating country vehicles, insurance certificate requirements, Fund administration, premium and liability limits, policy issuance conditions, settlement details and procedures, exemptions and modifications, evidence related to certificates, submission agencies for accident reports, information furnishing time limits and fees, prescribed higher compensations, interim relief sums, compensation payment procedures, Fund income sources, Fund compensation recipients, maximum liability amounts, Fund management criteria, and other prescribed matters.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 164D - Power of State Government to make rules
content: (1) The State Government may make rules for this Chapter except matters specified in section 164C. (2) Such rules may provide for other authorities referenced in section 147(5) and any other prescribed or necessary provisions.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 165 - Claims Tribunals
content: (1) A State Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, constitute one or more Motor Accidents Claims Tribunals for specified areas to adjudicate claims for compensation in respect of accidents involving death, bodily injury, or damage to property arising out of the use of motor vehicles. Explanation: 'claims for compensation' includes claims under section 164. (2) A Claims Tribunal consists of such number of members as the State Government decides; if more than one, one member is appointed Chairman. (3) Qualifications for a member: (a) is/was a Judge of a High Court; (b) is/was a District Judge; (c) is qualified for appointment as a Judge of a High Court or District Judge. (4) Where two or more Tribunals are constituted for one area, the State Government may regulate distribution of business among them.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 166 - Application for compensation
content: (1) Application for compensation from an accident may be made by: (a) the person injured; (b) owner of property; (c) legal representatives of a deceased; (d) agent of injured or legal representatives. If all legal representatives do not join, others are impleaded as respondents. Application lapses if compensation under section 164 is accepted per section 149 procedure. (2) Application may be made to the Tribunal where accident occurred, or where claimant resides, does business, or where defendant resides, with prescribed form and particulars. (3) Application must be made within six months of the accident. (4) Accident reports under section 159 are treated as applications for compensation. (5) Right to claim compensation survives to legal representatives even if death is unrelated to the injury.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 167 - Option regarding claims for compensation in certain cases
content: Where death or injury gives rise to a claim under both the Motor Vehicles Act and the Workmen’s Compensation Act, the claimant may claim compensation under either Act, but not both.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 168 - Award of the Claims Tribunal
content: (1) On receiving an application for compensation under section 166, the Claims Tribunal notifies the insurer and parties, and after giving opportunity of hearing, holds an inquiry and may make an award determining a just compensation and who is to be paid, specifying the amount to be paid by the insurer, owner, driver, or jointly. (2) Tribunal must deliver award copies to parties within 15 days. (3) Payment required by an award must be deposited within 30 days.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 169 - Procedure and powers of Claims Tribunals
content: (1) The Claims Tribunal may follow summary procedure in any inquiry. (2) The Tribunal holds powers of a Civil Court for taking evidence on oath, enforcing attendance of witnesses, compelling document production, and other prescribed purposes; it is deemed a Civil Court for section 195 and Chapter XXVI of the Criminal Procedure Code. (3) Tribunal may appoint experts to assist in inquiries. (4) Tribunal has full Civil Court powers to execute its award as a decree for payment of money.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 170 - Impleading insurer in certain cases
content: If the Tribunal finds collusion between claimant and respondent, or the respondent fails to contest, it may record reasons and direct the insurer be impleaded as a party. The insurer can contest the claim on any grounds available to the respondent, subject to section 150(2).

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 171 - Award of interest where any claim is allowed
content: Where the Claims Tribunal allows a compensation claim, it may direct that simple interest at a specified rate and from a specified date (not earlier than the claim date) be paid in addition to the compensation amount.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 172 - Award of compensatory costs in certain cases
content: (1) The Claims Tribunal may order special costs by way of compensation, up to one thousand rupees, if: (a) the insurance policy is void due to material false facts, or (b) a false or vexatious claim or defence is made. (2) No order for special costs may exceed one thousand rupees. (3) Such an order does not exempt from criminal liability. (4) The amount is taken into account in any subsequent suits for damages or compensation.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 173 - Appeals
content: (1) A person aggrieved by a Claims Tribunal award may appeal to the High Court within ninety days. Appeals by award-payer require deposit of Rs. 25,000 or 50% of the award, whichever is less. High Court may allow late appeals if sufficient cause shown. (2) No appeal lies if the disputed amount in the award is less than one lakh rupees.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 174 - Recovery of money from insurer as arrear of land revenue
content: Where any amount is due under a Tribunal award, the Tribunal may issue a certificate to the Collector to recover the amount as an arrear of land revenue.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 175 - Bar on jurisdiction of Civil Courts
content: Where a Claims Tribunal has been constituted, no Civil Court may entertain any compensation claim adjudicated by the Tribunal and may not grant any injunction on Tribunal action.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 176 - Power of State Government to make rules
content: The State Government may make rules for sections 165 to 174, including: (a) form and particulars of compensation applications and any fees; (b) procedure for Tribunal inquiries; (c) Civil Court powers exercisable by Tribunals; (d) appeal form, manner, and fees for Tribunal awards; (e) any other prescribed matter.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 177 - General provision for punishment of offences
content: Whoever contravenes a provision of this Act or related rules and no penalty is provided, is punishable for the first offence with fine up to five hundred rupees; for second/subsequent offence, up to one thousand five hundred rupees.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 177A - Penalty for contravention of regulations under section 118
content: Whoever contravenes regulations made under section 118 shall be punished with a fine of not less than five hundred rupees, but up to one thousand rupees.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 178 - Penalty for travelling without pass or ticket and for dereliction of duty on the part of conductor and refusal to ply contract carriage, etc.
content: (1) Anyone travelling in a stage carriage without a proper pass or ticket, or failing to present or deliver it when required, is punishable with fine up to five hundred rupees. (2) If the conductor or driver performing conductor’s duties wilfully or negligently fails to accept fare, supply a ticket, supplies an invalid or lower-value ticket, or fails to check pass/ticket, is punishable with fine up to five hundred rupees. (3) If the permit-holder or contract carriage driver refuses to ply or carry passengers in contravention of Act or rules: (a) for two/three-wheelers, fine up to fifty rupees; (b) for others, fine up to five hundred rupees.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 179 - Disobedience of orders, obstruction and refusal of information
content: (1) Whoever wilfully disobeys lawful directions from an empowered authority, or obstructs that authority’s functions, if no other penalty is provided, is punishable with fine up to two thousand rupees. (2) Whoever, required to supply information under this Act, wilfully withholds or supplies false information, is punishable with up to one month’s imprisonment, or fine up to two thousand rupees, or both.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 180 - Allowing unauthorised persons to drive vehicles
content: If the owner or person in charge allows someone not meeting section 3 or 4 requirements to drive, is punishable with up to three months’ imprisonment, or fine of five thousand rupees, or both.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 181 - Driving vehicles in contravention of section 3 or section 4
content: Anyone driving a motor vehicle in contravention of section 3 or 4 is punishable with up to three months’ imprisonment, or fine of five thousand rupees, or both.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 182 - Offences relating to licences
content: (1) If disqualified from holding or obtaining a driving licence, or fails to disclose endorsements, and drives or applies for/obtains licence, shall be punished with up to three months' imprisonment or fine of ten thousand rupees or both; such licence is void. (2) Same provisions for conductors’ licence, with up to one month’s imprisonment or fine of ten thousand rupees or both; such licence is void.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 182A - Punishment for offences relating to construction, maintenance, sale and alteration of motor vehicles and components
content: (1) Manufacturer, importer or dealer selling, delivering, or altering a vehicle in contravention of Chapter VII faces up to one year’s imprisonment, or fine of one lakh rupees per vehicle, or both, unless disclosure of contravention is proven. (2) Manufacturer failing to comply with Chapter VII and rules faces up to one year’s imprisonment or fine up to one hundred crore rupees or both. (3) Selling or permitting sale of a notified critical safety component not compliant with Chapter VII faces up to one year’s imprisonment or fine of one lakh rupees per component or both. (4) Vehicle owner altering vehicle, including retrofitting parts not permitted under Act/rules, faces up to six months’ imprisonment or fine of five thousand rupees per alteration or both.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 182B - Punishment for contravention of section 62A
content: Anyone contravening section 62A shall be punished with fine not less than five thousand rupees, and up to ten thousand rupees.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 183 - Driving at excessive speed, etc.
content: (1) Driving or causing another to drive in excess of speed limits under section 112: (i) for light vehicles: fine of one to two thousand rupees; (ii) for medium/heavy vehicles: fine of two to four thousand rupees; (iii) second/subsequent offences: licence impounded as per section 206(4). (3) No conviction solely on opinion evidence unless mechanical/electronic device used. (4) Impractical time tables or directions to complete journeys are prima facie evidence of offence by publisher/director.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 184 - Driving dangerously
content: Driving a motor vehicle at dangerous speed or manner or causing alarm or distress to occupants, other road users, or near roads, having regard to conditions and traffic, is punishable for first offence by imprisonment up to one year but not less than six months, or fine of one to five thousand rupees, or both; second or subsequent offence within three years, up to two years’ imprisonment or fine of ten thousand rupees or both. Explanation: Includes jumping red lights, violating stop signs, handheld communication, illegal overtaking, driving against traffic, or driving far below expected competence.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 185 - Driving by a drunken person or by a person under the influence of drugs
content: Whoever, while driving or attempting to drive: (a) has blood alcohol over 30 mg/100 ml detected by breath or laboratory test; or (b) is under influence of drug so as to be incapable of proper control, is punishable for first offence by up to six months' imprisonment or fine of ten thousand rupees, or both; for subsequent offences, up to two years, or fine of fifteen thousand rupees, or both. 'Drug' includes specified intoxicants, narcotic drugs, and psychotropic substances.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 186 - Driving when mentally or physically unfit to drive
content: Whoever drives when knowingly suffering from any disease or disability calculated to make driving dangerous is punishable for first offence with fine up to one thousand rupees, and for subsequent offences up to two thousand rupees.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 187 - Punishment for offences relating to accident
content: Failure to comply with section 132(1)(a), 133, or 134 is punishable with up to six months' imprisonment, or fine of five thousand rupees, or both; repeat offenders face up to one year imprisonment, or fine of ten thousand rupees, or both.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 188 - Punishment for abetment of certain offences
content: Whoever abets offences under sections 184, 185, or 186 is punishable with the same penalties as for the original offence.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 189 - Racing and trials of speed
content: Anyone permitting or taking part in a race or speed trial between motor vehicles in a public place without State Government written consent, is punishable with up to three months' imprisonment, or fine of five thousand rupees, or both; for subsequent offences, up to one year imprisonment, or fine of ten thousand rupees, or both.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 190 - Using vehicle in unsafe condition
content: (1) Driving or allowing to be driven any vehicle or trailer with a known or discoverable defect calculated to cause danger, is punishable with fine of one thousand five hundred rupees, or if bodily injury/property damage results, up to three months’ imprisonment or fine of five thousand rupees, or both; subsequent offence, up to six months' imprisonment or fine of ten thousand rupees for bodily injury or damage. (2) Driving or allowing to be driven a vehicle violating prescribed standards for road safety, noise, or air pollution is punishable for first offence by up to three months’ imprisonment or fine up to ten thousand rupees or both, and licence disqualification for three months; repeat offences: up to six months or fine up to ten thousand rupees or both. (3) Driving or allowing the carriage of goods dangerous or hazardous to human life in violation of rules is punishable for first offence by ten thousand rupees and disqualification for three months, or up to one year imprisonment or both; subsequent offences: twenty thousand rupees or up to three years imprisonment or both.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 192 - Using vehicle without registration
content: (1) Driving or allowing driving of vehicle in contravention of section 39 is punishable for first offence with fine up to five thousand rupees (not less than two thousand), for second or subsequent offence up to one year imprisonment or fine up to ten thousand rupees (not less than five thousand), or both; court may impose lesser punishment for reasons recorded. (2) Does not apply for emergency conveyance with prompt report to authority. (3) Appeal courts may set aside/vary punishment orders. Use of vehicle in contravention of section 56 is deemed a contravention of section 39 and punished accordingly.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 192A - Using vehicle without permit
content: (1) Driving or allowing driving contrary to section 66(1) or permit conditions regarding route/area/purpose is punishable for first offence by up to six months' imprisonment or fine of ten thousand rupees or both; for subsequent offences, up to one year (not less than six months) or fine of ten thousand rupees or both. (2) Exemption for certain emergency uses with notification to authority. (3) Appeal court can set aside/vary orders regardless of appeal status.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 192B - Offences relating to registration
content: (1) Owner failing to apply for registration under section 41(1) is punishable with fine of five times the annual road tax or one-third lifetime tax, whichever is higher. (2) Dealer failing to apply for registration of new vehicle under section 41 second proviso faces fine of fifteen times annual road tax or lifetime tax, whichever is higher. (3) Owners obtaining registration by false documents or with mismatch engine/chassis numbers face six months to one year imprisonment and fine ten times annual road tax or two-thirds lifetime tax, whichever is higher. (4) Dealers doing likewise face same punishment.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 193 - Punishment of agents, canvassers and aggregators without proper authority
content: (1) Engaging as agent or canvasser contravening section 93 or rules is punishable for first offence with fine of one thousand rupees, for second/subsequent offence with up to six months' imprisonment or fine of two thousand rupees or both. (2) Engaging as aggregator in contravention of section 93 or rules is punishable with fine not less than twenty-five thousand rupees, up to one lakh rupees. (3) Aggregator operating in contravention of non-material licence conditions faces fine of five thousand rupees.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 194 - Driving vehicle exceeding permissible weight
content: (1) Driving or allowing to be driven in contravention of sections 113, 114, or 115 is punishable with fine of twenty thousand rupees plus two thousand rupees per tonne of excess load, and off-loading charges; vehicle cannot move until excess load is removed. (1A) Loading vehicle beyond permissible limits triggers twenty thousand rupees fine plus liability for off-loading charges and cannot move until load is compliant, unless exempted by authority. (2) Driver refusing weighing or removing load prior to weighing when directed faces fine of forty thousand rupees.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 194A - Carriage of excess passengers
content: Driving or allowing driving while carrying more passengers than permitted in registration or permit is punishable with fine of two hundred rupees per excess passenger; vehicle cannot move until excess passengers are off-loaded and alternatives arranged.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 194B - Use of safety belts and the seating of children
content: (1) Driving without wearing a safety belt or carrying passengers not wearing seat belts: fine of one thousand rupees; State Government may exempt transport vehicles for standing passengers or specified classes. (2) Driving with a child under 14 not secured by a safety belt or restraint system: fine of one thousand rupees.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 194C - Penalty for violation of safety measures for motor cycle drivers and pillion riders
content: Driving a motorcycle or allowing driving in contravention of section 128 or related rules attracts fine of one thousand rupees and disqualification from holding licence for three months.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 194D - Penalty for not wearing protective headgear
content: Driving a motorcycle or allowing driving in contravention of section 129 or rules: fine of one thousand rupees and disqualification for three months from holding licence.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 194E - Failure to allow free passage to emergency vehicles
content: Not drawing to side of road on approach of emergency vehicle (fire, ambulance or other as specified) is punishable with up to six months' imprisonment, or fine of ten thousand rupees, or both.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 194F - Use of horns and silence zones
content: While driving: (a)(i) sounding horn needlessly, continuously or excessively, (ii) sounding horn in prohibited area, (b) driving with exhaust gases released through cut-out bypassing silencer, is punishable with fine of one thousand rupees; for subsequent offences, fine of two thousand rupees.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 196 - Driving uninsured vehicle
content: Driving or allowing driving in contravention of the insurance requirements under section 146 is punishable for first offence with up to three months' imprisonment, or fine of two thousand rupees, or both; for subsequent offence, up to three months' imprisonment or fine of four thousand rupees or both.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 197 - Taking vehicle without authority
content: (1) Whoever takes and drives away any motor vehicle without the owner's consent or other lawful authority is punishable with up to three months’ imprisonment, or fine of five thousand rupees, or both. No conviction if court is satisfied the person reasonably believed they had authority or that the owner would have consented. (2) Whoever unlawfully seizes or controls a motor vehicle by force, threat, or intimidation is punishable with up to three months’ imprisonment, or fine of five thousand rupees, or both. (3) Attempts or abetment of acts in sub-sections (1) or (2) are deemed offences under those sub-sections.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 198 - Unauthorised interference with vehicle
content: Whoever, without lawful authority or reasonable excuse, enters or mounts any stationary motor vehicle or tampers with its brake or any part of its mechanism, is punishable with a fine of one thousand rupees.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 198A - Failure to comply with standards for road design, construction and maintenance
content: (1) Designated authorities, contractors, consultants, or concessionaires responsible for road design, construction, or maintenance must follow safety standards prescribed by the Central Government. (2) Failure to comply resulting in death or disability is punishable with a fine up to one lakh rupees, payable to the Motor Vehicle Accident Fund under section 164B. (3) In such cases, the court considers factors including: (a) road characteristics and expected traffic; (b) applicable maintenance norms; (c) expected state of repair; (d) whether the responsible authority knew or should have known of danger; (e) whether repair was reasonably possible before the cause; (f) whether adequate warning signs were displayed; and (g) other prescribed matters. Explanation: 'Contractor' includes sub-contractors and persons responsible for any stage of road design, construction, or maintenance.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 199 - Offences by companies
content: (1) Where a company commits an offence under the Act, persons in charge and responsible for business conduct, as well as the company, are deemed guilty and liable, unless they prove lack of knowledge or due diligence. (2) If the offence is committed with consent, connivance, or neglect of a director, manager, secretary, or officer, such person is also deemed guilty and liable. Explanation: 'Company' includes body corporates, firms, and associations; 'Director' in relation to a firm means a partner.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 199A - Offences by juveniles
content: (1) If a juvenile commits an offence under this Act, the guardian or vehicle owner is deemed guilty and liable unless they prove lack of knowledge or due diligence. Presumption: the juvenile used the vehicle with consent. (2) Additionally, guardian or owner is punishable with up to three years’ imprisonment and a fine of twenty-five thousand rupees. (3) This does not apply if the juvenile had a learner’s or driving licence for the operated vehicle class. (4) The vehicle registration is cancelled for 12 months. (5) The juvenile is ineligible for a driving or learner’s licence until age 25. (6) Juveniles are liable for fines under the Act; custodial sentences may be modified as per the Juvenile Justice Act, 2000.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 199B - Revision of fines
content: Fines under this Act may be increased annually by up to 10% of existing values on 1st April each year from the commencement of the Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act, 2019, as notified by the Central Government.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 200 - Composition of certain offences
content: (1) Offences specified, including those under sections 177, 177A, 178, 179, 180, 181, 182, certain sub-sections of 182A, 182B, 183, section 184(c) Explanation, 186, 189, 190(2), 192, 192A, 192B(3), 194, 194A-F, 196, 198, and 201, may be compounded before or after prosecution by officers/authorities specified in State Government notification, for amounts specified therein. State Government may also require community service. (2) Compounding leads to offender’s discharge and bars further proceedings, but offence counts as a previous offence for repeat-offence purposes and does not exempt from other penalties such as licence disqualification, driver retraining, or community service obligations.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 201 - Penalty for causing obstruction to free flow of traffic
content: (1) Keeping a vehicle in a public place causing impediment to free traffic flow attracts penalty up to five hundred rupees while it remains there. Accident-involved vehicles are penalised only after completion of legal inspection. Removal charges by authorised agencies are recoverable from vehicle owner/person in charge. (2) Penalties/removal charges are recovered by officers/authorities notified by the State Government. (3) Sub-section (1) does not apply if vehicle suffered unforeseen breakdown and is being removed. Explanation: 'Removal charges' include costs of moving and storing the vehicle.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 202 - Power to arrest without warrant
content: (1) A police officer in uniform may arrest without warrant any person committing in his presence an offence under section 184, 185, or 197. Arrest for section 185 offences requires medical examination within two hours, failing which the person must be released. (2) A police officer in uniform may arrest without warrant any person committing an offence under the Act who refuses to give name and address. (3) On arresting a driver, the officer may take steps for temporary disposal of the vehicle.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 203 - Breath tests
content: (1) Authorised police or motor vehicle officers may require any driving/attempting driver in a public place to provide breath specimens for testing if suspected of a section 185 offence, as soon as reasonably practicable. (2) If an accident occurs and the officer suspects alcohol/drug use, a breath specimen may be required at hospital (for in-patients) or near the site/police station, subject to medical approval for in-patients. (3) If the breath test indicates alcohol presence, the officer may arrest without warrant (except for hospital in-patients). (4) If a person refuses/fails to provide breath and officer suspects alcohol presence, the officer may arrest without warrant (except for hospital in-patients). (5) A person arrested must be given a chance to provide a specimen at the police station. (6) Breath test results are admissible. Explanation: 'Breath test' means an alcohol detection test via a device approved by the Central Government.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 204 - Laboratory test
content: (1) Persons arrested under section 203 may be required to provide blood specimens for laboratory testing to a registered medical practitioner if breath test indicated alcohol or if breath test was refused/failed; female specimens taken in presence of a woman. (2) In-patients can be required to provide a specimen if breath test indicated alcohol or was refused/failed, subject to medical approval. (3) Laboratory test results are admissible. Explanation: 'Laboratory test' means analysis of blood at a government-recognised laboratory.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 205 - Presumption of unfitness to drive
content: In proceedings under section 185, if the accused refused, omitted, or failed to consent to provide breath or blood specimens when requested by a police officer, such refusal or failure may be presumed to support prosecution evidence or rebut defence evidence about the accused's condition, unless reasonable cause is shown.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 206 - Power of police officer to impound document
content: (1) Police or authorised persons suspecting any identification mark or document (licence, permit, registration, insurance) as false may seize it and require explanation. (2) If driver charged with an offence may abscond, officer may seize licence and forward it to court, returning it on driver’s first appearance. (3) On seizing a licence, officer gives a temporary acknowledgment authorising driving until return or specified date, extendable if delay not due to holder. (4) If officer reasonably believes the driver committed offences under sections 183, 184, 185, 189, 190, 194C-E, licence is seized and sent to licensing authority for disqualification/revocation; temporary acknowledgment issued but does not authorise driving.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 207 - Power to detain vehicles used without certificate of registration permit, etc.
content: (1) Police or authorised persons suspecting a vehicle is used in contravention of sections 3, 4, or 39, or without permit under section 66(1), or in violation of permit conditions, may seize and detain it safely. Alternatively, they may seize registration certificate instead of vehicle and issue acknowledgment. (2) Owner/person in charge may apply with documents for vehicle release; authority may release after verification, subject to conditions. State amendment: Rajasthan omits 'or without the permit required by section 66(1)' from proviso to subsection (1).

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 208 - Summary disposal of cases
content: (1) Court taking cognizance of an offence (not specified by Central Government rules for exclusion) may allow summons to state that accused may appear personally/by lawyer, or plead guilty before hearing with remittance of fine by money order, not exceeding maximum fine; for certain offences, summons also requires surrender of driving licence with plea. (2) For offences specified for this purpose, the Court endorses the conviction on the licence. (3) Pleading guilty and remitting fine as above ends further proceedings and prevents disqualification for holding/obtaining a licence due to the conviction.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 209 - Restriction on conviction
content: No conviction for offences under section 183 or 184 unless: (a) warned at time of offence; or (b) within 14 days served/posted notice of offence details; or (c) within 28 days served summons. Not applicable if failure to serve was due to unascertainable address despite diligence, or caused by accused's conduct.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 210 - Courts to send intimation about conviction
content: Courts convicting a driving licence holder for an offence under this Act or involving a motor vehicle must inform the issuing and last-renewing licensing authorities, specifying holder's details, licence particulars, offence, punishment, and other prescribed information.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 210A - Power of State Government to increase penalties
content: Subject to Central Government conditions, a State Government may, by Gazette notification, specify a multiplier between one and ten to be applied to each fine under this Act, with different multipliers for different vehicle classes.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 210B - Penalty for offence committed by an enforcing authority
content: Any empowered enforcement authority committing an offence under this Act is liable for twice the corresponding penalty prescribed.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 210C - Power of Central Government to make rules
content: The Central Government may make rules for: (a) design, construction, and maintenance standards for national highways; (b) factors for courts to consider under section 198A(3); (c) any other matter to be prescribed by the Central Government.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 210D - Power of State Government to make rules
content: The State Government may make rules for design, construction, and maintenance standards for roads other than national highways, and for any other matter to be prescribed by the State Government.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 211 - Power to levy fee
content: Rules made under this Act by the Central or State Government may provide for levying fees for applications, document amendments, certificates, licences, permits, tests, endorsements, badges, plates, countersignatures, authorisations, supplying statistics/documents/orders, and other services. Governments may grant partial/full exemption to any class of persons in public interest.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 211A - Use of electronic forms and documents
content: (1) Requirements under this Act/rules for filing, issuing, granting, or payment in a specific manner are satisfied if done through prescribed electronic forms. (2) Central/State Government shall prescribe electronic form formats and fee/payment methods.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 212 - Publication, commencement and laying of rules and notifications
content: (1) Rule-making power is subject to previous publication. (2) All rules must be published in Official Gazette and, unless stated, come into force on publication. (3) State Government rules must be laid before State Legislature. (4) Central Government rules, certain schemes, and notifications under specified provisions must be laid before Parliament for 30 days; modifications or annulments agreed by both Houses affect future operation without invalidating prior actions. (5) State Government notifications under section 210A must be laid before the State Legislature for 30 days for potential modification or annulment.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 213 - Appointment of motor vehicles officers
content: (1) State Government may establish a Motor Vehicles Department and appoint officers. (2) Officers are public servants under IPC. (3) State Government may make rules regulating their functions, uniforms, subordination, duties, powers (including police powers), and conditions for exercising such powers. (4) Central Government may prescribe minimum qualifications by notification. (5) Empowered officers may: (a) conduct examinations/inquiries for Act compliance; (b) with assistance, enter, inspect, and search suspected premises (certain conditions for searches without warrant); (c) examine persons, require and record production of documents; (d) seize/copy relevant registers/documents; (e) launch prosecutions and take bonds for court appearance; (f) exercise other prescribed powers. No person is compelled to self-incriminate. (6) Code of Criminal Procedure provisions on search/seizure apply as far as possible.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 214 - Effect of appeal and revision on orders passed by original authority
content: (1) Appeals/revisions do not stay original authority's order unless otherwise directed; order remains in force. (2) If permit renewal is rejected and appeal/revision is pending, authority may order continuation of permit validity until decision. (3) Orders are not reversed/altered for procedural errors unless they caused failure of justice.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 215 - Road Safety Councils and Committees
content: (1) Central Government may constitute a National Road Safety Council by Gazette notification. (2) State Government may constitute a State Road Safety Council. (3) State Government may constitute District Road Safety Committees; if not, Central Government may do so. (4) Councils/Committees discharge functions related to road safety programmes as specified.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 215A - Power of Central Government and State Government to delegate
content: Central Government may delegate its powers/functions under this Act to any public servant/authority; likewise, State Government may delegate its powers/functions to any public servant/authority.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 215B - National Road Safety Board
content: (1) Central Government shall constitute by Gazette notification a National Road Safety Board, with a Chairman, State Government representatives, and other members on prescribed terms. (2) The Board advises on all aspects of road safety and traffic management, including motor vehicle and safety equipment standards; vehicle registration and licensing; road safety and infrastructure standards; safe and sustainable road transport; promotion of new vehicle technology; safety of vulnerable road users; and road user education and sensitisation programmes; and other prescribed functions.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 215C - Power of Central Government to make rules
content: (1) The Central Government may make rules for carrying into effect the provisions of this Chapter. (2) Rules may provide for: (a) use of electronic forms and means for filing documents, issuing or granting licences, permits, sanctions, approvals, endorsements, and receiving or paying money as referred to in section 211A; (b) minimum qualifications required for appointment of Motor Vehicles Department officers or any class thereof under section 213(4); (c) terms and conditions of appointment of Chairman and Members of the National Road Safety Board under section 215B(1); (d) other functions of the National Road Safety Board under section 215B(2); and (e) any other matter to be, or which may be, prescribed or for which provision is to be made by rules by the Central Government.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 215D - Power of State Government to make rules
content: (1) The State Government may make rules for carrying into effect the provisions of this Chapter, other than matters specified in section 215C. (2) Rules may provide for: (a) use of electronic forms and means for filing documents, issuing or granting licences, permits, sanctions, approvals, endorsements, and receiving or paying money as referred to in section 211A; (b) duties and functions of Motor Vehicles Department officers, their powers (including police powers under this Act), conditions for exercising such powers, uniform to be worn, and subordination as per section 213(3); (c) other powers exercisable by Motor Vehicles Department officers as per section 213(5)(f); and (d) any other matter to be, or which may be, prescribed or for which provision is to be made by State Government rules.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 216 - Power to remove difficulties
content: (1) If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Act, the Central Government may, by order in the Official Gazette, make provisions not inconsistent with the Act to remove the difficulty, provided no such order is made after three years from commencement of the Act. (2) Every such order shall be laid before each House of Parliament as soon as possible after it is made.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 217 - Repeal and savings
content: (1) The Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 and any corresponding State law in force immediately before commencement of this Act are repealed. (2) Despite repeal: (a) notifications, rules, orders, declarations, exemptions, confiscations, penalties, forfeitures, cancellations, actions, or appointments under the repealed laws, if not inconsistent with this Act, are deemed under corresponding provisions of this Act; (b) certificates of fitness, registration, licences, or permits under repealed laws continue under same conditions and period; (c) documents referring to repealed laws are construed as referring to this Act or corresponding provisions; (d) assignment/display of distinguishing marks under repealed laws continues until notification under section 41(6) is issued; (e) pending schemes under section 68C of the 1939 Act or corresponding State law are disposed under section 100; (f) permits under section 68F(1A) of the 1939 Act or corresponding State law remain valid until publication of approved scheme under Chapter VI. (3) Penalties payable under repealed laws may be recovered under this Act without prejudice to action already taken. (4) This section does not affect the general application of section 6 of the General Clauses Act, 1897.

title: Motor Vehicles Act Section 217A - Renewal of permits, driving licences and registration granted under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939
content: Notwithstanding the repeal of enactments under section 217(1), certificates of fitness, registration, licences, or permits issued under those enactments may be renewed under this Act.
