title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 1
content:
(1) This Act may be called the Right to Information Act, 2005.
(2) It extends to the whole of India except the State of Jammu and Kashmir.
(3) The provisions of sub-section (1) of section 4, sub-sections (1) and (2) of section 5, sections 12, 13, 15, 16, 24, 27 and 28 shall come into force at once, and the remaining provisions of this Act shall come into force on the one hundred and twentieth day of its enactment.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 2 (Part 1)
Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 2 (Part 2)
Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 2 (Part 3)
Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 3
content: Subject to the provisions of this Act, all citizens shall have the right to information.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 4 (Part 1)
Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 4 (Part 2)
Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 4 (Part 3)
content:
(3) For the purposes of sub-section (1), every information shall be disseminated widely and in such form and manner which is easily accessible to the public.
(4) All materials shall be disseminated taking into consideration the cost-effectiveness, local language, and the most effective method of communication in that local area. The information should be easily accessible, to the extent possible, in electronic format with the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, available free or at such cost of the medium or the print cost price as may be prescribed.

Explanation: For the purposes of sub-sections (3) and (4), "disseminated" means making known or communicating the information to the public through notice boards, newspapers, public announcements, media broadcasts, the internet or any other means, including inspection of offices of any public authority.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 5 (Part 1)
content:
(1) Every public authority shall, within one hundred days of the enactment of this Act, designate as many officers as the Central Public Information Officers or State Public Information Officers, as the case may be, in all administrative units or offices under it as may be necessary to provide information to persons requesting information under this Act.
(2) Without prejudice to sub-section (1), every public authority shall designate an officer, within one hundred days of the enactment of this Act, at each sub-divisional level or other sub-district level as a Central Assistant Public Information Officer or a State Assistant Public Information Officer, as the case may be, to receive applications for information or appeals under this Act for forwarding them forthwith to the Central Public Information Officer or the State Public Information Officer, or senior officer specified under sub-section (1) of section 19, or the Central Information Commission, or the State Information Commission, as the case may be.
Provided that where an application for information or appeal is given to a Central Assistant Public Information Officer or a State Assistant Public Information Officer, as the case may be, a period of five days shall be added in computing the period for response specified under sub-section (1) of section 7.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 5 (Part 2)
content:
(3) Every Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, shall deal with requests from persons seeking information and render reasonable assistance to the persons seeking such information.
(4) The Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, may seek the assistance of any other officer as he or she considers necessary for the proper discharge of duties.
(5) Any officer whose assistance has been sought under sub-section (4) shall render all assistance to the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be. For the purposes of any contravention of the provisions of this Act, such other officer shall be treated as a Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 6 (Part 1)
content:
(1) A person who desires to obtain any information under this Act shall make a request in writing or through electronic means in English, Hindi, or in the official language of the area in which the application is being made, accompanied by such fee as may be prescribed, to:
(a) the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, of the concerned public authority; or
(b) the Central Assistant Public Information Officer or State Assistant Public Information Officer, as the case may be,
specifying the particulars of the information sought.
Provided that where such request cannot be made in writing, the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, shall render all reasonable assistance to the person making the request orally to reduce it into writing.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 6 (Part 2)
content:
(2) An applicant making a request for information shall not be required to give any reason for requesting the information or any other personal details except those necessary for contacting him.
(3) Where an application is made to a public authority requesting information:
(i) which is held by another public authority; or
(ii) the subject matter of which is more closely connected with the functions of another public authority,
the public authority to which such application is made shall transfer the application or such part of it as may be appropriate to that other public authority and inform the applicant immediately about such transfer.
Provided that the transfer of an application pursuant to this sub-section shall be made as soon as practicable and in no case later than five days from the date of receipt of the application.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 7 (Part 1)
content:
(1) Subject to the proviso to sub-section (2) of section 5 or the proviso to sub-section (3) of section 6, the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, on receipt of a request under section 6 shall, as expeditiously as possible and in any case within thirty days of the receipt of the request, either provide the information on payment of such fee as may be prescribed or reject the request for any of the reasons specified in sections 8 and 9.
Provided that where the information sought concerns the life or liberty of a person, the same shall be provided within forty-eight hours of the receipt of the request.
(2) If the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer fails to give a decision on the request for information within the period specified under sub-section (1), the officer shall be deemed to have refused the request.
(3) Where a decision is taken to provide the information on payment of any further fee representing the cost of providing the information, the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer shall send an intimation to the person making the request, giving:
(a) the details of further fees representing the cost of providing the information as determined, together with the calculations made to arrive at the amount in accordance with the prescribed fee, requesting the applicant to deposit that fee. The period between the despatch of the intimation and payment of the fee shall be excluded for calculating the thirty-day period under sub-section (1);
(b) information concerning the applicant's right to review the decision on the amount of fees charged or the form of access provided, including particulars of the appellate authority, time limit, process and any other forms.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 7 (Part 2)
content:
(4) Where access to the record or a part thereof is required to be provided under this Act and the person to whom access is to be provided is sensorily disabled, the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer shall provide assistance to enable access to the information, including providing assistance appropriate for inspection.
(5) Where access to information is to be provided in printed or electronic format, the applicant shall, subject to sub-section (6), pay such fee as may be prescribed.
Provided that the fee prescribed under sub-section (1) of section 6 and sub-sections (1) and (5) of section 7 shall be reasonable, and no such fee shall be charged from persons below the poverty line as determined by the appropriate Government.
(6) Notwithstanding sub-section (5), the person making the request shall be provided the information free of charge where a public authority fails to comply with the time limits specified in sub-section (1).
(7) Before taking any decision under sub-section (1), the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer shall take into consideration any representation made by a third party under section 11.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 7 (Part 3)
content:
(8) Where a request has been rejected under sub-section (1), the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer shall communicate to the applicant:
(i) the reasons for such rejection;
(ii) the period within which an appeal against such rejection may be preferred; and
(iii) the particulars of the appellate authority.
(9) Information shall ordinarily be provided in the form in which it is sought unless it would disproportionately divert the resources of the public authority or be detrimental to the safety or preservation of the record in question.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 8(1)
Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 9
content: Without prejudice to the provisions of section 8, a Central Public Information Officer or a State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, may reject a request for information where providing access to such information would involve an infringement of copyright subsisting in a person other than the State.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 10
Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 11
content:
(1) Where a Central Public Information Officer or a State Public Information Officer intends to disclose any information or record, or part thereof, on a request made under this Act, which relates to or has been supplied by a third party and has been treated as confidential by that third party, the officer shall, within five days from receipt of the request, give a written notice to such third party of the request and the intention to disclose the information or record, and invite the third party to make a submission in writing or orally regarding whether the information should be disclosed. Such submission shall be considered while taking a decision on disclosure. Provided that, except in the case of trade or commercial secrets protected by law, disclosure may be allowed if the public interest in disclosure outweighs any possible harm or injury to the interests of such third party.

(2) Where a notice is served under sub-section (1), the third party shall, within ten days from the date of receipt of such notice, have the opportunity to make a representation against the proposed disclosure.

(3) Notwithstanding section 7, the officer shall, within forty days after receipt of the request under section 6, if the third party has been given an opportunity to make representation under sub-section (2), decide whether or not to disclose the information or record, or part thereof, and give written notice of the decision to the third party.

(4) A notice under sub-section (3) shall include a statement that the third party to whom the notice is given is entitled to prefer an appeal under section 19 against the decision.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 12
content:
(1) The Central Government shall, by notification in the Official Gazette, constitute a body to be known as the Central Information Commission to exercise the powers conferred on, and to perform the functions assigned to it under this Act.

(2) The Central Information Commission shall consist of:
(a) the Chief Information Commissioner; and
(b) such number of Central Information Commissioners, not exceeding ten, as may be deemed necessary.

(3) The Chief Information Commissioner and Information Commissioners shall be appointed by the President on the recommendation of a committee consisting of:
(i) the Prime Minister, who shall be the Chairperson of the committee;
(ii) the Leader of Opposition in the Lok Sabha; and
(iii) a Union Cabinet Minister to be nominated by the Prime Minister.
Explanation: For the purposes of removal of doubts, where the Leader of Opposition in the House of the People has not been recognised as such, the Leader of the single largest group in opposition of the Government in the House of the People shall be deemed to be the Leader of Opposition.

(4) The general superintendence, direction and management of the affairs of the Central Information Commission shall vest in the Chief Information Commissioner, who shall be assisted by the Information Commissioners, and may exercise all such powers and do all such acts and things which may be exercised or done by the Central Information Commission autonomously without being subjected to directions by any other authority under this Act.

(5) The Chief Information Commissioner and Information Commissioners shall be persons of eminence in public life with wide knowledge and experience in law, science and technology, social service, management, journalism, mass media, or administration and governance.

(6) The Chief Information Commissioner or an Information Commissioner shall not be a Member of Parliament or Member of the Legislature of any State or Union territory, or hold any other office of profit, or be connected with any political party, or carry on any business or pursue any profession.

(7) The headquarters of the Central Information Commission shall be at Delhi, and the Commission may, with the previous approval of the Central Government, establish offices at other places in India.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 13
content:
(1) The Chief Information Commissioner shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office and shall not be eligible for reappointment, provided that no Chief Information Commissioner shall hold office after attaining the age of sixty-five years.

(2) Every Information Commissioner shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office or until he attains the age of sixty-five years, whichever is earlier, and shall not be eligible for reappointment as such. However, an Information Commissioner may be appointed as the Chief Information Commissioner in the manner specified in sub-section (3) of section 12. Where an Information Commissioner is appointed as the Chief Information Commissioner, his total term shall not exceed five years in aggregate for both roles.

(3) Before entering office, the Chief Information Commissioner or an Information Commissioner shall make and subscribe an oath or affirmation before the President or a person appointed by him, in the form set out in the First Schedule.

(4) The Chief Information Commissioner or an Information Commissioner may resign at any time by writing under his hand addressed to the President, and may be removed as specified under section 14.

(5) The salaries, allowances, and other terms of service shall be:
(a) for the Chief Information Commissioner — the same as that of the Chief Election Commissioner;
(b) for an Information Commissioner — the same as that of an Election Commissioner.
If, at the time of appointment, the Chief Information Commissioner or an Information Commissioner is in receipt of a pension (other than disability or wound pension) from previous government service, the salary shall be reduced by the amount of that pension, including any commuted portion and pension equivalent of other retirement benefits, excluding retirement gratuity. If they are receiving retirement benefits from a corporation or government company, the salary shall be reduced by the pension equivalent of those benefits. Salaries, allowances, and other conditions of service shall not be varied to their disadvantage after appointment.

(6) The Central Government shall provide the Chief Information Commissioner and the Information Commissioners with such officers and employees as necessary for efficient performance of their functions, and the salaries, allowances, and terms of service of such officers and employees shall be as prescribed.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 14
content:
(1) Subject to the provisions of sub-section (3), the Chief Information Commissioner or any Information Commissioner shall be removed from office only by order of the President on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity, after the Supreme Court, on a reference made by the President, has inquired and reported that the removal is justified.

(2) The President may suspend from office, and if necessary prohibit from attending office during the inquiry, the Chief Information Commissioner or Information Commissioner in respect of whom a reference has been made to the Supreme Court under sub-section (1), until the President has passed orders upon receiving the Court's report.

(3) Notwithstanding sub-section (1), the President may by order remove the Chief Information Commissioner or any Information Commissioner if such person:
(a) is adjudged an insolvent; or
(b) has been convicted of an offence which, in the opinion of the President, involves moral turpitude; or
(c) engages during the term of office in any paid employment outside official duties; or
(d) is, in the opinion of the President, unfit to continue in office due to infirmity of mind or body; or
(e) has acquired such financial or other interest as is likely to prejudicially affect the performance of functions.

(4) If the Chief Information Commissioner or an Information Commissioner is concerned or interested in any contract or agreement made by or on behalf of the Government of India, or participates in any way in its profit or in any benefit arising therefrom otherwise than as a member in common with other members of an incorporated company, he shall be deemed guilty of misbehaviour for the purposes of sub-section (1).

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 15
content:
(1) Every State Government shall, by notification in the Official Gazette, constitute a body to be known as the (name of the State) Information Commission to exercise the powers conferred on, and to perform the functions assigned to it under this Act.

(2) The State Information Commission shall consist of:
(a) the State Chief Information Commissioner; and
(b) such number of State Information Commissioners, not exceeding ten, as may be deemed necessary.

(3) The State Chief Information Commissioner and the State Information Commissioners shall be appointed by the Governor on the recommendation of a committee consisting of:
(i) the Chief Minister, who shall be the Chairperson of the committee;
(ii) the Leader of Opposition in the Legislative Assembly; and
(iii) a Cabinet Minister to be nominated by the Chief Minister.
Explanation: For the purposes of removal of doubts, where the Leader of Opposition in the Legislative Assembly has not been recognised as such, the Leader of the single largest group in opposition of the Government in the Legislative Assembly shall be deemed to be the Leader of Opposition.

(4) The general superintendence, direction and management of the affairs of the State Information Commission shall vest in the State Chief Information Commissioner, who shall be assisted by the State Information Commissioners, and may exercise all such powers and do all such acts and things which may be exercised or done by the State Information Commission autonomously without being subjected to directions by any other authority under this Act.

(5) The State Chief Information Commissioner and the State Information Commissioners shall be persons of eminence in public life with wide knowledge and experience in law, science and technology, social service, management, journalism, mass media, or administration and governance.

(6) The State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner shall not be a Member of Parliament or Member of the Legislature of any State or Union territory, or hold any other office of profit, or be connected with any political party, or carry on any business or pursue any profession.

(7) The headquarters of the State Information Commission shall be at such place in the State as the State Government may specify by notification in the Official Gazette, and the State Information Commission may, with the previous approval of the State Government, establish offices at other places in the State.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 16
content:
(1) The State Chief Information Commissioner shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office and shall not be eligible for reappointment, provided that no State Chief Information Commissioner shall hold office after attaining the age of sixty-five years.

(2) Every State Information Commissioner shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office or until he attains the age of sixty-five years, whichever is earlier, and shall not be eligible for reappointment as such. However, a State Information Commissioner shall, on vacating office, be eligible for appointment as the State Chief Information Commissioner in the manner specified in sub-section (3) of section 15. Where a State Information Commissioner is appointed as the State Chief Information Commissioner, the total term shall not exceed five years in aggregate for both roles.

(3) Before entering office, the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner shall make and subscribe an oath or affirmation before the Governor or another person appointed by him, according to the form set out in the First Schedule.

(4) The State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner may, at any time, by writing under his hand addressed to the Governor, resign from office, and may be removed in the manner specified under section 17.

(5) The salaries, allowances, and other terms and conditions of service shall be:
(a) for the State Chief Information Commissioner — the same as that of an Election Commissioner;
(b) for a State Information Commissioner — the same as that of the Chief Secretary to the State Government.
If, at the time of appointment, the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner is in receipt of a pension (other than disability or wound pension) from previous government service, the salary shall be reduced by the amount of that pension, including any commuted portion and pension equivalent of other retirement benefits, excluding retirement gratuity. If they are receiving retirement benefits from a corporation or government company, the salary shall be reduced by the pension equivalent of those benefits. Salaries, allowances, and other conditions of service shall not be varied to their disadvantage after appointment.

(6) The State Government shall provide the State Chief Information Commissioner and the State Information Commissioners with such officers and employees as may be necessary for the efficient performance of their functions, and the salaries, allowances, and terms of service of such officers and employees shall be as prescribed.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 17
content:
(1) Subject to the provisions of sub-section (3), the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner shall be removed from office only by order of the Governor on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity, after the Supreme Court, on a reference made to it by the Governor, has, upon inquiry, reported that the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner, as the case may be, ought on such ground to be removed.
(2) The Governor may suspend from office, and if deemed necessary also prohibit from attending the office during inquiry, the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner in respect of whom a reference has been made to the Supreme Court under sub-section (1) until the Governor has passed orders on receipt of the report of the Supreme Court on such reference.
(3) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), the Governor may by order remove from office the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner if such person:
(a) is adjudged an insolvent; or
(b) has been convicted of an offence which, in the opinion of the Governor, involves moral turpitude; or
(c) engages during his term of office in any paid employment outside the duties of his office; or
(d) is, in the opinion of the Governor, unfit to continue in office by reason of infirmity of mind or body; or
(e) has acquired such financial or other interest as is likely to affect prejudicially his functions as the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner.
(4) If the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner is in any way concerned or interested in any contract or agreement made by or on behalf of the Government of the State, or participates in any way in the profit thereof or in any benefit or emoluments arising therefrom otherwise than as a member and in common with the other members of an incorporated company, he shall, for the purposes of sub-section (1), be deemed to be guilty of misbehaviour.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 18
content: (1) Subject to the provisions of this Act, it shall be the duty of the Central Information Commission or State Information Commission, as the case may be, to receive and inquire into a complaint from any person— (a) who has been unable to submit a request to a Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, either because no such officer has been appointed under this Act, or because the Central Assistant Public Information Officer or State Assistant Public Information Officer has refused to accept his or her application for information or appeal for forwarding to the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer or the senior officer specified in subsection (1) of section 19 or the Central or State Information Commission; (b) who has been refused access to any information requested under this Act; (c) who has not been given a response to a request for information or access to information within the time limit specified under this Act; (d) who has been required to pay a fee considered unreasonable; (e) who believes they have been given incomplete, misleading, or false information under this Act; and (f) in respect of any other matter relating to requesting or obtaining access to records under this Act. (2) Where the Central or State Information Commission is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to inquire into the matter, it may initiate an inquiry in respect thereof.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 18
content: (3) The Central Information Commission or State Information Commission, as the case may be, shall, while inquiring into any matter under this section, have the same powers as are vested in a civil court while trying a suit under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, in respect of the following matters— (a) summoning and enforcing the attendance of persons and compelling them to give oral or written evidence on oath and to produce documents or things; (b) requiring the discovery and inspection of documents; (c) receiving evidence on affidavit; (d) requisitioning any public record or copies thereof from any court or office; (e) issuing summons for examination of witnesses or documents; and (f) any other matter which may be prescribed. (4) Notwithstanding anything inconsistent contained in any other Act of Parliament or State Legislature, the Central or State Information Commission may, during the inquiry of any complaint under this Act, examine any record to which this Act applies that is under the control of the public authority, and no such record may be withheld from it on any grounds.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 19
content: (1) Any person who does not receive a decision within the time specified in subsection (1) or clause (a) of subsection (3) of section 7, or is aggrieved by a decision of the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, may within thirty days from the expiry of such period or from the receipt of such decision prefer an appeal to an officer senior in rank to the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer in each public authority. Provided that such officer may admit the appeal after the expiry of the thirty-day period if satisfied that the appellant was prevented by sufficient cause from filing on time. (2) Where an appeal is preferred against an order made by a Central or State Public Information Officer under section 11 to disclose third party information, the appeal by the concerned third party shall be made within thirty days from the date of the order. (3) A second appeal against the decision under subsection (1) shall lie within ninety days from the date on which the decision should have been made or was actually received, with the Central or State Information Commission. Provided that the Commission may admit the appeal after the ninety-day period if satisfied that the appellant was prevented by sufficient cause from filing on time. (4) If the decision against which an appeal is preferred relates to third party information, the Commission shall give a reasonable opportunity of being heard to that third party. (5) In any appeal proceedings, the onus to prove that a denial of a request was justified shall be on the Central or State Public Information Officer who denied the request.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 19
content: (6) An appeal under subsection (1) or (2) shall be disposed of within thirty days of receipt or within such extended period not exceeding a total of forty-five days from the date of filing, for reasons to be recorded in writing. (7) The decision of the Central or State Information Commission shall be binding. (8) In its decision, the Commission has the power to— (a) require the public authority to take necessary steps to secure compliance with this Act, including— (i) providing access to information, if requested, in a particular form; (ii) appointing a Central or State Public Information Officer; (iii) publishing certain information or categories of information; (iv) making changes to practices in relation to maintenance, management, and destruction of records; (v) enhancing training on the right to information for officials; (vi) providing an annual report in compliance with clause (b) of subsection (1) of section 4; (b) require the public authority to compensate the complainant for any loss or detriment suffered; (c) impose any of the penalties provided under this Act; (d) reject the application. (9) The Commission shall give notice of its decision, including any right of appeal, to the complainant and the public authority. (10) The Commission shall decide the appeal in accordance with the prescribed procedure.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 20
content:
(1) Where the Central Information Commission or the State Information Commission, as the case may be, at the time of deciding any complaint or appeal is of the opinion that the Central Public Information Officer (CPIO) or the State Public Information Officer (SPIO), as the case may be, has, without any reasonable cause, refused to receive an application for information, has not furnished information within the time specified under sub-section (1) of section 7, has malafidely denied the request for information, has knowingly given incorrect, incomplete or misleading information, has destroyed information that was the subject of the request, or has obstructed in any manner the furnishing of information, it shall impose a penalty of two hundred and fifty rupees for each day until the application is received or the information is furnished. However, the total amount of such penalty shall not exceed twenty-five thousand rupees.
Provided that the CPIO or SPIO, as the case may be, shall be given a reasonable opportunity of being heard before any penalty is imposed.
Provided further that the burden of proving that they acted reasonably and diligently shall be on the CPIO or SPIO, as the case may be.

(2) Where the Central Information Commission or the State Information Commission, as the case may be, at the time of deciding any complaint or appeal, is of the opinion that the CPIO or SPIO, as the case may be, has, without any reasonable cause and persistently, failed to receive an application for information, has not furnished information within the time specified under sub-section (1) of section 7, has malafidely denied the request for information, has knowingly given incorrect, incomplete or misleading information, has destroyed information that was the subject of the request, or has obstructed in any manner the furnishing of information, it shall recommend disciplinary action against the CPIO or SPIO, as the case may be, under the service rules applicable to them.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 21
content: No suit, prosecution, or other legal proceeding shall lie against any person for anything which is done or intended to be done in good faith under this Act or any rule made thereunder.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 22
content: The provisions of this Act shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in the Official Secrets Act, 1923, or any other law for the time being in force, or in any instrument having effect by virtue of any law other than this Act.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 23
content: No court shall entertain any suit, application, or other proceeding in respect of any order made under this Act, and no such order shall be called in question otherwise than by way of an appeal under this Act.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 24
content:
(1) Nothing contained in this Act shall apply to the intelligence and security organisations specified in the Second Schedule, being organisations established by the Central Government, or to any information furnished by such organisations to that Government. Provided that information pertaining to allegations of corruption and human rights violations shall not be excluded under this sub-section. Provided further that, in the case of information sought in respect of allegations of violation of human rights, the information shall only be provided after the approval of the Central Information Commission and, notwithstanding anything contained in section 7, such information shall be provided within forty-five days from the date of receipt of the request.

(2) The Central Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, amend the Schedule by including any other intelligence or security organisation established by that Government or omitting any organisation already specified therein. Upon publication of such notification, the organisation shall be deemed to be included in or omitted from the Schedule.

(3) Every notification issued under sub-section (2) shall be laid before each House of Parliament.

(4) Nothing contained in this Act shall apply to such intelligence and security organisations established by the State Government, as specified by that Government from time to time by notification in the Official Gazette. Provided that information pertaining to allegations of corruption and human rights violations shall not be excluded under this sub-section. Provided further that, in the case of information sought in respect of allegations of violation of human rights, the information shall only be provided after the approval of the State Information Commission and, notwithstanding anything contained in section 7, such information shall be provided within forty-five days from the date of receipt of the request.

(5) Every notification issued under sub-section (4) shall be laid before the State Legislature.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 – Section 25
Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 26
content: (1) The appropriate Government may, to the extent of availability of financial and other resources: (a) develop and organise educational programmes to advance the understanding of the public, particularly disadvantaged communities, on exercising the rights under this Act; (b) encourage public authorities to participate in such programmes and to undertake them independently; (c) promote timely and effective dissemination of accurate information by public authorities about their activities; and (d) train Central Public Information Officers or State Public Information Officers, as applicable, of public authorities, and produce relevant training materials for their use. (2) The appropriate Government shall, within eighteen months from the commencement of this Act, compile in its official language a guide containing information, in an easily comprehensible form and manner, as may reasonably be required by a person wishing to exercise any right under this Act.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 26
content: (3) The appropriate Government shall, if necessary, update and publish the guidelines referred to in sub-section (2) at regular interval.

title: Right to Information Act - 2005 Section 27
content: (1) The appropriate Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, make rules to carry out the provisions of this Act. (2) In particular, and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for all or any of the following matters, namely: the cost of the medium or print cost price of the materials to be disseminated under sub-section (4) of section 4; the fee payable under sub-section (1) of section 6; sub-section (6) of section 16; the procedure to be adopted by the Central Information Commission or State Information Commission, as the case may be, in deciding the appeals under sub-section (10) of section 19; any other matter which is required to be, or may be, prescribed; the fee payable under sub-sections (1) and (5) of section 7; the salaries and allowances payable to and the terms and conditions of service of the officers and other employees under sub-section (6) of section 13 and sub-section (6) of section 16.

title: Right to Information Act 2005 Section 28
content: (1) The competent authority may, by notification in the Official Gazette, make rules to carry out the provisions of this Act. (2) In particular, and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for all or any of the following matters, namely: the cost of the medium or print cost price of the materials to be disseminated under sub-section (4) of section 4; the fee payable under sub-section (1) of section 6; the fee payable under sub-section (1) of section 7; and any other matter which is required to be, or may be, prescribed.

title: Right to Information Act 2005 Section 29
content: (1) Every rule made by the Central Government under this Act shall be laid, as soon as may be after it is made, before each House of Parliament, while it is in session, for a total period of thirty days which may be comprised in one session or in two or more successive sessions, and if, before the expiry of the session immediately following the session or the successive sessions aforesaid, both Houses agree in making any modification in the rule or both Houses agree that the rule should not be made, the rule shall thereafter have effect only in such modified form or be of no effect, as the case may be; so, however, that any such modification or annulment shall be without prejudice to the validity of anything previously done under that rule.

title: Right to Information Act 2005 Section 30
content: (1) If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Act, the Central Government may, by order published in the Official Gazette, make such provisions not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act as appear to it to be necessary or expedient for removal of the difficulty: Provided that no such order shall be made after the expiry of a period of two years from the date of the commencement of this Act. (2) Every order made under this section shall, as soon as may be after it is made, be laid before each House of Parliament.

title: Right to Information Act 2005 Section 31
content: The Freedom of Information Act, 2002 is hereby repealed.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 1: Short title, extent and commencement
content: This Act may be called the Copyright Act, 1957, extends to the whole of India, and shall come into force on a date appointed by the Central Government through a notification in the Official Gazette.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 2: Interpretation
content: Section 2 of the Copyright Act, 1957 defines key terms such as adaptation, Appellate Board, work of architecture, artistic work, author, broadcast, calendar year, cinematograph film, commercial rental, communication to the public, composer, computer, computer programme, copyright society, delivery, dramatic work, duplicating equipment, engravings, exclusive licence, Government work, Indian work, infringing copy, lecture, literary work, musical work, performance, performer, photograph, plate, prescribed, producer, reprography, Right Management Information, sound recording, visual recording, work, work of joint authorship, and work of sculpture.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 3: Meaning of publication
content: For the purposes of this Act, publication means making a work available to the public by issuing copies or by communicating the work to the public.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 4: When work not deemed to be published or performed in public
content: Except in relation to infringement of copyright, a work shall not be deemed published or performed in public if such publication or performance takes place without the licence of the copyright owner.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 5: When work deemed to be first published in India
content: A work published in India is deemed first published in India even if published simultaneously in another country, unless that country provides a shorter copyright term; publication is simultaneous if the gap between publication in India and in the other country does not exceed thirty days or a period specified by the Central Government for that country.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 6: Certain disputes to be decided by Appellate Board
content: If any question arises regarding whether a work has been published or its date of publication for Chapter V purposes, or whether copyright term in another country is shorter than under this Act, it shall be referred to the Appellate Board whose decision is final; if the Board considers the issue of copies or communication to the public under Section 3 insignificant, it shall not be deemed publication for that section's purposes.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 7: Nationality of author where the making of unpublished work is extended over considerable period
content: For an unpublished work created over a considerable period, the author is deemed a citizen of or domiciled in the country of which they were a citizen or domiciled during any substantial part of that period.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 8: Domicile of corporations
content: A body corporate is deemed domiciled in India if incorporated under any law in force in India.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 9: Copyright Office
content: There shall be established a Copyright Office for the purposes of this Act, under the immediate control of the Registrar of Copyrights who shall act under the superintendence and direction of the Central Government, and the Office shall have a seal.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 10: Registrar and Deputy Registrar of Copyrights
content: The Central Government shall appoint a Registrar of Copyrights and may appoint one or more Deputy Registrars of Copyrights; a Deputy Registrar shall discharge functions assigned by the Registrar under his superintendence and direction, and references in this Act to the Registrar include a Deputy Registrar when so acting.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 11: Appellate Board
content: The Appellate Board established under section 83 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 shall, from the commencement of Part XIV of Chapter VI of the Finance Act, 2017, be the Appellate Board for the purposes of this Act with the jurisdiction, powers and authority conferred by or under this Act.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 12: Powers and procedure of Appellate Board
content: The Appellate Board may regulate its own procedure, including fixing of sittings, and shall ordinarily hear matters in the zone where the proceeding's institutor resides, carries on business, or works for gain; the Board may act through benches constituted by its Chairman, who may refer important matters to a special bench of five members; members with personal interest shall not take part; acts or proceedings are not invalid due to vacancies or defects in constitution; the Board is deemed a civil court for sections 345 and 346 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, and proceedings before it are judicial proceedings under sections 193 and 228 of the Indian Penal Code.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 13: Works in which copyright subsists
content: Copyright subsists throughout India in original literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works, cinematograph films, and sound recordings, subject to conditions regarding nationality, place of first publication, and location in the case of architectural works; it does not subsist where the work infringes another copyright, and in architecture covers only artistic character and design, not methods of construction.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 14: Meaning of copyright
content: Copyright means the exclusive right, subject to this Act, to do or authorise specified acts in relation to a work or substantial part thereof, including reproduction, issuing copies to the public, performance or communication to the public, making films or recordings, translations, adaptations, and commercial rental in cases of literary, dramatic, musical, artistic works, computer programmes, cinematograph films, and sound recordings, with variations according to the class of work.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 15: Special provision regarding copyright in designs registered or capable of being registered under the Designs Act, 2000
content: Copyright does not subsist in any design registered under the Designs Act, 2000; and for designs capable of being registered but not so registered, copyright ceases once the design is reproduced more than fifty times by an industrial process by or with the licence of the copyright owner.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 16: No copyright except as provided in this Act
content: No person is entitled to copyright or similar rights in any work, whether published or unpublished, except as provided under this Act or other laws in force; however, this does not affect rights or jurisdiction to restrain breach of trust or confidence.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 17: First owner of copyright
content: Subject to this Act, the author of a work is the first owner of copyright, except where: (a) works are made during employment by a newspaper proprietor, who owns copyright for publication purposes only; (b) photographs, paintings, portraits, engravings or cinematograph films are made for valuable consideration at another's instance, in which case that person owns the copyright; (c) works are made during employment under contract of service or apprenticeship (not covered by (a) or (b)), where the employer owns the copyright; (cc) public addresses or speeches are owned by the person delivering them or on whose behalf they are delivered; (d) Government works are owned by Government; (dd) works made or first published under direction or control of a public undertaking are owned by that undertaking; (e) works to which section 41 applies are owned by the relevant international organisation; provided that for works in cinematograph films, authors retain rights in underlying literary, dramatic or musical works as per section 13(1)(a).

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 18: Assignment of copyright
content: The owner or prospective owner of copyright may assign it wholly or partially, generally or with limitations, for the whole or part of the term. For future works, assignment takes effect when the work exists. Assignments cannot apply to modes of exploitation not existing or commercially used at the time unless specified. Authors of literary or musical works in films or sound recordings retain the right to equal royalties for uses beyond film cinema-hall communication, unless assigning to heirs or a copyright society, with contrary agreements void. Assignees and assignors are treated separately as owners for assigned and unassigned rights. 'Assignee' includes legal representatives if the assignee dies before the work exists.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 19: Mode of assignment
content: Assignments must be in writing signed by the assignor or authorised agent, identifying the work, specifying rights, duration, and territorial extent, and stating royalty and other consideration payable to the author or heirs. Assignments are subject to mutual revision/termination terms. If the assignee fails to exercise rights within one year, the assignment lapses unless otherwise specified. If no duration is stated, it is deemed five years; if no territory is specified, it is deemed India. These provisions do not apply to pre-1994 assignments. Assignments contrary to rights already granted to a copyright society are void. Assignments to make films or sound recordings do not affect authors' rights to equal royalties for uses beyond film cinema-hall communication or other exploitations.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 19A: Disputes with respect to assignment of copyright
content: If an assignee fails to sufficiently exercise assigned rights without the assignor's fault, the Appellate Board may revoke the assignment upon complaint. The Board may also resolve disputes over assignments, including ordering royalty recovery, but cannot revoke an assignment unless its terms are harsh to the author-assignor. Pending revocation, the Board may issue orders on implementing assignment terms and consideration. Revocation cannot occur within five years of assignment. Complaints should be decided within six months where possible, with reasons recorded for any delay.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 20: Transmission of copyright in manuscript by testamentary disposition
content: Where a manuscript of a literary, dramatic, musical, or artistic work is bequeathed and was unpublished before the testator's death, the bequest is construed to include any copyright the testator owned at death, unless the will or codicil shows contrary intention. 'Manuscript' means the original document embodying the work, whether handwritten or not.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 21: Right of author to relinquish copyright
content: An author may relinquish all or part of copyright rights by giving notice to the Registrar of Copyrights or via public notice; rights cease from the notice date, subject to rights existing in favour of others on that date. The Registrar publishes the notice in the Official Gazette and as deemed fit, and within 14 days posts it on the Copyright Office website for at least three years.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 22: Term of copyright in published literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works
content: Copyright in any literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work published within the lifetime of the author subsists until sixty years from the beginning of the calendar year following the year of the author's death; for joint authorship, it is calculated from the death of the last surviving author.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 23: Term of copyright in anonymous and pseudonymous works
content: For literary, dramatic, musical or artistic works (other than photographs) published anonymously or pseudonymously, copyright lasts until sixty years from the start of the calendar year following first publication; if the author's identity is disclosed before this period ends, it lasts sixty years from the year following the author's death, with detailed rules for joint authorship, partial disclosure, and pseudonyms; disclosure is recognised if made publicly by both author and publisher or established to the Appellate Board's satisfaction.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 24: Term of copyright in posthumous works
content: For literary, dramatic or musical works or engravings in which copyright exists at the author's death (or last surviving author's death for joint works) but unpublished, copyright lasts until sixty years from the start of the calendar year following first publication, or from the year after publication of an adaptation; public performance or sale/offer of a sound recording of the work counts as publication.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 26: Term of copyright in cinematograph films
content: Copyright in a cinematograph film lasts until sixty years from the start of the calendar year following the year of first publication.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 27: Term of copyright in sound recordings
content: Copyright in a sound recording lasts until sixty years from the start of the calendar year following the year of first publication.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 28: Term of copyright in Government works
content: Where Government is the first owner, copyright lasts until sixty years from the start of the calendar year following the year of first publication.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 28A: Term of copyright in works of public undertakings
content: Where a public undertaking is the first owner, copyright lasts until sixty years from the start of the calendar year following the year of first publication.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 29: Term of copyright in works of international organisations
content: For works of an international organisation to which section 41 applies, copyright lasts until sixty years from the start of the calendar year following first publication.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 30: Licences by owners of copyright
content: The owner or prospective owner of copyright may grant rights by licence in writing or via authorised agent; for future works, the licence takes effect when the work comes into existence; if the licensee dies before that, their legal representatives inherit the benefit unless the licence states otherwise.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 30A: Application of section 19
content: The provisions of section 19, with necessary adaptations and modifications, apply to licences under section 30 as they do to copyright assignments.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 31: Compulsory licence in works withheld from public
content: If the owner unreasonably refuses to republish, perform publicly, or allow broadcast of a published or performed work, the Appellate Board may direct the Registrar of Copyrights to grant a licence for such purposes to qualified persons, with compensation and conditions determined by the Board.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 31A: Compulsory licence in unpublished or published works
content: Where an unpublished or published work is withheld from the public in India and the author is dead, unknown, untraceable, or the copyright owner cannot be found, any person may apply to the Appellate Board for a licence to publish or translate it; the applicant must first advertise the proposal; if granted, royalties are deposited for the owner or heirs; the Government may direct heirs to publish in the national interest, failing which the Board may allow others to do so on royalty terms.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 31B: Compulsory licence for benefit of disabled
content: Any person working for the benefit of persons with disability may apply to the Appellate Board for a compulsory licence to publish a copyrighted work for their benefit (in cases outside section 52(1)(zb)); the Board must verify credentials, ensure good faith, hear rights owners, and if justified, direct the Registrar to grant the licence specifying means, format, period, and royalty, with possible extension.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 31C: Statutory licence for cover versions
content: Any person may make a cover version (sound recording of a literary, dramatic or musical work previously recorded with rights owner's consent) in the same medium as the last recording unless obsolete, by giving prior notice, submitting covers/labels, and paying royalties at rates fixed by the Appellate Board; restrictions apply on misleading packaging, unauthorised alterations, timing (five years after first recording), mandatory minimum royalty for 50,000 copies unless reduced for certain languages, record-keeping, inspection, and remedies for non-payment.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 31D: Statutory licence for broadcasting of literary and musical works and sound recordings
content: Broadcasting organisations may communicate published literary or musical works and sound recordings to the public via broadcast or performance by giving prior notice, stating duration and territory, and paying royalties at rates fixed by the Appellate Board (with separate rates for radio and television); the Board may require advance payments; authors and principal performers must be credited; only technically necessary alterations are allowed; broadcasters must keep records, report, and allow inspection; existing pre-2012 licences and agreements remain unaffected.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 32: Licence to produce and publish translations
content: Any person may apply to the Appellate Board for a licence to produce and publish a translation of a literary or dramatic work after seven years from first publication; for non-Indian works needed for teaching, scholarship, or research, after three years (or one year if in a language not generally used in developed countries). An application must be in prescribed form, state retail price, and be accompanied by a fee. The Board may grant a non-exclusive licence subject to royalty payments, export restrictions for certain translations, and conditions that no authorised translation exists or is out of print, the applicant has requested and been refused authorisation (or cannot locate the owner), proper notices are given, time limits for owner response have elapsed, and competence to translate is proven. Special provisions apply to broadcasting authority translations for teaching or research. Definitions of developed and developing countries, teaching, scholarship, and research are provided.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 32A: Licence to reproduce and publish works for certain purposes
content: After the 'relevant period' (7 years for fiction/poetry/drama/music/art, 3 years for science/tech/math, 5 years for others) from first publication, if copies of an edition are unavailable or not offered for sale in India for six months at a reasonable price, any person may apply to the Appellate Board for a non-exclusive licence to reproduce and publish the work for systematic instructional activities at the same or lower price. The applicant must have sought and been refused authorisation (or cannot locate the owner), sent notice to the publisher, shown competence and means to pay royalties, agreed to price conditions, and ensured certain time periods have elapsed without the owner publishing. Copies must state author and edition details, and the author must not have withdrawn copies. Export is prohibited, and special rules apply to translations and audiovisual instructional texts.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 32B: Termination of licences issued under this Chapter
content: A licence to translate under section 32(1A) terminates if the copyright owner or authorised person publishes a substantially similar translation in the same language at a reasonable price, effective three months after notice to the licensee; remaining copies may be sold until exhausted. Similarly, a licence to reproduce or translate under section 32A terminates if the owner sells or distributes substantially the same work or translation at a reasonable price, with three months' notice; remaining copies may be sold until exhausted.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 33: Registration of Copyright society
content: No one may carry on the business of granting licences for copyrighted works except with registration under this section, though owners may license their own works individually. Licensing of certain works in films and sound recordings must be through a registered society. Existing functioning societies must register within one year of amendment commencement. Associations meeting prescribed conditions may apply via the Registrar to the Central Government, which may register one society per class of works, considering the interests of rights owners, the public, and applicant competence. Registration lasts five years and is renewable if authors retain collective control. The Government may suspend or cancel registration for mismanagement, non-compliance, or certain changes, appointing an administrator if suspended.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 33A: Tariff scheme by copyright societies
content: Every copyright society must publish its tariff scheme as prescribed. Aggrieved persons may appeal to the Appellate Board, which may modify unreasonable elements after inquiry. The appellant must pay due fees before appealing and continue payments during appeal; the Board may fix an interim tariff pending the decision.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 34: Administration of rights of owner by copyright society
content: A copyright society may, subject to conditions, accept exclusive authorisation from authors or other rights owners to administer rights in works by issuing licences and/or collecting fees, and owners may withdraw such authorisation. Societies may contract with foreign societies to administer rights abroad or in India, without discrimination between Indian and foreign works. Societies may issue licences, collect fees, distribute royalties (after expenses), and perform related functions under section 35.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 35: Control over the copyright society by the author and other owners of right
content: Copyright societies are under the collective control of the owners whose rights they administer, except foreign-administered rights. They must obtain owner approval for collection/distribution procedures, use of funds for other purposes, and provide regular detailed activity reports. Royalties must be distributed in proportion to actual use. Governing bodies must have equal numbers of authors and owners of works, all members have equal rights, and there must be no discrimination in royalty distribution.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 36: Submission of returns and reports
content: Copyright societies must submit prescribed returns to the Registrar of Copyrights. Authorised government officers may request reports and records to ensure collected fees are used or distributed in accordance with the Act.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 36A: Rights and liabilities of performing rights societies
content: Nothing in this Chapter affects any rights or liabilities regarding a copyright society that accrued, were incurred, or were pending before commencement of the Copyright (Amendment) Act, 2012.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 37: Broadcast reproduction right
content: Every broadcasting organisation has a special 'broadcast reproduction right' in its broadcasts for 25 years from the start of the calendar year following the year of the broadcast. During this term, without the owner's licence, acts such as rebroadcasting, causing it to be seen or heard by the public for payment, making sound or visual recordings, reproducing such recordings made without licence or beyond licence terms, or selling/renting such recordings, constitute infringement, subject to section 39.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 38: Performer's right
content: Any performer appearing or engaging in a performance has a special 'performer's right' lasting 50 years from the start of the calendar year following the year of the performance.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 38A: Exclusive right of performers
content: A performer has the exclusive right to make sound or visual recordings of the performance, reproduce them in any material form including electronic storage, issue copies to the public, communicate to the public, sell or rent copies, and broadcast or otherwise communicate the performance to the public (except when already broadcast). Once a performer consents in writing to incorporation of the performance in a cinematograph film, they cannot object to the producer's enjoyment of these rights in that film, but remain entitled to royalties for commercial use.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 38B: Moral rights of the performer
content: Independently of economic rights, a performer has the right to be identified as such (except where omission is due to the manner of use) and to restrain or claim damages for any distortion, mutilation, or modification prejudicial to their reputation. Technical edits, shortening, or other purely technical modifications are not considered prejudicial.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 39: Acts not infringing broadcast reproduction right or performer's right
content: No infringement occurs by making recordings for private use or bona fide teaching/research; using excerpts of a performance or broadcast for reporting current events or bona fide review, teaching or research consistent with fair dealing; or carrying out other acts (with necessary adaptations) that do not constitute copyright infringement under section 52.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 39A: Certain provisions to apply in case of broadcast reproduction right and performer's rights
content: Sections 18, 19, 30, 30A, 33, 33A, 34, 35, 36, 53, 55, 58, 63, 64, 65, 65A, 65B, and 66 apply with necessary adaptations to broadcast reproduction rights and performer’s rights. No licence to reproduce a broadcast of a copyrighted work or performance may be given without consent of the copyright owner or performer. These rights do not subsist in any infringing broadcast or performance and do not affect separate copyright in underlying works.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 40: Power to extend copyright to foreign works
content: The Central Government may, by order in the Official Gazette, direct that all or specified provisions of this Act apply to works first published outside India, to unpublished works by foreign authors, to domicile in foreign territories, or to works by foreign citizens, as if relating to India, subject to conditions including reciprocal protection, class limitations, term limits not exceeding those in this Act, prescribed formalities, modifications for foreign law, and possible exclusion of works made or published before the order's commencement.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 40A: Power of Central Government to apply Chapter VIII to broadcasting organisations and performers in certain other countries
content: If satisfied that a foreign country provides reciprocal protection for rights of broadcasting organisations and performers as under this Act, the Central Government may, by order in the Official Gazette, apply Chapter VIII to such foreign entities and performances, treating them as if in India. Orders may set class applicability, ensure terms of rights do not exceed those in this Act, impose conditions/formalities, exclude pre‑order broadcasts/performances, and make exceptions/modifications for ownership in line with foreign law.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 41: Provisions as to works of certain international organisations
content: Where a work is made or first published by or under the direction/control of an international organisation declared by order to which one or more sovereign powers are members, and absent this section no copyright would exist in India, copyright shall subsist if made/published under agreement without reserving rights to the author or otherwise owned by the organisation under section 17. Such organisations have the legal capacity of a body corporate for copyright purposes.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 42: Power to restrict rights in works of foreign authors first published in India
content: If the Central Government finds that a foreign country does not give adequate protection to Indian authors' works, it may, by order in the Official Gazette, direct that provisions conferring copyright on works first published in India shall not apply to works published after a specified date whose authors are subjects or citizens of that country and not domiciled in India.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 42A: Power to restrict rights of foreign broadcasting organisations and performers
content: If the Central Government finds that a foreign country does not give adequate protection to broadcasting organisations' or performers' rights, it may, by order in the Official Gazette, direct that provisions conferring such rights shall not apply to entities or persons from that country who are not incorporated or domiciled in India.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 43: Orders under this Chapter to be laid before Parliament
content: Every order made by the Central Government under this Chapter must be laid before both Houses of Parliament as soon as possible and is subject to modification by Parliament during the session in which it is laid or the following session.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 44: Register of Copyrights
content: The Register of Copyrights shall be kept at the Copyright Office in the prescribed form and may include names or titles of works, names and addresses of authors, publishers, owners of copyright, and other prescribed particulars.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 45: Entries in Register of Copyrights
content: Authors, publishers, owners, or interested persons may apply in the prescribed form with fee to enter particulars of a work in the Register of Copyrights; for artistic works used or capable of use with goods or services, a trademark clearance certificate is required. The Registrar may enter particulars after inquiry.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 46: Indexes
content: The Copyright Office shall keep prescribed indexes of the Register of Copyrights.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 47: Form and inspection of register
content: The Register of Copyrights and its indexes shall be open to inspection at reasonable times, and copies or extracts may be taken on payment of prescribed fee and conditions.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 48: Register of Copyrights to be prima facie evidence
content: The Register of Copyrights is prima facie evidence of its entries; certified copies or extracts from it are admissible in all courts without further proof or production of the original.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 49: Correction of entries in the Register of Copyrights
content: The Registrar may amend or alter the Register to correct errors in names, addresses, particulars, or accidental slips or omissions, subject to prescribed cases and conditions.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 50: Rectification of Register by Appellate Board
content: On application by the Registrar or any aggrieved person, the Appellate Board shall order rectification of the Register by making omitted entries, expunging wrongly made entries, or correcting errors or defects.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 50A: Entries in the Register of Copyrights to be published
content: Every entry, correction, or rectification in the Register of Copyrights shall be published in the Official Gazette or in such other manner as the Registrar deems fit.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 51: When copyright infringed
content: Copyright is infringed when a person, without licence or in breach of licence conditions, does acts reserved for the copyright owner, permits a place to be used for infringing communication for profit (unless unaware), or makes, sells, hires, distributes to trade/prejudicially, exhibits publicly, or imports infringing copies, with a one‑copy import exception for private use; reproducing a work in film form is deemed an infringing copy.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 52: Certain acts not to be infringement of copyright
content: Lists acts that do not constitute infringement, including fair dealing for private use, criticism, review, current event reporting; certain uses of computer programs by lawful possessors; transient/incidental storage; use in judicial or legislative proceedings; reasonable public readings; instructional collections; educational performances; club use; religious ceremonies; non‑commercial library uses; reproduction for research; publication of official material and judgments; artistic works in public places; architectural reconstructions; exhibitions after copyright expiry; ephemeral recordings; adaptations for persons with disabilities; import of incidental material; and applies similarly to translations/adaptations.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 52A: Particulars to be included in sound recording and video films
content: Sound recordings must display maker's and copyright owner's names/addresses and year of first publication; video films must display Board of Film Certification certificate (if applicable), maker's name/address with licensing statement, and copyright owner's name/address, both in the film and on the container.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 53: Importation of infringing copies
content: A copyright owner or agent may notify Customs to treat infringing copies as prohibited goods for up to one year; Commissioner may require security deposit; detained goods require notification to importer and complainant; release occurs if no court order is produced within 14 days; excludes goods in transit.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 53A: Resale share right in original copies
content: On resale above ₹10,000 of original paintings, sculptures, drawings, or original literary/dramatic/musical manuscripts, the author (or heirs) retains a resale price share (max 10%) fixed by the Appellate Board, notwithstanding copyright assignment, until copyright expiry; disputes go to the Board.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 54: Definition
content: 'Owner of copyright' includes an exclusive licensee; for anonymous/pseudonymous works, the publisher until the author's identity is publicly disclosed or established to the Appellate Board's satisfaction.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 55: Civil remedies for infringement of copyright
content: The copyright owner may seek injunctions, damages, accounts and other remedies; if the infringer proves good faith belief that copyright did not subsist, remedies are limited; name appearing on copies creates presumption of authorship or publication; costs are at court's discretion.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 56: Protection of separate rights
content: Where different copyright rights in a work are owned separately, each owner may enforce their right individually without joining other owners.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 57: Author’s special rights
content: Independently of copyright and after assignment, authors have moral rights to claim authorship and to restrain or claim damages for distortions, mutilations, modifications or other acts prejudicial to honour or reputation, with exceptions for certain computer program adaptations; rights pass to legal representatives.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 58: Rights of owner against persons possessing or dealing with infringing copies
content: Infringing copies and plates are the property of the copyright owner, who may recover them or seek conversion remedies, unless the possessor proves lack of knowledge/reasonable grounds to believe infringement.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 59: Restriction on remedies in the case of works of architecture
content: For infringing buildings/structures under construction, the copyright owner cannot obtain an injunction or order demolition; section 58 remedies do not apply to such constructions.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 60: Remedy in the case of groundless threat of legal proceedings
content: If a person threatens legal proceedings for alleged copyright infringement, the aggrieved may sue for a declaration of non‑infringement, injunction against threats, and damages, unless the threatener diligently commences infringement proceedings.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 61: Owner of copyright to be party to the proceeding
content: In infringement suits by exclusive licensees, the copyright owner must be made a defendant unless the court directs otherwise; if the licensee succeeds, the owner cannot sue again for the same cause of action.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 62: Jurisdiction of court over matters arising under this Chapter
content: Infringement suits must be filed in a district court having jurisdiction, including courts where the plaintiff resides, carries on business, or works for gain, notwithstanding other laws.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 63: Offence of infringement of copyright or other rights conferred by this Act
content: Any person who knowingly infringes or abets the infringement of copyright in a work or any other right under this Act (except section 53A) is punishable with imprisonment of at least six months up to three years and fine of at least ₹50,000 up to ₹2 lakh; lesser punishment may be imposed for non‑commercial infringements; construction of an infringing building is not an offence under this section.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 63A: Enhanced penalty on second and subsequent convictions
content: A repeat convict under section 63 is punishable with imprisonment of at least one year up to three years and fine of at least ₹1 lakh up to ₹2 lakh; lesser punishment may be imposed for non‑commercial infringements; convictions before the 1984 Amendment are not counted.

title: Copyright Act, 1957 - Section 63B: Knowing use of infringing copy of computer programme to be an offence
content: Knowingly using on a computer an infringing copy of a computer program is punishable with imprisonment of at least seven days up to three years and fine of at least ₹50,000 up to ₹2 lakh; for non‑commercial use, court may forgo imprisonment and impose a fine up to ₹50,000.
