content: (1) Where a Court in India desires a warrant for arrest of a person to be executed in a contracting State, it shall send it in duplicate to a Court, Judge or Magistrate there through an authority notified by the Central Government; such authority shall cause it to be executed. (2) During investigation/inquiry, if attendance of a person in a contracting State is required, the Court may issue a summons or warrant to be served/executed there. (3) Warrants from contracting States are executed as if from another Court in India. (4) Where a person is transferred to a contracting State from India and is a prisoner, the Court or Central Government may impose conditions. (5) Where a person transferred to India is a prisoner in a contracting State, the Court in India shall ensure compliance with transfer conditions and custody directions of the Central Government.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105C. Assistance in relation to orders of attachment or forfeiture of property
content: (1) If a Court in India has reasonable grounds to believe property is derived from an offence, it may order attachment or forfeiture under sections 105D to 105J. (2) If such property is suspected to be in a contracting State, the Court may issue a letter of request to that State for execution. (3) Letters of request from contracting States for attachment/forfeiture in India may be forwarded by the Central Government to the appropriate Court for execution under sections 105D to 105J or other applicable law.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105D. Identifying unlawfully acquired property
content: (1) The Court shall, on its own or on receiving a letter of request under section 105C(3), direct a police officer not below Sub-Inspector to take steps to trace and identify such property. (2) Steps may include inquiry, investigation, or survey of persons, places, property, assets, bank accounts, and relevant matters. (3) Such inquiries must follow Court directions.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105E. Seizure or attachment of property
content: (1) If an officer under section 105D believes property may be concealed, transferred or dealt with to prevent recovery, he may seize it or, if impracticable, order that it not be transferred/dealt with without permission. Copy of order served on concerned person. (2) Such order lapses unless confirmed by the Court within 30 days.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105F. Management of properties seized or forfeited
content: (1) The Court may appoint the District Magistrate or another nominated officer as Administrator. (2) The Administrator shall receive and manage property attached or forfeited as directed by the Central Government. (3) The Administrator shall dispose of forfeited property as directed by the Central Government.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105G. Notice of forfeiture of property
content: (1) If after inquiry under section 105D the Court believes property is proceeds of crime, it may serve notice to the affected person to explain the source within 30 days and show cause why it should not be forfeited. (2) If held on behalf by another, a copy shall be served on that person.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105H. Forfeiture of property in certain cases
content: (1) After considering the explanation to notice under section 105G and hearing affected persons, the Court shall decide if property is proceeds of crime; failure to appear allows ex parte decision. (2) If certain proceeds cannot be specifically identified, the Court may specify them to the best of its judgment. (3) Property found as proceeds stands forfeited to the Central Government free of encumbrances. (4) Forfeited company shares shall be transferred to the Government by the company.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105-I. Fine in lieu of forfeiture
content: (1) Where only part of property’s source is unproved, the Court may allow payment of a fine equal to its market value instead of forfeiture. (2) The affected person must be heard before imposing fine. (3) On payment within allowed time, forfeiture is revoked and property released.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105J. Certain transfers to be null and void
content: Any transfer of property after order under section 105E or notice under section 105G is to be ignored; if forfeited under section 105H, such transfers are void.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105K. Procedure in respect of letter of request
content: Every letter of request, summons or warrant to/from a contracting State under this Chapter shall be transmitted in such form and manner as the Central Government notifies.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105L. Application of this Chapter
content: The Central Government may, by notification, apply this Chapter to a contracting State subject to specified conditions, exceptions or qualifications.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 106. Security for keeping the peace on conviction
content: (1) On convicting for offences in subsection (2), a Court may order the person to execute a bond, with/without sureties, to keep the peace up to three years. (2) Offences include: (a) offences under Chapter VIII IPC excluding sections 153A, 153B, 154; (b) offences involving assault, criminal force or mischief; (c) criminal intimidation; (d) other offences causing/likely to cause breach of peace. (3) If conviction is set aside, bond is void. (4) Appellate/Revision Courts may also make such orders.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 107. Security for keeping the peace in other cases
content: (1) An Executive Magistrate with sufficient grounds may require a person likely to cause breach of peace or disturb public tranquillity to show cause why he should not execute a bond (with/without sureties) for up to one year. (2) Jurisdiction exists if the place of apprehended breach is within the Magistrate’s local jurisdiction or such person is within it.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 108. Security for good behaviour from persons disseminating seditious matters
content: (1) An Executive Magistrate may act if a person intentionally disseminates, attempts to disseminate or abets dissemination of: (a) matter punishable under sections 124A, 153A, 153B, 295A IPC; (b) matter concerning a Judge amounting to criminal intimidation or defamation; or produces, keeps for sale, distributes or exhibits obscene matter under section 292 IPC. The Magistrate may require a bond (with/without sureties) for up to one year. (2) No proceedings against registered publication editors, proprietors, printers or publishers without State Government authority.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 109. Security for good behaviour from suspected persons
content: If an Executive Magistrate receives information about a person concealing his presence with intent to commit a cognizable offence, he may require a bond (with/without sureties) for good behaviour for up to one year.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 110. Security for good behaviour from habitual offenders
content: If an Executive Magistrate is informed of a person who is habitually a robber, house-breaker, forger, receiver of stolen property, protector of thieves, commits specified offences (kidnapping, extortion, cheating, mischief, IPC Chapter XII, currency offences), or habitually breaches peace, commits offences under listed Acts (Drugs & Cosmetics, FERA, EPF, Prevention of Food Adulteration, Essential Commodities, Untouchability (Offences), Customs, Foreigners), laws against hoarding, profiteering, adulteration, corruption, or is so dangerous as to require security, he may order a bond with sureties for up to three years.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 111. Order to be made
content: When acting under sections 107-110, the Magistrate shall make a written order stating the substance of the information, bond amount, term, and number/class of sureties required.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 112. Procedure in respect of person present in Court
content: If the person is present, the order under section 111 shall be read to him or explained if he wishes.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 113. Summons or warrant in case of person not so present
content: If the person is absent, the Magistrate shall issue a summons, or if in custody, a warrant to bring him. Proviso: If breach of peace is feared and immediate arrest is necessary, the Magistrate may issue a warrant at any time.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 114. Copy of order to accompany summons or warrant
content: Every summons or warrant under section 113 shall be accompanied by a copy of the section 111 order, to be delivered to the person served/arrested.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 115. Power to dispense with personal attendance
content: The Magistrate may dispense with personal attendance and permit appearance by pleader for persons required to show cause regarding security.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 116. Inquiry as to truth of information
content: (1) After an order under section 111, the Magistrate shall inquire into the truth of the information and take evidence. (2) Inquiry to follow summons-case trial procedure. (3) Before completion, the Magistrate may require interim bond for peace/good behaviour if immediate measures are needed; may detain until bond executed. Proviso: (a) No bond for good behaviour from persons not under sections 108-110; (b) Bond conditions not harsher than section 111 order. (4) Habitual offender/desperate person status may be proved by general repute or otherwise. (5) Multiple persons may be dealt with jointly or separately. (6) Inquiry to be completed within six months, else terminate unless special reasons recorded; detention cases terminate after six months. (7) Sessions Judge may vacate extension if without valid special reason.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 117. Order to give security
content: If proved necessary after inquiry, the Magistrate shall order execution of bond with/without sureties as per section 111. Bond amount to be reasonable. Minors' bonds executed only by sureties.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 118. Discharge of person informed against
content: If not proved necessary to require security, the Magistrate shall record this and discharge the person, releasing him if in custody solely for the inquiry.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 119. Commencement of period for which security is required
content: (1) If the person is serving a sentence when order made under section 106 or 117, the security period starts after sentence expiry. (2) In other cases, it starts on order date unless later date fixed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 120. Contents of bond
content: Bond binds the person to keep peace or good behaviour; for good behaviour, committing, attempting, or abetting any imprisonable offence anywhere breaches the bond.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 121. Power to reject sureties
content: (1) Magistrate may refuse/reject surety as unfit, after inquiry on oath. (2) Notice of inquiry to surety and proposer; evidence recorded. (3) If found unfit, order with reasons to refuse/reject. Before rejecting an accepted surety, issue summons/warrant to the bound person.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 122. Imprisonment in default of security
content: (1)(a) If ordered to give security under section 106 or 117 and fails, commit/detain in prison until period expires or security given; (b) If person bound to peace breaches bond, may be arrested/detained until term expires, in addition to other penalties. (2) If security period exceeds one year and not given, refer to Sessions Judge; he may decide case. (3) Sessions Court may call for more evidence, hear the person, and decide; detention not over three years. (4) Joint proceedings may be referred together. (5) Sessions Judge may transfer to Additional/Assistant Sessions Judge. (6) If security tendered to jail officer, refer to issuing Court/Magistrate. (7) Prison for default in security for peace is simple. (8) Default in security for good behaviour under section 108 is simple; under sections 109 or 110, rigorous or simple as directed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 123. Power to release persons imprisoned for failing to give security
content: (1) The District Magistrate (for orders by an Executive Magistrate under section 117) or the Chief Judicial Magistrate (in other cases) may order the release of a person imprisoned for failing to give security, if satisfied release poses no hazard to the community or others. (2) The High Court, Court of Session, District Magistrate (for section 117 orders), or Chief Judicial Magistrate (in other cases) may reduce the amount, number of sureties, or time of security. (3) Discharge may be unconditional or on conditions accepted by the person; conditions cease when the security period expires. (4) State Government may prescribe conditions for conditional discharge. (5) If conditions are not fulfilled, the District Magistrate/Chief Judicial Magistrate may cancel discharge. (6) On cancellation, the person may be arrested without warrant and brought before the relevant Magistrate. (7) Unless security is given for the unexpired period, the Magistrate may remand the person to prison for that period. (8) Such person may be released anytime on giving security for the unexpired period to the original Court or its successor. (9) The High Court, Court of Session, or relevant Magistrate may cancel any bond executed under this Chapter. (10) A surety may apply to cancel a bond; in such case the Court shall summon or produce the bound person before it.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 124. Security for unexpired period of bond
content: (1) When a person appears or is brought before the Magistrate or Court under section 121(3) proviso or section 123(10), the bond executed by him shall be cancelled, and he shall be ordered to give fresh security of the same description for the unexpired term. (2) Such order is deemed to be under section 106 or section 117 for sections 120–123 purposes.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 125. Order for maintenance of wives, children and parents
content: (1) If a person with sufficient means neglects or refuses to maintain: (a) his wife unable to maintain herself; (b) his legitimate or illegitimate minor child unable to maintain itself (married or not); (c) his legitimate or illegitimate child (not a married daughter) who has attained majority but cannot maintain itself due to physical/mental abnormality or injury; (d) his father or mother unable to maintain themselves; a Magistrate of the first class may order such person to make a monthly allowance at a rate deemed fit. Provisos allow orders for minor female child until majority if husband lacks means; allow interim maintenance and expenses during proceedings; such applications should be disposed of within 60 days of service. Explanation: 'minor' as per Indian Majority Act, 1875; 'wife' includes divorced but unmarried women. (2) Allowance is payable from order date or, if ordered, from application date. (3) Failure to comply without sufficient cause permits issuing warrant to levy amount as fine and possible imprisonment up to one month for each month's unpaid sum. Recovery must be applied for within one year of due date. Grounds for wife's refusal to live with husband may be considered. Husband's remarriage or mistress is just ground for refusal to live. (4) No maintenance if wife in adultery, refuses to live with husband without sufficient cause, or by mutual consent. (5) Order may be cancelled if wife in adultery, refuses without cause, or they agree to live separately. State amendments: Madhya Pradesh — limit increased to Rs. 3000, includes grandparents; West Bengal — limit increased to Rs. 1500, added immediate relief provision (later limit proviso omitted).

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 126. Procedure
content: (1) Proceedings under section 125 may be taken in any district: (a) where the person is; (b) where he or his wife resides; or (c) where he last resided with his wife or mother of illegitimate child. (2) Evidence to be taken in presence of the person (or pleader), recorded as in summons-cases. Proviso: if person avoids service or neglects to attend, case may be heard ex parte; ex parte order may be set aside for good cause within three months, with possible cost terms. (3) Court may make orders as to costs.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 127. Alteration in allowance
content: (1) On proof of change in circumstances, Magistrate may alter maintenance or interim maintenance ordered under section 125. (2) If a Civil Court decision warrants cancellation/variation, Magistrate shall do so. (3) For orders in favour of divorced women: (a) remarriage — cancel from date of remarriage; (b) sum payable on divorce fully received — cancel from date of order or expiry of paid period; (c) voluntary surrender of rights — cancel from date of surrender. (4) When decreeing maintenance or dowry, Civil Court shall account for amounts paid under section 125. State amendments: MP — includes grandparents; WB — raised limit to Rs. 1500 then removed limit proviso.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 128. Enforcement of order of maintenance
content: A copy of the maintenance/interim maintenance order shall be given free to the beneficiary or guardian. It may be enforced by any Magistrate where the liable person is found, on being satisfied about identity and non-payment.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 129. Dispersal of assembly by use of civil force
content: (1) Executive Magistrate, officer in charge of police station, or sub-inspector (if OIC absent) may command unlawful assembly or assembly of 5+ persons likely to disturb peace to disperse. Members must comply. (2) If they do not disperse, or show determination not to, the authority may disperse by force and seek assistance of any male person (not armed forces member acting as such) to disperse and/or arrest/confine members for dispersal or punishment.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 130. Use of armed forces to disperse assembly
content: (1) If assembly cannot otherwise be dispersed and public security requires, the highest-ranking Executive Magistrate present may cause it to be dispersed by armed forces. (2) Magistrate may require armed forces officer to disperse and arrest/confine persons as needed. (3) Armed forces officer shall comply, using minimal necessary force and injury.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 131. Power of certain armed force officers to disperse assembly
content: If public security is endangered by an assembly and no Executive Magistrate is available, a commissioned/gazetted armed forces officer may disperse it and arrest members. Upon contacting a Magistrate, he must follow that Magistrate’s instructions.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 132. Protection against prosecution for acts done under preceding sections
content: (1) No prosecution for acts under sections 129–131 without: (a) Central Government sanction for armed forces; (b) State Government sanction otherwise. (2) Protection applies to Executive Magistrates, police, persons assisting under 129–130, armed forces officers under 131, and members obeying lawful orders, if acting in good faith. (3) Definitions: 'armed forces' includes military, naval, air, and other Union armed forces operating as land forces; 'officer' includes commissioned, gazetted, in-pay officers, JCOs, warrant, petty, NCOs, non-gazetted officers; 'member' means armed forces personnel other than officers.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 133. Conditional order for removal of nuisance
content: (1) Certain Magistrates, on report/info and evidence, may order removal of unlawful obstruction/nuisance in public places/ways, regulate or remove injurious trades/goods, prevent dangerous construction/disposal, remove dangerous structures/trees, fence dangerous tanks/wells, destroy/confine dangerous animals, or require appearance to show cause. (2) Such orders cannot be questioned in Civil Court. Explanation: 'public place' includes State property, camping grounds, sanitary or recreational grounds.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 134. Service or notification of order
content: (1) Serve on the person per summons service method. (2) If not practicable, notify by proclamation as per State Government rules and post copies in suitable places.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 135. Person to whom order is addressed to obey or show cause
content: Person against whom order is made shall either perform act within specified time/manner or appear and show cause.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 136. Consequences of failing to do so
content: If the person does not perform or appear and show cause, he is liable under section 188 IPC and the order is made absolute.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 137. Procedure where existence of public right is denied
content: (1) In section 133 cases regarding public use of way/river/channel/place, Magistrate shall ask respondent if public right is denied. If so, inquire into matter before section 138 proceedings. (2) If reliable evidence supports denial, stay proceedings until competent Court decides; if none, proceed under section 138. (3) Failure to deny when questioned, or failure to prove denial, bars later denial.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 138. Procedure where person appears to show cause
content: (1) If person appears and shows cause, Magistrate takes evidence as in summons-cases. (2) If satisfied the order is reasonable/proper, make absolute (with/without modifications). (3) If not satisfied, close proceedings.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 139. Power of Magistrate to direct local investigation and examination of an expert
content: For inquiries under sections 137–138, Magistrate may order local investigation by suitable person or summon/examine an expert.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 140. Power of Magistrate to furnish written instructions, etc.
content: (1) Magistrate may provide written instructions and determine cost liability for local investigations under section 139. (2) Such report may be read as evidence. (3) For experts, Magistrate may direct cost liability.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 141. Procedure on order being made absolute and consequences of disobedience
content: (1) On order being absolute, Magistrate notifies the person and requires compliance within time, warning of section 188 IPC penalty. (2) On non-compliance, Magistrate may perform act and recover costs via sale of removed items or distress/sale of other movables (even outside jurisdiction with endorsement). (3) No suit lies for good-faith acts under this section.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 142. Injunction pending inquiry
content: (1) If urgent action needed to prevent serious public danger/injury, Magistrate may issue injunction pending determination. (2) On default, Magistrate may take measures to prevent danger/injury. (3) No suit for good-faith actions under this section.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 143. Magistrate may prohibit repetition or continuance of public nuisance
content: A DM, SDM, or other empowered Executive Magistrate may prohibit repetition/continuance of a public nuisance as defined in IPC or special/local law.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 144. Power to issue order in urgent cases of nuisance or apprehended danger
content: (1) A DM, SDM, or specially empowered Executive Magistrate, if immediate prevention/speedy remedy desirable, may by written order (stating facts) direct any person to abstain from certain acts or regulate property use to prevent obstruction, annoyance, danger to life/health/safety, disturbance of public tranquillity, riot or affray. (2) May be passed ex parte in emergencies or if notice service impracticable. (3) May be directed to individuals, residents of area, or public frequenting place/area. (4) Valid for max 2 months unless extended by State Government for up to 6 months. (5) Magistrate may rescind/alter own order or that of subordinate/predecessor on own motion or application. (6) State Government may rescind/alter its orders. (7) Applicant must be given early hearing opportunity; rejections must be reasoned.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 144A. Power to prohibit carrying arms in procession or mass drill or mass training with arms
content: (1) DM may prohibit carrying arms in procession or organising/participating in mass drill/training with arms in public place to preserve peace/safety/order. (2) May be directed to specific persons or groups. (3) Valid for max 3 months. (4) State Government may extend up to 6 months. (5) State Government may delegate extension power to DMs. Explanation: 'arms' has meaning under section 153AA IPC.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 145. Procedure where dispute concerning land or water is likely to cause breach of peace
content: (1) If satisfied on police/information report of dispute likely to cause breach of peace over land/water within jurisdiction, Executive Magistrate shall order parties to attend and file written statements of possession claims. (2) 'Land or water' includes buildings, markets, fisheries, crops, produce, and rental/profits. (3) Copy of order served per summons procedure and posted near dispute site. (4) Without considering title merits, Magistrate hears parties, takes evidence, and decides possession as of order date; may treat recent forcible dispossession as possession. (5) Parties may show no dispute exists; if so, order is cancelled and proceedings stayed; otherwise, order under (1) is final. (6)(a) If one party is found in possession (or deemed under (4) proviso), declare their entitlement and forbid disturbance until eviction by law; may restore possession if wrongfully dispossessed. (b) Order served/published as in (3). (7) On death of party, legal representatives are substituted; disputes over such status result in all claimants being made parties. (8) Magistrate may order custody or sale of perishable produce and dispose accordingly post-inquiry. (9) Magistrate may summon witnesses/documents. (10) Powers here are without prejudice to section 107 proceedings.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 146. Power to attach subject of dispute and to appoint receiver
content: (1) After making an order under section 145(1), if the Magistrate considers the case one of emergency, or finds none of the parties in possession, or cannot decide possession, he may attach the subject of dispute until a competent Court determines rights to possession. Attachment may be withdrawn if no longer likely to cause breach of peace. (2) On attachment, if no Civil Court receiver exists, the Magistrate may make arrangements for the property or appoint a receiver with powers as per the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908. If a Civil Court later appoints a receiver: (a) the Magistrate's receiver must hand over possession; (b) the Magistrate may make incidental or consequential orders.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 147. Dispute concerning right of use of land or water
content: (1) If satisfied from police report or information that a dispute likely to cause breach of peace exists on alleged right of user of land or water within jurisdiction, the Executive Magistrate shall order parties to attend and file written claims. 'Land or water' as per section 145(2). (2) Magistrate hears parties, takes evidence, and applies section 145 provisions as far as possible to decide if such right exists. (3) If such right exists, Magistrate may prohibit interference, including removing obstruction, provided such right has been exercised recently as per proviso conditions. (4) Proceedings under section 145 can be continued under this section if dispute is about right of user, and vice versa, with reasons recorded.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 148. Local inquiry
content: (1) For purposes of sections 145, 146, or 147, a DM or SDM may depute a subordinate Magistrate to conduct a local inquiry, give written instructions, and decide cost liability. (2) The deputed person's report is admissible as evidence. (3) Decision-making Magistrate may order costs, including witness expenses and pleader's fees, to be paid by any party, in whole or in part, as reasonable.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 149. Police to prevent cognizable offences
content: Every police officer may and shall, to the best of his ability, prevent the commission of any cognizable offence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 150. Information of design to commit cognizable offences
content: A police officer receiving information of a design to commit a cognizable offence shall inform his superior and any officer whose duty it is to prevent or take cognizance of such offence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 151. Arrest to prevent the commission of cognizable offences
content: (1) A police officer aware of a design to commit a cognizable offence may, without warrant or Magistrate's order, arrest the person if necessary to prevent the offence. (2) Such person cannot be detained over 24 hours unless further detention is authorised under law.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 152. Prevention of injury to public property
content: A police officer may act on his own to prevent injury to public property or to prevent removal or injury of public landmarks, buoys, or navigation marks in his view.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 153. Inspection of weights and measures
content: (1) An officer in charge may, without warrant, enter a place within station limits to inspect or search for false weights, measures, or weighing instruments if he has reason to believe such exist. (2) If found, he may seize them and must promptly inform a Magistrate with jurisdiction.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 154. Information in cognizable cases
content: (1) Information on a cognizable offence given orally to the OIC must be reduced to writing, read over, signed by informant, and entered in the prescribed book. Provisos: if victim is a woman for IPC sections 326A, 326B, 354 series, 376 series, 509, etc., statement must be recorded by a woman officer; special provisions for disabled victims include home recording, interpreter, videography, and prompt Magistrate recording. (2) Copy of recorded information given free to informant. (3) If OIC refuses to record, aggrieved may send written info to SP, who may investigate or direct a subordinate to do so. Chhattisgarh amendment adds sections 509A and 509B to list in proviso.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 155. Information as to non-cognizable cases and investigation of such cases
content: (1) On receiving info about a non-cognizable offence, OIC shall record summary and refer informant to Magistrate. (2) No investigation without Magistrate's order. (3) With order, officer may investigate with powers of OIC in cognizable case except arrest without warrant. (4) If case involves both cognizable and non-cognizable offences, treat as cognizable.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 156. Police officer’s power to investigate cognizable case
content: (1) OIC may investigate any cognizable case within his Court's jurisdiction without Magistrate's order. (2) Such actions cannot be challenged for lack of empowerment. (3) Magistrate under section 190 may order investigation. Maharashtra amendment: no Magistrate may order investigation against a public servant for acts in official duty without prior sanction; sanction decision must be made within 90 days or deemed granted.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 157. Procedure for investigation
content: (1) If OIC suspects offence he may investigate, report to Magistrate, visit spot, investigate facts, arrest offender if needed. Provisos: (a) may skip visiting personally in non-serious named-accused cases; (b) may not investigate if no sufficient ground. Further proviso for rape cases: victim's statement at her residence/place of choice, preferably by woman officer, in presence of relatives/social worker. (2) In such clause (a) or (b) cases, reasons to be recorded in report, and in (b) cases, inform informant of decision not to investigate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 158. Report how submitted
content: (1) Reports under section 157 shall be submitted through superior police officer if State directs. (2) Superior may give instructions, record them on the report, and forward promptly to Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 159. Power to hold investigation or preliminary inquiry
content: Magistrate receiving a section 157 report may direct investigation or conduct/assign a preliminary inquiry, or otherwise dispose of the case per this Code.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 160. Police officer’s power to require attendance of witnesses
content: (1) Police officer investigating may order attendance of persons within same or adjoining station limits acquainted with case facts; persons must attend. Proviso: men under 15 or over 65, women, or mentally/physically disabled cannot be required to attend outside their residence. (2) State may provide by rules for payment of reasonable expenses for such attendance away from residence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 161. Examination of witnesses by police
content: (1) Investigating police officer may orally examine persons acquainted with case facts. (2) Such persons must answer truly except to self-incriminating questions. (3) Officer may write statements, keeping separate records for each. Provisos: may record via audio-video means; women victims of specified sexual offences must be interviewed by woman officer. Chhattisgarh amendment expands offences list and mandates AV recording, identity protection.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 162. Statements to police not to be signed: Use of statements in evidence
content: (1) Statements to police during investigation not to be signed or used in evidence, except as provided; may be used to contradict prosecution witness per Indian Evidence Act section 145, with re-examination permitted to explain contradictions. (2) Does not apply to statements under Indian Evidence Act section 32(1) or section 27. Explanation: omissions may be contradictions if significant and relevant; determination is factual.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 163. No inducement to be offered
content: (1) No police/authority person shall offer inducement, threat, or promise barred by section 24 Indian Evidence Act. (2) No person shall be prevented from making voluntary statements; proviso preserves section 164(4) provisions.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 164. Recording of confessions and statements
content: (1) Any Magistrate may record confessions/statements before inquiry/trial; may use AV means in advocate's presence; police officers with magisterial powers cannot do so. (2) Before recording confession, Magistrate must caution that making it is voluntary and it may be used against the maker. (3) If unwilling to confess, Magistrate shall not authorise police custody. (4) Confessions must follow section 281 procedure, be signed by maker, with Magistrate certifying voluntariness and correctness in prescribed form. (5) Non-confession statements recorded per evidence rules; oath may be administered. (5A) In specified sexual offences, Magistrate must record victim statements promptly, with interpreter/special educator for disabled victims, and videography; such depositions count as examination-in-chief. (6) Magistrate must forward confession/statement to trial Magistrate. Chhattisgarh amendment adds offences to list; UT amendment allows empowering Executive Magistrate to act if no Judicial Magistrate is available.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 164A. Medical examination of the victim of rape
content: (1) In rape/attempt cases under investigation, examination must be by registered medical practitioner in Government/local authority hospital, or otherwise if unavailable, with woman's consent or her proxy's consent, within 24 hours of receiving information. (2) Practitioner must report: (i) victim and escort's names/addresses; (ii) age; (iii) DNA material description; (iv) injury marks; (v) general mental condition; (vi) other details. (3) Report must state reasons for conclusions. (4) Consent to examination must be recorded. (5) Report must note start/end times. (6) Practitioner sends report promptly to IO for forwarding to Magistrate under section 173. (7) No examination is lawful without consent. Explanation: 'examination' and 'registered medical practitioner' as in section 53. Chhattisgarh amendment replaces 'registered medical practitioner' with 'female registered medical practitioner' except in explanation.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 165. Search by police officer
content: (1) OIC or IO may search within station limits for an item necessary for investigation if it cannot be obtained without undue delay, after recording reasons and item description. (2) If practicable, officer conducts search personally. (3) If unable, he may order a subordinate in writing to search, specifying place and item. (4) Section 100 search provisions apply. (5) Copies of recorded reasons/orders must be sent at once to nearest Magistrate; owner/occupier may obtain a free copy from Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 166. When officer in charge of police station may require another to issue search-warrant
content: (1) An officer in charge of a police station or a police officer not below sub‑inspector rank making an investigation may require an officer in charge of another police station, in the same or a different district, to cause a search within that station's limits if the former could do so in his own station. (2) The requested officer proceeds per section 165 and forwards any item found to the requesting officer. (3) If delay in such requisition may result in evidence concealment/destruction, the officer may search in another station's limits as if within his own, per section 165. (4) Officer searching under (3) must notify the local station OIC, send copy of the list (if any) under section 100, and send to the nearest Magistrate copies of the section 165 records. (5) Owner/occupier of place searched may obtain free copy of any record sent to Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 166A. Letter of request to competent authority for investigation in a country or place outside India
content: (1) If during investigation it appears that evidence may be available abroad, the investigating officer or superior may apply to Court to issue a letter of request to a foreign Court/authority to examine persons acquainted with the facts, record their statements, require production of documents/things, and forward the evidence or authenticated copies to the issuing Court. (2) Transmission of the letter is as specified by the Central Government. (3) Statements/documents/things so obtained are deemed evidence collected during investigation under this Chapter.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 166B. Letter of request from a country or place outside India to a Court or an authority for investigation in India
content: (1) On receiving a letter of request from a foreign Court/authority for examination of persons or production of documents/things in relation to an offence under investigation abroad, the Central Government may: (i) forward it to the competent Magistrate to summon and record or cause production; or (ii) send it to police for investigation as if offence committed in India. (2) Evidence so taken/collected or authenticated copies/things are to be sent to the Central Government for transmission to the requesting foreign authority.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 167. Procedure when investigation cannot be completed in twenty-four hours
content: (1) If investigation cannot be completed in 24 hours and accusation/information appears well-founded, OIC or IO (min. sub‑inspector) must send case diary entries to the nearest Judicial Magistrate and forward accused. (2) Magistrate may authorise custody up to 15 days in total; if lacking trial jurisdiction, may forward to competent Magistrate. Proviso: (a) detention beyond 15 days (otherwise than police custody) allowed if adequate grounds exist, max 90 days for offences punishable with death/life/≥10 years, else 60 days; thereafter bail is mandatory on furnishing bond; (b) police custody detention requires in‑person production the first time and thereafter until police custody ends; judicial custody extension may be via in‑person or video linkage; (c) second‑class Magistrates need High Court empowerment for police custody orders. Explanation I: Accused remains detained after period expiry until bail furnished. Explanation II: Production proof includes signature on order or Magistrate‑certified order/video linkage record. Further proviso: Women under 18 to be kept in remand home or recognised social institution. (2A) Where no Judicial Magistrate is available, accused and diary may be sent to empowered Executive Magistrate, who may authorise up to 7 days’ custody; before expiry, must send records to a Judicial Magistrate. (3) Magistrate authorising police custody must record reasons. (4) Non‑CJM Magistrates must send custody orders to CJM. (5) For summons‑cases, if investigation not done in 6 months, Magistrate shall stop further investigation unless special reasons given. (6) Sessions Judge may vacate stop order and direct further investigation. State amendments in several states modify maximum periods, production requirements, and custody rules.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 168. Report of investigation by subordinate police officer
content: A subordinate police officer who investigates under this Chapter shall report the result to the officer in charge of the police station.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 169. Release of accused when evidence deficient
content: If, during investigation, the OIC finds insufficient evidence or grounds to justify forwarding the accused to a Magistrate, he shall release the accused on bond (with/without sureties) to appear when required before a Magistrate empowered to take cognizance and try or commit the accused.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 170. Cases to be sent to Magistrate, when evidence is sufficient
content: (1) If, on investigation, there is sufficient evidence or reasonable grounds, OIC shall: (i) forward accused in custody to competent Magistrate, or (ii) if bailable and bail furnished, take security for appearance. (2) OIC shall send necessary articles to Magistrate and require complainant and required witnesses to execute bonds to appear and prosecute or give evidence. (3) Bonds mentioning CJM include any Court to which CJM refers the case, with reasonable notice. (4) Officer shall give copy of bond to an executing party and send original with report to Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 171. Complainant and witnesses not to be required to accompany police officer and not to be subjected to restraint
content: Complainants/witnesses en route to Court cannot be compelled to accompany police, restrained unnecessarily, inconvenienced, or required to furnish security beyond own bond. Proviso: refusal to attend or execute bond per section 170 allows OIC to forward them in custody to Magistrate, who may detain until bond executed or hearing completed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 172. Diary of proceedings in investigation
content: (1) IO shall maintain daily diary including times of receiving information, starting/ending investigation, places visited, and facts ascertained. (1A) Witness statements under section 161 to be inserted. (1B) Diary to be a paginated volume. (2) Criminal Courts may call for diaries for aid but not as evidence. (3) Accused/agents cannot inspect diaries unless used by IO to refresh memory or to contradict IO, in which case Evidence Act rules apply.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 173. Report of police officer on completion of investigation
content: (1) Investigation to be completed without unnecessary delay. (1A) Offences under sections 376 series — investigation to be completed within 2 months from date of FIR. (2)(i) On completion, OIC to forward report to Magistrate in prescribed form stating: (a) names of parties; (b) nature of information; (c) names of persons acquainted with case facts; (d) offences committed and by whom; (e) whether accused arrested; (f) bail details; (g) if forwarded in custody under section 170; (h) medical report attached in certain sexual offences. (ii) Action taken to be communicated to informant. (3) In cases with superior officer under section 158, report to be submitted through him if directed, and he may order further investigation. (4) If accused released on bond, Magistrate to make suitable order. (5) In section 170 cases, police shall also send all relied-upon documents and section 161 statements of proposed witnesses. (6) IO may request withholding irrelevant or sensitive portions from accused's copies, with reasons, for Magistrate's decision. (7) IO may give copies of such documents to accused. (8) Further investigation after report allowed; any further evidence found to be reported similarly. State amendments impose expedited investigation timelines for certain offences.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 174. Police to enquire and report on suicide, etc.
content: (1) When the officer in charge of a police station or another police officer specially empowered by the State Government receives information that a person has committed suicide, or has been killed by another, by an animal, by machinery, or by accident, or has died under circumstances raising reasonable suspicion that another person committed an offence, he shall immediately inform the nearest Executive Magistrate empowered to hold inquests and proceed to the place of the body. There, in the presence of two or more respectable inhabitants, he shall make an investigation and draw up a report on the apparent cause of death, describing wounds, fractures, bruises, or other injury marks and the manner or weapon by which inflicted. (2) The report shall be signed by such police officer and those concurring, and forwarded to the District or Sub-divisional Magistrate. (3) When the case (i) involves suicide by a woman within seven years of marriage; (ii) relates to her death raising suspicion of an offence; (iii) relatives request investigation; (iv) doubts exist regarding cause of death; or (v) the police officer deems it expedient, the body shall be forwarded for medical examination to a Civil Surgeon or qualified medical person, provided conditions permit. (4) Magistrates empowered to hold inquests include District Magistrate, Sub-divisional Magistrate, and specially empowered Executive Magistrates.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 175. Power to summon persons
content: (1) Police officers proceeding under Section 174 may summon two or more respectable inhabitants and others acquainted with the case facts to attend and answer all questions except those exposing them to criminal charge or penalty. (2) Persons summoned shall not be required to attend a Magistrate's court if the facts do not disclose a cognizable offence as per Section 170.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 176. Inquiry by Magistrate into cause of death
content: (1) In cases under Section 174(3)(i) or (ii), the nearest Magistrate empowered to hold inquests shall hold an inquiry into cause of death; otherwise, such Magistrate may hold such inquiry in addition to police investigation. (1A) If death or disappearance occurs or rape is alleged while under police or authorized custody, inquiry must be held by the Judicial or Metropolitan Magistrate within whose jurisdiction offence occurred. (2) Evidence shall be recorded as per circumstances. (3) Magistrates may order disinterment and examination of buried bodies to discover causes of death. (4) Relatives of deceased known by name and address shall be informed and allowed to attend inquiries. (5) Within 24 hours of death, the magistrate or designated officer shall forward the body for medical examination to the Civil Surgeon or qualified medical person unless impracticable. Explanation: 'Relative' includes parents, children, siblings, and spouse.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 177. Ordinary place of inquiry and trial
content: Every offence shall ordinarily be enquired into and tried by a Court within whose local jurisdiction it was committed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 178. Place of inquiry or trial
content: Where it is uncertain which of several local areas an offence was committed, or where offences occur partially in different local areas, including continuations over multiple areas or multiple acts, trial may be held in any Court competent for any of those areas.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 179. Offence triable where act done or consequence ensues
content: When the offence arises from an act and consequent events, trial may be held in the Court of the jurisdiction where the act was done or the consequence occurred.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 180. Place of trial where act is offence by relation to other offence
content: If an act is an offence by relation to another offence, trial may be held in the Court of jurisdiction where either offence was committed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 181. Place of trial for certain offences
content: (1) Offences such as being a thug, murder by a thug, dacoity or gang membership, and escaping custody may be tried where committed or where accused is found. (2) Kidnapping or abduction trials may be held where the person was kidnapped, conveyed, concealed, or detained. (3) Theft, extortion, or robbery trials may be held where offence occurred or stolen property was possessed by perpetrators or holders knowingly of stolen goods. (4) Criminal misappropriation or breach of trust trials may be held where offence or part thereof occurred or property was received or required to be accounted. (5) Possession of stolen property trials may be held where offence or possession by recipients of stolen goods occurred.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 182. Offences committed by letters, etc.
content: (1) Cheating by letters or telecom messages may be tried where such letters/messages were sent or received. Delivery-based cheating offences tried where property delivered or received. (2) Offences under IPC Sections 494 or 495 tried where committed or where offender last resided with spouse from first marriage or where wife from first marriage established permanent residence post-offence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 183. Offence committed on journey or voyage
content: Offences committed during journey or voyage may be tried where the person or thing involved passed during such traveling.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 184. Place of trial for offences triable together
content: Offences triable together as per Sections 219, 220, 221 (same person) or Section 223 (multiple persons) may be tried in any competent Court for these offences.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 185. Power to order cases to be tried in different sessions divisions
content: State Government may direct trials of cases in districts to occur in any sessions division, consistent with existing High Court or Supreme Court directions.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 186. High Court decision on doubt in place of trial
content: If multiple Courts take cognizance of the same offence, the High Court of relevant jurisdiction decides which Court shall try, discontinuing others.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 187. Power to issue summons or warrant beyond local jurisdiction
content: A Magistrate may try offences committed outside jurisdiction, compelling accused to appear or be sent to a competent Magistrate, with bail options when applicable. If multiple Magistrates competent, the High Court decides proper venue.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 188. Offence committed outside India
content: Offences committed outside India by Indian citizens (on sea or abroad) or persons on Indian ships or aircraft are triable in India where accused is found, subject to Central Government sanction.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 189. Receipt of evidence relating to offences committed outside India
content: The Court may admit depositions or exhibits from foreign jurisdictions as evidence, as if obtained via judicial commission.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 190. Cognizance of offences by Magistrates
content: (1) Magistrates may take cognizance on complaint, police report, or information. (2) Chief Judicial Magistrate may empower second class Magistrates for cognizance of offences. Amendments may require prior sanction to prosecute public servants for official acts.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 191. Transfer on application of the accused
content: When a Magistrate takes cognizance of an offence under clause (c) of section 190(1), the accused shall, before any evidence is taken, be informed of entitlement to have the case inquired into or tried by another Magistrate. If the accused objects, the case shall be transferred to another Magistrate as specified by the Chief Judicial Magistrate. State amendment (Assam): Reference to 'Chief Judicial Magistrate' in relation to offences taken cognizance of by an Executive Magistrate construed as reference to the District Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 192. Making over of cases to Magistrates
content: (1) Any Chief Judicial Magistrate may, after taking cognizance of an offence, make over the case for inquiry or trial to any competent subordinate Magistrate. (2) A first-class Magistrate empowered by the Chief Judicial Magistrate may, after taking cognizance, make over the case to another competent Magistrate specified by general or special order. State amendment (Assam): In subsection (1), insert 'District Magistrate' after 'Any'; substitute subsection (2) to empower Sub‑divisional Magistrates or first‑class Magistrates authorised by the District Magistrate or Chief Judicial Magistrate to transfer cases accordingly.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 193. Cognizance of offences by Courts of Session
content: Except as otherwise provided, no Court of Session shall take cognizance of any offence as a Court of original jurisdiction unless committed to it by a Magistrate under this Code.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 194. Additional and Assistant Sessions Judges to try cases made over to them
content: An Additional or Assistant Sessions Judge shall try such cases as the Sessions Judge may assign via general or special order, or as the High Court may direct.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 195. Prosecution for contempt of lawful authority of public servants, for offences against public justice and offences relating to documents given in evidence
content: (1) No Court shall take cognizance: (a) of IPC ss.172‑188 or their abetment/attempt/conspiracy, except on written complaint of concerned public servant or superior; (b) of IPC ss.193‑196, 199, 200, 205‑211, 228 in relation to court proceedings; or offences under s.463 or 471, 475, 476 IPC regarding documents in evidence; or related conspiracy/attempt/abetment, except on written complaint of that Court or authorised officer, or a superior Court. (2) Public servant complaints under 195(1)(a) may be withdrawn by administrative superior before trial concludes. (3) 'Court' includes Civil, Revenue, Criminal Courts and declared tribunals. (4) Defines subordination of Courts for this section. Provisos clarify hierarchy. Section 195A allows a witness/other person to file a complaint under IPC s.195A.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 196. Prosecution for offences against the State and for criminal conspiracy to commit such offence
content: (1) No Court shall take cognizance of offences under IPC Chapter VI, s.153A, s.295A, s.505(1), or related conspiracies/abetment, without prior sanction of Central or State Government. (1A) No Court shall take cognizance of offences under s.153B or s.505(2)/(3) IPC or related conspiracies without prior sanction of Central or State Government or District Magistrate. (2) Criminal conspiracy under s.120B IPC (other than those punishable with death, life, or ≥2 years' RI) requires State Government/District Magistrate's written consent unless s.195 applies. (3) Authorities may order preliminary investigation before sanction/consent. State amendments may vary authorities or procedures.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 197. Prosecution of Judges and public servants
content: (1) When a Judge, Magistrate, or public servant (not removable without government sanction) is accused of offences alleged while acting/purporting to act in official duty, no Court shall take cognizance without prior sanction—Central Government for Union affairs, State for State affairs, with provisos for Art.356 proclamations. Sanction not required for specified IPC sexual offences. (2) Armed Forces members need Central Government sanction. (3) State Government may extend (2) to forces maintaining public order. (3A‑3B) Special provisions during Art.356 periods. (4) Government may determine prosecutor and trial court. State amendments (Tripura, Assam) broaden 'in connection with official duty', add certification/stay and appeal procedures for certain accused public servants.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 198. Prosecution for offences against marriage
content: (1) No Court shall take cognizance of IPC Ch.XX offences except upon complaint by aggrieved person, with provisos allowing complaints by authorised others in cases of minority, incapacity, certain customs, or armed service absence. Clause (c) allows certain relatives to complain for IPC s.494/s.495 where wife is aggrieved. (2) Only husband deemed aggrieved for IPC s.497/s.498, with proviso for caretaker complaint in husband's absence. (3) Guardian notice required before leave to complain on behalf of minor/lunatic if guardian exists. (4‑5) Authorisation by armed service husbands detailed; presumed genuine unless proven otherwise. (6) No cognizance of marital rape of wife <18 years if >1 year after offence. (7) Applies to abetment/attempt as well. 198A: For IPC s.498A, complaint may be by aggrieved woman or specified relatives/police report. 198B: For IPC s.376B in marital relationship, cognizance on wife's complaint with prima facie satisfaction.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 199. Prosecution for defamation
content: (1) No Court shall take cognizance of IPC Ch.XXI offences except on complaint by aggrieved person, with proviso for authorised complaints in cases of minority, incapacity, or certain customs. (2) For defamation of specified constitutional/public functionaries in respect of conduct in public functions, Court of Session may take cognizance without commitment on written complaint by Public Prosecutor. (3) Such complaints must state facts and particulars sufficient for notice. (4) Public Prosecutor needs prior sanction: State for State officials/Governors/State Ministers; Central for others. (5) Complaint under (2) must be within 6 months of offence. (6) Does not affect right of aggrieved to complain directly to Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 200. Examination of complainant
content: Magistrate taking cognizance on complaint shall examine complainant and witnesses on oath, record substance in writing signed by all and the Magistrate. Proviso: need not examine if complaint by public servant/Court or if case is made over under s.192. If examined before transfer under s.192, no re-examination needed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 201. Procedure by Magistrate not competent to take cognizance
content: If complaint is made to a Magistrate without jurisdiction, he shall: (a) if in writing, return it for presentation to proper Court with endorsement; (b) if oral, direct complainant to proper Court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 202. Postponement of issue of process
content: (1) Magistrate receiving complaint may, and shall if accused resides beyond jurisdiction, postpone process issuance to inquire himself or direct investigation to decide if sufficient ground exists. Proviso: No investigation direction if offence triable exclusively by Sessions or if complainant/witnesses not examined on oath for non‑court complaints. (2) In such inquiry, Magistrate may take witness evidence; if offence triable exclusively by Sessions, complainant must produce all witnesses for oath examination. (3) Non‑police investigators have police station officer powers except arrest without warrant.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 203. Dismissal of complaint
content: If, after considering statements on oath and result of inquiry/investigation under s.202, Magistrate believes no sufficient ground exists, he shall dismiss the complaint, recording reasons.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 204. Issue of process
content: (1) If sufficient grounds exist, Magistrate shall issue summons for summons‑cases or may issue warrant/summons for warrant‑cases, to appear before him or other competent Magistrate. (2) No process until prosecution witness list filed. (3) For written complaints, process accompanied by complaint copy. (4) No process until fees paid where applicable; default may lead to dismissal. (5) Does not affect s.87.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 205. Magistrate may dispense with personal attendance of accused
content: (1) Magistrate issuing summons may permit accused to appear via pleader. (2) Magistrate may later require personal attendance and enforce it.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 206. Special summons in cases of petty offence
content: (1) For petty offences fit for summary disposal under s.260/261, Magistrate shall issue summons allowing accused to appear personally or by pleader, or plead guilty and remit fine/pleader authorisation with fine. Fine not to exceed Rs.1,000. (2) 'Petty offence' means punishable only with fine ≤Rs.1,000, excluding specified laws. (3) State Government may empower exercise of these powers for certain compoundable/offences with ≤3 months' imprisonment or fine/both where fine alone meets justice ends.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 207. Supply to the accused of copy of police report and other documents
content: In proceedings on police report, Magistrate shall furnish free copies to accused of: (i) police report; (ii) FIR; (iii) s.161(3) statements of proposed witnesses (with possible exclusions per s.173(6)); (iv) s.164 confessions/statements; (v) other forwarded documents. Magistrate may withhold parts of statements or voluminous documents with inspection allowed instead.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 208. Supply of copies of statements and documents to accused in other cases triable by Court of Session
content: In non‑police report cases triable exclusively by Sessions, Magistrate shall furnish free copies of: (i) s.200/202 statements; (ii) s.161/164 statements/confessions; (iii) relied‑on documents. Voluminous documents may be allowed for inspection only.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 209. Commitment of case to Court of Session when offence is triable exclusively by it
content: When offence triable exclusively by Sessions and accused appears, Magistrate shall comply with s.207/208, commit to Sessions, and remand accused as per bail/remand provisions until commitment. Magistrate shall send record, documents, articles, and notify Public Prosecutor. State amendment (Gujarat) substitutes clause (a) accordingly.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 210. Procedure when complaint case and police investigation exist for same offence
content: (1) If during complaint case inquiry/trial, police investigation is ongoing into same offence, Magistrate shall stay and call for police report. (2) If report under s.173 results in cognizance against accused in complaint case, both cases tried together as police report cases. (3) If police report unrelated or no cognizance taken, Magistrate resumes stayed case per Code.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 211. Contents of charge
content: (1) Charge shall state the offence. (2) If offence has specific legal name, use that name. (3) If not, state definition sufficient to inform accused. (4) Mention law/section allegedly violated. (5) Charge implies all legal conditions constituting offence are met. (6) Written in Court language. (7) For previous convictions affecting punishment, state fact/date/place; may be added before sentencing. Illustrations provided.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 212. Particulars as to time, place and person
content: (1) Charge must state time/place, person or thing related to offence to sufficiently inform accused. (2) For criminal breach of trust/misappropriation, gross sum or description with date range suffices; period cannot exceed one year.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 213. When manner of committing offence must be stated
content: If particulars in ss.211‑212 insufficient, charge must include manner of offence commission adequate to inform accused. Illustrations show when detail is required or not (e.g., theft need not detail method; cheating must).

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 214. Words in charge taken in sense of law under which offence is punishable
content: Words describing offences in a charge are deemed to carry the meaning given by the law creating the offence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 215. Effect of errors
content: No error in stating the offence or particulars in the charge, and no omission to state them, shall be regarded as material unless the accused was in fact misled and a failure of justice occurred. Illustrations: (a) omission of 'fraudulently' in a counterfeit coin charge is immaterial if no misleading occurred; (b) omission or incorrect statement of cheating manner is immaterial if accused defended without prejudice; (c) omission is material if accused could not know which transaction was meant and offered no defence; (d) wrong name/date of murder victim immaterial if only one case existed and accused knew facts; (e) error material if accused was tried for a different murder than charged and misled.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 216. Court may alter charge
content: (1) Court may alter/add to any charge before judgment. (2) Alteration/addition must be read and explained to accused. (3) If no prejudice is likely, Court may proceed immediately as if altered/added charge was original. (4) If prejudice is likely, Court may order new trial or adjourn. (5) If altered/added charge needs previous sanction, trial must wait for sanction unless already obtained for same facts.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 217. Recall of witnesses when charge altered
content: When a charge is altered/added after trial start, both prosecution and accused may recall/re‑summon and examine witnesses with reference to the change, unless Court records reasons to prevent vexation/delay/defeating justice; may also call further material witnesses.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 218. Separate charges for distinct offences
content: (1) Each distinct offence must be separately charged and tried separately, unless accused applies in writing for joint trial and Magistrate thinks no prejudice will occur. (2) This does not affect ss.219, 220, 221, 223. Illustration: theft and grievous hurt on different occasions must be separately charged/tried.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 219. Three offences of same kind within year may be charged together
content: (1) Accused of more than one offence of the same kind within 12 months may be charged/tried together for up to three offences. (2) Offences are same kind if punishable with same punishment under same IPC/special/local law section; includes certain deemed same kind cases, e.g., theft under s.379 deemed same as theft in dwelling s.380, or attempts.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 220. Trial for more than one offence
content: (1) Multiple offences in same transaction may be charged/tried together. (2) Criminal breach of trust/dishonest misappropriation with related falsification of accounts may be tried together. (3) Acts constituting offences under multiple definitions may be charged/tried for each. (4) Acts that individually are offences but together form another offence may be charged/tried for combined and individual offences. (5) Section 71 IPC unaffected. Illustrations given for each subsection (a–m).

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 221. Where it is doubtful what offence has been committed
content: (1) If doubtful which offence facts constitute, accused may be charged with all/any, or alternatively with one; tried together. (2) If charged with one offence but evidence shows another offence under (1), may be convicted of that though not charged. Illustrations: theft/receiving/criminal breach of trust/cheating; contradictory false evidence statements.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 222. When offence proved included in offence charged
content: (1) If charged offence has several particulars constituting a minor offence and only those are proved, accused may be convicted of minor offence. (2) Charged offence reduced by facts to a minor offence allows conviction for minor. (3) Attempt to commit charged offence may be convicted though not charged. (4) No conviction if conditions for minor offence proceedings unmet. Illustrations: breach of trust as carrier reduces to general breach of trust; grievous hurt reduced to hurt on provocation.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 223. What persons may be charged jointly
content: Persons may be jointly charged/tried if: (a) same offence in same transaction; (b) offence with its abetment/attempt; (c) more than one offence of same kind committed jointly within 12 months; (d) different offences in same transaction; (e) offence including theft/extortion/cheating/misappropriation with receiving/retaining/disposal/abetment/attempt thereof; (f) offences under IPC ss.411, 414 relating to same property; (g) offences under IPC Ch.XII on same counterfeit coin or related abetment/attempt. Proviso allows joint trial of separate offences on joint written request and Court satisfaction.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 224. Withdrawal of remaining charges on conviction on one of several charges
content: If convicted on one/more charges in a multi‑count charge, prosecution may, with Court consent, withdraw remaining charges; Court may also stay them; withdrawal acts as acquittal unless conviction set aside, in which case trial may proceed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 225. Trial to be conducted by Public Prosecutor
content: In every Court of Session trial, prosecution shall be conducted by a Public Prosecutor.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 226. Opening case for prosecution
content: At commencement of Sessions trial under s.209 commitment, prosecutor opens case by describing charge and evidence to prove guilt.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 227. Discharge
content: If, after considering case record/documents and hearing both sides, Judge considers no sufficient ground to proceed, he shall discharge accused with recorded reasons.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 228. Framing of charge
content: (1) If Judge sees ground for presuming offence: (a) if not exclusively triable by Sessions, frame charge and transfer to CJM or other JMFC with direction to appear, who shall try per police‑report warrant‑case procedure; (b) if exclusively triable by Court, frame written charge. (2) Charge read and explained to accused, who is asked to plead. State amendments (Chhattisgarh, Karnataka, West Bengal) adjust procedure and language for transfers and video linkage.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 229. Conviction on plea of guilty
content: If accused pleads guilty, Judge shall record plea and may convict on it.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 230. Date for prosecution evidence
content: If accused refuses/does not plead, or not convicted under s.229, Judge fixes date for prosecution witnesses and may issue process for attendance or document/thing production.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 231. Evidence for prosecution
content: (1) On fixed date, Judge takes prosecution evidence. (2) Judge may defer cross‑examination or recall witnesses for further cross‑examination.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 232. Acquittal
content: If, after prosecution evidence, examining accused and hearing both sides, Judge finds no evidence of offence, he shall record order of acquittal.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 233. Entering upon defence
content: (1) If not acquitted under s.232, accused called to present defence evidence. (2) Written statements filed with record. (3) Defence process for witnesses/documents to be issued unless for vexation/delay/defeating justice; reasons to be recorded if refused.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 234. Arguments
content: After defence evidence, prosecutor sums up and accused/pleader replies; prosecution may reply on law points raised by defence with Judge's permission.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 235. Judgment of acquittal or conviction
content: (1) After arguments and law points, Judge gives judgment. (2) If convicted, Judge hears accused on sentence before passing sentence, unless proceeding under s.360.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 236. Previous conviction
content: If previous conviction is charged under s.211(7) and not admitted, Judge, after convicting under s.229 or s.235, takes evidence and records finding. Proviso: previous conviction not read/pleaded/referred to unless and until convicted under s.229 or s.235.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 237. Procedure in cases instituted under section 199(2)
content: (1) Court of Session trying offence under s.199(2) uses warrant‑case procedure for non‑police report cases before Magistrates; alleged victim to be prosecution witness unless otherwise directed; trial in camera if either party desires or Court thinks fit. (3) If acquits/discharges and finds no reasonable cause for accusation, may direct accuser (except President, VP, Governor, Administrator) to show cause for compensation. (4) If satisfied, may order up to Rs.1,000 compensation. (5) Compensation recovered as Magistrate's fine. (6) Such order does not exempt from other liabilities; (7) appeal lies to High Court; (8) payment delayed until appeal time expires/appeal decided.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 238. Compliance with section 207
content: In warrant‑case on police report, Magistrate must ensure compliance with s.207 at trial start.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 239. When accused shall be discharged
content: If, after considering police report, s.173 documents, examining accused if needed, hearing both sides, Magistrate finds charge groundless, he shall discharge with recorded reasons.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 240. Framing of charge
content: (1) If, after consideration/examination/hearing, Magistrate presumes accused committed offence triable and punishable by him, he shall frame written charge. (2) Charge then read and explained; accused asked to plead. State amendment (Chhattisgarh) allows presence via video with pleader.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 241. Conviction on plea of guilty
content: If accused pleads guilty, Magistrate records plea and may convict.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 242. Evidence for prosecution
content: (1) If accused refuses/does not plead, claims trial, or not convicted under s.241, Magistrate fixes witness examination date; must supply accused in advance witness statements recorded by police. (2) Magistrate may summon witnesses/documents. (3) On set date, hears prosecution evidence; may defer/recall witnesses for cross‑examination.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 243. Evidence for defence
content: (1) Accused then called to present defence evidence; written statements filed with record. (2) Defence may seek process for witnesses/documents unless application is for vexation/delay/defeating justice—reasons to be recorded; proviso limits compulsion for witnesses already cross‑examined unless necessary for justice. (3) Magistrate may require deposit of reasonable witness expenses.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 244. Evidence for prosecution
content: (1) In warrant‑cases not from police report, when accused appears, Magistrate hears prosecution and takes supporting evidence. (2) Magistrate may summon witnesses/documents.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 245. When accused shall be discharged
content: (1) After all s.244 evidence, if no case is made out which would warrant conviction unrebutted, Magistrate shall discharge with reasons. (2) May discharge earlier if charge is groundless, with reasons. State amendment (West Bengal) adds subsection (3): discharge if all s.244 evidence not produced within 4 years unless prosecution shows special cause and interest of justice.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 246. Procedure where accused is not discharged
content: (1) If after s.244 evidence or earlier Magistrate presumes accused committed offence triable/punishable by him, frame written charge. (2) Charge read/explained, accused asked to plead. (3) If guilty plea, record and may convict. (4) If not guilty, require accused to state at next hearing (or forthwith if ordered) which prosecution witnesses to cross‑examine; (5) such witnesses recalled, cross‑examined and re‑examined, then discharged; (6) remaining prosecution witnesses examined, cross‑examined, re‑examined, and discharged.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 247. Evidence for defence
content: Accused called to present defence evidence; s.243 provisions apply.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 248. Acquittal or conviction
content: (1) If charge framed and accused found not guilty, record acquittal. (2) If found guilty and not proceeding under s.325 or s.360, hear accused on sentence and pass sentence. (3) If previous conviction charged under s.211(7) and not admitted, Magistrate after conviction takes evidence and records finding; proviso limits when previous conviction can be referred to.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 249. Absence of complainant
