content: (1) State cannot remit/commute under ss.432,433 without Centre's consultation if offence: (a) investigated by DSPE/Central agency; (b) involved misappropriation/destruction/damage of Central Govt property; (c) committed by Central Govt servant in official duty. (2) Where offences include both Union and other matters with concurrent sentences, no State order effective unless Centre also orders remission/commutation for Union offences.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 436. In what cases bail to be taken
content: (1) Person not accused of non‑bailable offence, if under arrest/detained without warrant or appearing before court, and ready to give bail, must be released; proviso allows release on bond without sureties if indigent (presumed if bail not furnished within 1 week). Second proviso saves s.116(3)/s.446A. (2) If bail‑bond conditions breached, court may refuse bail on later appearance without prejudice to s.446 penalty recovery.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 436A. Maximum period for which an undertrial prisoner can be detained
content: If undertrial (non‑capital offence) has spent half of max imprisonment as detention during investigation/inquiry/trial, must be released on personal bond with/without sureties; court may order continued detention beyond half‑term or bail after hearing PP with reasons. In no case detention exceeds max imprisonment term. Explanation: exclude delay caused by accused in computing period.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 437. When bail may be taken in case of non-bailable offence
content: (1) For non-bailable offences, court/police may grant bail unless: (i) reasonable grounds to believe offence punishable with death or life imprisonment; (ii) cognizable offence with prior conviction for death/life/≥7 years, or prior 2+ convictions for cognizable offences punishable 3–7 years. Provisos: bail allowed if under 16, woman, sick/infirm; special reasons for (ii); witness identification need not bar bail if undertaking given; no bail for death/life/≥7 yrs without hearing PP. (2) If insufficient grounds for belief of guilt but sufficient for further inquiry, release on bail/own bond pending inquiry, subject to s.446A. (3) For offences punishable with ≥7 years or under IPC Ch.VI/XVI/XVII or related attempt/abetment/conspiracy, bail must include conditions: attend as required, not commit similar offence, not tamper/threaten, plus other necessary conditions. (4) Reasons/special reasons for bail to be recorded. (5) Bail may be revoked and custody ordered. (6) In Magistrate-triable non-bailable cases, if trial not concluded within 60 days from first evidence date, in-custody accused to be released on bail unless otherwise directed with reasons. (7) After trial but before judgment, if grounds to believe accused not guilty, release on bond without sureties.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 437A. Bail to require accused to appear before next appellate Court
content: (1) Before trial conclusion and appeal disposal, trial/appellate court to require accused to execute bail bonds with sureties to appear before higher court if notice issued re any appeal/petition; bonds valid 6 months. (2) Failure to appear forfeits bond; s.446 applies.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 438. Direction for grant of bail to person apprehending arrest
content: (1) Person anticipating arrest for non-bailable offence may apply to HC or Sessions for direction to be released on bail if arrested. (2) Direction may impose conditions: appear for interrogation when required; no inducement/threat/promise to witnesses; not leave India without permission; other s.437(3)-type conditions. (3) If arrested thereafter and ready to give bail, release; if Magistrate issues warrant, must be bailable in conformity. (4) Does not apply to cases under IPC s.376(3), 376AB, 376DA, 376DB. State amendments (WB/Orissa) add notice requirements before final orders in serious offences and timelines for disposal.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 439. Special powers of High Court or Court of Session regarding bail
content: (1) HC/Sessions may: (a) grant bail to accused in custody; for s.437(3) offences, impose necessary conditions; (b) set aside/modify Magistrate's bail conditions. Proviso: for offences triable only by Sessions or punishable with life, give PP notice unless not practicable. Further proviso: for IPC s.376(3), 376AB, 376DA, 376DB, notify PP within 15 days; (1A) informant/person authorised must be present at bail hearing in such cases. (2) HC/Sessions may order arrest/commit to custody of person already on bail. State amendment (Assam) inserts s.439A with restrictions on bail for enumerated serious offences except on listed grounds.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 440. Amount of bond and reduction thereof
content: (1) Bond amounts to be fixed considering case circumstances; not excessive. (2) HC/Sessions may order police/Magistrate bail amount reduced.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 441. Bond of accused and sureties
content: (1) Before release on bail/own bond, accused to execute bond for sum fixed, and for bail, one or more sufficient sureties to ensure attendance until directed otherwise. (2) Bond must include imposed conditions. (3) May also bind person to appear before appellate court(s) when called. (4) Court may verify surety sufficiency/fitness via affidavits or inquiry by itself/subordinate Magistrate. State amendment (AP) adds provision for fine in surety bond if surety fails to produce accused in serious offences.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 441A. Declaration by sureties
content: Surety must declare before court the number of persons he has stood surety for, including accused, with relevant particulars.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 442. Discharge from custody
content: (1) Once bond executed, accused released; if in jail, release order issued to jail OIC. (2) Does not require release if liable to be detained in other matters.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 443. Power to order sufficient bail when first taken is insufficient
content: If sureties accepted are insufficient or later become so, court may issue arrest warrant, require sufficient sureties, and if none given, commit to jail.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 444. Discharge of sureties
content: (1) Sureties may apply to Magistrate to discharge bond wholly/partially. (2) Magistrate issues arrest warrant for accused. (3) On appearance/surrender, bond discharged as per application; accused to find fresh sureties or be committed to jail. West Bengal amendment: adds ‘on showing sufficient cause’, allows inquiry into reasons before discharge, and modifies (2).

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 445. Deposit instead of recognizance
content: When bond required (except for good behaviour), court/officer may permit deposit of money or Govt promissory notes in lieu. West Bengal amendment removes 'with or without sureties' and substitutes 'permit' with 'direct'.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 446. Procedure when bond has been forfeited
content: (1) On proof of bond forfeiture, court records grounds and calls on bound person to pay penalty or show cause. Explanation: appearance/production conditions cover transfers to other courts. (2) If no cause/penalty unpaid, recover as fine; proviso: if unrecoverable, surety may be imprisoned in civil jail up to 6 months. (3) Court may remit part penalty for reasons. (4) Surety's estate discharged if he dies before forfeiture. (5) Copy of conviction judgment for breach of bond may be used as evidence against surety, with presumption unless rebutted.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 446A. Cancellation of bond and bail bond
content: If appearance bond forfeited for breach, both personal and surety bonds are cancelled; person cannot be released on own bond in that case unless fresh bonds given, unless sufficient cause for breach shown.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 447. Procedure in case of insolvency or death of surety or when a bond is forfeited
content: If surety becomes insolvent/dies or bond forfeited, court/Magistrate may order fresh securities; failure treated as default of original order.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 448. Bond required from minor
content: If person required to execute bond is minor, court/officer may accept bond from surety/sureties only.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 449. Appeal from orders under section 446
content: Orders under s.446 appealable: (i) by Magistrate—to Sessions; (ii) by Sessions Court—to higher appellate court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 450. Power to direct levy of amount due on certain recognizances
content: HC or Sessions may direct Magistrate to levy amount due on appearance/attendance bond for such courts.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 451. Order for custody and disposal of property pending trial
content: During inquiry/trial, court may order proper custody of property produced; if perishable or expedient, may order sale/disposal after recording necessary evidence. 'Property' includes property/documents produced or in court's custody or related to offence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 452. Order for disposal of property at conclusion of trial
content: (1) On conclusion, court may order disposal (destruction/confiscation/delivery/other) of property/documents produced or in custody or related to offence. (2) Delivery may be unconditional or on bond to restore if order modified/set aside. (3) Sessions may direct CJM to handle under ss.457–459. (4) Except for livestock/perishables/bond goods, execution delayed 2 months or pending appeal. (5) 'Property' includes converted/exchanged property and proceeds.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 453. Payment to innocent purchaser of money found on accused
content: If conviction for theft/receiving stolen property and an innocent purchaser bought stolen goods unknowingly, and money was found on accused, court may, on application and restitution of goods, order repayment up to purchase price from such money.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 454. Appeal against orders under section 452 or 453
content: (1) Aggrieved may appeal to appropriate appellate court. (2) Appellate court may stay order, modify/alter/annul, or make other just orders. (3) Same powers exercisable in appeal/confirmation/revision of related case.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 455. Destruction of libellous and other matter
content: (1) On IPC s.292,293,501,502 conviction, court may order destruction of offending copies in custody or with convict. (2) On IPC s.272–275 conviction, may order destruction of related food/drink/drug/medical preparation.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 456. Power to restore possession of immovable property
content: (1) On conviction for offence with criminal force/show or intimidation causing dispossession from immovable property, court may order restoration within 1 month of conviction. (2) Appellate/confirmation/revision court may also order restoration if trial court did not. (3) s.454 appeal provisions apply. (4) Does not prejudice civil property rights.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 457. Procedure by police upon seizure of property
content: (1) On police reporting seizure of property not produced in court, Magistrate may order its disposal/delivery to entitled person or, if unknown, order custody/production. (2) If entitled known, may order delivery with conditions; if unknown, detain and issue proclamation for claims within 6 months.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 458. Procedure where no claimant appears within six months
content: (1) If no claim in 6 months and possessor cannot show legal acquisition, Magistrate may order property to State Government for disposal/sale; proceeds per rules. (2) Order appealable to usual appellate court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 459. Power to sell perishable property
content: If entitled person unknown/absent and property perishable, or value < ₹500, or sale benefits owner, Magistrate may direct sale; apply ss.457–458 to proceeds.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 460. Irregularities which do not vitiate proceedings
content: If Magistrate without empowerment in good faith does listed acts (e.g., issue search warrant, order investigation, hold inquest, issue process for outside offender, take cognizance under s.190(1)(a)/(b), make over case, tender pardon, recall case, sell property under s.458/459), proceedings not set aside merely for lack of power.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 461. Irregularities which vitiate proceedings
content: If Magistrate without empowerment does listed acts (e.g., attach/sell under s.83, postal/telegraph search-warrant, demand security, make maintenance order, try offender, pass sentence under s.325 on another's record, decide appeal, call for/revise proceedings), proceedings are void.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 462. Proceedings in wrong place
content: Finding/sentence/order not set aside just for being in wrong jurisdiction unless failure of justice occurred.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 463. Non-compliance with provisions of section 164 or section 281
content: (1) If confession/statement under s.164/s.281 non-compliant, court may take evidence on non-compliance and, if satisfied no prejudice and statement genuine, admit it. (2) Applies also to appellate/reference/revisional courts.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 464. Effect of omission to frame, or absence of, or error in, charge
content: (1) No finding/sentence/order invalid merely for no charge or charge error/omission/misjoinder unless appellate/confirmation/revision court thinks failure of justice occurred. (2) If so, may order charge to be framed and trial recommenced after framing; or direct new trial with corrected charge. Proviso: if no valid charge possible on facts, quash conviction.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 465. Finding or sentence when reversible by reason of error, omission or irregularity
content: (1) No finding/sentence/order reversed/altered for error/omission/irregularity in proceedings/sanction unless, in court's opinion, failure of justice occurred. (2) In deciding, court to consider if objection could/should have been raised earlier.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 466. Defect or error not to make attachment unlawful
content: Attachment not unlawful nor officer trespasser merely for defect/want of form in related process.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 467. Definitions
content: 'Period of limitation' means period in s.468 for taking cognizance.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 468. Bar to taking cognizance after lapse of the period of limitation
content: (1) Except otherwise provided, no cognizance after limitation in (2). (2) Period: (a) 6 months—fine only offences; (b) 1 year—max imprisonment ≤1 year; (c) 3 years—imprisonment >1 year ≤3 years. (3) For offences tried together, limitation determined by most severe punishment offence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 469. Commencement of the period of limitation
content: (1) Limitation starts: (a) on offence date; (b) if offence not known to victim/police, on first day it becomes known; (c) if offender identity not known, on first day identity known to victim/police. (2) Exclude starting day in computation.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 470. Exclusion of time in certain cases
content: (1) In computing limitation, exclude time during which prosecution of same facts in another court was being pursued with due diligence and in good faith but failed for want of jurisdiction/like cause. (2) Exclude period during which prosecution stayed by injunction/order, including issue/withdrawal days. (3) Exclude period of required notice before prosecution or time to obtain prior consent/sanction, excluding dates of application and receipt. (4) Exclude time offender was (a) outside India or Union‑administered territory, or (b) absconding/concealing to avoid arrest.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 471. Exclusion of date on which Court is closed
content: If limitation expires when court closed, cognizance may be taken on reopening day. Explanation: Court deemed closed if shut during normal hours on that day.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 472. Continuing offence
content: For continuing offences, fresh limitation period starts at every moment the offence continues.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 473. Extension of period of limitation in certain cases
content: Court may take cognizance after expiry of limitation if delay properly explained or required in interests of justice.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 474. Trials before High Courts
content: When HC tries offence otherwise than under s.407 transfer, it follows Sessions Court trial procedure.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 475. Delivery to commanding officers of persons liable to be tried by Court-martial
content: (1) Central Govt may make rules with service Acts on when persons subject to military/naval/air force/other armed forces law are tried by civilian court or court-martial. Magistrates must have regard to rules and in proper cases deliver accused to commanding officer with offence details for court‑martial. Explanation: 'Unit' includes regiment, corps, ship, etc.; 'Court-martial' includes any similar tribunal. (2) Magistrate must assist CO's written request to apprehend such accused. (3) HC may direct prisoner in State jail be brought before court‑martial for trial/examination.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 476. Forms
content: Forms in Second Schedule, with variations, may be used; if used, deemed sufficient for purposes mentioned.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 477. Power of High Court to make rules
content: (1) HC may, with State Govt approval, make rules: (a) on petition‑writers in subordinate criminal courts; (b) licensing, conduct, fee scales; (c) penalties for contravention and authority/procedure; (d) other prescribed matters. (2) Rules to be published in Official Gazette.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 478. Power to alter functions allocated to Executive Magistrate in certain cases
content: If State Legislative Assembly so resolves, State Govt may, after HC consultation, notify that references in ss.108, 109, 110, 145, 147 to Executive Magistrate be read as Judicial Magistrate 1st class. UT amendment (A&N Islands, Dadra & Nagar Haveli, Lakshadweep) omits requirement of Assembly resolution.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 479. Case in which Judge or Magistrate is personally interested
content: Judge/Magistrate cannot try/commit case where he is party/personally interested, without permission of appellate court; nor hear appeal from his own judgment/order. Explanation: not deemed interested if involved only in public capacity, site visit, or related inquiry.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 480. Practising pleader not to sit as Magistrate in certain Courts
content: No pleader practising in a Magistrate's court shall sit as Magistrate in that court or within its jurisdiction.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 480A (Karnataka). Other powers of Magistrate
content: Inserted by Karnataka: Any Judicial/Executive Magistrate may attest, verify, authenticate documents brought before him for such purposes and affix seals as prescribed by law.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 481. Public servant concerned in sale not to purchase or bid for property
content: Public servant with duty in property sale under Code cannot purchase or bid for that property.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 482. Saving of inherent powers of High Court
content: Nothing limits HC's inherent power to pass orders to give effect to Code orders, prevent abuse of process, or secure ends of justice.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 483. Duty of High Court to exercise continuous superintendence over Courts of Judicial Magistrates
content: HC to continually supervise subordinate Judicial Magistrates to ensure expeditious and proper disposal of cases.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 484. Repeal and savings
content: (1) CrPC 1898 repealed. (2) Despite repeal: (a) pending matters disposed per old Code, as if new Code not in force, except pending Ch.XVIII inquiries to follow new Code; (b) notifications, orders, rules, etc. under old Code continue as if under new; (c) sanctions/consents under old Code where no proceeding commenced deemed under new Code; (d) old Code applies to prosecutions against Rulers under Art.363. (3) If period for application/proceeding under old Code expired before commencement, new provisions do not revive it.

title: Section 1 - Short title, extent and commencement
content: This Act may be called the Equal Remuneration Act, 1976. It extends to the whole of India and shall come into force on the date appointed by the Central Government through notification.

title: Section 2 - Definitions
content: Defines key terms such as 'employer', 'worker', 'remuneration', 'same work or work of similar nature', along with explanations related to payment and discrimination under the Act.

title: Section 3 - Act to have overriding effect
content: The provisions of this Act shall prevail over any other law, agreement, or contract inconsistent with its principles, whether made before or after this Act commences.

title: Section 4 - Duty of employer to pay equal remuneration
content: No employer shall pay any worker remuneration lower than that paid to the opposite sex worker for the same or similar work under similar conditions.

title: Section 5 - No discrimination in recruitment
content: Employers shall not discriminate between men and women in recruitment or conditions of service, except where the law prohibits employment of women in such jobs.

title: Section 6 - Advisory Committee
content: Establishment of an Advisory Committee to advise the Government on increasing employment opportunities for women and reviewing the Act’s implementation.

title: Section 7 - Authorities for hearing claims
content: The appropriate Government shall appoint authorities to hear complaints related to non-payment of equal wages and discrimination claims under the Act.

title: Section 8 - Duty of employers to maintain registers
content: Employers must maintain registers and documents relating to workers as specified by the Act.

title: Section 9 - Inspectors
content: Inspection authorities are empowered to check compliance, examine documents, and initiate action against violations of the Act.

title: Section 10 - Penalties
content: Penalties for employers who fail to comply include imprisonment up to one month, fines up to ten thousand rupees, or both, depending on the offence.

title: Section 11 - Offences by companies
content: Companies can be held liable for offences committed by their officers or employees related to violations of the Act.

title: Section 12 - Cognizance and trial of offences
content: Legal procedures for trials of offences under the Act, including jurisdiction and powers of the courts.

title: Section 13 -Power to make rules
content: Central Government is empowered to make rules for carrying out the provisions of the Act.

title: Section 14 -Power of Central Government to give directions
content: The Central Government may issue directions to ensure compliance with the Act.

title: Section 15 -Act not to apply in certain special cases
content: Certain special employments or professions may be exempted from the provisions of the Act.

title: Section 16 - Power to make declaration
content: Government’s power to make declarations regarding the application or exemption of the Act.

title: Section 17 - Power to remove difficulties
content: The Government may take necessary steps to remove difficulties in implementing the Act.

title: Section 18 - Repeal and saving
content: Repeal of previous laws inconsistent with this Act and saving of actions taken under them.

title: Preamble
content: WHEREAS it is expedient to provide a general Penal Code for India; It is enacted as follows:

title: Section 1 – Title and extent of operation of the Code
content: This Act shall be called the Indian Penal Code and shall extend to the whole of India.

title: Section 2 – Punishment of offences committed within India
content: Every person shall be liable to punishment under this Code and not otherwise for every act or omission contrary to its provisions of which they shall be guilty within India.

title: Section 3 – Punishment of offences committed beyond but which by law may be tried within India
content: Any person liable by any Indian law to be tried for an offence committed beyond India shall be dealt with according to this Code as if the act had been committed within India.

title: Section 4 – Extension of Code to extra-territorial offences
content: This Code applies also to offences committed by: (1) any citizen of India outside India; (2) any person on any ship or aircraft registered in India; (3) any person outside India committing an offence targeting a computer resource located in India. Offence includes acts outside India that would be punishable if committed in India. 'Computer resource' has the meaning in section 2(1)(k) of the IT Act, 2000. Illustration: A, a citizen of India, commits murder in Uganda. He can be tried in any place in India where he may be found.

title: Section 5 – Certain laws not to be affected by this Act
content: Nothing in this Act shall affect provisions of any Act for punishing mutiny and desertion in the armed forces of the Government of India or provisions of any special or local law.

title: Section 6 – Definitions subject to exceptions
content: Definitions, penal provisions, and illustrations in this Code are subject to the exceptions in the chapter on General Exceptions, though not repeated in each definition. Illustrations show that acts by a child under seven or acts bound by law are covered by such exceptions.

title: Section 7 – Sense of expression once explained
content: Every expression explained in any part of this Code is used consistently with that explanation throughout the Code.

title: Section 8 – Gender
content: The pronoun 'he' and its derivatives refer to any person, male or female.

title: Section 9 – Number
content: Singular includes plural and plural includes singular, unless context otherwise requires.

title: Section 10 – 'Man' and 'Woman'
content: 'Man' denotes a male human being of any age; 'Woman' denotes a female human being of any age.

title: Section 11 – 'Person'
content: Includes any company or association or body of persons, incorporated or not.

title: Section 12 – 'Public'
content: Includes any class of the public or community.

title: Section 14 – 'Servant of Government'
content: Denotes any officer or servant continued, appointed, or employed in India by or under the authority of Government.

title: Section 17 – 'Government'
content: Denotes the Central Government or the Government of a State.

title: Section 18 – 'India'
content: Means the territory of India excluding the State of Jammu and Kashmir.

title: Section 19 – 'Judge'
content: Includes persons officially designated as Judges and others empowered by law to give definitive judgments. Illustrations: A Collector under certain Acts; a Magistrate with sentencing power; a member of a panchayat with judicial authority; not a committing Magistrate without trial powers.

title: Section 20 – 'Court of Justice'
content: Denotes a Judge or body of Judges empowered to act judicially. Illustration: A panchayat with power to try suits is a Court of Justice.

title: Section 21 – 'Public servant'
content: Lists categories including commissioned officers in armed forces, Judges, court officers, jurymen, arbitrators, officers empowered to confine persons, officers to prevent offences, protect public health, manage public property, levy taxes, conduct elections, and others. Includes explanations: applies whether or not appointed by Government; covers de facto holders; defines 'election'. Rajasthan amendment adds exam supervisors under recognised public bodies.

title: Section 22 – 'Movable property'
content: Includes corporeal property of every description except land and things attached to the earth.

title: Section 23 – 'Wrongful gain' and 'Wrongful loss'
content: Wrongful gain: gain by unlawful means of property to which not legally entitled. Wrongful loss: loss by unlawful means of property to which legally entitled. Covers wrongful retention, deprivation, or exclusion from property.

title: Section 24 – 'Dishonestly'
content: Doing anything with intention to cause wrongful gain to one or wrongful loss to another.

title: Section 25 – 'Fraudulently'
content: Doing a thing with intent to defraud but not otherwise.

title: Section 26 – 'Reason to believe'
content: Having sufficient cause to believe a thing, but not otherwise.

title: Section 27 – 'Property in possession of wife, clerk or servant'
content: Property in possession of one's wife, clerk, or servant on account of that person is considered in that person's possession. Applies to temporary or occasional clerks or servants.

title: Section 28 – 'Counterfeit'
content: Causing one thing to resemble another intending or knowing it likely to deceive. Not necessary that imitation be exact; likelihood of deception implies intent.

title: Section 29 – 'Document'
content: Any matter expressed on any substance by letters, figures, or marks intended to be used as evidence. Includes writings, cheques, maps, instructions. Covers expressions explained by usage. Illustration: endorsement on a bill of exchange is a document with implied meaning by mercantile usage.

title: Section 29A – 'Electronic record'
content: Has the meaning assigned in section 2(1)(t) of the Information Technology Act, 2000.

title: Section 30 – 'Valuable security'
content: A document creating, transferring, restricting, extinguishing, or acknowledging legal rights or liabilities. Example: endorsement on bill of exchange transferring rights.

title: Section 31 – 'A will'
content: Any testamentary document.

title: Section 32 – Words referring to acts include illegal omissions
content: Words referring to acts done extend also to illegal omissions.

title: Section 33 – 'Act' and 'Omission'
content: 'Act' includes a series of acts; 'Omission' includes a series of omissions.

title: Section 34 – Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention
content: When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of their common intention, each is liable as if done by him alone.

title: Section 35 – When act is criminal by reason of knowledge or intention
content: If an act is criminal only by reason of knowledge or intention, each participant with such knowledge or intention is liable as if he alone did it with that knowledge or intention.

title: Section 36 – Effect caused partly by act and partly by omission
content: Where causing an effect by act or omission is an offence, causing it partly by act and partly by omission is the same offence. Illustration: starving and beating causing death constitutes murder.

title: Section 37 – Co-operation by doing one of several acts
content: When an offence is committed by several acts, anyone intentionally co‑operating by any such act commits that offence. Includes illustrations of joint poisoning, joint omission by jailors, and separate non‑collusive omissions causing death.

title: Section 38 – Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences
content: Several persons engaged in a criminal act may be guilty of different offences by means of that act. Illustration: one under provocation commits culpable homicide, another without provocation commits murder in same act.

title: Section 39 – 'Voluntarily'
content: Causing an effect voluntarily means causing it by means intended to cause it or known likely to cause it. Illustration: setting fire to house at night to rob, knowing death likely, is voluntary causing of death.

title: Section 40 – 'Offence'
content: Primarily denotes acts punishable by this Code, with specific extended meanings in certain Chapters and sections, including some special and local laws if punishable with six months' imprisonment or more.

title: Section 41 – 'Special law'
content: A law applicable to a particular subject.

title: Section 42 – 'Local law'
content: A law applicable only to a particular part of India.

title: Section 43 – 'Illegal' and 'Legally bound to do'
content: 'Illegal' includes offences, things prohibited by law, or giving rise to civil action. 'Legally bound to do' is whatever is illegal to omit.

title: Section 44 – 'Injury'
content: Any harm illegally caused to body, mind, reputation, or property.

title: Section 45 – 'Life'
content: Denotes life of a human being.

title: Section 46 – 'Death'
content: Denotes death of a human being.

title: Section 47 – 'Animal'
content: Any living creature other than a human being.

title: Section 48 – 'Vessel'
content: Anything made for conveyance by water of human beings or property.

title: Section 49 – 'Year' and 'Month'
content: Reckoned according to the British calendar.

title: Section 50 – 'Section'
content: Denotes a portion of a Chapter distinguished by prefixed numeral figures.

title: Section 51 – 'Oath'
content: Includes solemn affirmation, any declaration required or authorised by law to be made before a public servant or for use as proof.

title: Section 52 – 'Good faith'
content: Nothing is done or believed in good faith if done or believed without due care and attention.

title: Section 52A – 'Harbour'
content: Except in section 157 and section 130 when given by spouse, includes supplying shelter, food, drink, money, clothes, arms, ammunition, means of conveyance, or assisting to evade apprehension by any means.

title: Section 53 – Punishments
content: The punishments to which offenders are liable under this Code are: First—Death; Secondly—Imprisonment for life; Fourthly—Imprisonment, which may be rigorous (with hard labour) or simple; Fifthly—Forfeiture of property; Sixthly—Fine.

title: Section 53A – Construction of reference to transportation
content: (1) 'Transportation for life' in any law or instrument shall be read as 'imprisonment for life'. (2) Sentences of transportation for a term passed before the 1955 CrPC Amendment Act are to be treated as rigorous imprisonment for the same term. (3) References to transportation for a term or shorter term are omitted. (4) References to 'transportation' shall be construed as: (a) imprisonment for life, if meaning transportation for life; (b) omitted, if meaning shorter term.

title: Section 54 – Commutation of sentence of death
content: In every case of death sentence, the appropriate Government may, without the offender's consent, commute it to any other punishment in this Code.

title: Section 55 – Commutation of sentence of imprisonment for life
content: In every case of imprisonment for life, the appropriate Government may, without the offender's consent, commute it to imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

title: Section 55A – Definition of 'appropriate Government'
content: For sections 54 and 55: (a) if the sentence is death or for an offence under Union jurisdiction, 'appropriate Government' means Central Government; (b) in other cases under State jurisdiction, it means the State Government where the offender is sentenced.

title: Section 57 – Fractions of terms of punishment
content: In calculating fractions of terms of punishment, imprisonment for life is reckoned as equivalent to imprisonment for 20 years.

title: Section 60 – Sentence may be wholly or partly rigorous or simple
content: Where imprisonment of either description is awarded, the Court may direct it to be wholly rigorous, wholly simple, or partly rigorous and partly simple.

title: Section 63 – Amount of fine
content: Where no maximum is specified, the fine may be unlimited but shall not be excessive.

title: Section 64 – Sentence of imprisonment for non-payment of fine
content: In offences punishable with imprisonment and fine, or fine alone, the Court may direct that in default of payment the offender shall suffer imprisonment in excess of any other imprisonment awarded.

title: Section 65 – Limit to imprisonment for non-payment of fine
content: When an offence is punishable with imprisonment and fine, imprisonment in default shall not exceed one-fourth of the maximum imprisonment fixed for the offence.

title: Section 66 – Description of imprisonment for non-payment of fine
content: Imprisonment in default of fine may be of any description to which the offender could have been sentenced for the offence.

title: Section 67 – Imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when offence punishable with fine only
content: In such cases, imprisonment shall be simple and term shall not exceed: 2 months if fine not over Rs. 50; 4 months if not over Rs. 100; 6 months in any other case.

title: Section 68 – Imprisonment to terminate on payment of fine
content: Imprisonment in default of fine ends whenever the fine is paid or levied.

title: Section 69 – Termination of imprisonment on proportional payment of fine
content: If before expiry of default sentence a proportionate part of the fine is paid/levied, and imprisonment served is proportionate to fine unpaid, imprisonment terminates. Illustration: Various examples of payment timing and release.

title: Section 70 – Fine leviable within six years, or during imprisonment
content: Fine may be levied within six years of sentence or during imprisonment if longer; death of offender does not discharge property from liability.

title: Section 71 – Limit of punishment for offence made up of several offences
content: When an act is made up of parts each an offence, punishment is only for one unless law expressly provides otherwise. Includes cases where act falls under multiple definitions; punishment not to exceed that for any one offence. Illustrations show limits.

title: Section 72 – Punishment where guilty of one of several offences but doubtful which
content: Where judgment states doubt as to which offence, punishment shall be for the offence with lowest prescribed punishment if punishments differ.

title: Section 73 – Solitary confinement
content: Court may order solitary confinement for those sentenced to rigorous imprisonment, up to: 1 month if term ≤ 6 months; 2 months if >6 months and ≤1 year; 3 months if >1 year.

title: Section 74 – Limit of solitary confinement
content: Solitary confinement shall not exceed: 14 days at a time, intervals equal to confinement duration; where imprisonment > 3 months, 7 days in any month, with equal intervals.

title: Section 75 – Enhanced punishment for certain offences after previous conviction
content: A person previously convicted of certain offences under Chapters XII or XVII punishable with 3+ years imprisonment, and again guilty of such offences, is liable to life imprisonment or up to 10 years imprisonment.

title: Section 76 – Act done by person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law
content: Nothing is an offence if done by a person bound by law to do it or who in good faith, through mistake of fact (not law), believes himself bound. Illustrations: soldier firing on superior's order; officer arresting wrong person in good faith.

title: Section 77 – Act of Judge when acting judicially
content: Nothing is an offence if done by a Judge acting judicially under powers given by law or believed in good faith to be given.

title: Section 78 – Act done pursuant to judgment or order of Court
content: Nothing is an offence if done in pursuance of or warranted by judgment/order of a Court, while in force, even if Court lacked jurisdiction, if doer in good faith believed jurisdiction existed.

title: Section 79 – Act justified, or by mistake of fact believed justified, by law
content: Nothing is an offence if done by a person justified by law, or in good faith believes justified by law, due to mistake of fact not law. Illustration: apprehending a supposed murderer in good faith.

title: Section 80 – Accident in doing a lawful act
content: Nothing is an offence if done by accident or misfortune without criminal intent/knowledge in the doing of a lawful act by lawful means with proper care and caution. Illustration: hatchet head flies off accidentally.

title: Section 81 – Act likely to cause harm but done without criminal intent to prevent other harm
content: Nothing is an offence if done with knowledge of likely harm, without criminal intent, in good faith to prevent/avoid other imminent harm to person/property, judged by facts. Illustrations: altering ship's course to avoid greater danger; demolishing houses to stop fire.

title: Section 82 – Act of a child under seven years
content: Nothing is an offence if done by a child under seven years of age.

title: Section 83 – Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding
content: Nothing is an offence if done by child between seven and twelve lacking sufficient maturity to judge conduct's nature/consequences.

title: Section 84 – Act of person of unsound mind
content: Nothing is an offence if done by a person unable, due to unsound mind, to know nature of act or that it is wrong or contrary to law.

title: Section 85 – Act of person incapable of judgment by intoxication caused against his will
content: Nothing is an offence if at the time, due to intoxication not self‑induced, person incapable of knowing act's nature or wrongfulness.

title: Section 86 – Offence requiring particular intent/knowledge by intoxicated person
content: In offences requiring particular knowledge/intent, an intoxicated person is dealt with as if he had such knowledge, unless intoxication was caused without his knowledge/will.

title: Section 87 – Act not intended and not known to cause death/grievous hurt, done by consent
content: Acts not intended/known to cause death or grievous hurt are not offences if harm is to consenting person aged 18+, or with their risk consent. Illustration: friendly fencing causing injury.

title: Section 88 – Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit
content: Nothing intended for person's benefit, done in good faith with consent, is an offence though harm/death risk exists. Illustration: surgeon operates with consent knowing death risk for cure.

title: Section 89 – Act in good faith for benefit of child or insane person with guardian consent
content: Acts in good faith for benefit of under‑12 or insane person with guardian's consent are not offences, with provisos excluding intentional killing, grievous harm except for cure/prevention, or abetment thereof. Illustration: risky surgery on child for cure.

title: Section 90 – Consent given under fear or misconception
content: Consent is invalid if given under fear of injury/misconception of fact known to actor; if giver is insane/intoxicated; or if given by person under 12, unless context otherwise shows.

title: Section 91 – Exclusion of acts offences independently of harm caused
content: Exceptions in sections 87–89 don't apply to acts which are offences regardless of harm to consenting person. Illustration: causing miscarriage (unless to save life) is still an offence despite consent.

title: Section 92 – Act in good faith for benefit of person without consent
content: Acts in good faith for benefit of person without consent are not offences if consent impossible/unavailable in time, with provisos similar to section 89. Illustrations: emergency surgery; shooting tiger to save person at risk of also harming them; dropping child to safety risking harm.

title: Section 93 – Communication made in good faith
content: No offence for communication made in good faith for a person's benefit despite harm. Illustration: surgeon bluntly informing patient of fatal prognosis.

title: Section 94 – Act compelled by threats
content: Except murder and capital State offences, acts compelled by threats of instant death are not offences, unless person voluntarily placed themselves in that situation. Explanations illustrate cases of joining dacoits voluntarily vs. being seized and compelled.

title: Section 95 – Act causing slight harm
content: Acts causing harm so slight that a person of ordinary sense/temper would not complain are not offences.

title: Section 96 – Things done in private defence
content: Nothing is an offence if done in exercise of the right of private defence.

title: Section 97 – Right of private defence of body and property
content: Right to defend: (1) own or another's body against any offence affecting human body; (2) property (own or another's) against theft, robbery, mischief, criminal trespass or attempts thereof, subject to section 99 restrictions.

title: Section 98 – Right of private defence against acts of certain persons
content: Right of private defence applies against acts of persons not criminally liable due to youth, immaturity, unsoundness of mind, intoxication, or misconception, as if the conduct were an offence. Illustrations show defending against lunatic's attack or mistaken assault.

title: Section 99 – Acts against which there is no right of private defence
content: No right of private defence against acts by public servants or by their direction if done in good faith and without causing reasonable apprehension of death or grievous hurt, nor where time exists to seek public aid. The right never extends to more harm than necessary. Explanations clarify knowledge of authority.

title: Section 100 – Right of private defence of body extending to causing death
content: Right of private defence of body extends to causing death if assault causes reasonable apprehension of: death; grievous hurt; intention to commit rape; intention to gratify unnatural lust; intention to kidnap/abduct; intention to wrongfully confine without recourse to authorities; or act of throwing/attempting to throw acid causing such apprehension.

title: Section 101 – Right of private defence of body when not extending to death
content: If the offence is not under section 100 descriptions, the right extends only to causing harm other than death, subject to section 99 restrictions.

title: Section 102 – Commencement and continuance of right of private defence of body
content: Begins with reasonable apprehension of danger from attempt/threat of offence; continues as long as apprehension continues.

title: Section 103 – Right of private defence of property extending to causing death
content: Right extends to causing death if offence is: robbery; house‑breaking by night; mischief by fire to human dwelling/custody of property; or theft/mischief/house‑trespass causing reasonable apprehension of death/grievous hurt. Karnataka amendment adds explosive substances, places of worship, Government/local authority property, railways, and passenger vehicles.

title: Section 104 – Right of private defence of property when not extending to death
content: In other cases of theft, mischief, or criminal trespass not in section 103, right extends to causing harm other than death, subject to section 99.

title: Section 105 – Commencement and continuance of right of private defence of property
content: Begins with reasonable apprehension of danger to property. Continues: against theft, until offender retreats with property, public aid obtained, or property recovered; against robbery, while offender causes/attempts instant death/hurt/restraint; against criminal trespass/mischief, while act continues; against house‑breaking by night, while trespass begun continues.

title: Section 106 – Right of private defence against deadly assault with risk to innocent person
content: Where defending against deadly assault reasonably causing apprehension of death, the right extends to risk of harm to an innocent person if defence cannot be effective otherwise. Illustration: firing at mob attempting murder despite risk to mingled children.

title: Section 107 – Abetment of a thing
content: A person abets the doing of a thing who: First – instigates any person to do that thing; or Secondly – engages with one or more persons in any conspiracy for the doing of that thing, if an act or illegal omission takes place in pursuance thereof; or Thirdly – intentionally aids, by act or illegal omission, the doing of that thing. Explanation 1: Wilful misrepresentation or concealment of a material fact bound to be disclosed, causing or procuring a thing to be done, is instigation. Illustration: A public officer is misled by B into apprehending C, knowing C is not the person named in the warrant – B abets by instigation. Explanation 2: Whoever prior to or during commission does anything to facilitate it and thereby facilitates it, aids the act.

title: Section 108 – Abettor
content: A person abets an offence by abetting its commission, or abetting an act which would be an offence if done by a capable person with the same intent or knowledge as the abettor. Explanation 1: Abetment of illegal omission can be an offence even if abettor is not bound to do the act. Explanation 2: Offence need not be committed or completed. Explanation 3: Person abetted need not be capable of committing offence or have the same guilty mind. Explanation 4: Abetment of abetment is also an offence. Explanation 5: Abetment by conspiracy does not require direct contact with the perpetrator if engaged in the conspiracy. Multiple illustrations provided including instigation of minors and persons of unsound mind.

title: Section 108A – Abetment in India of offences outside India
content: Whoever in India abets commission of any act outside India which would be an offence if committed in India is guilty of abetment. Illustration: A in India instigates B, a foreigner in Goa, to commit murder in Goa – A is guilty of abetting murder.

title: Section 109 – Punishment of abetment if act abetted is committed and no express provision for punishment
content: Whoever abets an offence shall, if committed in consequence of abetment and no express punishment is provided, be punished with the punishment for the offence. Explanation: Act is committed in consequence when committed due to instigation, conspiracy, or aid constituting abetment. Illustrations: instigating bribery; inducement to give false evidence; conspiring to commit murder.

title: Section 110 – Punishment of abetment if act done with different intention from abettor
content: If the person abetted acts with different intent or knowledge than abettor, punishment is for offence as if done with abettor's intention/knowledge.

title: Section 111 – Liability of abettor when one act abetted and different act done
content: Abettor is liable for act done if it is a probable consequence of abetment and under its influence, even if different from that abetted. Illustrations: poisoning intended for Z affects Y; burning house accompanied by theft not abetted; armed robbery leading to murder.

title: Section 112 – Cumulative punishment for act abetted and act done
content: If act under section 111 is in addition to act abetted and is a distinct offence, abettor is liable for each. Illustration: instigation to resist distress leading to grievous hurt.

title: Section 113 – Liability for effect different from that intended
content: If act abetted with intention to cause a particular effect causes a different effect, abettor is liable for the effect caused if he knew it likely. Illustration: instigation to cause grievous hurt leading to death with knowledge of risk attracts liability for murder.

title: Section 114 – Abettor present when offence is committed
content: An abettor who is present when the offence is committed is deemed to have committed it.

title: Section 115 – Abetment of offence punishable with death or life imprisonment if offence not committed
content: Whoever abets such offence, if not committed and no express provision exists, is punishable with imprisonment up to 7 years and fine. If act causing harm is done, punishment may extend to 14 years and fine. Illustration: instigation to murder where no murder occurs but harm caused.

title: Section 116 – Abetment of offence punishable with imprisonment if offence not committed
content: Punishable with imprisonment up to one-fourth of maximum term for offence, or fine, or both. If abettor or person abetted is public servant bound to prevent offence, punishment up to one-half of maximum term. Illustrations include offering bribe refused, instigating false evidence not given, police officer abetting robbery not committed.

title: Section 117 – Abetting offence by public or more than ten persons
content: Punishable with imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both. Illustration: placard instigating large group to attack others.

title: Section 118 – Concealing design to commit offence punishable with death or life imprisonment
content: Voluntarily concealing, by act/omission or using encryption or other means, existence of a design to commit such offence, or making false representation about it, intending or knowing facilitation of offence: if offence committed – imprisonment up to 7 years; if not – up to 3 years; in either case also liable to fine.

title: Section 119 – Public servant concealing design to commit offence duty bound to prevent
content: If offence committed – imprisonment up to half maximum for offence, or up to 10 years if offence punishable with death/life; if not committed – up to one-fourth maximum. Also liable to fine. Applies to acts/illegal omissions or use of encryption to conceal design.

title: Section 120 – Concealing design to commit offence punishable with imprisonment
content: Concealing existence of a design to commit such offence, intending or knowing facilitation: if offence committed – imprisonment up to one-fourth of max term; if not – up to one-eighth. Also fine.

title: Section 120A – Criminal conspiracy defined
content: Agreement between two or more persons to do an illegal act, or legal act by illegal means, is criminal conspiracy. If not to commit an offence, requires an overt act in pursuance. Explanation: illegal act may be ultimate object or incidental.

title: Section 120B – Punishment of criminal conspiracy
content: (1) Conspiracy to commit offence punishable with death, life, or 2+ years rigorous imprisonment – punished as if abetting such offence. (2) Other conspiracies – imprisonment up to 6 months, or fine, or both.

title: Section 121 – Waging, attempting to wage, or abetting war against Government of India
content: Punishable with death or life imprisonment and fine. Illustration: joining insurrection against Government of India.

title: Section 121A – Conspiracy to commit offences punishable by section 121
content: Conspiring in or outside India to commit offences in 121, or to overawe Central/State Government by criminal force/show of force – punishable with life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine. No act/omission in pursuance required.

title: Section 122 – Collecting arms, etc., with intention of waging war
content: Collecting men, arms, ammunition, or otherwise preparing to wage war against Government of India – punishable with life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine.

title: Section 123 – Concealing with intent to facilitate design to wage war
content: By act/illegal omission conceals existence of design to wage war against Government of India intending or knowing facilitation – punishable with imprisonment up to 10 years and fine.

title: Section 124 – Assaulting President, Governor, etc., to compel or restrain lawful powers
content: Assaults, restrains, or overawes President of India or Governor of State with intent to induce or compel lawful power exercise/refrain – punishable with imprisonment up to 7 years and fine.

title: Section 124A – Sedition
content: By words, signs, or representations, brings/attempts to bring into hatred or contempt, or excites/attempts to excite disaffection towards Government established by law – punishable with life imprisonment and fine, or up to 3 years and fine, or fine. 'Disaffection' includes disloyalty and enmity. Lawful disapprobation without exciting hatred/contempt/disaffection is not an offence.

title: Section 125 – Waging war against any Asiatic Power in alliance with Government of India
content: Waging/attempting/abetting war – punishable with life imprisonment and fine, or up to 7 years and fine, or fine.

title: Section 126 – Committing depredation on territories of Power at peace with India
content: Punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment, fine, and forfeiture of property used in or acquired by depredation.

title: Section 127 – Receiving property taken by war or depredation
content: Receiving property knowing it taken in offences under ss.125–126 – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment, fine, and forfeiture.

title: Section 128 – Public servant voluntarily allowing prisoner of State or war to escape
content: Punishable with life imprisonment, or up to 10 years and fine.

title: Section 129 – Public servant negligently suffering prisoner of State or war to escape
content: Punishable with simple imprisonment up to 3 years and fine.

title: Section 130 – Aiding escape of, rescuing or harbouring prisoner of State or war
content: Knowingly aids escape, rescues, harbours such prisoner – punishable with life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine. Escape includes breach of parole limits.

title: Section 131 – Abetting mutiny, or attempting to seduce soldier, sailor or airman from duty
content: Punishable with life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine. Includes all persons subject to relevant service laws.

title: Section 132 – Abetment of mutiny if committed in consequence
content: If mutiny committed due to abetment, punishment is death, life imprisonment, or up to 10 years and fine.

title: Section 133 – Abetment of assault by soldier, sailor or airman on superior officer
content: Punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 134 – Abetment of such assault if committed
content: If committed in consequence of abetment, punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 135 – Abetment of desertion
content: Punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 136 – Harbouring deserter
content: Knowing harbour of deserter – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, fine, or both. Exception for wife harbouring husband.

title: Section 137 – Deserter concealed on merchant vessel through negligence of master
content: Master/person in charge liable to penalty up to Rs. 500 if deserter concealed and could have known but for neglect or lack of discipline.

title: Section 138 – Abetment of act of insubordination
content: If committed in consequence, punishable with up to 6 months imprisonment, fine, or both.

title: Section 139 – Persons subject to certain Acts
content: Persons subject to military/naval/air force discipline laws not punishable under this Chapter for its offences.

title: Section 140 – Wearing garb or carrying token used by soldier, sailor or airman
content: Not being such service member, wearing garb or carrying token resembling such with intent to be believed as such – punishable with up to 3 months imprisonment, Rs. 500 fine, or both.

title: Section 141 – Unlawful assembly
content: An assembly of five or more persons is unlawful if its common object is: (1) to overawe by criminal force the Central or State Government, Parliament, a State Legislature, or any public servant in lawful exercise of power; (2) to resist execution of law or legal process; (3) to commit mischief, criminal trespass or other offence; (4) by criminal force to obtain possession of property, deprive someone of a right, or enforce a right or supposed right; (5) by criminal force compel a person to do or omit what he is legally entitled. An initially lawful assembly may later become unlawful.

title: Section 142 – Being member of unlawful assembly
content: Whoever, knowing facts rendering an assembly unlawful, intentionally joins or continues in it, is a member of an unlawful assembly.

title: Section 143 – Punishment
content: Membership of an unlawful assembly is punishable with up to 6 months imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 144 – Joining unlawful assembly armed with deadly weapon
content: Membership of an unlawful assembly while armed with a deadly weapon or anything likely to cause death as a weapon is punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 145 – Joining or continuing in unlawful assembly knowing it has been commanded to disperse
content: Joining or continuing in an unlawful assembly knowing it has been commanded by law to disperse is punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 146 – Rioting
content: When force or violence is used by an unlawful assembly or any member in pursuit of its common object, every member is guilty of rioting.

title: Section 147 – Punishment for rioting
content: Rioting is punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 148 – Rioting, armed with deadly weapon
content: Rioting while armed with a deadly weapon or anything likely to cause death is punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 149 – Every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object
content: If an offence is committed by any member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of its common object, or if members knew it likely to be committed, every member at the time is guilty of that offence.

title: Section 150 – Hiring persons to join unlawful assembly
content: Whoever hires, engages, or connives at hiring of persons to join an unlawful assembly is punishable as a member and for any offences committed by such persons while members.

title: Section 151 – Knowingly joining assembly after it commanded to disperse
content: Knowingly joining or continuing in any assembly of five or more likely to disturb public peace after command to disperse is punishable with up to 6 months imprisonment, or fine, or both. If assembly is unlawful, punishment applies under section 145.

title: Section 152 – Assaulting or obstructing public servant when suppressing riot
content: Assaulting, threatening, or obstructing a public servant in dispersing unlawful assembly or suppressing riot/affray, or using/threatening criminal force to such servant, is punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 153 – Wantonly giving provocation with intent to cause riot
content: Malignantly or wantonly doing anything illegal to provoke another intending or knowing it likely to cause rioting: if riot occurs, punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both; if not committed, up to 6 months, or fine, or both.

title: Section 153A – Promoting enmity between groups
content: Promoting or attempting to promote on various grounds disharmony or feelings of enmity, hatred, or ill-will between groups; committing acts prejudicial to harmony; organising or participating in training with intent to use violence causing fear among groups – punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both. If in a place of worship or during religious worship, punishment up to 5 years and fine.

title: Section 153AA – Punishment for knowingly carrying arms in procession or mass drill
content: Knowingly carrying arms in public procession or taking part in mass drill/training with arms in violation of order under sec 144A CrPC – punishable with up to 6 months imprisonment and fine up to Rs 2000. 'Arms' includes offensive/defensive weapons such as firearms, sharp-edged weapons, lathis, sticks.

title: Section 153B – Imputations prejudicial to national integration
content: Making, publishing imputations or assertions that any class of persons cannot bear allegiance to Constitution, should be denied rights, or making appeals causing disharmony – punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both; if in a place of worship, up to 5 years and fine.

title: Section 154 – Owner/occupier of land where unlawful assembly held
content: Owner/occupier or person with interest in land where unlawful assembly/riot occurs, knowing or having reason to believe it likely, must inform police and use lawful means to prevent/disperse; failing so punishable with fine up to Rs 1000.

title: Section 155 – Liability of person for whose benefit riot committed
content: Owner/occupier/beneficiary of riot for benefit over land/dispute must prevent assembly/riot; failure punishable with fine.

title: Section 156 – Liability of agent of owner/occupier for whose benefit riot committed
content: Agent/manager for owner/beneficiary of riot has similar duty as in section 155; failure punishable with fine.

title: Section 157 – Harbouring persons hired for unlawful assembly
content: Harbouring or assembling persons known to be hired to join unlawful assembly is punishable with up to 6 months imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 158 – Being hired to take part in unlawful assembly or riot
content: Being hired or offering to be hired to commit acts in s.141 – punishable with up to 6 months; if armed with deadly weapon – up to 2 years; or fine; or both.

title: Section 159 – Affray
content: When two or more persons fight in a public place disturbing public peace, they commit affray.

title: Section 160 – Punishment for affray
content: Affray punishable with up to 1 month imprisonment, or fine up to Rs 100, or both.

title: Section 166 – Public servant disobeying law with intent to cause injury
content: Public servant knowingly disobeying legal direction in conduct, intending or knowing likely to cause injury, punishable with up to 1 year simple imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 166A – Public servant disobeying direction under law
content: Public servant disobeying law prohibiting requiring attendance; or disobeys investigation procedure; or fails to record certain offences in Sec 154 CrPC – punishable with rigorous imprisonment 6 months to 2 years and fine.

title: Section 166B – Punishment for non-treatment of victim
content: Person in charge of hospital contravening Sec 357C CrPC – punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 167 – Public servant framing incorrect document with intent to cause injury
content: Public servant preparing/translating document or electronic record incorrectly, intending or knowing likely to cause injury – punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 168 – Public servant unlawfully engaging in trade
content: Public servant engaging in trade despite legal prohibition – punishable with up to 1 year simple imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 169 – Public servant unlawfully buying or bidding for property
content: Public servant prohibited from purchasing/bidding for certain property who does so – punishable with up to 2 years simple imprisonment, or fine, or both; property confiscated.

title: Section 170 – Personating a public servant
content: Falsely pretending to hold a public office and doing/attempting act under colour – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 171 – Wearing garb or carrying token used by public servant with fraudulent intent
content: Not of that class of public servants but wearing/carrying similar garb/token intending to be believed as such – punishable with up to 3 months imprisonment, or fine up to Rs 200, or both.

title: Section 171A – 'Candidate', 'Electoral right' defined
content: 'Candidate' means nominated person for election; 'Electoral right' means right to stand, withdraw as candidate or to vote/refrain.

title: Section 171B – Bribery
content: Giving gratification to induce electoral right exercise or rewarding; accepting gratification as reward – offence of bribery. Public policy declaration or promise of public action not offence. Includes attempts/agreements to give/accept gratification.

title: Section 171C – Undue influence at elections
content: Voluntarily interfering with free exercise of electoral right. Includes threats of injury or inducing belief of divine displeasure. Public policy declarations, lawful exercise without intent, not interference.

title: Section 171D – Personation at elections
content: Voting in another's name (living/dead/fictitious), voting twice, or procuring such voting – personation. Proxy voting under law excluded.

title: Section 171E – Punishment for bribery
content: Punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both; bribery by treating (gratification of food, drink, entertainment) punishable with fine only.

title: Section 171F – Punishment for undue influence or personation
content: Punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 171G – False statement in connection with election
content: Making/publishing false statements of fact about candidate's personal character/conduct, knowing/believing it false, to affect election – punishable with fine.

title: Section 171H – Illegal payments in connection with an election
content: Incurring/authorising expenses for promoting a candidate without their written authority – punishable with fine up to Rs 500. Certain small expenses with later approval exempt.

title: Section 171-I – Failure to keep election accounts
content: Failing to keep required election expense accounts – punishable with fine up to Rs 500.

title: Section 172 – Absconding to avoid service of summons or other proceeding
content: Absconding to avoid being served summons/notice/order from competent public servant – punishable with up to 1 month simple imprisonment or Rs 500 fine; if to attend/produce in court – up to 6 months or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 173 – Preventing service or publication of summons or other proceeding
content: Preventing service on self/another, preventing lawful affixing, removing lawfully affixed, or preventing lawful proclamation – punishable similar to s.172 with higher penalty if for court attendance/production.

title: Section 174 – Non-attendance in obedience to order from public servant
content: Legally bound person intentionally omitting to attend or leaving early from required attendance by summons/notice/order from public servant – punishable with up to 1 month simple imprisonment or Rs 500 fine; if for court attendance – up to 6 months or Rs 1000 fine. Includes illustrations of failure to attend High Court or District Judge as required.

title: Section 174A – Non-appearance in response to a proclamation under s.82 CrPC
content: Failure to appear as required by proclamation – punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both. If declared proclaimed offender under s.82(4), up to 7 years and fine.

title: Section 175 – Omission to produce document to public servant
content: Legally bound person intentionally omitting to produce/deliver document/electronic record to public servant – punishable with up to 1 month simple imprisonment or Rs 500 fine; if for court – up to 6 months or Rs 1000 fine.

title: Section 176 – Omission to give notice or information to public servant
content: Legally bound person omitting to give notice/information to public servant – punishable with up to 1 month simple imprisonment or Rs 500 fine; if respecting commission/prevention/apprehension of offence – up to 6 months or Rs 1000 fine; other specified cases same.

title: Section 177 – Furnishing false information
content: Legally bound person furnishing false information to public servant – punishable with up to 6 months simple imprisonment or Rs 1000 fine; if respecting offence/prevention/apprehension – up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both. Includes illustrations on misinforming magistrate or police. Explanation extends to certain serious offences committed abroad.

title: Section 178 – Refusing oath or affirmation when required by public servant
content: Refusal to bind by oath/affirmation to state truth when lawfully required by public servant – punishable with up to 6 months simple imprisonment or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 179 – Refusing to answer public servant authorised to question
content: Whoever, being legally bound to state the truth on any subject to any public servant, refuses to answer any question demanded of him on that subject by such public servant in the exercise of his legal powers, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

title: Section 180 – Refusing to sign statement
content: Whoever refuses to sign any statement made by him, when required to sign by a public servant legally competent to require it, is punishable with up to 3 months simple imprisonment, or fine up to Rs 500, or both.

title: Section 181 – False statement on oath or affirmation to public servant
content: Whoever, being legally bound by oath or affirmation to state truth to any public servant or authorised person, makes a statement which is false and which he knows/believes to be false or does not believe to be true, is punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 182 – False information to cause public servant to misuse lawful power
content: Giving false information to a public servant intending or knowing it likely to cause him to do/omit or use lawful power to injure/annoy another – punishable with up to 6 months imprisonment, or fine up to Rs 1000, or both. Illustrations include giving false misconduct allegations, false contraband info, or false robbery claims causing annoyance.

title: Section 183 – Resistance to taking of property by lawful authority
content: Offering resistance to lawful taking of property by a public servant, knowing or having reason to believe that he is such servant, is punishable with up to 6 months imprisonment, or fine up to Rs 1000, or both.

title: Section 184 – Obstructing sale of property by authority of public servant
content: Intentionally obstructing any sale of property offered by lawful authority of a public servant is punishable with up to 1 month imprisonment, or fine up to Rs 500, or both.

title: Section 185 – Illegal purchase or bid for property offered for sale by authority
content: Knowingly purchasing or bidding for property at sale by lawful authority when legally incapacitated, or bidding without intent to perform obligations, is punishable with up to 1 month imprisonment, or fine up to Rs 200, or both.

title: Section 186 – Obstructing public servant in discharge of public functions
content: Voluntarily obstructing any public servant in the discharge of public functions is punishable with up to 3 months imprisonment, or fine up to Rs 500, or both.

title: Section 187 – Omission to assist public servant when bound by law
content: Being bound by law to assist public servant and intentionally omitting to do so – punishable with up to 1 month simple imprisonment, or Rs 200 fine, or both; if demanded for process execution, offence prevention, riot suppression, or apprehension, up to 6 months or Rs 500 fine, or both.

title: Section 188 – Disobedience to order promulgated by public servant
content: Disobeying lawful order from authorised public servant to abstain from an act or deal with property in certain way – if causing obstruction/annoyance/injury, punishable with up to 1 month simple imprisonment or Rs 200 fine; if causing danger to life/health/safety or riot/affray risk – up to 6 months or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 189 – Threat of injury to public servant
content: Threatening injury to public servant or related person to induce that servant to act/forbear in official capacity – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 190 – Threat of injury to induce person to refrain from seeking public protection
content: Threatening injury to induce a person to refrain from applying for protection to a legally empowered public servant – punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 191 – Giving false evidence
content: Legally bound by oath/law to state truth and making statement known/believed false or not believed true is giving false evidence. Applies to verbal/written statements, beliefs not genuinely held, and to interpreters/translators. Includes multiple illustrations of false testimony.

title: Section 192 – Fabricating false evidence
content: Causing circumstances, false entries, or documents/electronic records with false statements to exist, intending they appear in evidence in proceedings to mislead decision on a material point – is fabricating false evidence. Includes illustrations like planting jewels, false shop-book entry, forged conspiracy letter.

title: Section 193 – Punishment for false evidence
content: Giving/fabricating false evidence in judicial proceeding – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine; in other cases – up to 3 years and fine. Explanations treat stages of trial, enquiries, and certain investigations as judicial proceedings.

title: Section 194 – False evidence to procure conviction of capital offence
content: Punishable with life imprisonment or up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine; if innocent person thereby executed – punishable with death or same penalty.

title: Section 195 – False evidence to procure conviction of offence punishable with life or long imprisonment
content: Punishable as if convicted of that offence when intending to cause conviction for offence punishable with life imprisonment or 7+ years. Illustration: false evidence to procure conviction for dacoity.

title: Section 195A – Threatening person to give false evidence
content: Threatening injury to person/reputation/property to cause them to give false evidence – punishable with up to 7 years, or same punishment as consequence offence if innocent person convicted for serious offences.

title: Section 196 – Using evidence known to be false
content: Corruptly using or attempting to use as true evidence known to be false/fabricated – punishable as if gave/fabricated false evidence.

title: Section 197 – Issuing or signing false certificate
content: Issuing/signing any legally required/admissible certificate, knowing/believing it false in any material point – punishable as if gave false evidence.

title: Section 198 – Using as true a certificate known to be false
content: Corruptly using/attempting to use as true any certificate known to be false in a material point – punishable as if gave false evidence.

title: Section 199 – False statement in declaration receivable as evidence
content: In a declaration legally admissible as evidence, making false statement known/believed false or not believed true on a material point – punishable as if gave false evidence.

title: Section 200 – Using declaration known to be false
content: Corruptly using/attempting to use as true any declaration known to be false in material point – punishable as if gave false evidence. Explanation: even inadmissible for informality is included.

title: Section 201 – Causing disappearance of evidence or giving false info to screen offender
