content: Knowing/reason to believe offence committed and causing evidence to disappear or giving false info to screen: if capital offence – up to 7 years & fine; if life imprisonment offence – up to 3 years & fine; if <10 years max punishment – up to 1/4 of max imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 202 – Intentional omission to give info of offence by person bound to inform
content: Knowing/reason to believe offence committed and omitting to give info legally bound to give – punishable with up to 6 months imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 203 – Giving false information respecting an offence
content: Knowing/reason to believe offence committed and giving info known/believed false – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both. Explanation extends 'offence' to certain serious crimes committed outside India.

title: Section 204 – Destruction of document to prevent production as evidence
content: Secreting, destroying, obliterating, or making illegible document/e-record lawfully compellable as evidence to prevent its production – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 205 – False personation in suit or prosecution
content: Falsely personating another in any suit/prosecution and doing acts in that assumed character – punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 206 – Fraudulent removal/concealment of property to prevent seizure
content: Fraudulently removing/concealing/transferring/delivering property to prevent seizure as forfeited or in execution of sentence/decree – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 207 – Fraudulent claim to property to prevent seizure
content: Fraudulently accepting/receiving/claiming property without right to prevent seizure as forfeited or in execution – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 208 – Fraudulently suffering decree for sum not due
content: Fraudulently causing/suffering decree for sum/property not due or larger than due, or executing after satisfaction – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both. Illustration: collusive judgment to defraud other creditor.

title: Section 209 – Dishonestly making false claim in court
content: Fraudulently/dishonestly or to injure/annoy making in court any claim known to be false – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 210 – Fraudulently obtaining decree for sum not due
content: Fraudulently obtaining/causing execution of decree for sum/property not due, or after satisfaction – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 211 – False charge of offence made with intent to injure
content: Instituting/causing to institute criminal proceeding or falsely charging someone with offence knowing no lawful ground – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both; if offence alleged punishable with death/life/7+ years – up to 7 years and fine. Chhattisgarh amendment: false charges for certain sexual offences min 3 years up to 5 years and fine.

title: Section 212 – Harbouring offender
content: Harbouring/concealing offender to screen from punishment: if capital offence – up to 5 years and fine; if life imprisonment/10 years offence – up to 3 years and fine; if up to 1 year max offence – up to one-fourth of max term, or fine, or both. Offence includes certain serious crimes outside India. Exception: spouse harbouring offender exempt.

title: Section 213 – Taking gift to screen an offender from punishment
content: Accepting, attempting to obtain, or agreeing to accept gratification or restitution of property in consideration of concealing an offence, screening a person from punishment, or not proceeding against them: if capital offence – up to 7 years imprisonment and fine; if punishable with life or up to 10 years – up to 3 years and fine; if punishable with less than 10 years – imprisonment up to one‑fourth of maximum term, or fine, or both.

title: Section 214 – Offering gift or restoration of property for screening offender
content: Giving or offering gratification, or restoring property, to cause concealment of an offence, screening an offender, or preventing proceedings: same punishments as section 213 depending on severity. Exception: lawful compounding of offence permitted.

title: Section 215 – Taking gift to help recover stolen property
content: Taking or agreeing to take gratification on pretext of helping to recover stolen movable property, without using all means to apprehend and convict the offender – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 216 – Harbouring offender who escaped custody or ordered to be apprehended
content: Harbouring/concealing escaped or ordered‑to‑be‑apprehended person: if capital offence – up to 7 years and fine; if life/10 years offence – up to 3 years and fine; if less than 10 years – up to one‑fourth maximum term, or fine, or both. Exception: spouse harbouring exempt.

title: Section 216A – Penalty for harbouring robbers or dacoits
content: Knowing intent to commit or recent commission of robbery/dacoity and harbouring participants to facilitate or screen them – rigorous imprisonment up to 7 years and fine. Exception: spouse harbouring exempt.

title: Section 217 – Public servant disobeying law to save person from punishment or property from forfeiture
content: Public servant knowingly disobeying legal direction with intent to save person from full legal punishment or property from forfeiture – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 218 – Public servant framing incorrect record to save person from punishment or property from forfeiture
content: Public servant preparing any record/writing incorrectly, intending to cause harm or to save person from punishment or property from forfeiture – punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 219 – Public servant corruptly making report or decision contrary to law in judicial proceeding
content: Public servant corruptly/maliciously making report/order/verdict/decision contrary to law in any stage of judicial proceeding – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 220 – Commitment or confinement contrary to law by person with authority
content: Person with authority to commit for trial/confinement who corruptly/maliciously so commits or keeps person in custody knowing it is contrary to law – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 221 – Intentional omission to apprehend by public servant bound to apprehend
content: Public servant bound to apprehend/keep in confinement intentionally omitting or allowing escape/aiding escape: if capital offence – up to 7 years and fine; if life/10 years – up to 3 years and fine; if less than 10 years – up to 2 years, or fine, or both.

title: Section 222 – Intentional omission to apprehend person under sentence or lawfully committed
content: Public servant bound to apprehend person under sentence/custody intentionally omitting or aiding escape: if under sentence of death – life imprisonment or up to 14 years; if life/10+ years – up to 7 years; if less than 10 years – up to 3 years or fine.

title: Section 223 – Escape negligently suffered by public servant
content: Public servant bound to confine person charged/convicted of offence negligently allowing escape – punishable with up to 2 years simple imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 224 – Resistance or obstruction to lawful apprehension of self
content: Intentionally resisting or obstructing lawful apprehension of self or escaping custody – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both, in addition to original offence punishment.

title: Section 225 – Resistance or obstruction to lawful apprehension of another
content: Intentionally resisting/obstructing or rescuing another from lawful custody – punishment varies: up to 2 years in ordinary cases; up to 3 years if offence punishable with life/10 years; up to 7 years if punishable with death or life.

title: Section 225A – Omission to apprehend or sufferance of escape by public servant
content: Public servant omitting to apprehend/keep in confinement in cases not covered elsewhere: intentional – up to 3 years; negligent – up to 2 years; or fine; or both.

title: Section 225B – Resistance or obstruction to lawful apprehension or escape in cases not otherwise provided
content: Resistance/obstruction to lawful apprehension of self/other, or escape/rescue in cases not covered elsewhere – punishable with up to 6 months imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 227 – Violation of condition of remission of punishment
content: Knowingly violating condition of accepted remission of punishment – punishable with remaining unserved part of original sentence.

title: Section 228 – Intentional insult or interruption to public servant in judicial proceeding
content: Intentional insult or interruption to public servant while sitting in judicial proceeding – punishable with up to 6 months simple imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 228A – Disclosure of identity of victim of certain offences
content: Printing/publishing details making known identity of victim of specified sexual offences – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment and fine. Exceptions for investigative and authorised disclosures. Publishing court proceedings without permission – same penalty. Publishing HC/SC judgments excluded.

title: Section 229 – Personation of a juror or assessor
content: By personation or otherwise causing oneself to be or serving as juror/assessor knowing not entitled – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 229A – Failure by person on bail or bond to appear in court
content: Failing without sufficient cause to appear as required by bail/bond terms – punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both. Additional to original offence punishment; does not preclude bond forfeiture.

title: Section 230 – 'Coin' defined
content: Coin is metal used as money, stamped and issued by authority of a State/Sovereign. Indian coin is stamped and issued by Government of India, remains such even if not used as money. Examples: cowries/medals not coin; Company's rupee, Farukhabad rupee are Indian coin.

title: Section 231 – Counterfeiting coin
content: Counterfeiting or performing any part of process of counterfeiting coin – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine. Includes altering genuine coin to appear like different coin.

title: Section 232 – Counterfeiting Indian coin
content: Counterfeiting Indian coin or part thereof – punishable with life imprisonment, or up to 10 years, and fine.

title: Section 233 – Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting coin
content: Making/mending, or buying/selling/disposal of die/instrument for counterfeiting coin – punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 234 – Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting Indian coin
content: Same acts as section 233 but for Indian coin – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 235 – Possession of instrument or material for counterfeiting coin
content: Possession for using or knowing intended use for counterfeiting coin – punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment and fine; if Indian coin – up to 10 years and fine.

title: Section 236 – Abetting in India the counterfeiting out of India of coin
content: Abetting counterfeiting of coin outside India – same punishment as if committed within India.

title: Section 237 – Import or export of counterfeit coin
content: Importing/exporting counterfeit coin knowing it to be such – punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 238 – Import or export of counterfeit Indian coin
content: Same as section 237 for Indian coin – punishable with life imprisonment, or up to 10 years, and fine.

title: Section 239 – Delivery of coin known to be counterfeit
content: Possessing counterfeit coin known at time of possession and delivering it fraudulently/with intent to defraud – up to 5 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 240 – Delivery of Indian coin known to be counterfeit
content: Same as section 239 for Indian coin – punishable with up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 241 – Delivery of coin as genuine not known to be counterfeit when first possessed
content: Delivering counterfeit coin as genuine after later discovering its falsity – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine up to 10× coin value, or both. Illustration provided.

title: Section 242 – Possession of counterfeit coin known when possessed
content: Possessing counterfeit coin known as such when acquired, with fraudulent intent – punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 243 – Possession of counterfeit Indian coin known when possessed
content: Same as section 242 for Indian coin – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 244 – Mint employee causing coin to be of different weight or composition
content: Mint employee acting/omitting with intent to cause coin to differ in weight/composition from lawful standard – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 245 – Unlawfully taking coining instrument from mint
content: Taking without authority any coining tool/instrument from lawfully established Indian mint – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 246 – Fraudulently or dishonestly diminishing weight or altering composition of coin
content: Punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment and fine; includes operations altering composition of coin.

title: Section 247 – Fraudulently or dishonestly diminishing weight or altering composition of Indian coin
content: Same as section 246 for Indian coin – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 248 – Altering appearance of coin to pass as different coin
content: Doing any operation to alter appearance of coin to pass as different description – up to 3 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 249 – Altering appearance of Indian coin to pass as different coin
content: Same as section 248 for Indian coin – up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 250 – Delivery of coin known to be altered
content: Possessing altered coin known as such when acquired and delivering fraudulently – up to 5 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 251 – Delivery of Indian coin known to be altered
content: Same as section 250 for Indian coin – up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 252 – Possession of coin known to be altered when acquired
content: Possession of altered coin known to be altered when acquired, with fraudulent intent – up to 3 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 253 – Possession of Indian coin known to be altered when acquired
content: Same as section 252 for Indian coin – up to 5 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 254 – Delivery of coin as genuine not known to be altered when first possessed
content: Delivering altered coin as genuine, later discovering alteration – up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine up to 10× value of represented coin, or both.

title: Section 255 – Counterfeiting Government stamp
content: Counterfeiting any revenue stamp issued by Government – punishable with life imprisonment, or up to 10 years, and fine. Includes making stamp of different denomination appear like another.

title: Section 256 – Possession of instrument or material for counterfeiting Government stamp
content: Possessing instrument/material for counterfeiting Government revenue stamps – up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 257 – Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting Government stamp
content: Making/selling/disposal of instrument for counterfeiting Government revenue stamps – up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 258 – Sale of counterfeit Government stamp
content: Selling/offering for sale Government revenue stamp known to be counterfeit – up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 259 – Possession of counterfeit Government stamp
content: Possessing counterfeit Government revenue stamp intending to use/dispose of as genuine – up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 260 – Using as genuine a Government stamp known to be counterfeit
content: Using a Government revenue stamp known to be counterfeit as genuine – up to 7 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 261 – Effacing writing from substance bearing Government stamp
content: Fraudulently removing/effacing writing from stamped substance or removing stamp from document so it can be reused – up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 262 – Using Government stamp known to have been used before
content: Using for any purpose a Government revenue stamp known to have been used before – up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 263 – Erasure of mark denoting stamp has been used
content: Erasing/removing mark from Government revenue stamp showing it was used, or possessing/selling such stamp – up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 263A – Prohibition of fictitious stamps
content: Making/dealing in/selling/using fictitious postage stamp; possessing without excuse; possessing stamp‑making die/instruments without lawful excuse – punishable with fine up to Rs 200; items may be seized and forfeited. Defines 'fictitious stamp' and deems 'Government' to include authorised entities in India, certain dominions, or foreign country for postage stamps.

title: Section 264 – Fraudulent use of false instrument for weighing
content: Fraudulently using any instrument for weighing known to be false – punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 265 – Fraudulent use of false weight or measure
content: Fraudulently using any false weight or false measure of length or capacity, or using any weight/measure as a different one than it is – punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 266 – Being in possession of false weight or measure
content: Possessing any false instrument for weighing, weight, or measure of length or capacity, known to be false, intending fraudulent use – punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 267 – Making or selling false weight or measure
content: Making, selling, or disposing of any false instrument for weighing, weight, or measure of length or capacity, to be or likely to be used as true – punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 268 – Public nuisance
content: Whoever does any act or illegal omission causing common injury, danger, or annoyance to the public or people in the vicinity, or necessarily causing obstruction or danger to people using a public right, commits public nuisance. Not excused by reason that it provides some convenience or advantage.

title: Section 269 – Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life
content: Unlawfully or negligently doing any act known/likely to spread infection of a disease dangerous to life – punishable with up to 6 months imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 270 – Malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life
content: Malignantly doing any act known/likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 271 – Disobedience to quarantine rule
content: Knowingly disobeying quarantine rules made and promulgated by Government for vessels, intercourse between places with infectious disease, etc. – punishment up to 6 months imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 272 – Adulteration of food or drink intended for sale
content: Adulterating any article of food or drink to make it noxious, intending it for sale as food/drink or knowing likely to be sold as such – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 273 – Sale of noxious food or drink
content: Selling/offering/exposing for sale any article rendered or become noxious or unfit for food/drink, knowing/believing it to be so – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 274 – Adulteration of drugs
content: Adulterating drugs/medical preparations to lessen efficacy, change operation, or make noxious, intending/knowing likely to be sold or used for medicinal purposes – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 275 – Sale of adulterated drugs
content: Selling/offering/exposing or issuing adulterated drug/medicine as unadulterated for medicinal purposes, knowing it to be adulterated – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 276 – Sale of drug as a different drug or preparation
content: Knowingly selling/offering/exposing or issuing a drug/medicine as a different one – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 277 – Fouling water of public spring or reservoir
content: Voluntarily corrupting/fouling water of any public spring/reservoir to render it less fit for ordinary use – up to 3 months imprisonment, or Rs 500 fine, or both.

title: Section 278 – Making atmosphere noxious to health
content: Voluntarily vitiating the atmosphere to make it noxious to health of persons in general nearby – punishable with fine up to Rs 500.

title: Section 279 – Rash driving or riding on a public way
content: Driving any vehicle or riding on a public way rashly/negligently to endanger life or cause injury – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 280 – Rash navigation of vessel
content: Navigating vessel rashly/negligently to endanger life or cause injury – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 281 – Exhibition of false light, mark or buoy
content: Exhibiting false light/mark/buoy intending/knowing likely to mislead any navigator – up to 7 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 282 – Conveying person by water for hire in unsafe or overloaded vessel
content: Knowingly/negligently conveying or causing to be conveyed for hire any person in unsafe/overloaded vessel endangering life – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 283 – Danger or obstruction in public way or line of navigation
content: Causing danger, obstruction or injury to any person in public way or navigation by act or omission – punishable with fine up to Rs 200.

title: Section 284 – Negligent conduct with respect to poisonous substance
content: Doing any rash/negligent act with poisonous substance or omitting precautions, endangering life – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 285 – Negligent conduct with respect to fire or combustible matter
content: Doing rash/negligent act with fire/combustible matter or omitting precautions, endangering life – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 286 – Negligent conduct with respect to explosive substance
content: Doing rash/negligent act with explosive substance or omitting precautions, endangering life – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 287 – Negligent conduct with respect to machinery
content: Doing rash/negligent act with machinery or omitting precautions, endangering life – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 288 – Negligent conduct with respect to pulling down or repairing buildings
content: Knowingly/negligently omitting precautions in pulling down/repairing buildings, risking danger from fall – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 289 – Negligent conduct with respect to animal
content: Knowingly/negligently omitting precautions with any animal to prevent danger to life or grievous hurt – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 290 – Punishment for public nuisance in cases not otherwise provided for
content: Committing public nuisance not otherwise punishable – fine up to Rs 200.

title: Section 291 – Continuance of nuisance after injunction to discontinue
content: Repeating or continuing public nuisance after being lawfully enjoined not to – up to 6 months simple imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 292 – Sale, etc., of obscene books, etc.
content: Deals in, makes, possesses, imports, exports, advertises, or offers obscene materials; first conviction – up to 2 years imprisonment and Rs 2000 fine; subsequent – up to 5 years and Rs 5000 fine. Exceptions for public good, religious use, historic/artistic works.

title: Section 293 – Sale, etc., of obscene objects to young person
content: Selling, etc., to a person under 20 any obscene object – first conviction up to 3 years imprisonment and Rs 2000 fine; subsequent – up to 7 years and Rs 5000 fine.

title: Section 294 – Obscene acts and songs
content: To annoyance of others: (a) doing obscene act in public; (b) singing/reciting/uttering obscene song/words in or near public place – up to 3 months imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 294A – Keeping lottery office
content: Keeping lottery office not being state/authorised lottery – up to 6 months imprisonment, or fine, or both. Publishing related proposals – fine up to Rs 1000.

title: Section 295 – Injuring or defiling place of worship with intent to insult religion
content: Destroying, damaging, or defiling place of worship or sacred object with intent to insult religion – up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 295A – Deliberate and malicious acts intended to outrage religious feelings
content: With deliberate and malicious intention to outrage religious feelings of any class, insults religion or beliefs – up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 296 – Disturbing religious assembly
content: Voluntarily causing disturbance to assembly lawfully performing religious worship/ceremonies – up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 297 – Trespassing on burial places, etc.
content: With intent/knowledge of wounding feelings or insulting religion, trespasses in place of worship or sepulture, or commits indignity to human corpse, or disturbs funeral ceremonies – up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 298 – Uttering words etc., with deliberate intent to wound religious feelings
content: With deliberate intent to wound religious feelings, utters words, makes sounds, gestures, or places objects in sight of a person – up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 299 – Culpable homicide
content: Whoever causes death by doing an act with (i) intention of causing death, or (ii) intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or (iii) knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits culpable homicide. Includes illustrations of indirect acts causing death and exclusions where knowledge/intention is absent. Expl. 1: Causing injury to infirm person accelerating death deemed causing death. Expl. 2: Death caused by injury is still caused by offender though treatment might have saved life. Expl. 3: Causing death of child partly brought forth is homicide, though not for unborn child in womb.

title: Section 300 – Murder
content: Culpable homicide is murder if act done: (1) with intention to cause death; (2) with intention to cause such bodily injury as offender knows likely to cause death of that person; (3) with intention to cause bodily injury sufficient in ordinary course to cause death; (4) knowing act is so imminently dangerous it must in all probability cause death or such injury likely to cause death, and committing without excuse. Contains illustrations and 5 exceptions: (1) grave and sudden provocation; (2) exceeding right of private defence; (3) public servant exceeding powers in good faith; (4) sudden fight without cruelty/advantage; (5) death consented to by person over 18. Exceptions have provisos; explanation: whether provocation was grave and sudden is a fact question.

title: Section 301 – Culpable homicide by causing death of person other than intended
content: If by doing something intended or known to be likely to cause death, one causes death of a different person, offence is of the description as if death of intended/known person were caused.

title: Section 302 – Punishment for murder
content: Punishable with death, or imprisonment for life, and also liable to fine.

title: Section 303 – Punishment for murder by life-convict
content: Life convict committing murder – punishable with death.

title: Section 304 – Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder
content: If act done with intention of causing death or injury likely to cause death – imprisonment for life, or up to 10 years, and fine; if act done with knowledge likely to cause death but without intention – up to 10 years, or fine, or both.

title: Section 304A – Causing death by negligence
content: Causing death by rash/negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both. HP Amendment: 304-AA – causing death/injury while intoxicated driving public service vehicle (later broadened to 'any vehicle') – punishable as if act done with knowledge of likely death/injury; max life imprisonment.

title: Section 304B – Dowry death
content: Death of woman by burns, bodily injury or otherwise than normal within 7 years of marriage, with evidence of cruelty/harassment by husband or his relative for dowry soon before death – 'dowry death'; deemed caused by husband/relative – punishment min 7 years to life imprisonment. 'Dowry' as in s.2 Dowry Prohibition Act.

title: Section 305 – Abetment of suicide of child or insane person
content: Abetment of suicide by person under 18, insane, delirious, idiot, or intoxicated – punishable with death, or life imprisonment, or up to 10 years imprisonment, and fine.

title: Section 306 – Abetment of suicide
content: Abetting suicide of any person – punishable with up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 307 – Attempt to murder
content: Doing any act with such intention/knowledge and circumstances that if death caused, act would be murder – punishable with up to 10 years imprisonment and fine; if hurt caused – may get life imprisonment. Life convict causing hurt in such attempt – punishable with death. Includes illustrations of attempts by shooting, poisoning, etc.

title: Section 308 – Attempt to commit culpable homicide
content: Doing any act with such intention/knowledge and circumstances that if death caused, it would be culpable homicide not amounting to murder – punishable with up to 3 years, or fine, or both; if hurt caused – up to 7 years and fine. Includes illustration of provoked shooting.

title: Section 309 – Attempt to commit suicide
content: Attempting to commit suicide and doing any act towards commission – punishable with up to 1 year simple imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 310 – Thug
content: Habitually associating for robbery or child-stealing accompanied with murder – offender is a thug.

title: Section 311 – Punishment of thug
content: Punishable with life imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 312 – Causing miscarriage
content: Voluntarily causing woman to miscarry, not in good faith to save her life – up to 3 years imprisonment or fine, or both; if woman quick with child – up to 7 years and fine. Woman causing self-miscarriage is included.

title: Section 313 – Causing miscarriage without woman's consent
content: Causing miscarriage without consent – punishable with life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine.

title: Section 314 – Death caused by act with intent to cause miscarriage
content: Doing act to cause miscarriage causing woman's death – up to 10 years and fine; if without consent – life imprisonment or as above. Knowledge of likelihood of death not essential.

title: Section 315 – Act done with intent to prevent child being born alive or to cause it to die after birth
content: Act before birth intending to prevent live birth or cause death after birth, and doing so – up to 10 years imprisonment or fine, or both; unless in good faith to save mother.

title: Section 316 – Causing death of quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide
content: Act amounting to culpable homicide causing death of quick unborn child – up to 10 years imprisonment and fine. Illustration given.

title: Section 317 – Exposure and abandonment of child under twelve years
content: Parent/person having care exposing/leaving child under 12 intending wholly to abandon – up to 7 years imprisonment, or fine, or both. Does not preclude liability for murder/homicide if child dies.

title: Section 318 – Concealment of birth by secret disposal of dead body
content: Secretly burying or disposing dead body of child to conceal birth – up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 319 – Hurt
content: Causing bodily pain, disease or infirmity to any person.

title: Section 320 – Grievous hurt
content: Only the following: emasculation; permanent loss of sight of an eye; permanent loss of hearing of an ear; loss of member/joint; destruction/permanent impairment of powers of member/joint; permanent disfiguration of head/face; fracture/dislocation of bone/tooth; any hurt endangering life or causing 20 days' severe pain or inability to follow ordinary pursuits.

title: Section 321 – Voluntarily causing hurt
content: Act with intention or knowledge likely to cause hurt, causing hurt.

title: Section 322 – Voluntarily causing grievous hurt
content: Voluntarily causing hurt intending/knowing likely to cause grievous hurt, and actually causing it; includes causing different kind of grievous hurt than intended.

title: Section 323 – Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt
content: Except where s.334 applies – up to 1 year imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 324 – Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means
content: Except where s.334 applies – up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both; when caused by shooting/stabbing/cutting instruments, fire, heated substances, poison, corrosives, explosives, deleterious inhalants/ingestants, or animals.

title: Section 325 – Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt
content: Except where s.335 applies – up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 326 – Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means
content: Except where s.335 applies – life imprisonment, or up to 10 years and fine; when caused by instruments/weapons or means described in s.324.

title: Section 326A – Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acid, etc.
content: Causing permanent/partial damage, deformity, burns, maiming, disfigurement, or disability, by throwing/administering acid or other means with intention or knowledge to cause such injury – min 10 years to life imprisonment and fine payable to victim for just medical expenses.

title: Section 326B – Voluntarily throwing or attempting to throw acid
content: Attempting to throw/administer acid or similar act with intent to cause permanent/partial damage, deformity, burns, maiming, disfigurement, disability, or grievous hurt – min 5 years to 7 years imprisonment and fine. Acid includes any corrosive/burning substance causing bodily injury/scars/disfigurement; damage need not be irreversible.

title: Section 327 – Voluntarily causing hurt to extort property or constrain to illegal act
content: Causing hurt to extort property or valuable security, or to constrain to do illegal act/facilitate offence – up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 328 – Causing hurt by means of poison, etc., with intent to commit an offence
content: Administering poison, stupefying/intoxicating/unwholesome drug or thing with intent to cause hurt, commit/facilitate offence, or knowing likely to cause hurt – up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 329 – Voluntarily causing grievous hurt to extort property or constrain to illegal act
content: Causing grievous hurt to extort property/valuable security or constrain to illegal act/facilitate offence – life imprisonment, or up to 10 years, and fine.

title: Section 330 – Voluntarily causing hurt to extort confession or compel restoration of property
content: Causing hurt to extort confession/information for offence detection/misconduct, or to compel restoration of property/valuable security, satisfy claim/demand, or give info for recovery – up to 7 years imprisonment and fine. Includes illustrations involving police, revenue officers, or landlords.

title: Section 331 – Voluntarily causing grievous hurt to extort confession or compel restoration of property
content: Causing grievous hurt for same purposes as in s.330 – up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 332 – Voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from duty
content: Causing hurt to deter public servant from duty or in consequence of lawful discharge – up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both. Maharashtra amendment: max 5 years.

title: Section 333 – Voluntarily causing grievous hurt to deter public servant from duty
content: Causing grievous hurt to deter/in consequence of public servant's duty – up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 334 – Voluntarily causing hurt on provocation
content: Causing hurt on grave and sudden provocation, without intent/knowledge to hurt others than provoker – up to 1 month imprisonment, or Rs 500 fine, or both.

title: Section 335 – Voluntarily causing grievous hurt on provocation
content: Causing grievous hurt on grave and sudden provocation, without intent/knowledge to hurt others than provoker – up to 4 years imprisonment, or Rs 2000 fine, or both. Subject to same provisos as Exception 1 to s.300.

title: Section 336 – Act endangering life or personal safety of others
content: Doing rash/negligent act endangering human life or personal safety – up to 3 months imprisonment, or Rs 250 fine, or both.

title: Section 337 – Causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others
content: Causing hurt by rash/negligent act endangering life/personal safety – up to 6 months imprisonment, or Rs 500 fine, or both.

title: Section 338 – Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others
content: Causing grievous hurt by rash/negligent act endangering life/personal safety – up to 2 years imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 339 – Wrongful restraint
content: Voluntarily obstructing any person from proceeding in direction they have a right to proceed. Exception for obstructing private way believed lawfully owned/obstructable in good faith. Illustration provided.

title: Section 340 – Wrongful confinement
content: Wrongfully restraining person to prevent them proceeding beyond circumscribing limits. Illustrations include locking in a walled space or guarding building exits.

title: Section 341 – Punishment for wrongful restraint
content: Punishable with up to 1 month simple imprisonment, or Rs 500 fine, or both.

title: Section 342 – Punishment for wrongful confinement
content: Punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 343 – Wrongful confinement for three or more days
content: Punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 344 – Wrongful confinement for ten or more days
content: Punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment, and fine.

title: Section 345 – Wrongful confinement of person for whose liberation writ has been issued
content: Keeping person in wrongful confinement knowing writ for liberation has been issued – up to 2 years imprisonment in addition to other punishment.

title: Section 346 – Wrongful confinement in secret
content: Wrongfully confining person intending their confinement may not be known to persons interested/public servant, or concealment of place – up to 2 years imprisonment in addition to other punishment.

title: Section 347 – Wrongful confinement to extort property or constrain to illegal act
content: Wrongfully confining person to extort property or valuable security or to constrain to illegal act/facilitate offence – up to 3 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 348 – Wrongful confinement to extort confession or compel restoration of property
content: Wrongfully confining person to extort confession/information for offence detection/misconduct, or to compel restoration of property/valuable security/satisfaction of claim/demand – up to 3 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 349 – Force
content: A person uses force on another if they cause motion, change of motion, or cessation of motion to that person or to any substance so that it comes into contact with that person’s body, clothing, or carried items, affecting their sense of feeling. Force must be caused: (1) by own bodily power; (2) by disposing a substance so motion occurs without further act; (3) by inducing an animal to move/change/stop.

title: Section 350 – Criminal force
content: Intentionally using force to any person without their consent, in order to commit an offence, or intending/knowing it likely to cause injury, fear, or annoyance. Includes various illustrations: unfastening moorings, lashing horses, seizing palanquin, pushing in street, throwing object to cause contact, pulling veil, pouring boiling water, inciting dog attack.

title: Section 351 – Assault
content: Making a gesture or preparation intending/knowing it likely to cause a person present to apprehend imminent use of criminal force. Mere words do not amount to assault but can add meaning to make gestures/preparations assault. Illustrations: shaking fist, unleashing dog, raising stick with threat.

title: Section 352 – Punishment for assault or criminal force otherwise than on grave provocation
content: Punishable with up to 3 months imprisonment, or fine up to Rs 500, or both. Grave and sudden provocation will not mitigate punishment if provoked/seeking excuse or given in lawful act/authority or lawful private defence. Provocation sufficiency is a question of fact.

title: Section 353 – Assault or criminal force to deter public servant from duty
content: Assault/criminal force to public servant in execution of duty, or to deter or in consequence of lawful duty – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both. Maharashtra amendment: max 5 years.

title: Section 354 – Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage modesty
content: Assault/criminal force to woman intending/knowing it likely to outrage her modesty – punishable with 1–5 years imprisonment and fine. Chhattisgarh proviso: if offender is relative, guardian, teacher, or in position of trust – 2–7 years and fine. Arunachal Pradesh: 2–7 years minimum.

title: Section 354A – Sexual harassment and punishment
content: A man commits sexual harassment if: (i) physical contact & unwelcome sexual overtures; (ii) demand/request for sexual favours; (iii) showing pornography against will; (iv) making sexually coloured remarks. Punishment: clauses (i)-(iii) – up to 3 years rigorous imprisonment, or fine, or both; clause (iv) – up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 354B – Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to disrobe
content: Any man assaulting/using criminal force to woman or abetting with intention to disrobe or compel nakedness – punishable with 3–7 years imprisonment and fine. Arunachal Pradesh: second/subsequent conviction – 7–10 years & fine min Rs 1 lakh.

title: Section 354C – Voyeurism
content: Watching, capturing image of woman in private act where she expects privacy, or disseminating such image: first conviction – 1–3 years imprisonment and fine; subsequent – 3–7 years and fine. 'Private act' includes exposure of intimate parts, using lavatory, or sexual act; non-consensual dissemination is an offence.

title: Section 354D – Stalking
content: Any man who (i) follows & repeatedly contacts woman despite disinterest; or (ii) monitors her electronic communication. Exceptions: prevention/detection of crime, legal compliance, reasonableness. Punishment: first – up to 3 years & fine; second/subsequent – up to 5 years & fine. Arunachal Pradesh: second/subsequent – 3–7 years & fine min Rs 1 lakh.

title: Section 354E – Sextortion
content: Whoever, being in authority/fiduciary/public servant, abuses position to coerce sexual favours from woman in exchange for benefits – punishable with 3–5 years rigorous imprisonment and fine. 'Sexual favour' includes unwanted sexual activity including electronic exposure. Chhattisgarh variant: liability for presence & failure to prevent/report offences under s.354/354A–D – up to 3 years or fine or both.

title: Section 355 – Assault or criminal force with intent to dishonour person
content: Assault/criminal force intending to dishonour person, otherwise than on grave & sudden provocation – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 356 – Assault or criminal force in attempt to commit theft of property carried by person
content: Assault/criminal force in attempting theft of property worn or carried – punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 357 – Assault or criminal force in attempt wrongfully to confine a person
content: Assault/criminal force in attempting wrongful confinement – punishable with up to 1 year imprisonment, or Rs 1000 fine, or both.

title: Section 358 – Assault or criminal force on grave provocation
content: Assault/criminal force on grave & sudden provocation – punishable with up to 1 month simple imprisonment, or Rs 200 fine, or both.

title: Section 359 – Kidnapping
content: Two kinds: (1) kidnapping from India; (2) kidnapping from lawful guardianship.

title: Section 360 – Kidnapping from India
content: Conveying any person beyond India without consent of person or legal consenter – kidnapping from India.

title: Section 361 – Kidnapping from lawful guardianship
content: Taking/enticing male under 16, female under 18, or person of unsound mind from lawful guardian without consent – kidnapping from lawful guardianship. 'Lawful guardian' includes anyone lawfully entrusted with care. Exception for good faith belief in paternity/right to custody unless for immoral/unlawful purpose.

title: Section 362 – Abduction
content: By force compelling, or by deceit inducing, any person to go from any place.

title: Section 363 – Punishment for kidnapping
content: Punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 363A – Kidnapping or maiming a minor for purposes of begging
content: Kidnapping/obtaining custody of minor for begging – up to 10 years and fine; maiming minor for begging – imprisonment for life and fine; employing minor for begging presumes kidnapping. Defines 'begging' and 'minor'.

title: Section 364 – Kidnapping or abducting in order to murder
content: Kidnapping/abduction to murder or dispose to danger of murder – life imprisonment or up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 364A – Kidnapping for ransom, etc.
content: Kidnapping/abduction or detention with threats/hurt/death to compel Government, foreign State, organisation or person to act/refrain or pay ransom – punishable with death or life imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 365 – Kidnapping or abducting with intent to secretly and wrongfully confine person
content: Punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 366 – Kidnapping, abducting or inducing woman to compel her marriage, etc.
content: Punishable with up to 10 years imprisonment and fine; includes inducement by threats/authority to go for illicit intercourse.

title: Section 366A – Procuration of minor girl
content: Inducing girl under 18 to go/do act intending/knowing likely to be forced/seduced to illicit intercourse – up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 366B – Importation of girl from foreign country
content: Importing girl under 21 from outside India or J&K intending/knowing likely to be forced/seduced to illicit intercourse – up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 367 – Kidnapping/abducting to subject person to grievous hurt, slavery, etc.
content: Punishable with up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 368 – Wrongfully concealing or keeping confined kidnapped/abducted person
content: Punishable as if had kidnapped/abducted with same intent/knowledge.

title: Section 369 – Kidnapping/abducting child under 10 with intent to steal from person
content: Punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 370 – Trafficking of person
content: Recruiting, transporting, harbouring, transferring, or receiving person by threats, force, coercion, abduction, fraud, abuse of power, or inducement for exploitation. 'Exploitation' includes physical/sexual exploitation, slavery, servitude, organ removal. Consent immaterial. Punishments: 7–10 years & fine; more for multiple persons minors, repeat, public servant involvement.

title: Section 370A – Exploitation of a trafficked person
content: Engaging trafficked minor for sexual exploitation – 5–7 years & fine; trafficked person (adult) – 3–5 years & fine.

title: Section 371 – Habitual dealing in slaves
content: Punishable with life imprisonment or up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 372 – Selling minor for purposes of prostitution, etc.
content: Punishable with up to 10 years imprisonment and fine; presumption if sold to prostitute/brothel-keeper. 'Illicit intercourse' defined.

title: Section 373 – Buying minor for purposes of prostitution, etc.
content: Punishable with up to 10 years imprisonment and fine; presumption for prostitutes/brothel-keepers; 'Illicit intercourse' as in s.372.

title: Section 374 – Unlawful compulsory labour
content: Compelling person to labour against will – up to 1 year imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 375 – Rape
content: A man commits rape if he: (a) penetrates penis into vagina/mouth/urethra/anus of woman; (b) inserts object/body part (not penis); (c) manipulates woman’s body to cause penetration; (d) applies mouth to genitalia/anus/urethra, under certain descriptions: against will; without consent; consent obtained by fear of death/hurt; consent believing man is husband; consent when unable to understand; under 18 years; unable to communicate consent. 'Vagina' includes labia majora; 'consent' means unequivocal voluntary agreement. Exceptions: medical procedure; intercourse with own wife over 15.

title: Section 376 – Punishment for rape
content: General cases – rigorous imprisonment 10 years to life and fine. Aggravated circumstances (police, public servant, armed forces, custodial situations, pregnancy, control/dominance, disability, grievous harm, repeated rape) – 10 years to life remainder of natural life and fine. Rape on woman under 16 – 20 years to life remainder of natural life and fine to victim. Explanation defines relevant terms.

title: Section 376A – Punishment for causing death or vegetative state in rape
content: If rape causes death or persistent vegetative state – punishable with minimum 20 years to life remainder of natural life, or death penalty.

title: Section 376AA – Punishment for rape on woman up to twelve years of age
content: Rape on woman up to 12 years – punishable with death, or rigorous imprisonment minimum 14 years to life remainder of natural life, and fine. Arunachal Pradesh provision.

title: Section 376DA – Punishment for gang rape on a woman twelve years of age
content: Where a woman up to twelve years of age is raped by one or more persons constituting a group or acting in furtherance of common intention, each shall be deemed to have committed rape and punished with death, or rigorous imprisonment not less than 20 years to life remainder of natural life, and fine just and reasonable to meet victim’s medical expenses and rehabilitation; fine to be paid to victim. Arunachal Pradesh provision.

title: Section 376AB – Punishment for rape on woman under twelve years of age
content: Rape on woman under 12 years – rigorous imprisonment not less than 20 years to life remainder of natural life, and fine, or death. Fine to be just and reasonable for victim’s medical expenses and rehabilitation, and paid to victim.

title: Section 376B – Sexual intercourse by husband upon his wife during separation
content: Sexual intercourse with own wife living separately, without her consent – punishable with imprisonment 2–7 years and fine. 'Sexual intercourse' means any act in clauses (a)–(d) of Section 375.

title: Section 376C – Sexual intercourse by a person in authority
content: Being in authority/fiduciary/public servant/superintendent or manager of custody or women’s/children’s institution or hospital, abusing position to induce/seduce woman in custody or charge to have sexual intercourse (not amounting to rape) – rigorous imprisonment 5–10 years and fine. 'Sexual intercourse' as per s.375(a)–(d); Explanation 1 to s.375 applies; 'Superintendent', 'hospital', 'women’s/children’s institution' defined.

title: Section 376D – Gang rape
content: Where a woman is raped by one or more persons constituting a group or acting in furtherance of common intention, each deemed to have committed rape – rigorous imprisonment not less than 20 years to life remainder of natural life, and fine just and reasonable for victim’s medical expenses and rehabilitation; fine to victim.

title: Section 376DA – Punishment for gang rape on woman under sixteen years of age
content: Where a woman under 16 is raped by group/acting in common intention – imprisonment for life remainder of natural life, and fine just and reasonable for victim’s medical expenses and rehabilitation; fine to victim.

title: Section 376DB – Punishment for gang rape on woman under twelve years of age
content: Where woman under 12 is raped by group/acting in common intention – imprisonment for life remainder of natural life and fine, or death. Fine to be just and reasonable for victim’s medical expenses and rehabilitation, and paid to victim.

title: Section 376E – Punishment for repeat offenders
content: Person previously convicted under s.376, 376A, 376AB, 376D, 376DA or 376DB, and subsequently convicted under any of these – punishment: life imprisonment remainder of natural life, or death.

title: Section 376F – Liability of person in charge of workplace and others to give information about offence
content: Chhattisgarh: Person in charge of workplace or any person present, knowing offence under s.376 or 376D is being committed and able to prevent it, who fails to prevent or to give info to magistrate/police with intent to screen offender – punishable for abetment with up to 3 years imprisonment and fine. 'Workplace' includes transport for conveyance of woman to/by work.

title: Section 377 – Unnatural offences
content: Voluntarily having carnal intercourse against the order of nature with man, woman, or animal – punishable with life imprisonment, or up to 10 years, and fine. Penetration sufficient.

title: Section 378 – Theft
content: Intending to take dishonestly any movable property out of possession without consent, moves it in order to taking – theft. Includes explanations on when property becomes movable, causing movement by various means, consent express/implied. Multiple illustrations provided.

title: Section 379 – Punishment for theft
content: Punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 379A – Snatching (Gujarat)
content: With theft intention, suddenly/quickly/forcibly taking movable property from person/physical possession and attempting escape – attempt: rigorous imprisonment 5–10 years & fine up to Rs 25,000; commit: RI 7–10 years & fine up to Rs 25,000; causing hurt/wrongful restraint/fear to escape – extra RI up to 3 years.

title: Section 379B – Snatching after preparation for causing death, hurt, restraint (Gujarat)
content: Committing/attempting snatching with preparation for causing death/hurt/restraint or fear thereof – RI 7–10 years and fine up to Rs 25,000.

title: Section 380 – Theft in dwelling house, etc.
content: Theft in any building, tent or vessel used as human dwelling or for custody of property – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 381 – Theft by clerk or servant of property in possession of master
content: Theft by clerk/servant of property in master/employer's possession – punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 382 – Theft after preparation for causing death, hurt or restraint
content: Committing theft with preparation for causing death/hurt/restraint/fear thereof to commit theft, escape, or retain property – RI up to 10 years and fine. Illustrations include being armed during theft or having accomplices ready to restrain victim.

title: Section 382A – Snatching (Tripura)
content: Stealthily/asault/criminal force to take property causing hurt/endangering life – offence of snatching.

title: Section 382B – Punishment for snatching (Tripura)
content: Punishable with 7–10 years imprisonment or fine or both.

title: Section 382C – Vehicle lifting (Tripura)
content: Theft of a vehicle from open or closed place – offence of vehicle lifting. 'Vehicle' as in s.2(28) Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

title: Section 382D – Punishment for vehicle lifting (Tripura)
content: Punishable with 7–10 years imprisonment or fine or both.

title: Section 382E – Cattle lifting (Tripura)
content: Theft of cattle from open or closed place – offence of cattle lifting. 'Cattle' includes cow, calf, bull, bullock, buffalo and calves, ox/oxen.

title: Section 382F – Punishment for cattle lifting (Tripura)
content: Punishable with 7–10 years imprisonment or fine or both.

title: Section 383 – Extortion
content: Intentionally putting person in fear of injury and thereby dishonestly inducing delivery of property/valuable security/thing signed or sealed convertible to valuable security – extortion. Includes illustrations: threats to publish libel, confine child, destroy crops, cause hurt to obtain signed paper.

title: Section 384 – Punishment for extortion
content: Punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 385 – Putting person in fear of injury in order to commit extortion
content: Punishable with up to 2 years imprisonment, or fine, or both.

title: Section 386 – Extortion by putting person in fear of death or grievous hurt
content: Punishable with up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 387 – Putting person in fear of death or grievous hurt in order to commit extortion
content: Punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.

title: Section 388 – Extortion by threat of accusation of offence punishable with death, life imprisonment, etc.
content: Extortion by putting person in fear of accusation of offence punishable with death/life imprisonment/10 years/attempt thereof – punishable with up to 10 years imprisonment and fine; if under s.377 – may be life imprisonment.

title: Section 389 – Putting person in fear of accusation in order to commit extortion
content: Punishable with up to 10 years imprisonment and fine; if offence punishable under s.377 – may be life imprisonment.

title: Section 390 – Robbery
content: In all robbery there is either theft or extortion. Theft is robbery if, in committing/carrying away property, offender voluntarily causes/attempts to cause death, hurt, wrongful restraint, or fear of instant death/hurt/restraint. Extortion is robbery if, in presence of victim, offender puts in fear of instant death/hurt/restraint to deliver thing extorted. Offender is 'present' if near enough to cause such fear. Illustrations include theft with restraint, armed extortion, threats to child in presence, etc.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 391. Dacoity
content: When five or more persons conjointly commit or attempt to commit a robbery, or where the whole number of persons conjointly committing or attempting to commit a robbery, together with persons present and aiding such commission or attempt, amounts to five or more, every person so committing, attempting, or aiding is said to commit 'dacoity'.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 392. Punishment for robbery
content: Whoever commits robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. If the robbery is committed on the highway between sunset and sunrise, the imprisonment may be extended to fourteen years.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 393. Attempt to commit robbery
content: Whoever attempts to commit robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 394. Voluntarily causing hurt in committing robbery
content: If any person, in committing or attempting to commit robbery, voluntarily causes hurt, such person and any other person jointly concerned in committing or attempting to commit such robbery shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 395. Punishment for dacoity
content: Whoever commits dacoity shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 396. Dacoity with murder
content: If any one of five or more persons, who are conjointly committing dacoity, commits murder during such commission, every one of those persons shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 397. Robbery, or dacoity, with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt
content: If, at the time of committing robbery or dacoity, the offender uses any deadly weapon, causes grievous hurt, or attempts to cause death or grievous hurt to any person, the imprisonment shall not be less than seven years.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 398. Attempt to commit robbery or dacoity when armed with deadly weapon
content: If, at the time of attempting to commit robbery or dacoity, the offender is armed with any deadly weapon, the imprisonment shall not be less than seven years.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 399. Making preparation to commit dacoity
content: Whoever makes any preparation for committing dacoity shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 400. Punishment for belonging to gang of dacoits
content: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, belongs to a gang of persons associated for the purpose of habitually committing dacoity shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 401. Punishment for belonging to gang of thieves
content: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, belongs to any wandering or other gang of persons associated for the purpose of habitually committing theft or robbery, and not being a gang of thugs or dacoits, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 402. Assembling for purpose of committing dacoity
content: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, is one of five or more persons assembled for the purpose of committing dacoity, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 403. Dishonest misappropriation of property
content:
Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use any movable property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

Illustrations:
(a) A takes property belonging to Z out of Z's possession, in good faith believing at the time that the property belongs to himself. A is not guilty of theft; but if A, after discovering his mistake, dishonestly appropriates the property to his own use, he is guilty under this section.
(b) A, being on friendly terms with Z, goes into Z's library in his absence and takes a book without Z's express consent. If A believed he had Z's implied consent to take it to read, there is no theft. If he later sells it for his own benefit, he is guilty under this section.
(c) A and B, joint owners of a horse, A takes the horse from B's possession intending to use it. As joint owner, A has right to use it, so no offence. But if A sells it and keeps proceeds, he is guilty.

Explanation 1: Dishonest misappropriation for a time only is still misappropriation.
Illustration: A finds a Government promissory note belonging to Z, pledges it knowing it belongs to Z, intending to return later — this is an offence.

Explanation 2: A person who finds property and takes it to protect or return to the owner does not commit an offence unless he appropriates it knowing or having means to find the owner, before taking reasonable steps and keeping it for a reasonable time.

Further Illustrations cover cases of finding coins, letters with bank notes, cheques, lost purses, or valuable items without attempts to find owners — in all such, misappropriation amounts to an offence under this section.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 404. Dishonest misappropriation of property possessed by deceased person at death
content:
Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use property, knowing that such property was in the possession of a deceased person at the time of death, and has not since been in possession of any legally entitled person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine. If the offender at the time of death was employed by the deceased as a clerk or servant, imprisonment may extend to seven years.

Illustration: Z dies in possession of furniture and money. His servant A, before the money comes to any person entitled, dishonestly misappropriates it. A has committed the offence defined in this section.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 405. Criminal breach of trust
content:
Whoever, being entrusted with property or with dominion over it, dishonestly misappropriates or converts it to his own use, or dishonestly uses or disposes of it in violation of legal directions or contract, or wilfully suffers another to do so, commits criminal breach of trust.

Explanation 1: An employer, regardless of exemption under section 17 of Employees’ Provident Funds and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1952, who deducts employee’s contribution and fails to pay into the Provident or Family Pension Fund, is deemed entrusted and guilty if in default.

Explanation 2: An employer who deducts employees’ contribution for the Employees’ State Insurance Fund and defaults in paying it to the Fund is likewise deemed guilty.

Illustrations include cases of executors misappropriating estate assets, warehouse-keepers selling goods entrusted for safekeeping, agents disobeying investment instructions for personal gain, revenue officers appropriating public money, and carriers misappropriating goods entrusted — in all cases, if dishonest intent is present, it constitutes criminal breach of trust.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 406. Punishment for criminal breach of trust
content: Whoever commits criminal breach of trust shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 407. Criminal breach of trust by carrier, etc.
content: Whoever, being entrusted with property as a carrier, wharfinger or warehouse-keeper, commits criminal breach of trust in respect of such property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 408. Criminal breach of trust by clerk or servant
content: Whoever, being a clerk or servant, or employed as such, and being entrusted in such capacity with property or dominion over it, commits criminal breach of trust in respect of that property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 409. Criminal breach of trust by public servant, or banker, merchant or agent
content: Whoever, being entrusted with property or with any dominion over property in the capacity of a public servant or in the way of business as a banker, merchant, factor, broker, attorney or agent, commits criminal breach of trust in respect of that property, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 410. Stolen property
content: Property whose possession has been transferred by theft, extortion, or robbery, or property criminally misappropriated, or subject to criminal breach of trust, is designated as 'stolen property', whether the act occurred within or outside India. If such property later comes into the possession of a person legally entitled to it, it ceases to be stolen property.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 411. Dishonestly receiving stolen property
content: Whoever dishonestly receives or retains any stolen property, knowing or having reason to believe it to be stolen, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 412. Dishonestly receiving property stolen in the commission of a dacoity
content: Whoever dishonestly receives or retains any stolen property, knowing or having reason to believe it to have been transferred by commission of dacoity, or receives from a person known to belong to a gang of dacoits property known or believed to be stolen, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for up to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 413. Habitually dealing in stolen property
content: Whoever habitually receives or deals in property knowing or having reason to believe it to be stolen property shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 414. Assisting in concealment of stolen property
content: Whoever voluntarily assists in concealing, disposing of, or making away with property known or believed to be stolen property shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 415. Cheating
content:
Whoever, by deceiving any person, fraudulently or dishonestly induces them to deliver property, allow retention of property, or to do or omit something they would not otherwise do, causing harm to body, mind, reputation, or property, is said to cheat. Dishonest concealment of facts is deception.

Illustrations range from false claims of status, forging trademarks, showing false samples, issuing worthless bills, pledging fake valuables, making false promises to repay loans or deliver goods, falsifying contract performance, or selling property already sold without disclosing prior sale — all with dishonest intent, constitute cheating.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 416. Cheating by personation
content:
A person cheats by pretending to be someone else, knowingly substituting one person for another, or representing themselves or someone else as a different person — whether the impersonated person is real or imaginary.

Illustrations: (a) Pretending to be a banker of same name; (b) Pretending to be a deceased person.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 417. Punishment for cheating
content: Whoever cheats shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 418. Cheating with knowledge that wrongful loss may ensue to person whose interest offender is bound to protect
content: Whoever cheats knowing that wrongful loss is likely to be caused to a person whose interest in the transaction he was bound by law or contract to protect, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 419. Punishment for cheating by personation
content: Whoever cheats by personation shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 420. Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property
content: Whoever cheats and thereby dishonestly induces the person deceived to deliver any property, or to make, alter, or destroy the whole or part of a valuable security, or anything signed or sealed capable of being converted into a valuable security, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 421. Dishonest or fraudulent removal or concealment of property to prevent distribution among creditors
content: Whoever dishonestly or fraudulently removes, conceals, delivers or transfers any property without adequate consideration, intending or knowing that he will thereby prevent the distribution of that property according to law among his creditors or the creditors of any other person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 422. Dishonestly or fraudulently preventing debt being available for creditors
content: Whoever dishonestly or fraudulently prevents any debt or demand due to himself or to any other person from being made available according to law for payment of his debts or the debts of such other person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 423. Dishonest or fraudulent execution of deed of transfer containing false statement of consideration
content: Whoever dishonestly or fraudulently signs, executes or becomes a party to any deed or instrument purporting to transfer or subject to charge any property or interest therein, containing any false statement relating to the consideration or to the person or persons for whose use or benefit it is really intended, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 424. Dishonest or fraudulent removal or concealment of property
content: Whoever dishonestly or fraudulently conceals or removes any property of himself or of any other person, or dishonestly or fraudulently assists in such concealment or removal, or dishonestly releases any demand or claim to which he is entitled, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 425. Mischief
content:
Whoever with intent to cause, or knowing that he is likely to cause, wrongful loss or damage to the public or any person, causes destruction or any such change in any property as destroys or diminishes its value or affects it injuriously, commits mischief.

Explanations:
1. It is not necessary that the loss or damage be to the owner; it suffices that wrongful loss or damage to any person results.
2. Mischief may be committed by acts affecting one's own property or jointly owned property.

Illustrations include burning securities, causing ice to melt, throwing rings into rivers, destroying effects about to be taken in execution, causing ships to be cast away, shooting jointly owned animals, and causing damage to crops.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 426. Punishment for mischief
content: Whoever commits mischief shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 427. Mischief causing damage to the amount of fifty rupees
content: Whoever commits mischief causing loss or damage to the amount of fifty rupees or upwards shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 428. Mischief by killing or maiming animal of the value of ten rupees
content: Whoever commits mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any animal or animals of value ten rupees or upwards shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 429. Mischief by killing or maiming cattle etc., of any value or any animal of the value of fifty rupees
content: Whoever commits mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any elephant, camel, horse, mule, buffalo, bull, cow or ox or any other animal of value fifty rupees or upwards shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 430. Mischief by injury to works of irrigation or by wrongfully diverting water
content: Whoever commits mischief by causing or likely to cause diminution in water supply for agricultural or other specified purposes shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 431. Mischief by injury to public road, bridge, river or channel
content: Whoever commits mischief by making or likely to make any public road, bridge, navigable river or channel impassable or less safe for travel or conveying property shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 432. Mischief by causing inundation or obstruction to public drainage attended with damage
content: Whoever commits mischief by causing or likely to cause inundation or obstruction to public drainage attended with injury or damage shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.
