title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 433. Mischief by destroying, moving or rendering less useful a light-house or sea-mark
content: Whoever commits mischief by destroying, moving or making less useful any lighthouse, sea-mark, buoy or guide for navigators shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 434. Mischief by destroying or moving a land-mark fixed by public authority
content: Whoever commits mischief by destroying or moving any landmark fixed by public authority, or by making it less useful as such, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 435. Mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to cause damage to amount of one hundred or (in case of agricultural produce) ten rupees
content: Whoever commits mischief by fire or explosive substance intending or knowing it likely to cause damage to property to the amount of one hundred rupees or upwards, or ten rupees or upwards in the case of agricultural produce, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 436. Mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to destroy house etc.
content: Whoever commits mischief by fire or explosive substance intending or knowing it likely to cause destruction of any building ordinarily used as a place of worship, human dwelling, or custody of property, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 437. Mischief with intent to destroy or make unsafe a decked vessel or one of twenty tons burden
content: Whoever commits mischief to any decked vessel or vessel of twenty tons burden or upwards intending or knowing it likely to destroy or render unsafe that vessel shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 438. Punishment for mischief described in section 437 committed by fire or explosive substance
content: Whoever commits or attempts to commit the mischief described in section 437 by fire or explosive substance shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 439. Punishment for intentionally running vessel aground or ashore with intent to commit theft etc.
content: Whoever intentionally runs any vessel aground or ashore intending to commit theft of any property contained therein or to dishonestly misappropriate any such property, or with intent that such theft or misappropriation may be committed, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 440. Mischief committed after preparation made for causing death or hurt
content: Whoever commits mischief, having made preparation for causing death, hurt, wrongful restraint, or fear of death, hurt, or wrongful restraint to any person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 441. Criminal trespass
content:
Whoever enters into or upon property in possession of another with intent to commit an offence or to intimidate, insult or annoy any person in possession, or having lawfully entered unlawfully remains there with such intent, or with intent to commit an offence, commits criminal trespass.

Orissa Amendment adds that unlawfully remaining with intention of taking unauthorized possession or use and failing to withdraw when notified in writing by another person is also criminal trespass.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 442. House-trespass
content:
Whoever commits criminal trespass by entering or remaining in any building, tent, or vessel used as human dwelling, place of worship, or for custody of property is said to commit house-trespass.

Introduction of any part of the body is sufficient to constitute entry.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 443. Lurking house-trespass
content: Whoever commits house-trespass having taken precautions to conceal from a person entitled to exclude or eject the trespasser from the premises commits lurking house-trespass.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 444. Lurking house-trespass by night
content: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass after sunset and before sunrise commits lurking house-trespass by night.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 445. House-breaking
content:
House-breaking is house-trespass if the entrance or exit is effected in any of six specified ways including making passages, entering unintentional passages for human entrance, opening passages not intended to be opened, opening locks, using force or assault, or entering through fastened passages unfastened by self or abettor.

Explanation notes out-houses or buildings with immediate internal communication as part of the house.

Illustrations show various examples of entering by hole, window, door, lifting latch, using lost key, forcing passage, or deterring door-keeper by threat.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 446. House-breaking by night
content: Whoever commits house-breaking after sunset and before sunrise is said to commit house-breaking by night.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 447. Punishment for criminal trespass
content: Whoever commits criminal trespass shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine up to five hundred rupees, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 448. Punishment for house-trespass
content: Whoever commits house-trespass shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine up to one thousand rupees, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 449. House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with death
content: Whoever commits house-trespass in order to commit any offence punishable with death shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and also liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 450. House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment for life
content: Whoever commits house-trespass in order to commit any offence punishable with imprisonment for life shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding ten years, and also liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 451. House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment
content: Whoever commits house-trespass to commit any offence punishable with imprisonment shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term that may extend to two years, and also liable to fine; if the offence is theft, imprisonment may extend to seven years.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 452. House-trespass after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint
content: Whoever commits house-trespass having prepared to cause hurt, assault, wrongful restraint, or fear of any such shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term that may extend to seven years, and also liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 453. Punishment for lurking house-trespass or house-breaking
content: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass or house-breaking shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, and also liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 454. Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment
content: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass or house-breaking to commit any offence punishable with imprisonment shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and also liable to fine; if the offence is theft, imprisonment may extend to ten years.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 455. Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint
content: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass or house-breaking having prepared to cause hurt, assault, wrongful restraint, or fear thereof, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for up to ten years, and also liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 456. Punishment for lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night
content: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass by night, or house-breaking by night, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and also liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 457. Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment
content: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass by night, or house-breaking by night, to commit an offence punishable with imprisonment shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, and also liable to fine; if the offence is theft, imprisonment may extend to fourteen years.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 458. Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint
content: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass by night, or house-breaking by night, having prepared to cause hurt, assault, wrongful restraint, or fear thereof, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to fourteen years, and also liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 459. Grievous hurt caused whilst committing lurking house-trespass or house-breaking
content: Whoever, while committing lurking house-trespass or house-breaking, causes grievous hurt to any person or attempts to cause death or grievous hurt, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for up to ten years, and also liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 460. All persons jointly concerned in lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night punishable where death or grievous hurt caused by one of them
content: If, at the time of the committing of lurking house-trespass by night or house-breaking by night, any person guilty of such offence voluntarily causes or attempts to cause death or grievous hurt to any person, every person jointly concerned in committing such offence shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 461. Dishonestly breaking open receptacle containing property
content: Whoever dishonestly, or with intent to commit mischief, breaks open or unfastens any closed receptacle which contains, or which he believes to contain, property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 462. Punishment for same offence when committed by person entrusted with custody
content: Whoever, being entrusted with any closed receptacle which contains or which he believes to contain property, without authority to open it, dishonestly, or with intent to commit mischief, breaks open or unfastens that receptacle, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 463. Forgery
content: Whoever makes any false document or false electronic record, or part thereof, with intent to cause damage or injury to the public or any person, to support any claim or title, to cause any person to part with property, to enter into any contract, or with intent to commit fraud or that fraud may be committed, commits forgery.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 464. Making a false document
content:
A person is said to make a false document or false electronic record—
First: Who dishonestly or fraudulently— makes, signs, seals, or executes a document or part thereof; makes or transmits any electronic record; affixes any electronic signature on any electronic record; or makes any mark denoting execution or authenticity of such signature, with intention to cause it to be believed it was made, signed, sealed, executed, transmitted, or affixed by or with the authority of someone by whom or whose authority he knows it was not.
Secondly: Who, without lawful authority, dishonestly or fraudulently alters a document or electronic record in any material part after it has been executed, whether by himself or another, living or dead.
Thirdly: Who dishonestly or fraudulently causes someone to sign, seal, execute or alter a document or electronic record, or affix their electronic signature, knowing that such person cannot due to unsoundness of mind or intoxication, or is deceived about its contents or nature of alteration.

Numerous illustrations are provided in the Code, showing examples such as altering financial figures, falsifying wills, forging cheques, antedating documents to defraud, signing another's name without authority, etc.

Explanation 1: Signing one's own name may amount to forgery if done to impersonate another of same name.
Explanation 2: Making a false document in the name of a fictitious or deceased person, intending it to be believed genuine, may amount to forgery.
Explanation 3: 'Affixing electronic signature' has the meaning given in the Information Technology Act, 2000.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 465. Punishment for forgery
content: Whoever commits forgery shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 466. Forgery of record of Court or of public register, etc.
content:
Whoever forges a document or an electronic record purporting to be a record or proceeding of or in a Court of Justice, or a register of birth, baptism, marriage, or burial, or a register kept by a public servant, or a certificate or document made by a public servant in official capacity, or an authority to take legal steps such as instituting or defending a suit, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
Explanation: 'Register' includes any list, data or record maintained in electronic form as per the Information Technology Act, 2000.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 467. Forgery of valuable security, will, etc.
content: Whoever forges a document purporting to be a valuable security, a will, an authority to adopt a son, an authority to make or transfer a valuable security, to receive principal, interest or dividends thereon, or to receive/deliver any money, property, or acquittance/receipt for the same, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 468. Forgery for purpose of cheating
content: Whoever commits forgery intending that the forged document or electronic record shall be used for the purpose of cheating shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 469. Forgery for purpose of harming reputation
content: Whoever commits forgery intending that the forged document or electronic record shall harm the reputation of any party, or knowing it likely to be so used, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 470. Forged document
content: A false document or electronic record made wholly or in part by forgery is designated 'a forged document or electronic record'.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 471. Using as genuine a forged document or electronic record
content: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly uses as genuine any document or electronic record which he knows or has reason to believe to be forged, shall be punished in the same manner as if he had forged it.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 472. Making or possessing counterfeit seal, etc., with intent to commit forgery punishable under section 467
content: Whoever makes or counterfeits any seal, plate or other instrument for making an impression, intending it to be used for committing forgery punishable under section 467, or possesses such knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 473. Making or possessing counterfeit seal, etc., with intent to commit forgery punishable otherwise
content: Whoever makes or counterfeits any seal, plate or other instrument for making an impression, intending it to be used for committing forgery punishable under any section other than section 467, or possesses such knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 474. Having possession of document described in section 466 or 467, knowing it to be forged and intending to use it as genuine
content: Whoever possesses any document or electronic record knowing it to be forged and intending to use it fraudulently or dishonestly as genuine, if it is of the type in section 466, shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and fine; if it is of the type in section 467, punishment is imprisonment for life or imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 475. Counterfeiting device or mark used for authenticating documents described in section 467, or possessing counterfeit marked material
content: Whoever counterfeits on any material any device or mark used to authenticate a document described in section 467, intending it to give appearance of authenticity to any document forged or to be forged thereon, or who possesses such material knowing the same to be counterfeit, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for up to seven years, and fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 476. Counterfeiting device or mark used for authenticating documents other than those described in section 467, or possessing counterfeit marked material
content: Whoever counterfeits upon any material any device or mark used to authenticate any document or electronic record other than those described in section 467, intending it to be used for appearance of authenticity to any document forged or to be forged thereon, or possessing such material knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 477. Fraudulent cancellation, destruction, etc., of will, authority to adopt, or valuable security
content: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly, or intending to cause damage or injury to the public or to any person, cancels, destroys, defaces, or attempts the same, or secretes, any will, authority to adopt a son, or valuable security, or commits mischief in respect of such document, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for up to seven years, and fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 477A. Falsification of accounts
content:
Whoever, being a clerk, officer or servant, or acting as such, wilfully and with intent to defraud, destroys, alters, mutilates or falsifies any book, electronic record, paper, writing, valuable security or account belonging to or in possession of his employer, or makes/abets any false entry, or omits/alters any material particular therein, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for up to seven years, or with fine, or with both.
Explanation: It is sufficient to allege a general intent to defraud without naming a particular person defrauded or amount of money or exact date.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 479. Property mark
content: A mark used for denoting that movable property belongs to a particular person is called a property mark.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 481. Using a false property mark
content: Whoever marks any movable property or goods, or any receptacle containing them, or uses such receptacle, in a manner reasonably calculated to cause it to be believed that they belong to someone to whom they do not, is said to use a false property mark.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 482. Punishment for using a false property mark
content: Whoever uses any false property mark, unless proving no intent to defraud, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for up to one year, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 483. Counterfeiting a property mark used by another
content: Whoever counterfeits any property mark used by another person shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for up to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 484. Counterfeiting a mark used by a public servant
content: Whoever counterfeits any property mark used by a public servant, or a mark denoting origin, quality, manufacture, or exemption status, or uses as genuine such counterfeit mark, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for up to three years, and fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 485. Making or possession of any instrument for counterfeiting a property mark
content: Whoever makes or possesses any die, plate or instrument for counterfeiting a property mark, or possesses a property mark for denoting goods belonging to someone to whom they do not, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for up to three years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 486. Selling goods marked with a counterfeit property mark
content: Whoever sells, exposes, or possesses for sale goods with a counterfeit property mark, unless proving reasonable precautions and innocence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for up to one year, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 487. Making a false mark upon any receptacle containing goods
content: Whoever makes any false mark on a receptacle containing goods to mislead any person or public servant about its contents or their nature/quality, unless proving no intent to defraud, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for up to three years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 488. Punishment for making use of any such false mark
content: Whoever makes use of any false mark prohibited by section 487, unless proving no intent to defraud, shall be punished as if he committed an offence under section 487.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 489. Tampering with property mark with intent to cause injury
content: Whoever removes, destroys, defaces or adds to any property mark, intending or knowing it likely to cause injury to any person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for up to one year, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 489A. Counterfeiting currency-notes or bank-notes
content:
Whoever counterfeits, or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting, any currency-note or bank-note, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for up to ten years, and fine.
Explanation: 'Bank-note' includes promissory notes or engagements issued by any banking entity or state authority to be used as money.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 489B. Using as genuine, forged or counterfeit currency-notes or bank-notes
content: Whoever sells, buys, receives, trafficks in, or uses as genuine any forged or counterfeit currency-note or bank-note, knowing or having reason to believe it to be such, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for up to ten years, and fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 489C. Possession of forged or counterfeit currency-notes or bank-notes
content: Whoever possesses forged or counterfeit currency-note or bank-note, knowing or having reason to believe it to be such and intending to use it as genuine, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for up to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 489D. Making or possessing instruments or materials for forging or counterfeiting currency-notes or bank-notes
content: Whoever makes or performs any part of making, or buys, sells, disposes of, or possesses any machinery, instrument, or material for forging or counterfeiting any currency-note or bank-note, intending to use it or knowing it is intended to be used for such purpose, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for up to ten years, and fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 489E. Making or using documents resembling currency-notes or bank-notes
content: Whoever makes, causes to be made, uses, or delivers to any person any document purporting to be, or resembling so as to be likely to deceive, any currency-note or bank-note shall be punished with fine up to one hundred rupees. Refusal to disclose printer/maker when required by police is punishable with fine up to two hundred rupees. Name appearing on such document is presumed maker unless proved otherwise.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 491. Breach of contract to attend on and supply wants of helpless person
content: Whoever, being bound by lawful contract to attend on or supply the wants of any person helpless due to youth, unsoundness of mind, disease, or bodily weakness, voluntarily omits to do so, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description up to three months, or fine up to two hundred rupees, or both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 493. Cohabitation caused by a man deceitfully inducing a belief of lawful marriage
content: Every man who by deceit causes any woman not lawfully married to him to believe that she is lawfully married to him, and to cohabit or have sexual intercourse in that belief, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 494. Marrying again during lifetime of husband or wife
content:
Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries in any case in which such marriage is void by reason of taking place during the lifetime of such spouse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and fine.
Exception: Does not apply where the marriage has been declared void by a competent Court, or where the spouse has been continually absent for seven years and not heard of as alive within that time, provided the person contracting such marriage informs the other party of such facts before the marriage.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 495. Same offence with concealment of former marriage from person with whom subsequent marriage is contracted
content: Whoever commits the offence defined in the last preceding section (Section 494) having concealed from the person with whom the subsequent marriage is contracted the fact of the former marriage, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 496. Marriage ceremony fraudulently gone through without lawful marriage
content: Whoever, dishonestly or with a fraudulent intention, goes through the ceremony of being married, knowing that he is not thereby lawfully married, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 497. Adultery
content: Whoever has sexual intercourse with a person who is, and whom he knows or has reason to believe to be, the wife of another man, without the consent or connivance of that man, such sexual intercourse not amounting to rape, is guilty of adultery, and shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or both. In such case the wife shall not be punishable as an abettor.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 498. Enticing or taking away or detaining with criminal intent a married woman
content: Whoever takes or entices away any woman who is, and whom he knows or has reason to believe to be, the wife of any other man, from that man or from any person having the care of her on his behalf, with intent that she may have illicit intercourse with any person, or conceals or detains with that intent any such woman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 498A. Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty
content:
Whoever, being the husband or the relative of the husband of a woman, subjects her to cruelty shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
Explanation: 'Cruelty' means—(a) any wilful conduct likely to drive the woman to commit suicide or cause grave injury or danger to her life, limb or health (mental or physical); or (b) harassment where such harassment is to coerce her or her relatives to meet unlawful demands for property or valuable security, or is on account of failure to meet such demand.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 499. Defamation
content:
Whoever, by words, spoken or intended to be read, by signs, or visible representations, makes or publishes an imputation concerning any person, intending to harm, or knowing or having reason to believe it will harm, the reputation of such person, is said—except in the cases hereinafter excepted—to defame that person.
Explanations: (1) Can apply to imputations about a deceased person if it would harm their reputation if living and is intended to hurt feelings of family or relatives. (2) Applies to companies or collections of persons. (3) Imputations in the form of alternatives or irony may amount to defamation. (4) No imputation harms unless it lowers a person's character, credit, or causes belief of a disgraceful bodily condition.
Ten exceptions are recognized, including: imputation of truth for public good, opinions on public conduct of public servants or persons in public questions, true reports of judicial proceedings, fair opinions on merits of decided cases or public performances, good faith censures by authority, good faith accusations to lawful authorities, good faith imputations for protection of interests, and good faith cautions for the good of the recipient or public.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 500. Punishment for defamation
content: Whoever defames another shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 501. Printing or engraving matter known to be defamatory
content: Whoever prints or engraves any matter knowing or having good reason to believe that it is defamatory of any person, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 502. Sale of printed or engraved substance containing defamatory matter
content: Whoever sells or offers for sale any printed or engraved substance containing defamatory matter, knowing it contains such matter, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 503. Criminal intimidation
content:
Whoever threatens another with injury to his person, reputation, or property, or to the person or reputation of anyone in whom he is interested, with intent to cause alarm to that person, or to cause him to do an unlawful act or omit a lawful act as a means of avoiding execution of such threat, commits criminal intimidation.
Explanation: Threat to injure the reputation of a deceased person in whom the threatened person is interested is within this section.
Illustration: A threatens to burn B's house to induce B to withdraw a civil suit—A is guilty.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 504. Intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace
content: Whoever intentionally insults, giving provocation to any person intending or knowing it likely to cause him to break public peace or commit an offence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 505. Statements conducing to public mischief
content:
(1) Whoever makes, publishes, or circulates any statement, rumour, or report—(a) With intent to cause, or likely to cause, mutiny or disregard of duty among armed forces; or (b) With intent to cause, or likely to cause, fear or alarm to the public leading to an offence against the State or public tranquility; or (c) With intent to incite, or likely to incite, any class or community to commit offences against another class/community, shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years, or with fine, or both.
(2) Whoever makes, publishes, or circulates any such matter with intent to create or promote enmity, hatred or ill-will between groups on grounds such as religion, race, language, caste, etc., shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years, or with fine, or both.
(3) If such offence in (2) is committed in a place of worship or during religious ceremonies, punishment may extend to five years and fine.
Exception: No offence if person had reasonable grounds to believe it true, acted in good faith, and without such illegal intent.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 506. Punishment for criminal intimidation
content:
Whoever commits criminal intimidation shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
If the threat is to cause death or grievous hurt, to destroy property by fire, to commit an offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to seven years, or to impute unchastity to a woman, punishment may extend to seven years and fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 507. Criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication
content: Whoever commits criminal intimidation by anonymous communication, or takes precaution to conceal the name or abode of the person from whom the threat comes, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, in addition to the punishment for the offence under section 506.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 508. Act caused by inducing person to believe he will be rendered an object of Divine displeasure
content:
Whoever voluntarily causes or attempts to cause a person to do something not legally bound to do, or omit something legally entitled to do, by inducing belief that non-compliance will render him or someone he cares about an object of Divine displeasure, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for up to one year, or with fine, or both.
Illustrations: (a) A sits dhurna at Z's door to cause belief Z becomes object of Divine displeasure—offence committed. (b) A threatens to kill his own child to render Z an object of Divine displeasure if Z does not act—offence committed.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 509. Word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman
content:
Whoever, intending to insult the modesty of any woman, utters words, makes any sound or gesture, or exhibits any object intending it to be heard or seen by such woman, or intrudes upon her privacy, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, and fine.
State Amendment (Chhattisgarh): Introduces Sections 509A and 509B—(a) 509A: Sexual harassment by relative—punishable with rigorous imprisonment from one to five years and fine. (b) 509B: Sexual harassment by electronic mode—punishable with rigorous imprisonment from six months to two years and fine.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 510. Misconduct in public by a drunken person
content: Whoever, in a state of intoxication, appears in a public place, or a place trespassed into, and conducts himself so as to cause annoyance to any person, shall be punished with simple imprisonment up to 24 hours, or with fine up to ten rupees, or with both.

title: Indian Penal Code, 1860 - Section 511. Punishment for attempting to commit offences punishable with imprisonment for life or other imprisonment
content:
Whoever attempts to commit an offence punishable by this Code with imprisonment for life or other imprisonment, or to cause such offence to be committed, and does any act towards its commission, shall, where no express provision exists for punishment of such attempt, be punished with imprisonment up to one-half of the maximum term provided for the offence, or fine, or both.
Illustrations: (a) A breaks open a box to steal jewels but finds none—attempt to commit theft. (b) A thrusts his hand into Z's pocket to pick it but finds nothing—attempt to commit theft.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 1: Short title, extent and commencement
content: 1. This Act may be called the Maternity Benefit Act, 1961. 2. It extends to the whole of India. 3. It shall come into force on such date as may be notified in this behalf in the Official Gazette: (a) in relation to mines and to any other establishment wherein persons are employed for the exhibition of equestrian, acrobatic, and other performances, by the Central Government; and (b) in relation to other establishments in a State, by the State Government.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 2: Application of Act
content: 1. It applies, in the first instance,— (a) to every establishment being a factory, mine or plantation, including any such establishment belonging to Government, and to every establishment wherein persons are employed for the exhibition of equestrian, acrobatic and other performances; (b) to every shop or establishment within the meaning of any law for the time being in force in relation to shops and establishments in a State, in which ten or more persons are employed, or were employed, on any day of the preceding twelve months. Provided that the State Government may, with the approval of the Central Government, after giving not less than two months’ notice of its intention so to do, by notification in the Official Gazette, declare that all or any of the provisions of this Act shall apply also to any other establishment or class of establishments, industrial, commercial, agricultural or otherwise. 2. Save as otherwise provided in sections 5A and 5B, nothing contained in this Act shall apply to any factory or other establishment to which the provisions of the Employees’ State Insurance Act, 1948, apply for the time being.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 3: Definitions
content: In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires: (a) "appropriate Government" means, in relation to an establishment being a mine, or an establishment wherein persons are employed for the exhibition of equestrian, acrobatic and other performances, the Central Government, and in relation to any other establishment, the State Government; (b) "child" includes a still-born child; (ba) "commissioning mother" means a biological mother who uses her egg to create an embryo implanted in any other woman; (c) "delivery" means the birth of a child; (d) "employer" means— (i) in relation to an establishment under the control of the Government, a person or authority appointed by the Government for supervision and control of employees, or where none is appointed, the head of the department; (ii) in relation to an establishment under any local authority, the person appointed by such authority for supervision and control of employees, or where none is appointed, the chief executive officer of the local authority; (iii) in any other case, the person or authority with ultimate control over the affairs of the establishment, and where the affairs are entrusted to another person, whether called a manager, managing director, managing agent, or by any other name, such person; (e) "establishment" means— (i) a factory; (ii) a mine; (iii) a plantation; (iv) an establishment wherein persons are employed for the exhibition of equestrian, acrobatic and other performances; (iva) a shop or establishment; or (v) an establishment to which the provisions of this Act have been declared applicable under sub-section (1) of section 2; (f) "factory" means a factory as defined in clause (m) of section 2 of the Factories Act, 1948; (g) "Inspector" means an Inspector appointed under section 14; (h) "maternity benefit" means the payment referred to in sub-section (1) of section 5; (ha) "medical termination of pregnancy" means the termination permissible under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971; (i) "mine" means a mine as defined in clause (j) of section 2 of the Mines Act, 1952; (j) "miscarriage" means expulsion of the contents of a pregnant uterus at any time prior to or during the twenty-sixth week of pregnancy, but does not include any miscarriage punishable under the Indian Penal Code; (k) "plantation" means a plantation as defined in clause (f) of section 2 of the Plantations Labour Act, 1951; (l) "prescribed" means prescribed by rules made under this Act; (m) "State Government" in relation to a Union territory means the Administrator thereof; (n) "wages" means all remuneration paid or payable in cash to a woman if the terms of the contract of employment were fulfilled, and includes— (1) cash allowances (including dearness and house rent allowance); (2) incentive bonus; (3) money value of concessional supply of food grains and other articles; but does not include— (i) any bonus other than incentive bonus; (ii) overtime earnings, fines, or deductions; (iii) any contribution to a pension or provident fund; (iv) any gratuity payable on termination of service; (o) "woman" means a woman employed, whether directly or through any agency, for wages in any establishment.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 4: Employment of, or work by, women prohibited during certain periods
content: (1) No employer shall knowingly employ a woman in any establishment during the six weeks immediately following the day of her delivery, miscarriage, or medical termination of pregnancy. (2) No woman shall work in any establishment during the six weeks immediately following the day of her delivery, miscarriage, or medical termination of pregnancy. (3) Without prejudice to section 6, no pregnant woman shall, on a request being made by her in this behalf, be required by her employer to do, during the period specified in sub-section (4), any work that is arduous, involves long hours of standing, is likely to interfere with her pregnancy or normal development of the foetus, is likely to cause her miscarriage, or adversely affect her health. (4) The period referred to in sub-section (3) shall be: (a) the period of one month immediately preceding the period of six weeks before the expected delivery date; and (b) any period during the said six weeks for which the pregnant woman does not avail leave of absence under section 6.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 5: Right to payment of maternity benefit
content:
(1) Subject to the provisions of this Act, every woman shall be entitled to, and her employer shall be liable for, the payment of maternity benefit at the rate of the average daily wage for the period of her actual absence, that is, the period immediately preceding the day of her delivery, the actual day of her delivery, and any period immediately following that day. Explanation: For the purposes of this sub-section, the average daily wage means the average of the woman’s wages payable for the days on which she worked during the three calendar months immediately preceding the date from which she absents herself on account of maternity, the minimum rate of wage fixed or revised under the Minimum Wages Act, 1948, or ten rupees, whichever is the highest.

(2) No woman shall be entitled to maternity benefit unless she has actually worked in an establishment of the employer from whom she claims benefit for not less than eighty days in the twelve months immediately preceding the expected date of delivery. Provided that this qualifying period shall not apply to a woman who has immigrated into the State of Assam while already pregnant at the time of immigration. Explanation: For calculating days actually worked, the days for which she was laid off or was on holidays declared under any law to be with wages during the said twelve months shall be counted.

(3) The maximum period for which any woman shall be entitled to maternity benefit shall be twenty-six weeks, of which not more than eight weeks shall precede the date of her expected delivery. Provided that for a woman having two or more surviving children, the entitlement shall be twelve weeks, of which not more than six weeks shall precede the expected delivery date. Provided further that if a woman dies during this period, the maternity benefit shall be payable only for the days up to and including the day of her death. Provided also that where a woman, having been delivered of a child, dies during her delivery or during the period of maternity benefit for which she is otherwise entitled, leaving behind the child, the employer shall be liable to pay maternity benefit for the whole period. If the child also dies during that period, payment shall be made only up to and including the day of the child’s death.

(4) A woman who legally adopts a child below the age of three months or a commissioning mother shall be entitled to maternity benefit for twelve weeks from the date the child is handed over to her.

(5) Where the nature of work assigned to a woman is such that she may work from home, the employer may allow her to do so after she has availed maternity benefit, for such period and on such conditions as may be mutually agreed.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 6: Notice of claim for maternity benefit and payment thereof
content:
(1) Any woman employed in an establishment and entitled to maternity benefit under this Act may give written notice, in such form as may be prescribed, to her employer stating that her maternity benefit and any other amount to which she is entitled under this Act may be paid to her or to a nominee named in the notice, and that she will not work in any establishment during the period for which she receives maternity benefit.

(2) In the case of a pregnant woman, such notice shall state the date from which she will be absent from work, not being earlier than six weeks from her expected date of delivery.

(3) Any woman who has not given such notice when pregnant may give the notice as soon as possible after delivery.

(4) On receipt of the notice, the employer shall permit the woman to absent herself from the establishment during the period for which she receives maternity benefit.

(5) The amount of maternity benefit for the period preceding the expected delivery date shall be paid in advance by the employer upon production of prescribed proof of pregnancy, and the amount for the subsequent period shall be paid within forty-eight hours of production of prescribed proof that the woman has been delivered of a child.

(6) Failure to give notice under this section shall not disentitle a woman from maternity benefit or other amounts if otherwise entitled. In such cases, an Inspector may, on his own motion or on application by the woman, order payment within a specified period.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 7: Payment of maternity benefit in case of death of a woman
content: If a woman entitled to maternity benefit or any other amount under this Act dies before receiving it, or where the employer is liable for maternity benefit under the second proviso to sub-section (3) of section 5, the employer shall pay such benefit or amount to the person nominated by the woman in the notice under section 6, and where there is no nominee, to her legal representative.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 8: Payment of medical bonus
content:
(1) Every woman entitled to maternity benefit under this Act shall also be entitled to receive from her employer a medical bonus of one thousand rupees, if no pre-natal confinement and post-natal care is provided free of charge by the employer.

(2) The Central Government may, before every three years, by notification in the Official Gazette, increase the amount of the medical bonus up to a maximum of twenty thousand rupees.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 9: Leave for miscarriage, etc.
content: In case of miscarriage or medical termination of pregnancy, a woman shall, on production of prescribed proof, be entitled to leave with wages at the maternity benefit rate for six weeks immediately following the day of her miscarriage or medical termination of pregnancy.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 9A: Leave with wages for tubectomy operation
content: In case of tubectomy operation, a woman shall, on production of prescribed proof, be entitled to leave with wages at the maternity benefit rate for two weeks immediately following the day of her tubectomy operation.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 10: Leave for illness arising out of pregnancy, delivery, premature birth of child, miscarriage, medical termination of pregnancy or tubectomy operation
content: A woman suffering from illness arising out of pregnancy, delivery, premature birth of a child, miscarriage, medical termination of pregnancy, or tubectomy operation shall, on production of prescribed proof, be entitled, in addition to the period of absence allowed under section 6 or section 9, to leave with wages at the rate of maternity benefit for a maximum period of one month.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 11: Nursing breaks
content: Every woman who has been delivered of a child and returns to duty shall, in addition to the interval for rest allowed to her, be allowed during her daily work two breaks of the prescribed duration for nursing the child until the child attains the age of fifteen months.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 11A: Crèche facility
content:
(1) Every establishment having fifty or more employees shall provide a crèche facility within the prescribed distance, either separately or along with common facilities. The employer shall allow four visits a day to the crèche by the woman, including the interval for rest allowed to her.

(2) Every establishment shall inform in writing and electronically to every woman, at the time of her initial appointment, regarding all benefits available under this Act.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 12: Dismissal during absence of pregnancy
content:
(1) It shall be unlawful for an employer to discharge or dismiss a woman during or on account of her absence in accordance with this Act, to give notice of dismissal such that the notice will expire during such absence, or to vary to her disadvantage any condition of service.

(2)(a) Discharge or dismissal of a woman during pregnancy, where she would have been entitled to maternity benefit or medical bonus, shall not deprive her of such benefit or bonus. However, if dismissal is for prescribed gross misconduct, the employer may, by written order, deprive her of such benefit or bonus or both.

(b) Any woman deprived of maternity benefit or medical bonus, or both, or discharged or dismissed during or on account of such absence, may within sixty days of communication of the order, appeal to the prescribed authority, whose decision shall be final.

(c) This sub-section does not affect the provisions of sub-section (1).

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 13: No deduction of wages in certain cases
content: No deduction from the normal daily wages of a woman entitled to maternity benefit shall be made by reason only of: (a) the nature of work assigned to her under section 4(3); or (b) breaks for nursing the child allowed under section 11.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 14: Appointment of Inspectors
content: The appropriate Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, appoint such officers as it deems fit to be Inspectors for the purposes of this Act and may define their jurisdiction.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 15: Powers and duties of Inspectors
content: An Inspector may, subject to prescribed restrictions or conditions: (a) enter at reasonable times, with assistants, any premises where women are employed to examine registers, records, and notices required under this Act; (b) examine any person found in such premises who is reasonably believed to be employed there, provided no one is compelled to answer self-incriminating questions; (c) require the employer to provide information regarding women employed, their payments, and applications or notices received under this Act; (d) take copies of registers, records, or notices or parts thereof.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 16: Inspectors to be public servants
content: Every Inspector appointed under this Act shall be deemed to be a public servant within the meaning of section 21 of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860).

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 17: Power of Inspector to direct payments to be made
content:
(1) Any woman claiming that maternity benefit or any amount due to her under this Act, or any person claiming that payment due under section 7 has been improperly withheld, or that she was discharged or dismissed during or on account of her absence under this Act, may complain to the Inspector.

(2) The Inspector may, on his own or upon such complaint, conduct or cause an inquiry and, if satisfied that payment has been wrongfully withheld, direct such payment, or if she was wrongfully discharged or dismissed, pass just and proper orders.

(3) Any person aggrieved by the Inspector’s decision may, within thirty days of its communication, appeal to the prescribed authority.

(4) The prescribed authority’s decision, or that of the Inspector if no appeal is preferred, shall be final.

(5) Any amount payable under this section shall be recoverable by the Collector, on a certificate issued by the Inspector, as an arrear of land revenue.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 18: Forfeiture of maternity benefit
content: If a woman works in any establishment after being permitted to absent herself under section 6, she shall forfeit her claim to maternity benefit for the period she so works.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 19: Abstract of Act and rules thereunder to be exhibited
content: An abstract of this Act and the rules made under it, in the language(s) of the locality, shall be displayed conspicuously by the employer in every part of the establishment where women are employed.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 20: Registers, etc.
content: Every employer shall prepare and maintain prescribed registers, records, and muster rolls in the prescribed manner.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 21: Penalty for contravention of Act by employer
content:
(1) If any employer fails to pay any amount of maternity benefit to a woman entitled under this Act or discharges or dismisses such woman during or on account of her absence from work in accordance with this Act, he shall be punishable with imprisonment of not less than three months and up to one year, and with fine of not less than two thousand rupees and up to five thousand rupees. Provided that the court may, for recorded sufficient reasons, impose a lesser term of imprisonment or fine instead of imprisonment.

(2) If any employer contravenes the provisions of this Act or the rules made thereunder, and no other penalty is elsewhere provided for such contravention, he shall be punishable with imprisonment up to one year, or with fine up to five thousand rupees, or both. Provided that where the contravention relates to maternity benefit or payment of any other amount and the same has not yet been recovered, the court shall also recover such benefit or amount as if it were a fine, and pay it to the person entitled.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 22: Penalty for obstructing Inspector
content: Whoever fails to produce on demand by the Inspector any register or document kept under this Act or rules, or conceals or prevents any person from appearing before or being examined by an Inspector, shall be punishable with imprisonment up to one year, or with fine up to five thousand rupees, or with both.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 23: Cognizance of offences
content:
(1) Any aggrieved woman, an office-bearer of her registered trade union, a registered voluntary organisation, or an Inspector may file a complaint regarding the commission of an offence under this Act in any court of competent jurisdiction. No such complaint shall be filed after one year from the date of the alleged offence.

(2) No court inferior to that of a Metropolitan Magistrate or a Magistrate of the first class shall try any offence under this Act.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 24: Protection of action taken in good faith
content: No suit, prosecution, or other legal proceeding shall lie against any person for anything done or intended to be done in good faith in pursuance of this Act or any rule or order made thereunder.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 25: Power of Central Government to give directions
content: The Central Government may give such directions as it deems necessary to a State Government regarding the execution of the provisions of this Act, and the State Government shall comply with such directions.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 26: Power to exempt establishments
content: If the appropriate Government is satisfied that an establishment or class of establishments provides for benefits not less favourable than those under this Act, it may, by notification in the Official Gazette, exempt them from all or any provisions of this Act or its rules, subject to specified conditions or restrictions.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 27: Effect of laws and agreements inconsistent with this Act
content:
(1) The provisions of this Act override any inconsistent provision in any other law or in any award, agreement, or contract of service, whether made before or after commencement of this Act. Provided that if under such award, agreement, or contract a woman is entitled to more favourable benefits on any matter than under this Act, she shall continue to get the more favourable benefits for that matter.

(2) This Act does not prevent a woman from entering into an agreement with her employer for more favourable rights or privileges than those provided under this Act.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 28: Power to make rules
content:
(1) The appropriate Government may, after previous publication and by notification in the Official Gazette, make rules to carry out the purposes of this Act.

(2) Such rules may provide for: (a) preparation and maintenance of registers, records, and muster-rolls; (b) exercise of powers by Inspectors and performance of duties; (c) method of payment of maternity and other benefits; (d) form of notices under section 6; (e) nature of proof required under the Act; (f) duration of nursing breaks under section 11; (g) acts constituting gross misconduct for section 12; (h) appeal authority under section 12(2)(b), its form, manner, and procedure; (i) appeal authority under section 17, its form, manner, and procedure; (j) form and manner of complaints under section 17(1) and inquiry procedure; (k) any other prescribed matter.

(3) Every rule made by the Central Government shall be laid before both Houses of Parliament for thirty days, which may be in one or more successive sessions, and is subject to modification or annulment by both Houses, without affecting the validity of anything done previously under that rule.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 29: Amendment of Act 69 of 1951
content: In section 32 of the Plantations Labour Act, 1951: (a) in sub-section (1), the letter and brackets “(a)” before 'in the case of sickness', the word 'and' after 'sickness allowance', and clause (b) shall be omitted; (b) in sub-section (2), the words 'or maternity' shall be omitted.

title: Maternity Benefit Act, 1961 - Section 30: Repeal
content: On the application of this Act: (i) to mines, the Mines Maternity Benefit Act, 1941 (19 of 1941); and (ii) to factories in the Union territory of Delhi, the Bombay Maternity Benefit Act, 1929 (Bom. Act VII of 1929) as in force in that territory, shall stand repealed.

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - Section 1
content:
(1) These rules may be called the Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021.
(2) They shall come into force on the date of their publication in the Official Gazette.

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - Section 2
content: In the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016 (hereinafter referred to as the said rules), in rule 2, in sub-rule (1), after the word 'Importers', the words 'brand-owner, plastic waste processor (recycler, co-processor, etc.)' shall be inserted.

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - Sections 3 and 4
content:
In the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016, in rule 3:
(i) After clause (n), the following clause shall be inserted:
'(na) "Non-woven plastic bag" means a non-woven plastic bag made up of a plastic sheet or web-structured fabric of entangled plastic fibers or filaments (and by perforating films) bonded together by mechanical, thermal, or chemical means. The "non-woven fabric" means a flat or tufted porous sheet that is made directly from plastic fibres, molten plastic, or plastic films.'

(ii) After clause (q), the following clause shall be inserted:
'(qa) "Plastic waste processing" means any process by which plastic waste is handled for the purpose of reuse, recycling, co-processing, or transformation into new products.'

(iii) After clause (v), the following clauses shall be inserted:
'(va) "Single-use plastic commodity" means a plastic item intended to be used once for the same purpose before being disposed of or recycled.'
'(vb) "Thermoset plastic" means a plastic which becomes irreversibly rigid when heated and hence cannot be remoulded into a desired shape.'
'(vc) "Thermoplastic" means a plastic which softens on heating and can be moulded into a desired shape.'

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - Amendments to Rule 4
content:
In the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016, in rule 4:
(a) In sub-rule (1):
(i) For the words 'importer stocking', the words 'import, stocking' shall be substituted.
(ii) In clause (c), for the words 'fifty microns in thickness', the words, figures, letters, and brackets 'seventy-five microns in thickness with effect from the 30th September, 2021, and one hundred and twenty (120) microns in thickness with effect from the 31st December, 2022' shall be substituted.
(iii) In clause (h), after the words 'carry bags', the words 'and commodities' shall be inserted.
(iv) In clause (h), after the words 'compostable plastic carry bags', the words 'or commodities or both' shall be inserted.
(v) After clause (i), the following clause shall be inserted:
'(j) Non-woven plastic carry bag shall not be less than 60 Gram Per Square Meter (GSM) with effect from the 30th September, 2021.'

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - New Sub-Rules under Rule 4
content:
After sub-rule (1) of rule 4, the following sub-rules shall be inserted:
(2) The manufacture, import, stocking, distribution, sale, and use of the following single-use plastic items, including polystyrene and expanded polystyrene, shall be prohibited with effect from 1st July, 2022:
(a) Ear buds with plastic sticks, plastic sticks for balloons, plastic flags, candy sticks, ice-cream sticks, polystyrene (Thermocol) for decoration.
(b) Plates, cups, glasses, cutlery such as forks, spoons, knives, straws, trays, wrapping or packing films around sweet boxes, invitation cards, and cigarette packets, plastic or PVC banners less than 100 microns, stirrers.

(3) The provisions of sub-rule (2)(b) shall not apply to commodities made of compostable plastic.

(4) Any notification prohibiting the manufacture, import, stocking, distribution, sale, and use of carry bags, plastic sheets or similar items, covers made of plastic sheets, multi-layered packaging, and single-use plastic (including polystyrene and expanded polystyrene) commodities, issued after this notification, shall come into force after the expiry of ten years from the date of its publication.

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - Section 5
content: In the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016, in rule 5, in sub-rule (1), in clause (d), for the figures '2000', the figures '2016' shall be substituted.

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - Section 6
content:
In the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016, in rule 6, in sub-rule (2), after clause (a), the following clause shall be inserted:
'(aa) ensuring that the provisions of these rules, as amended, are adhered to;'.

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - Section 7
content:
In the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016, in rule 7, in sub-rule (1), after clause (a), the following clause shall be inserted:
'(aa) ensuring that the provisions of these rules, as amended, are adhered to;'.

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - Section 8
content: In the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016, in rule 9, in sub-rule (1), after the words 'local body concerned', the words 'as per guidelines issued under these rules from time to time' shall be inserted.

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - Sections 9 and 10
content:
In the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016, in rule 11, sub-rule (1):
(i) After the words 'plastic carry bag', the words 'plastic packaging' shall be inserted.
(ii) In clause (a), after the word 'manufacturer', the words 'producer or brand owner' shall be inserted, and after the words 'carry bag', the words 'and plastic packaging used by the brand owner' shall be inserted.
(iii) In clause (b), after the words 'multilayered packaging', the words 'excluding multi-layered packaging used for imported goods' shall be inserted.
(iv) In clause (c), after the words 'name and certificate number', the words 'of producer' shall be inserted.

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - Rule 12
content:
In the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016, in rule 12:
(i) In sub-rule (2), after the words 'waste generator,', the words 'restriction or prohibition on' shall be inserted.
(ii) In sub-rule (3), after the words 'waste generator,', the words 'restriction or prohibition on' shall be inserted.

title: Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2021 - Rule 13
content: In the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016, in rule 13, in sub-rule (1), after the words 'Union Territory concerned', the words 'or the Central Pollution Control Board' shall be inserted.

title: Police Act - Section 1: Interpretation Clause
content: The following words and expressions in this Act shall have the meanings assigned to them, unless there is something in the subject or context repugnant to such construction: "Magistrate of the district" means the chief officer charged with the executive administration of a district and exercising the powers of a Magistrate, regardless of the official designation of such officer; "Magistrate" includes all persons within the general police district exercising all or any of the powers of a Magistrate; "Police" includes all persons enrolled under this Act; "general police-district" embraces any presidency, State, place, or part thereof in which this Act is ordered to take effect; the terms "District Superintendent" and "District Superintendent of Police" include any Assistant District Superintendent or any other person appointed by general or special order of the State Government to perform all or any duties of a District Superintendent of Police under this Act in any district; "property" includes any movable property, money, or valuable security; "person" includes a company or corporation; "month" means a calendar month; "cattle" includes horned cattle, elephants, camels, horses, asses, mules, sheep, goats, and swine; references to the subordinate ranks of a police force shall be construed as references to members of that force below the rank of Deputy Superintendent.

title: Police Act - Section 2: Constitution of the Force
content: The entire police-establishment under a State Government shall, for the purposes of this Act, be deemed to be one police force and shall be formally enrolled. It shall consist of such number of officers and men, and shall be constituted in such manner, as may from time to time be ordered by the State Government. Subject to the provisions of this Act, the pay and all other conditions of service of members of the subordinate ranks of any police-force shall be such as may be determined by the State Government. COMMENTS: The entire police-establishment under a State Government is deemed to be one police-force.

title: Police Act - Section 3: Superintendence in the State Government
content: The superintendence of the police throughout a general police-district shall vest in and be exercised by the State Government to which such district is subordinate. Except as authorized under the provisions of this Act, no person or officer of Court shall be empowered by the State Government to supersede or control any police functionary. COMMENTS: The superintendence of the police has to be exercised by the State Government.

title: Police Act - Section 4: Inspector-General of Police, etc.
content: The administration of the police throughout a general police-district shall be vested in an officer styled the Inspector-General of Police, and in such Deputy Inspectors-General and Assistant Inspectors-General as the State Government shall deem fit. The administration of the police throughout the local jurisdiction of the Magistrate of the district shall, under the general control and direction of such Magistrate, be vested in a District Superintendent and such Assistant District Superintendents as the State Government shall consider necessary. COMMENTS: The administration of the police vests in the Inspector-General of Police, supported by Deputy Inspectors-General, Assistant Inspectors-General, District Superintendents, and Assistant District Superintendents.

title: Police Act - Section 5: Powers of Inspector-General
content: The Inspector-General of Police shall have the full powers of a Magistrate throughout the general police-district, but shall exercise those powers subject to such limitation as may, from time to time, be imposed by the State Government. COMMENTS: The State Government may impose any limitation on the powers of the Inspector-General of Police.

title: Police Act - Section 6: Magisterial Powers of Police Officers
content: [Repealed by the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1882 (10 of 1882), sec. 2 and Schedule 1(b)].

title: Police Act - Section 7: Appointment, Dismissal, etc. of Inferior Officers
content: Subject to the provisions of Article 311 of the Constitution, and to such rules as the State Government may, from time to time, make under this Act, the Inspector-General, Deputy Inspectors-General, Assistant Inspectors-General, and District Superintendents of Police may at any time dismiss, suspend, or reduce any police-officer of the subordinate ranks whom they think remiss or negligent in the discharge of duty, or unfit for service. They may also award any of the following punishments to such officers for careless or negligent discharge of duty, or for acts rendering them unfit for duty: (a) fine not exceeding one month's pay; (b) confinement to quarters for a term not exceeding fifteen days, with or without punishment-drill, extra guard, fatigue, or other duty; (c) deprivation of good-conduct pay; (d) removal from any office of distinction or special emolument. COMMENTS: These provisions govern appointment, dismissal, and disciplinary actions for subordinate police officers such as Inspectors, Sub-Inspectors, Assistant Sub-Inspectors, and Constables.

title: Police Act - Section 8: Certificates to Police Officers
content: Every police-officer appointed to the police force, other than an officer mentioned in Section 4, shall receive on appointment a certificate in the form annexed to this Act, under the seal of the Inspector-General or such other officer as the Inspector-General may appoint. This certificate vests the person named with the powers, functions, and privileges of a police-officer. Such certificate shall cease to have effect when the person ceases to be a police-officer for any reason, and must be surrendered to an officer empowered to receive it. A police-officer under suspension does not cease to be such an officer; however, during suspension, his powers, functions, and privileges are in abeyance, though he remains subject to the same responsibilities, discipline, penalties, and authorities as if not suspended. COMMENTS: A certificate is issued to every police-officer upon appointment, and is surrendered upon cessation of office.

title: Police Act - Section 9: Police-Officers Not to Resign Without Leave or Notice
content: No police-officer may withdraw from the duties of office unless expressly permitted by the District Superintendent or another authorized officer. No resignation may be made without such leave unless the officer has given written notice to his superior at least two months in advance of his intention to resign. COMMENTS: No police-officer may (a) withdraw from duties without permission, or (b) resign without giving at least two months' notice.

title: Police Act - Section 10: Police-Officers Not to Engage in Other Employment
content: No police-officer shall engage in any employment or office other than his duties under this Act, unless expressly permitted in writing by the Inspector-General. COMMENTS: Police officers must obtain written permission from the Inspector-General before undertaking any other employment.

title: Police Act - Section 11: Police Superannuation Fund
content: [Repealed by the Repealing Act, 1874 (16 of 1874), section 1 and Schedule, Part I].

title: Police Act - Section 12: Power of Inspector-General to Make Rules
content: The Inspector-General of Police may, from time to time, subject to the approval of the State Government, frame such orders and rules as deemed expedient regarding: (a) the organisation, classification, and distribution of the police-force; (b) the places where members of the force shall reside; (c) the particular services to be performed by them; (d) their inspection; (e) the description of arms, accoutrements, and other necessities to be furnished to them; (f) the collection and communication of intelligence and information; and (g) all other orders and rules to prevent abuse or neglect of duty and to render the force efficient in discharging its duties. COMMENTS: Subject to State Government approval, the Inspector-General may frame rules and orders concerning various operational and organisational aspects of the police force.

title: Police Act - Section 13: Additional Police Officers Employed at Cost of Individuals
content: The Inspector-General of Police, any Deputy Inspector-General, Assistant Inspector-General, or the District Superintendent (subject to the general direction of the Magistrate of the district), may, on the application of any person showing necessity, depute additional police-officers to keep the peace at any place within the general police-district for such time as deemed proper. The force remains under the orders of the District Superintendent and at the expense of the applicant. The applicant may require withdrawal of the deputed officers by giving one month's written notice to the appropriate authority, and shall then be relieved of the cost from the expiration of the notice. COMMENTS: On an applicant's request showing necessity, additional police can be employed at their cost until withdrawn.

title: Police Act - Section 14: Appointment of Additional Force in the Neighbourhood of Railway and Other Works
content: When any railway, canal, other public work, manufactory, or commercial concern is in operation, and the Inspector-General considers additional police necessary due to the behaviour or anticipated behaviour of those employed, the Inspector-General, with the consent of the State Government, may depute such force to the site. The cost is charged to the person having custody or control of the funds for carrying on such work or concern. This arrangement continues as long as the necessity persists, and orders for payment may be made from time to time. COMMENTS: Additional police may be posted near major works or industries if required, at the expense of the controlling authority.

title: Police Act - Section 15: Quartering of Additional Police in Disturbed or Dangerous Districts
content: (1) The State Government may, by proclamation in the Official Gazette and otherwise as directed, declare any area in its jurisdiction to be disturbed or dangerous, or that it is expedient to increase the number of police there. (2) With the State Government's sanction, the Inspector-General or authorised officer may quarter additional police in the proclaimed area. (3) The cost is borne by the inhabitants of the area unless exempt under sub-section (5). (4) The Magistrate shall apportion the cost among liable inhabitants according to their means. (5) The State Government may exempt individuals or groups from paying. (6) Proclamations specify the period in force but can be withdrawn or extended. Explanation: "Inhabitants" includes persons occupying property or collecting rents in the area, even if non-resident.
