COMMENTS: The State Government can declare areas disturbed or dangerous, levy costs on inhabitants, and adjust or withdraw the proclamation.

title: Police Act - Section 15A: Awarding Compensation to Sufferers from Misconduct of Inhabitants or Persons Interested in Land
content: (1) In areas under a Section 15 proclamation, if death, grievous hurt, or property loss/damage results from the misconduct of inhabitants (or a class/section of them), affected inhabitants may claim compensation from the Magistrate within one month of the injury (or a shorter prescribed period). (2) With State Government sanction, the Magistrate may: (a) declare the injured parties; (b) fix and distribute compensation; and (c) assess the proportion payable by non-exempt inhabitants other than the applicant. The Magistrate must be satisfied the injury resulted from a riot or unlawful assembly and that the injured party was free from blame. (3) The State Government may exempt any persons or class from paying. (4) Decisions are subject to revision by the Commissioner or State Government but otherwise final. (5) No civil suit is maintainable for awarded compensation. (6) Explanation: 'Inhabitants' has the same meaning as in Section 15. COMMENTS: Provides for official compensation awards for damages caused by misconduct in disturbed/dangerous areas.

title: Police Act - Section 16: Recovery of Moneys Payable Under Sections 13, 14, 15 and 15A, and Disposal of Same When Recovered
content: (1) Moneys payable under Sections 13, 14, 15, and 15A are recoverable by the Magistrate as per Sections 386 and 387 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1882 (or equivalent provisions in updated laws), or by suit in any competent court. (3) Moneys paid or recovered under Section 15A are to be paid by the Magistrate to eligible persons in the proportions determined. COMMENTS: The Magistrate can recover payable amounts under these sections via criminal procedure recovery provisions or civil suit, and must disburse Section 15A funds to entitled recipients.

title: Police Act - Section 17: Special Police-Officers
content: If an unlawful assembly, riot, or disturbance of the peace occurs or is anticipated, and the regular police are insufficient, any police-officer not below Inspector may apply to the nearest Magistrate to appoint residents of the area as special police-officers for a set time and within defined limits. The Magistrate shall generally comply unless there is reason to refuse. COMMENTS: Authorises temporary special police appointments from local residents during threats to public peace.

title: Police Act - Section 18: Powers of Special Police-Officers
content: Special police-officers have the same powers, privileges, protections, duties, penalties, and subordination as ordinary police officers. COMMENTS: Special police have full parity with regular police in powers and responsibilities during their service.

title: Police Act - Section 19: Refusal to Serve as Special Police-Officers
content: Any person appointed as a special police-officer who, without sufficient excuse, neglects or refuses to serve or to obey lawful orders or directions for duty performance, is liable on conviction before a Magistrate to a fine not exceeding fifty rupees for each instance of neglect, refusal, or disobedience. COMMENTS: Criminalises unjustified refusal or neglect of duty by appointed special police officers.

title: Police Act - Section 20: Authority to be Exercised by Police-Officers
content: Police officers enrolled under this Act may only exercise the authority provided under this Act and any future Act regulating criminal procedure. COMMENTS: Limits police authority strictly to statutory powers under relevant criminal procedure laws.

title: Police Act - Section 21: Village Police-Officers
content: Nothing in this Act shall affect any hereditary or other village police-officer unless such officer is enrolled as a police-officer under this Act. When so enrolled, such officer shall be bound by the provisions of the last preceding section. No hereditary or other village police-officer shall be enrolled without his consent and the consent of those with the right of nomination. Police chaukidars in the Presidency of Fort William: If any police-officer appointed under Act XX of 1856 for police-chaukidars in cities, towns, stations, suburbs, and bazaars in the Presidency of Fort William in Bengal is employed outside the district for which he was appointed under that Act, he shall not be paid from the rates levied under the said Act for that district. COMMENTS: No hereditary or other police-officer is affected by this Act unless enrolled under it.

title: Police Act - Section 22: Police-Officers Always on Duty and May Be Employed in Any Part of District
content: Every police-officer shall, for all purposes under this Act, be considered to be always on duty, and may, at any time, be employed as a police-officer in any part of the general police-district. COMMENTS: Every police-officer is considered always on duty and can be deployed anywhere in the general police-district.

title: Police Act - Section 23: Duties of Police-Officers
content: It is the duty of every police-officer to promptly obey and execute all lawful orders and warrants issued by competent authority; to collect and communicate intelligence affecting public peace; to prevent offences and public nuisances; to detect and bring offenders to justice; and to apprehend all persons legally authorised to be apprehended and for whose apprehension sufficient grounds exist. For these purposes, every police-officer may, without a warrant, enter and inspect any drinking-shop, gaming-house, or other place of resort of loose and disorderly characters. COMMENTS: Authorises police to inspect certain premises without warrant in furtherance of their duties.

title: Police Act - Section 24: Police-Officer May Lay Information, etc.
content: Any police-officer may lay information before a Magistrate and apply for a summons, warrant, search warrant, or other legal process as may, by law, be issued against any person committing an offence. COMMENTS: Permits police to apply to a Magistrate for various judicial processes in relation to offences.

title: Police Act - Section 25: Police-Officers to Take Charge of Unclaimed Property and Be Subject to Magistrate's Orders as to Disposal
content: Every police-officer must take charge of all unclaimed property and furnish an inventory to the District Magistrate, who will issue orders for its disposal. COMMENTS: Police are duty-bound to secure unclaimed property, inventory it, and follow disposal instructions from the Magistrate.

title: Police Act - Section 26: Magistrate May Detain Property and Issue Proclamation
content: The District Magistrate may detain unclaimed property and issue a proclamation specifying its articles and requiring any claimant to appear and prove their right within six months from the date of proclamation. The provisions of Section 525 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1882 apply to property referred to here. COMMENTS: The Magistrate must publicly announce unclaimed property and invite claims within a specified period.

title: Police Act - Section 27: Confiscation of Property if No Claimant Appears
content: If no claimant appears within the prescribed period, unclaimed property (or its sale proceeds) may be sold under orders of the District Magistrate. Sale proceeds of property with no established claim shall be at the disposal of the State Government. COMMENTS: Enables sale of unclaimed property and government ownership of proceeds after the claim period expires.

title: Police Act - Section 28: Persons Refusing to Deliver Up Certificate, etc., On Ceasing to Be Police-Officers
content: Any person who ceases to be an enrolled police-officer and fails to deliver up his certificate, clothing, accoutrements, appointments, and other supplied necessaries shall be liable, on conviction before a Magistrate, to a penalty up to two hundred rupees, or imprisonment up to six months (with or without hard labour), or both. COMMENTS: Penalises ex-officers who fail to return government-issued items.

title: Police Act - Section 29: Penalties for Neglect of Duty, etc.
content: A police-officer guilty of violating duty, wilfully breaching or neglecting any lawful order, withdrawing from duties without permission or adequate notice, failing to return from leave without reasonable cause, engaging in unauthorised employment, showing cowardice, or offering unwarranted personal violence to a person in custody is liable, on conviction before a Magistrate, to a penalty up to three months’ pay, or imprisonment up to three months (with or without hard labour), or both. COMMENTS: Lists offences and penalties applicable to police for misconduct.

title: Police Act - Section 30: Regulation of Public Assemblies and Processions and Licensing of the Same
content: The District Superintendent or Assistant District Superintendent of Police may direct the conduct of assemblies and processions on public roads, streets, or thoroughfares, prescribing routes and times. If necessary to prevent breaches of peace, they may require organisers to apply for a license, which may be issued with specified names and conditions. No fee shall be charged for such a license. They may also regulate the extent to which music may be used in streets during festivals and ceremonies. COMMENTS: Grants police powers to regulate public gatherings, processions, and associated activities.

title: Police Act - Section 30A: Powers with Regard to Assemblies and Processions Violating Conditions of Licence
content: A Magistrate, District Superintendent, Assistant District Superintendent, Inspector of Police, or Officer in Charge of a station may stop any procession or disperse any assembly violating license conditions, and such gatherings refusing to comply are deemed unlawful assemblies. COMMENTS: Allows police to take action against licensed events that breach their conditions.

title: Police Act - Section 31: Police to Keep Order on Public Roads, etc.
content: Police must maintain order on public roads, streets, thoroughfares, ghats, landing places, and other public resorts; prevent obstructions during public assemblies, processions, worship services, or times of crowding. COMMENTS: Establishes a police duty to maintain public order in common spaces.

title: Police Act - Section 32: Penalty for Disobeying Orders Issued Under Last Three Sections, etc.
content: Anyone opposing or disobeying orders issued under Sections 30, 30A, or 31, or violating conditions of a license issued for music or assemblies/processions, is liable on conviction before a Magistrate to a fine up to two hundred rupees. COMMENTS: Provides penalty for non-compliance with police orders regarding assemblies, processions, and music.

title: Police Act - Section 33: Saving of Control of Magistrate of District
content: Nothing in Sections 30, 30A, 31, and 32 shall interfere with the general control of the District Magistrate over the matters referred to therein. COMMENTS: Affirms Magistrate's overarching authority despite police regulation powers.

title: Police Act - Section 34: Punishment for Certain Offences on Roads, etc. - Powers of Police Officers
content: In towns where this section is applied by State Government, a person committing certain offences endangering or inconveniencing residents or passengers is liable, on conviction before a Magistrate, to a fine up to fifty rupees or imprisonment up to eight days (with or without hard labour). Police may arrest without warrant anyone committing such offences in their view. Offences include: (1) slaughtering cattle or cleaning carcasses; reckless/furious riding or driving; training/breaking animals; (2) cruelty to animals; (3) obstructing passengers with vehicles or animals; (4) exposing goods for sale; (5) throwing dirt or offensive matter into streets; (6) being drunk or riotous; (7) indecent exposure or nuisance bathing/washing; (8) neglecting to safeguard dangerous places. COMMENTS: Lists petty offences on streets and the power of police to arrest offenders on view.

title: Police Act - Section 35: Jurisdiction
content: Any charge against a police-officer above the rank of constable under this Act shall be enquired into and decided only by an officer exercising the powers of a Magistrate. COMMENTS: Ensures higher-ranking officers face inquiry before a competent Magistrate.

title: Police Act - Section 36: Power to Prosecute Under Other Law Not Affected
content: Nothing in this Act prevents prosecution under another law or imposition of any other or higher penalty for the same offence, but no person shall be punished twice for the same offence. COMMENTS: Preserves the applicability of other laws while prohibiting double punishment.

title: Police Act - Section 37: Recovery of Penalties and Fines Imposed by Magistrates
content: Provisions of Sections 64 to 70 of the Indian Penal Code and Sections 386 to 389 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1882 (or current equivalents) on fines apply to penalties and fines under this Act. A person fined under Section 34 may be imprisoned for up to eight days in default of payment. COMMENTS: Aligns penalty recovery with IPC and CrPC provisions; allows short imprisonment in default of Section 34 fines.

title: Police Act - Section 38: Procedure Until Return is Made to Warrant of Distress
content: [Repealed by the Police Act (1861) Amendment Act, 1895 (8 of 1895), Section 14].

title: Police Act - Section 39: Imprisonment of Distress Not Sufficient
content: [Repealed by the Police Act (1861) Amendment Act, 1895 (8 of 1895), Section 14].

title: Police Act - Section 40: Levy of Fines from European British Subjects
content: [Repealed by the Police Act (1861) Amendment Act, 1895 (8 of 1895), Section 14].

title: Police Act - Section 41: Rewards to Police and Informers Payable to General Police Fund
content: [Repealed by the A.D. 1937].

title: Police Act - Section 42: Limitation of Actions
content: All actions and prosecutions lawfully brought under this Act or under the general police powers given herein must be commenced within three months after the act complained of. Written notice of such action, stating the cause thereof, must be given to the defendant, or to the District Superintendent or Assistant District Superintendent of the district where the act occurred, at least one month before commencement. No plaintiff may recover if sufficient amends were tendered before the action, or if a sufficient sum of money was paid into court after commencement by or on behalf of the defendant. Even if the plaintiff wins, costs will not be awarded unless approved by the trial judge. No action lies if the officer has been criminally prosecuted for the same act. COMMENTS: Actions must be initiated within 3 months and preceded by a one-month written notice; recovery is barred if amends are made before or during the action.

title: Police Act - Section 43: Plea that Act Was Done Under Warrant
content: When any action or prosecution is brought against a police-officer for acts done in that capacity, the officer may plead that the act was done under the authority of a warrant issued by a Magistrate. This plea is proved by producing the warrant signed by such Magistrate, and the defendant is entitled to judgment even if the Magistrate lacked jurisdiction. Signature proof is not required unless the court doubts its genuineness. Proviso: Any remedy against the authority issuing the warrant is unaffected. COMMENTS: A valid Magistrate's warrant protects a police-officer from liability, though the issuer may still be liable.

title: Police Act - Section 44: Police-Officers to Keep Diary
content: Every officer in charge of a police station must keep a general diary in the form prescribed by the State Government, recording all complaints and charges, the names of arrested persons and complainants, offences charged, weapons or property seized, and witnesses examined. The District Magistrate may inspect this diary at will. COMMENTS: The 'general diary' under this section is distinct from the diary under Section 167(1) of the CrPC; it serves as a detailed daily police record.

title: Police Act - Section 45: State Government May Prescribe Form of Returns
content: The State Government may require the Inspector-General and other police officers to submit specified returns, prescribing the forms for such submissions. COMMENTS: Police are obliged to provide operational and administrative returns in prescribed formats to the State Government.

title: Police Act - Section 46: Scope of Act
content: (1) This Act does not automatically take effect in any presidency, state, or place. The State Government may, by order in the Official Gazette, extend the whole or part of the Act to any area, and only then will it take effect there. (2) Upon extension, the State Government may make rules to: (a) regulate procedures for Magistrates and police officers in performing duties under the Act; (b) prescribe time, manner, conditions, and particulars for making and verifying claims for compensation under Section 15A, and related proceedings; (c) generally, give effect to the Act. (3) These rules may be amended or cancelled from time to time. COMMENTS: The Act applies only when extended by State Government order; also empowers the State to make detailed procedural rules for its implementation.

title: Police Act - Section 47: Authority of District Superintendent of Police Over Village Police
content: In implementing this Act, the State Government may declare that any authority currently exercised by a District Magistrate over village-watchmen or other village police officers shall, for police purposes, be exercised instead by the District Superintendent of Police, subject to the Magistrate's general control. COMMENTS: Enables State Governments to delegate operational authority over village police to the District Superintendent of Police while retaining the Magistrate’s supervisory oversight.

title: Right to Education in India (Article 21A)
content: Education is a fundamental human right that is required for the full enjoyment of all other human rights. It encourages individual independence and empowerment while also providing significant development advantages. Nonetheless, millions of children and adults continue to be denied educational chances, often because of poverty. In 2009, the Right to Education Act (RTE) guaranteed free and compulsory education for children and established it as a fundamental right under Article 21-A. It explains the importance of free and compulsory education for children aged 6-14 years in India under Article 21 (A) of the Indian Constitution. The Right to Education is a cornerstone for ensuring that every child has the opportunity to receive a high-quality elementary education.

title: Right to Education in India (Article 21A) - History and Background
content: Article 21A was included to make the right to education a Fundamental right for children aged 6 to 14. Originally, Article 45 of the Indian Constitution and Article 39 (f) of the DPSP provided for state-funded, equal, and accessible education. The Ramamurti Committee Report, published in 1990, was the first formal document addressing the right to education. This clause recognises only primary education as a Fundamental Right, not further or professional education. The 86th amendment paved the way for the Right to Education Bill 2008 to be followed by the Right to Education Act 2009. The term "free" in the article means no child (except those allowed by their parents to a non-government school) is responsible to pay any fee, charge, or expense that may prohibit pursuing and completing primary education. This Act makes it mandatory for the government to ensure that all children aged six to fourteen years are admitted, attend school, and complete their elementary education. Essentially, this Act ensures that all children from economically disadvantaged families receive free elementary education. In the landmark case of Unnikrishnan JP against the State of Andhra Pradesh & Others, the Supreme Court ruled that education is a fundamental right derived from Article 21. The Tapas Majumdar Committee was established in 1999, with the goal of inserting Article 21A. In 2002, the 86th amendment to India's constitution designated education as a basic right in Part III of the Constitution. Article 21A states that the State shall offer free and compulsory education to all children aged six to fourteen years in the manner determined by the State.

title: Right to Education in India (Article 21A) - Provisions and Related Constitutional Articles
content: Article 21A states that the State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children of the age of six to fourteen years in such manner as the State may, by law, determine. Other provisions in the Indian Constitution promote and develop the educational structure: Article 28 guarantees the freedom to attend religious instruction or worship in educational institutions; Article 29 guarantees equitable access to educational institutions; Article 30 recognizes minorities' freedom to create and manage educational institutions; Article 46 discusses particular consideration for the advancement of education and economic interests of Scheduled Tribes, Scheduled Castes, OBCs, and the weakest sections of society; Article 337 governs the particular provision of educational subsidies for the Anglo-Indian community.

title: Right to Education in India - Amendments to Achieve Right to Education (86th Constitutional Amendment, 2002)
content: In 2002, the 86th Amendment to the Constitution provided the Right to Education as a fundamental right and inserted Article 21A, which made the RTE a fundamental right for children aged between six and 14 years. The passage of the amendment was followed by the launch of the Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan (SSA) that aimed to provide useful and relevant elementary education to all children between six and 14 years. According to this, the right to education was declared a basic right and was withdrawn from the list of State Policy Directive Principles. The RTE is the follow-up law envisioned by the 86th Amendment. The term "free" appears in the title of the article, implying that no child (save those allowed by his or her parents to a school not financed by the government) is required to pay any form of fee, tax, or expenditure that may prohibit him or her from pursuing and finishing primary education. This Act requires the government to assure the entrance, attendance, and completion of primary education for all children between the ages of six and fourteen.

title: Right to Education in India - 93rd Constitutional Amendment (2006)
content: In 2006, the 93rd Constitutional Amendment Act (CAA) inserted Clause (5) in Article 15, enabling the State to create special provisions such as reservations for the advancement of any backward classes of citizens like Scheduled Castes (SCs) and Scheduled Tribes (STs) in all aided or unaided educational institutes, except minority educational institutes. The act aims to increase access to higher education, especially professional education, for students from socially and educationally deprived sections of society, as well as those from Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. Compared to private unaided universities, the number of seats available in aided or State-maintained institutions was restricted, particularly in professional education. Article 46 states that the State should support with special attention the educational and economic interests of the weaker parts of the population and safeguard them from social injustice.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Summary
content: The government brought the Right to Education (RTE) Act, 2009, focusing on inclusive education for all and mandating the inclusion of underprivileged children in schools. Section 12(1)(c) of the Act provides for a 25% reservation of seats in unaided schools for children from economically weaker sections and disadvantaged groups. The Act originally contained a 'No Detention Policy' section, which was later deleted by the Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education (Amendment) Act, 2019. It prohibits the use of teachers for non-educational purposes except for the decennial census, elections to local governments, state legislatures, and parliament, and disaster assistance. The Act also mandates the selection of instructors with necessary entrance and academic credentials.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 2. Definitions
content: Section 2 defines words and expressions used in the Act.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 3. Right to Free and Compulsory Education
content: Section 3 provides to every child of the age of six to fourteen years the right to free and compulsory education in a neighbourhood school till the completion of elementary education. The idea of neighbourhood schools can be traced to the National System of Education as elaborated in the Kothari Commission report, whereby the neighbourhood school is meant to be a common space, where all children cutting across caste, class, gender lines learn together in the best inclusive manner. It is therefore meant to be a site for inclusion, so that the school becomes a common space for education. This concept has been incorporated in the RTE Act.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 3. Right to Free and Compulsory Education
content: In providing for the right of every child to free and compulsory education in a neighbourhood school, the RTE Act does not restrict the choice of the child to seek admission in a school which may not be in the neighbourhood of the child’s residence. In other words, there is no compulsion on the child to seek admission only in the school in his or her neighbourhood.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 3. Right to Free and Compulsory Education
content: The term ‘free education’ is explained to mean that no child shall be liable to pay any kind of fee or charges or expenses which may prevent him or her from pursuing and completing elementary education. The term ‘free education’ must be read in consonance with the provisions of section 12(1)(a)-(c) which specify the extent of the school’s responsibility for free and compulsory education.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 3. Right to Free and Compulsory Education
content: It further provides that the provisions of the Persons with Disabilities (Equal Opportunities, Protection and Full Participation) Act, 1996 will apply in the case of children suffering from disability as defined under that Act.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 4. Admission of Out-of-School Children
content: Section 4 provides children above six years, who have either not been admitted to any school or, having been admitted have not completed elementary education and have dropped out, the right to be admitted to a school in a class appropriate to his or her age for completing elementary education. A majority of out-of-school children belong to disadvantaged communities: scheduled castes, scheduled tribes, Muslim minorities, migrants, children with special needs, urban deprived children, working children, children in difficult circumstances, for example, those living in difficult terrain, children from displaced families, and areas affected by civil strife, etc.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 4. Admission of Out-of-School Children
content: This provision in the RTE Act enables these out-of-school children to be admitted to an age-appropriate class and complete elementary education. The overall objective of age appropriate admission for these children is to save them from the humiliation and embarrassment of sitting with younger children. When older children are forced to sit in a class younger than their age, they tend to be teased, taunted, suffer lower self esteem, and consequently drop out.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 4. Admission of Out-of-School Children
content: The Act facilitates a child admitted to an age appropriate class to be given Special Training to enable him or her to be at par with other children. Given the varied life experiences of these children, it is recognised in the field of education that their mental capabilities are higher than that of entry level 6-year old children, and that they are indeed capable of accelerated learning. At the end of the Special Training, the child will be assessed and his/her suitability for being placed in a particular class will be reviewed.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 4. Admission of Out-of-School Children
content: For example, if a 10-year old child was admitted to class IV, and received two years of Special Training till age 12, an assessment may be made as to whether the child could cope better in class V or VI in the formal school, and the child appropriately placed. If such child is found suitable for class V, she/he will be placed in class V, rather than mechanically being placed in class VI – because if she/he is mechanically placed in class VI, she/he might again drop out, and that would defeat the whole purpose of this provision.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 4. Admission of Out-of-School Children
content: That is the rationale for the provision that allows the child to be provided free and compulsory education even beyond age 14. Even after a child is appropriately placed in the formal school she may continue to receive special attention by the teacher to enable her to successfully integrate with the rest of the class, academically and emotionally.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 4. Admission of Out-of-School Children
content: The SSA Framework of Implementation has been revised to provide support for Special Training as envisaged under the RTE Act to ensure that out-of-school children are integrated into the school system. Such support will be in the form of residential or non-residential courses, as needed and such children will continue even beyond 14 years of age to complete elementary education.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 4. Admission of Out-of-School Children
content: The country is committed to creating an educated citizenry and environment, and therefore it would not be appropriate to impose an age ceiling for these children to complete elementary education. The obligation under section 4 is on the schools established by the State Government and local authority. Private aided and unaided institutions have no obligations under section 4.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 5. Right to Transfer and Issue of Transfer Certificate
content: Section 5 provides children the right to seek transfer from a Government or Government aided school to another such school in order to complete elementary education and for immediate issue of Transfer Certificate to a child seeking admission to another school. It provides that delay in producing Transfer Certificate shall not be a reason for denying or delaying admission in another school. This provision should lead to States instituting reform to remove procedural barriers to obtaining Transfer Certificates.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 6. Access to Elementary Education
content: The rationale of this provision is to provide all children access to elementary education. Universal access requires schooling facilities within reasonable reach of all children. If schools are not located in or near the habitations where children reside, children may not complete schooling, even if they are formally enrolled in schools, on account of distance factors. The RTE Act therefore mandates the appropriate governments and local authorities to provide for children’s access to elementary schools within the defined area or limits of neighbourhood. The RTE Act deliberately does not define the limits or area of neighbourhood as a centralised norm, but requires the appropriate Government to notify such limits or area in the RTE Rules. This is on account of the very diverse geographical, climatic terrain and the varied development requirements of the different States, and the conscious decision that States would be better placed to define the ‘neighbourhood’, keeping the best interests of different children in mind. However, the Central Government has attempted to exemplify this in the Model RTE Rules circulated to States, which provide for distance norms of one kilometre for children in classes I-V, and three kilometres for children in classes VI-VIII, as also provision for relaxation of norms in places with difficult terrain where there may be risk of landslides, floods, lack of roads and in general, danger for young children in the approach from their homes to the school. The Model Rules also provide that access of children to school should not be hindered on account of social and cultural factors. Such norms should be laid down keeping in view local contexts and requirements, rather than centrally prescribed through a law. These have also been incorporated in the Central RTE Rules applicable to all UTs without Legislature. States /UTs need to arrive at a clear picture of current availability of schools within defined area or limits of neighbourhoods. In order to do this, State/UTs need to (i) define the neighbourhood norms keeping in view that all primary and upper primary schools and composite schools (with primary and upper primary sections), established by the State Government and local bodies would be neighbourhood schools for the purpose of section 3(1), and (ii) map the neighbourhoods or habitations and link them to specific schools. It is possible that a neighbourhood may be linked to more than one school. Similarly, a school may be linked to more than one neighbourhood. The mapping exercise will help identify gaps and areas where new schools need to be opened to ensure universal access.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 7. Financial and Other Responsibilities
content: Section 7(1) – (5) provides for financial and other responsibilities of the Central Government and the State Governments for carrying out the provisions of the proposed Act. The Central Government has estimated a total requirement of Rs 2.31 lakh crore over a five year period from 2010-11 to 2014-15 to implement the RTE Act. Separately, the 13th Finance Commission has also provided a grant of Rs 24,068 crore specifically for elementary education. The grant of the 13th Finance Commission is released directly on an annual basis to the State Governments from the Finance Ministry. This amount is deducted from the overall estimate of Rs 2.31 lakh crore, and the balance amount of Rs 2.07 lakh crore will be shared between the Central and State Governments in the 65:35 ratio for the implementation of RTE through the SSA programme. In the case of States in the North East Region, the fund sharing pattern will be in the 90:10 ratio. Section 7(6) provides for the formulation of a National Curriculum Framework. The Central Government has notified the NCERT as the designated authority for this purpose. The National Curriculum Framework, 2005, formulated by the NCERT has been hailed nationally and internationally as trendsetting in defining learning processes, assessment, quality and integration of various aspects of education geared towards producing a creative citizen of the country, and has been accepted as the Curriculum Framework under the RTE Act.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 8. Duties of Appropriate Government
content: Section 8 assigns duties to the appropriate Government to ensure that it provides free and compulsory elementary education to every child, in a neighbourhood school. The term ‘compulsory education’ is explained to mean obligation of the appropriate Government to provide free elementary education and ensure compulsory admission, attendance and completion of elementary education. It further provides that where a child is not admitted to a school which is established, owned, controlled or substantially funded by the appropriate Government or local authority, such child or his or her parents will not be entitled to claim reimbursement of the cost of elementary education. It lays down the duties of the appropriate Government to ensure inter alia that children belonging to weaker sections and disadvantaged groups are not discriminated against and prevented from pursuing and completing elementary education, that admission, attendance and completion of elementary education by every child is monitored, that school building, teaching staff and learning equipment are provided, good quality elementary education conforming to norms and standards is provided, curriculum and courses of study are prescribed in a timely manner, and teachers are trained.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 9. Duties of Local Authority
content: Section 9 assigns duties to the local authority to ensure that it provides free and compulsory elementary education to every child, in a neighbourhood school. It lays down the duties of the local authority to ensure inter alia that children belonging to weaker sections and disadvantaged groups are not discriminated against and prevented from pursuing and completing elementary education, maintain records of children residing within its jurisdiction, ensure and monitor admission, attendance and completion of elementary education by every child, including migrant children, ensure that school building, teaching staff and learning equipment and good quality elementary education conforming to norms and standards is provided, decide on the academic calendar.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 10. Responsibility of Parents or Guardians
content: This provision casts a moral responsibility on every parent/guardian to admit their children/wards to school, and ensure that children are not deprived of their right to elementary education. This includes children involved in child labour, living in ecologically deprived areas, very poor slum communities, uprooted urban habitations, children of scavengers and stigmatised professions, children of itinerant or seasonal labour with mobile lifestyles like construction workers, road workers, and landless agricultural labourers required to augment family incomes. This provision should be read with the responsibility of the appropriate Government and local authority to provide free and compulsory elementary education in a neighbourhood school. It is not intended to compel parents/guardians and children/wards who do not wish to avail free education to necessarily admit their children in neighbourhood schools. Suggestions to penalize parents/guardians who do not send children to school were rejected, as most non-attending children are from weaker sections and disadvantaged groups, and penalizing parents would be penalizing poverty and deprivation. Many first generation learners lack home learning environments and drop out due to curriculum difficulties; penalizing parents would be discriminatory. Instead, the Act imposes a duty on the appropriate government to ensure admission, attendance, and completion of elementary education, leading to systemic reforms. Collaboration with civil society is encouraged to persuade parents, especially for older girls, to regularly send children to school.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 11. Provision for Pre-school Education
content: Section 11 provides that the appropriate government may make arrangements for pre-school education.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 12. Responsibility of Schools for Providing Free and Compulsory Education
content: Section 12 explains the responsibility of schools for providing free and compulsory education to children, namely: (a) All Government schools shall provide free and compulsory education to all children; (b) Government aided institutions shall provide free and compulsory education to such percentage of students in elementary classes which equals the percentage of recurring aid received by it from the Government to the annual recurring expenditure incurred by the school, subject to a minimum of 25%; (c) Private unaided institutions and special category schools shall provide free and compulsory education to at least 25% children belonging to disadvantaged groups and weaker sections admitted to class I or pre-primary classes. Such schools would be entitled to reimbursement at the per-child cost incurred by the Government. It has also since been clarified that residential private unaided schools, which do not start at class I, would not be required to admit 25% children from disadvantaged groups and weaker sections in their schools. The Act’s Statement of Objects and Reasons emphasizes that inclusive elementary education is the responsibility of all schools, including those not dependent on Government funds, to promote equality, social justice, and democracy. Inclusive schooling encourages children from different backgrounds and abilities to study together, fostering social cohesion and alignment with constitutional values. The provision for 25% admission of children from disadvantaged groups and weaker sections in class I aims to create a critical mass to avoid segregation and promote meaningful classroom interaction. This percentage is based on demographic data, reflecting reasonable representation of these groups. Admission applies to class I only, with new cohorts admitted annually, allowing gradual social integration and adaptation of schools and teachers to diverse student populations. The policy particularly benefits younger children, whose social identities are still forming, supporting diversity and learning while opposing segregation. The broader objectives include promoting social cohesion and enriching learning by interaction among children from diverse socio-economic backgrounds, requiring appropriate classroom practices and teacher training to ensure recognition and equality for all students.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 13. Prohibition of Capitation Fee and Screening Procedures
content: Section 13 provides that no school or person shall collect capitation fee or subject a child to any screening procedure, and prescribes a penalty for contravention of these provisions. The Government, after consultation with several private school principals, issued guidelines under section 35(1) to ensure that admission procedures are non-discriminatory, rational, and transparent. Schools are prohibited from subjecting children and their parents to admission tests or interviews to decide whether to admit a child. Extensive educational research recognizes that all children are born with equal potential to learn, regardless of caste, class, gender, or IQ. Language acquisition by children at around two years is an intrinsic stage of brain development unaffected by social factors. Differences in learning revealed by tests reflect differences in nurturing rather than intrinsic ability. Therefore, the State and society have an obligation to provide better nurturing through good schools to children from poor and disadvantaged sections. The guidelines under section 35(1) state that tests and interviews serve mainly as tools for profiling and eliminating children and that screening to assess intelligence should be prohibited. Equal opportunity for children from diverse social and economic backgrounds reinforces constitutional equality and prevents discrimination. The guidelines promote composite classrooms with children from diverse backgrounds, which fosters inter-learning, respect for differences, tolerance, and creativity. For the 25% quota for disadvantaged and weaker sections admitted in class I, selection must be random from applications received. For the remaining 75%, schools have freedom to formulate their admission policies based on rational, reasonable, and just criteria aligned with the school's objectives. There shall be no profiling based on parental education qualifications. Admission policies must be publicly available in the school prospectus with wide publicity. No testing or interviews are allowed; selection must be random.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 14. Proof of Age Certificate for Admission
content: Section 14 seeks to provide for proof of age certificate of a child and that admission cannot be denied in its absence. The rationale for this provision is that birth certificates under the Births, Deaths and Marriages Certification Act, 1886 are often not available, and in their absence, children and their parents often have to run from pillar to post to obtain age proof. Thus, other documents can be deemed to be proof of age of the child for the purposes of admission in schools. Examples of other documents are (i) ANM register record, (ii) Anganwadi record, (iii) declaration of age of the child by the parent or guardian. State Governments will identify documents, which may be in the form of affidavits or certificates that can be used for determining the age of the child for admission and suitably provide for them in the delegated legislation. Clause 14(2) explicitly states that since the child has a right to education, that right cannot be denied for lack of age proof. Therefore, admission would be given even in the absence of age proof, while an appropriate document of age proof would simultaneously be acquired.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 15. Prohibition of Denial of Admission
content: Section 15 prohibits schools from denying admission to a child, irrespective of the time in the academic year in which admission is sought. Admission of a child in school is a fundamental right and cannot be denied at any point of time. Ideally, all children should be enrolled at the beginning of the academic session. However, children in difficult circumstances, including those affected by migration, displacement, or ill health, may require flexibility for admission at any time during the session. The Central RTE Rules provide that children admitted after six months from the beginning of the academic session may be provided Special Training as determined by the Head Teacher to help them complete studies. Private unaided schools need not be concerned with this provision for the 75% admission quota, as they usually fill all seats at the start of the academic year, making any-time admission unlikely.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 16. Prohibition of Holding Back and Expulsion
content: Section 16 prohibits holding back and expulsion of a child from school until completion of elementary education. The 'no detention' provision addresses the problem of examinations being used to eliminate children who score poorly, leading to repetition of grades or school dropout. Repeating a class is demotivating and does not offer additional support to the child. The provision does not abandon assessment but mandates continuous and comprehensive evaluation that is non-threatening and supportive, enabling teachers to focus on individual learning. Research shows failure to improve learning quality, and detention often causes children to abandon schooling. Regarding expulsion, despite concerns about deviant behavior, expulsion is incompatible with the child's right to education. No civilized country expels elementary children (ages 6-14). Instead, the education system must address behavioral issues through counseling and tailored curricular or co-curricular activities to help the child develop self-awareness and change behavior patterns.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 17. Prohibition of Physical Punishment and Mental Harassment
content: Section 17 prohibits any child from being subjected to physical punishment or mental harassment. The mistaken notion that discipline requires punishment and fear is refuted by educationists who emphasize a nurturing learning environment rather than a correctional one. Physical punishment and mental trauma are counter-productive and may increase defiance. Childhood, characterized by impressionability and vulnerability, demands protection and nurturance; even minor punishment can cause injury or lasting harm. Article 39(f) of the Constitution of India mandates that children develop with dignity, which cannot coexist with punishment. The National Policy on Education (1986/1992) also forbids corporal punishment. As a signatory to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC), India aligns with Article 19 that requires protection of children from all forms of violence and abuse. Thus, the RTE Act's ban on corporal punishment and mental harassment aligns with constitutional, national, and international obligations.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 18. Certificate of Recognition for Private Schools
content: Section 18 stipulates that no private school shall be established or function without obtaining a Certificate of Recognition, which will be issued only to schools that fulfill the prescribed norms and standards. The Act does not provide for recognition of Government schools, as that would mean the Government giving recognition to its own schools. However, Section 19 clearly states that Government schools must meet the requirements of the schedule.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 19. Norms and Standards for Schools
content: Section 19 lays down the norms and standards for schools. Any school, whether Government or private, that does not fulfil the prescribed norms and standards shall do so within a period of three years from the date of commencement of the Act. There was a misconception that Government schools do not require meeting the norms due to a wrongly inserted comma in the Bill, but this has been corrected. The provision applies to all schools, and compliance will be monitored by the National Commission for Protection of Child Rights (NCPCR).

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 20. Power to Amend Schedule
content: Section 20 provides the Central Government the power to amend the schedule on norms and standards for schools.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 21. Constitution and Functions of School Management Committee
content: Section 21 provides for constitution and functions of a School Management Committee (SMC) in certain categories of schools. The Act envisages that parents would form a majority in the SMCs, which would also include elected members of the Panchayat and school teachers. This parent-dominated structure aims to improve school management and overall schooling quality. Private unaided institutions are exempted from constituting SMCs. An Amendment Bill proposes that SMCs in private unaided and minority institutions will only have an advisory role.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 22. Preparation of School Development Plan
content: Section 22 provides for preparation of a School Development Plan (SDP) by the School Management Committee. The SDP is a comprehensive plan focusing on all aspects of the school including protection of children’s rights, infrastructure, teacher availability, classroom transaction, child assessments, and inclusiveness. Private unaided institutions are not required to prepare SDPs under the RTE Act. The Amendment Bill also exempts private unaided and minority institutions from preparing SDPs.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 23. Qualifications and Terms and Conditions of Service of School Teachers
content: Section 23 provides for qualifications and terms and conditions of service of school teachers. The Central Government has notified the National Council for Teacher Education (NCTE) as the academic authority responsible for prescribing teacher qualifications. NCTE has laid down the requisite teacher qualifications as per its notification dated 23rd August 2010.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 24. Duties of Teachers
content: Section 24 provides for duties of teachers, including attending school regularly, transacting the syllabus in a timely manner, providing supplementary support to children who need it, assessing children’s learning, and interacting with parents.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 25. Maintenance of Pupil Teacher Ratio
content: Section 25 seeks to provide for maintenance of pupil teacher ratio by the appropriate government and local authority. The current contradiction between this provision, which requires that the pupil teacher ratio be maintained within six months, and the provision under section 19 mandating norms and standards to be met within three years, is proposed to be corrected through an Amendment Bill. The proviso to this section also states that teachers shall not be deployed for non-academic work, except for decennial population census, disaster relief, and elections to Parliament, State Legislatures, and Local Bodies as specified in section 27.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 26. Teacher Vacancies
content: Section 26 provides that vacancies in schools should not exceed 10% of the teacher strength for that school. This provision ensures that States take steps to fill existing teacher vacancies and rationalize teacher deployment to remove urban-rural imbalances.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 27. Deployment of Teachers for Non-Educational Purposes
content: Section 27 prohibits deployment of teachers for non-educational purposes other than decennial population census, disaster relief duties, or duties related to elections to local authorities, state legislatures, and Parliament. This ensures more time is available for school and classroom activities, preventing teachers from being taken away from their classroom responsibilities.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 28. Prohibition of Private Tuition by Teachers
content: Section 28 prohibits private tuition by teachers. Private tuition is recognized as a harmful practice affecting Indian education. This provision ensures that teachers do not exploit their position for commercial gain through private tuition, which often causes harassment to children and parents.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 29. Curriculum and Evaluation Procedure
content: Section 29 provides that State Governments must prescribe the academic authority to lay down the curriculum and evaluation procedure for elementary schools. The academic authority must ensure adherence to eight factors: (1) conformity with Constitutional values; (2) all-round development of the child; (3) building the child's knowledge, potentiality and talent; (4) development of physical and mental abilities to the fullest extent; (5) learning through activities, discovery and exploration in a child-friendly and child-centred manner; (6) use of the child's mother tongue as far as practicable as the medium of instruction; (7) making the child free of fear, trauma and anxiety and helping the child to express views freely; and (8) comprehensive and continuous evaluation of the child's understanding, knowledge, and ability to apply it. These factors reflect child-centred curricular policies aligned with the National Policy on Education (NPE) 1986/92 and the National Curriculum Framework (NCF) 2005.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 30. Prohibition of Board Examinations Before Completion of Elementary Education
content: Section 30 provides that no child shall be required to pass Board examinations until completion of elementary education. Board examinations cause stress and anxiety, especially among young children. The National Curriculum Framework 2005 emphasizes flexibility in assessment and states that board or state-level exams should not be conducted at stages such as class V, VIII, or XI. Boards are encouraged to consider making the Class X examination optional, allowing students continuing in the same school to take an internal school exam instead.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 31. Institutional Mechanism for Protection of Rights of the Child
content: Section 31 provides for protection of child rights through National and State Commissions for Protection of Child Rights (NCPCR/SCPCR). Monitoring for children in school covers: (i) Provision of neighbourhood schools with adequate classrooms, infrastructure, appropriate pupil-teacher ratio (PTR), and school hours; (ii) Access to school, both physical and social; (iii) Admission processes including denial of admission, capitation fee, screening procedures, demand for affidavits, and any-time admission; (iv) Entitlements like textbooks, uniforms, libraries, sports equipment, play materials, mid-day meals, special training for age-appropriate education, transfer and completion certificates, and other expenses; (v) Classroom transactions ensuring no discrimination or corporal punishment and employing appropriate teaching and evaluation methods; (vi) School Management Committee functions such as appointments, regular meetings, teacher accountability, and preparation of School Development Plans; and (vii) Responsibilities related to admission of children from weaker sections and disadvantaged groups in private aided and unaided schools. Additionally, NCPCR/SCPCR monitors out-of-school children including never enrolled, dropouts, temporarily absent, and migrant children to facilitate their access and participation in schooling.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 32. Mechanism for Redressal of Grievance
content: Section 32 provides a mechanism for redressal of grievances relating to rights of the child under the Act.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 33. Constitution of National Advisory Council
content: Section 33 provides for the constitution of a National Advisory Council to give expert advice to the Central Government on implementation of the provisions of the Act. This Council has been constituted and has commenced its work.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 34. Constitution of State Advisory Councils
content: Section 34 provides for the constitution of State Advisory Councils to advise the State Governments on the implementation of the Act.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 35. Guidelines and Directions for Effective Implementation
content: Section 35 provides for the Central Government to issue guidelines and directions to the appropriate government or local authority for effective implementation of the Act. It also provides for the appropriate Government to issue guidelines and directions to Local Authorities, and for Local Authorities to give guidelines to School Management Committees.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 36. Previous Sanction for Prosecution
content: Section 36 provides for previous sanction of an authorised officer for prosecution of offences under the Act.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 37. Protection from Legal Proceedings
content: Section 37 provides protection against any legal suit or proceedings to the appropriate government, local authority, or others for any action taken in good faith under the Act.

title: Right to Education Act, 2009 - Section 38. Power to Make Rules
content: Section 38 provides powers to the appropriate Government to make rules under the Act, and for laying of rules and notifications made before each House of Parliament.

title: Constitution of India - Article 19: Freedom of Speech and Expression
content:
The historian and philosopher of ideas, Isaiah Berlin, identified two types of freedom: negative freedom and positive freedom. Negative freedom centres on freedom from interference. Theories of negative freedom are generally understood as defining the acceptable limits of interference in an individual’s life. Negative freedom is restricted when a person reduces the number of choices another can make about their own life.

Positive freedom is understood as the freedom to do something. It is derived from an individual's wish to be their own master without external influence.

Right to Freedom of Speech and Expression is enshrined in Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution of India, which provides and guarantees to all citizens the right to freedom of speech and expression. The law states that all citizens shall have this right.

title: Constitution of India - Article 19: Freedom of Speech and Expression
content:
The Constitution of India provides various rights to ensure individual freedoms, as given in Articles 67, 45, 87, and 92, with the aim of guaranteeing rights considered important by the framers of the Constitution. Article 45 provides for free and compulsory education for children. The government is required to provide free education to all children until they complete the age of fourteen years.

Freedom of speech is considered one of the most basic freedoms. In India, the right is granted by Article 19(1)(a), while Article 19(2) allows for reasonable restrictions to be imposed on all fundamental rights, including the right to freedom of speech and expression.

title: Constitution of India - Article 19: Freedom of Speech and Expression
content:
Freedom is essential for the proper functioning of the democratic process. Freedom of speech and expression is regarded as the first condition of liberty and is considered the foundation or 'mother' of all liberties. This right allows citizens to participate in discussions on various issues and plays a crucial role in shaping public opinion on social, political, and economic matters.

In the case of Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India, Justice Bhagwati emphasized the importance of freedom of speech and expression, stating: "Democracy is based essentially on free debate and open discussion, for that is the only corrective of government action in a democratic setup. If democracy means government of the people by the people, it is obvious that every citizen must be entitled to participate in the democratic process and, in order to enable him to intelligently exercise his right of making a choice, free and general discussions of public matters are absolutely essential."

title: Constitution of India - Article 19: Freedom of Speech and Expression
content:
The right to freedom of speech and expression gives individuals the power to express their feelings to others. In State of Uttar Pradesh v. Raj Narain, the Supreme Court held that Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution guarantees freedom of speech and expression to all citizens, which includes the right to know and the right to receive information on matters of public concern.

Under freedom of speech and expression, there is no separate guarantee for the freedom of the press, as it is included in the general freedom of expression granted to all citizens. This was affirmed in cases such as Virender v. State of Punjab (1958 SC 986) and Sakal Papers v. Union of India (1962 SC 305).

title: Constitution of India - Article 19: Freedom of Speech and Expression
content:
In India, Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution states that all citizens have the right to freedom of speech and expression. The Preamble of the Constitution provides liberty to all citizens and ensures liberty of thought, expression, belief, faith, and worship.

In the recent Supreme Court judgment in Khushboo v. Kannaiammal, the Court upheld the right to freedom of speech and expression. In this case, Khushboo's right was violated through the institution of multiple criminal cases against her in various courts across the country, leading to harassment.

It is important to note that the liberty of one person must not infringe upon the liberty of others.

title: Constitution of India - Article 19: Security of State
content: Security of the state is given the highest priority. The government has the power to impose restrictions on rights when such actions affect the security of the state. The term 'security of the state' refers to serious forms of public disorder, including rebellion, waging war, breaches of public order, riots, and similar acts that threaten the stability and safety of the nation.

title: Constitution of India - Article 19: Decency or Morality
content: The manner of expressing thoughts and ideas should be decent, kind, and in accordance with accepted standards. Expression should not harm the morality of society or hurt the sentiments of others. Sections 292 to 294 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) provide examples of restrictions on the freedom of speech and expression in the interest of morality. These sections prohibit the use or exhibition of obscene or abusive words in public places.

title: Constitution of India - Article 19: Defamation
content: One's freedom, of any type, must not harm the reputation or status of another person. The right of one individual should not override the rights of another. Under the right to freedom of speech and expression, no person is permitted to hurt the sentiments of others, ridicule them, or express hatred or contempt that infringes upon another person's rights.

title: Constitution of India - Article 19: Sovereignty and Integrity of India
content: The Constitution grants the right to freedom of speech and expression; however, no citizen of India is permitted to challenge the sovereignty or make statements that undermine the integrity of the country. This restriction was added as a ground for limiting freedom of speech and expression by the Constitution (Sixteenth Amendment) Act, 1963.

title: Constitution of India - Right of Freedom of Speech and Expression: A Constitutional Analysis
content:
In the landmark judgment of Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India, AIR 1978 SC 597, the Supreme Court held that the freedom of speech and expression has no geographical limitation. It includes the right of citizens to gather information and exchange thoughts not only within India but also abroad. The right to freedom of speech and expression is considered part of natural law or common law—it is a birthright rather than a creation of legislation. This right is fundamental for the development of an individual's personality.

The Constitution of India is based on the principle of checks and balances. The Preamble expresses two complementary ideas:
1. Rights of the individual correspond to and coordinate with the duties of the state towards the individual.
2. Duties of the individual towards the state correspond to the rights of society against the individual.

title: Constitution of India - Right of Freedom of Speech and Expression: A Constitutional Analysis
content: Justice U.R. Krishna Iyer observed: "The right to express one’s thoughts is meaningless if it is not accompanied by a relaxed right to secure all information on matters of public concern from relevant public authorities." He further stated that to ensure there is no harm in exercising this right, the freedom of information should be explicitly recognized as a corollary to Article 19 of the Constitution.

title: Constitution of India - Article 19: Conclusion on Freedom of Speech and Expression
content:
The right to freedom of speech and expression is one of the most important fundamental rights. It empowers individuals to present their thoughts, opinions, and ideas. However, this right is not absolute and does not extend to acts that harm the sentiments or morality of others.

Case law analysis shows that the courts have consistently played a vital role in giving a broad interpretation to the value and scope of Article 19(1)(a). This right encompasses the right to information, freedom of the press, and other related freedoms. Freedom of speech and expression

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 1
content: This Act may be called the Right to Information Act, 2005. It extends to the whole of India except the State of Jammu and Kashmir. The provisions of sub-section (1) of section 4, sub-sections (1) and (2) of section 5, and sections 12, 13, 15, 16, 24, 27, and 28 shall come into force at once, and the remaining provisions of this Act shall come into force on the one hundred and twentieth day of its enactment.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 2
content: In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires,— (a) "appropriate Government" means in relation to a public authority which is established, constituted, owned, controlled, or substantially financed by funds provided directly or indirectly— (i) by the Central Government or the Union territory administration, the Central Government; (ii) by the State Government, the State Government; (b) "Central Information Commission" means the Central Information Commission constituted under sub-section (1) of section 12; (c) "Central Public Information Officer" means the Central Public Information Officer designated under sub-section (1) and includes a Central Assistant Public Information Officer designated as such under sub-section (2) of section 5; (d) "Chief Information Commissioner" and "Information Commissioner" mean the Chief Information Commissioner and Information Commissioner appointed under sub-section (3) of section 12; (e) "competent authority" means— (i) the Speaker in the case of the House of the People or the Legislative Assembly of a State or a Union territory having such Assembly and the Chairman in the case of the Council of States or Legislative Council of a State; (ii) the Chief Justice of India in the case of the Supreme Court; (iii) the Chief Justice of the High Court in the case of a High Court; (iv) the President or the Governor, as the case may be, in the case of other authorities established or constituted by or under the Constitution; (v) the administrator appointed under article 239 of the Constitution; (f) "information" means any material in any form, including records, documents, memos, e-mails, opinions, advices, press releases, circulars, orders, logbooks, contracts, reports, papers, samples, models, data material held in any electronic form and information relating to any private body which can be accessed by a public authority under any other law for the time being in force; (g) "prescribed" means prescribed by rules made under this Act by the appropriate Government or the competent authority, as the case may be; (h) "public authority" means any authority or body or institution of self-government established or constituted— (a) by or under the Constitution; (b) by any other law made by Parliament; (c) by any other law made by State Legislature; (d) by notification issued or order made by the appropriate Government, and includes any— (i) body owned, controlled or substantially financed; (ii) non-Government organisation substantially financed, directly or indirectly by funds provided by the appropriate Government; (i) "record" includes— (a) any document, manuscript and file; (b) any microfilm, microfiche and facsimile copy of a document; (c) any reproduction of image or images embodied in such microfilm (whether enlarged or not); and (d) any other material produced by a computer or any other device; (j) "right to information" means the right to information accessible under this Act which is held by or under the control of any public authority and includes the right to— (i) inspection of work, documents, records; (ii) taking notes, extracts or certified copies of documents or records; (iii) taking certified samples of material; (iv) obtaining information in the form of diskettes, floppies, tapes, video cassettes or in any other electronic mode or through printouts where such information is stored in a computer or in any other device; (k) "State Information Commission" means the State Information Commission constituted under sub-section (1) of section 15; (l) "State Chief Information Commissioner" and "State Information Commissioner" mean the State Chief Information Commissioner and the State Information Commissioner appointed under sub-section (3) of section 15; (m) "State Public Information Officer" means the State Public Information Officer designated under sub-section (1) and includes a State Assistant Public Information Officer designated as such under sub-section (2) of section 5; (n) "third party" means a person other than the citizen making a request for information and includes a public authority.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 3
content: Subject to the provisions of this Act, all citizens shall have the right to information.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 4
content: (1) Every public authority shall— (a) maintain all its records duly catalogued and indexed in a manner and form which facilitates the right to information under this Act and ensure that all records appropriate to be computerised are, within a reasonable time and subject to availability of resources, computerised and connected through a network across the country so that access to such records is facilitated; (b) publish within one hundred and twenty days from the enactment of this Act— (i) the particulars of its organisation, functions and duties; (ii) the powers and duties of its officers and employees; (iii) the procedure followed in the decision-making process, including channels of supervision and accountability; (iv) the norms set by it for the discharge of its functions; (v) the rules, regulations, instructions, manuals and records held by it or under its control or used by its employees for discharging its functions; (vi) a statement of the categories of documents that are held by it or under its control; (vii) the particulars of any arrangement that exists for consultation with or representation by the members of the public in relation to the formulation of its policy or implementation thereof; (viii) a statement of the boards, councils, committees and other bodies consisting of two or more persons constituted as its part or for the purpose of its advice, and whether meetings of those bodies are open to the public or the minutes are accessible; (ix) a directory of its officers and employees; (x) the monthly remuneration received by each of its officers and employees, including the system of compensation as provided in its regulations; (xi) the budget allocated to each of its agencies, indicating particulars of all plans, proposed expenditures and reports on disbursements made; (xii) the manner of execution of subsidy programmes, including allocated amounts and details of beneficiaries; (xiii) particulars of recipients of concessions, permits or authorisations granted by it; (xiv) details of the information available to or held by it in electronic form; (xv) particulars of facilities available to citizens for obtaining information, including the working hours of a library or reading room, if maintained for public use; (xvi) the names, designations and other particulars of the Public Information Officers; (xvii) such other information as may be prescribed; and thereafter update these publications every year; (c) publish all relevant facts while formulating important policies or announcing decisions which affect the public; (d) provide reasons for its administrative or quasi-judicial decisions to affected persons. (2) It shall be a constant endeavour of every public authority to take steps in accordance with clause (b) of sub-section (1) to provide as much information suo motu to the public at regular intervals through various means of communication, including the internet, so that the public have minimum resort to the use of this Act to obtain information. (3) For the purposes of sub-section (1), every information shall be disseminated widely and in such form and manner which is easily accessible to the public. (4) All materials shall be disseminated taking into consideration cost effectiveness, local language and the most effective method of communication in that local area, and information should be easily accessible, to the extent possible in electronic format, with the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, available free or at a cost of the medium or print cost price as may be prescribed. Explanation.—For the purposes of sub-sections (3) and (4), "disseminated" means making known or communicating the information to the public through notice boards, newspapers, public announcements, media broadcasts, the internet, or any other means, including inspection of offices of any public authority.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 5
content: (1) Every public authority shall, within one hundred days of the enactment of this Act, designate as many officers as the Central Public Information Officers or State Public Information Officers, as the case may be, in all administrative units or offices under it as may be necessary to provide information to persons requesting for the information under this Act. (2) Without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (1), every public authority shall designate an officer, within one hundred days of the enactment of this Act, at each sub-divisional level or other sub-district level as a Central Assistant Public Information Officer or a State Assistant Public Information Officer, as the case may be, to receive the applications for information or appeals under this Act for forwarding the same forthwith to the Central Public Information Officer or the State Public Information Officer or senior officer specified under sub-section (1) of section 19 or the Central Information Commission or the State Information Commission, as the case may be: Provided that where an application for information or appeal is given to a Central Assistant Public Information Officer or a State Assistant Public Information Officer, as the case may be, a period of five days shall be added in computing the period for response specified under sub-section (1) of section 7. (3) Every Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, shall deal with requests from persons seeking information and render reasonable assistance to the persons seeking such information. (4) The Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, may seek the assistance of any other officer as he or she considers it necessary for the proper discharge of his or her duties. (5) Any officer, whose assistance has been sought under sub-section (4), shall render all assistance to the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, seeking his or her assistance and for the purposes of any contravention of the provisions of this Act, such other officer shall be treated as a Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 6
content: (1) A person, who desires to obtain any information under this Act, shall make a request in writing or through electronic means in English or Hindi or in the official language of the area in which the application is being made, accompanying such fee as may be prescribed, to— (a) the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, of the concerned public authority; (b) the Central Assistant Public Information Officer or State Assistant Public Information Officer, as the case may be, specifying the particulars of the information sought by him or her: Provided that where such request cannot be made in writing, the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, shall render all reasonable assistance to the person making the request orally to reduce the same in writing.
