(2) An applicant making request for information shall not be required to give any reason for requesting the information or any other personal details except those that may be necessary for contacting him. (3) Where an application is made to a public authority requesting for an information— (i) which is held by another public authority; or (ii) the subject matter of which is more closely connected with the functions of another public authority, the public authority to which such application is made shall transfer the application or such part of it as may be appropriate to that other public authority and inform the applicant immediately about such transfer: Provided that the transfer of an application pursuant to this sub-section shall be made as soon as practicable but in no case later than five days from the date of receipt of the application.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 7
content: (1) Subject to the proviso to sub-section (2) of section 5 or the proviso to sub-section (3) of section 6, the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, on receipt of a request under section 6 shall, as expeditiously as possible, and in any case within thirty days of the receipt of the request, either provide the information on payment of such fee as may be prescribed or reject the request for any of the reasons specified in sections 8 and 9: Provided that where the information sought concerns the life or liberty of a person, the same shall be provided within forty-eight hours of the receipt of the request. (2) If the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, fails to give a decision on the request for information within the period specified under sub-section (1), they shall be deemed to have refused the request. (3) Where a decision is taken to provide the information on payment of any further fee representing the cost of providing the information, the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer shall send an intimation to the person making the request, giving— (a) the details of further fees and the calculations made to arrive at the amount, requesting deposit of that fee, and the period between despatch of the intimation and payment shall be excluded for the purpose of calculating the thirty-day period; (b) information concerning the right to review the decision as to fees charged or the form of access provided, including particulars of the appellate authority, time limit, process, and other forms. (4) Where access to the record or part thereof is to be provided under this Act and the person is sensorily disabled, the officer shall provide appropriate assistance for access, including inspection. (5) Where access to information is to be provided in printed or electronic format, the applicant shall, subject to sub-section (6), pay such fee as may be prescribed: Provided that the fee shall be reasonable and no fee shall be charged from persons below the poverty line as determined by the appropriate Government. (6) Notwithstanding anything in sub-section (5), the information shall be provided free of charge where the public authority fails to comply with the time limits under sub-section (1). (7) Before taking any decision under sub-section (1), the officer shall consider any representation made by a third party under section 11. (8) Where a request is rejected under sub-section (1), the officer shall communicate to the applicant— (i) the reasons for such rejection; (ii) the period within which an appeal may be preferred; and (iii) the particulars of the appellate authority. (9) Information shall ordinarily be provided in the form in which it is sought unless doing so would disproportionately divert the resources of the public authority or be detrimental to the safety or preservation of the record in question.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 8
content: (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, there shall be no obligation to give any citizen— (a) information, disclosure of which would prejudicially affect the sovereignty and integrity of India, the security, strategic, scientific or economic interests of the State, relation with foreign State or lead to incitement of an offence; (b) information which has been expressly forbidden to be published by any court of law or tribunal or the disclosure of which may constitute contempt of court; (c) information, the disclosure of which would cause a breach of privilege of Parliament or the State Legislature; (d) information including commercial confidence, trade secrets or intellectual property, the disclosure of which would harm the competitive position of a third party, unless the competent authority is satisfied that larger public interest warrants the disclosure of such information; (e) information available to a person in his fiduciary relationship, unless the competent authority is satisfied that the larger public interest warrants the disclosure of such information; (f) information received in confidence from foreign Government; (g) information, the disclosure of which would endanger the life or physical safety of any person or identify the source of information or assistance given in confidence for law enforcement or security purposes; (h) information which would impede the process of investigation or apprehension or prosecution of offenders; (i) cabinet papers including records of deliberations of the Council of Ministers, Secretaries and other officers: Provided that the decisions of Council of Ministers, the reasons thereof, and the material on the basis of which the decisions were taken shall be made public after the decision has been taken, and the matter is complete, or over: Provided further that those matters which come under the exemptions specified in this section shall not be disclosed; (j) information which relates to personal information the disclosure of which has no relationship to any public activity or interest, or which would cause unwarranted invasion of the privacy of the individual unless the Central Public Information Officer or the State Public Information Officer or the appellate authority, as the case may be, is satisfied that the larger public interest justifies the disclosure of such information: Provided that the information which cannot be denied to the Parliament or a State Legislature shall not be denied to any person. (2) Notwithstanding anything in the Official Secrets Act, 1923 nor any of the exemptions permissible in accordance with sub-section (1), a public authority may allow access to information, if public interest in disclosure outweighs the harm to the protected interests. (3) Subject to the provisions of clauses (a), (c) and (i) of sub-section (1), any information relating to any occurrence, event or matter which has taken place, occurred or happened twenty years before the date on which any request is made under section 6 shall be provided to any person making a request under that section: Provided that where any question arises as to the date from which the said period of twenty years has to be computed, the decision of the Central Government shall be final, subject to the usual appeals provided for in this Act.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 9
content: Without prejudice to the provisions of section 8, a Central Public Information Officer or a State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, may reject a request for information where such a request for providing access would involve an infringement of copyright subsisting in a person other than the State.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 10
content: (1) Where a request for access to information is rejected on the ground that it is in relation to information which is exempt from disclosure, then, notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, access may be provided to that part of the record which does not contain any information which is exempt from disclosure under this Act and which can reasonably be severed from any part that contains exempt information. (2) Where access is granted to a part of the record under sub-section (1), the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, shall give a notice to the applicant, informing— (a) that only part of the record requested, after severance of the record containing information which is exempt from disclosure, is being provided; (b) the reasons for the decision, including any findings on any material question of fact, referring to the material on which those findings were based; (c) the name and designation of the person giving the decision; (d) the details of the fees calculated by him or her and the amount of fee which the applicant is required to deposit; and (e) his or her rights with respect to review of the decision regarding non-disclosure of part of the information, the amount of fee charged or the form of access provided, including the particulars of the senior officer specified under sub-section (1) of section 19 or the Central Information Commission or the State Information Commission, as the case may be, time limit, process, and any other form of access.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 11
content: (1) Where a Central Public Information Officer or a State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, intends to disclose any information or record, or part thereof, on a request made under this Act, which relates to or has been supplied by a third party and has been treated as confidential by that third party, the officer shall, within five days from the receipt of the request, give a written notice to such third party of the request and of the fact that the officer intends to disclose the information or record, or part thereof, and invite the third party to make a submission in writing or orally regarding whether the information should be disclosed. Such submission of the third party shall be kept in view while taking a decision about disclosure of information: Provided that except in the case of trade or commercial secrets protected by law, disclosure may be allowed if the public interest in disclosure outweighs any possible harm or injury to the interests of such third party. (2) Where a notice is served under sub-section (1) to a third party, the third party shall, within ten days from the date of receipt of such notice, be given the opportunity to make representation against the proposed disclosure. (3) Notwithstanding anything contained in section 7, the officer shall, within forty days after receipt of the request under section 6, if the third party has been given an opportunity to make representation under sub-section (2), make a decision as to whether or not to disclose the information or record or part thereof and give in writing the notice of the decision to the third party. (4) A notice given under sub-section (3) shall include a statement that the third party to whom the notice is given is entitled to prefer an appeal under section 19 against the decision.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 12
content: (1) The Central Government shall, by notification in the Official Gazette, constitute a body to be known as the Central Information Commission to exercise the powers conferred on, and to perform the functions assigned to it under this Act. (2) The Central Information Commission shall consist of— (a) the Chief Information Commissioner; and (b) such number of Central Information Commissioners, not exceeding ten, as may be deemed necessary. (3) The Chief Information Commissioner and Information Commissioners shall be appointed by the President on the recommendation of a committee consisting of— (i) the Prime Minister, who shall be the Chairperson of the committee; (ii) the Leader of Opposition in the Lok Sabha; and (iii) a Union Cabinet Minister to be nominated by the Prime Minister. Explanation.—Where the Leader of Opposition in the House of the People has not been recognised as such, the Leader of the single largest group in opposition of the Government in the House of the People shall be deemed to be the Leader of Opposition. (4) The general superintendence, direction and management of the affairs of the Central Information Commission shall vest in the Chief Information Commissioner who shall be assisted by the Information Commissioners and may exercise all such powers and do all such acts and things which may be exercised or done by the Central Information Commission autonomously without being subjected to directions by any other authority under this Act. (5) The Chief Information Commissioner and Information Commissioners shall be persons of eminence in public life with wide knowledge and experience in law, science and technology, social service, management, journalism, mass media, or administration and governance. (6) The Chief Information Commissioner or an Information Commissioner shall not be a Member of Parliament or Member of the Legislature of any State or Union territory, or hold any other office of profit, or be connected with any political party, or carry on any business or pursue any profession. (7) The headquarters of the Central Information Commission shall be at Delhi, and the Commission may, with the previous approval of the Central Government, establish offices at other places in India.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 13
content: (1) The Chief Information Commissioner shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office and shall not be eligible for reappointment: Provided that no Chief Information Commissioner shall hold office as such after he has attained the age of sixty-five years. (2) Every Information Commissioner shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office or till he attains the age of sixty-five years, whichever is earlier, and shall not be eligible for reappointment as such: Provided that every Information Commissioner shall, on vacating his office under this sub-section, be eligible for appointment as the Chief Information Commissioner in the manner specified in sub-section (3) of section 12: Provided further that where the Information Commissioner is appointed as the Chief Information Commissioner, his term of office shall not be more than five years in aggregate as the Information Commissioner and the Chief Information Commissioner. (3) The Chief Information Commissioner or an Information Commissioner shall, before entering upon his office, make and subscribe before the President or some other person appointed by him an oath or affirmation in the form set out in the First Schedule. (4) The Chief Information Commissioner or an Information Commissioner may, at any time, by writing under his hand addressed to the President, resign from his office: Provided that the Chief Information Commissioner or an Information Commissioner may be removed in the manner specified under section 14. (5) The salaries and allowances payable to and other terms and conditions of service of— (a) the Chief Information Commissioner shall be the same as that of the Chief Election Commissioner; (b) an Information Commissioner shall be the same as that of an Election Commissioner: Provided that if they are in receipt of a pension or retirement benefits from previous service, their salary shall be reduced by the amount of such benefits, as specified in this section: Provided also that salaries, allowances and other conditions of service shall not be varied to their disadvantage after appointment. (6) The Central Government shall provide the Chief Information Commissioner and the Information Commissioners with such officers and employees as may be necessary for the efficient performance of their functions under this Act, and the salaries, allowances, and service conditions of such officers and employees shall be as prescribed.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 14
content: (1) Subject to sub-section (3), the Chief Information Commissioner or any Information Commissioner shall be removed from office only by order of the President on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity after the Supreme Court, on a reference made by the President, has on inquiry reported that the Chief Information Commissioner or Information Commissioner ought to be removed. (2) The President may suspend from office, and if deemed necessary prohibit from attending the office during inquiry, the Chief Information Commissioner or any Information Commissioner in respect of whom a reference has been made to the Supreme Court under sub-section (1) until the President has passed orders on receipt of the report of the Supreme Court. (3) Notwithstanding sub-section (1), the President may by order remove from office the Chief Information Commissioner or any Information Commissioner if he— (a) is adjudged an insolvent; or (b) has been convicted of an offence which, in the opinion of the President, involves moral turpitude; or (c) engages during his term of office in any paid employment outside the duties of his office; or (d) is, in the opinion of the President, unfit to continue in office by reason of infirmity of mind or body; or (e) has acquired such financial or other interest as is likely to prejudicially affect his functions as the Chief Information Commissioner or an Information Commissioner. (4) If the Chief Information Commissioner or an Information Commissioner is in any way concerned or interested in any contract or agreement made by or on behalf of the Government of India or participates in any profit or benefit arising therefrom otherwise than as a member in common with the other members of an incorporated company, he shall, for the purposes of sub-section (1), be deemed guilty of misbehaviour.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 15
content: (1) Every State Government shall, by notification in the Official Gazette, constitute a body to be known as the ......... (name of the State) Information Commission to exercise the powers conferred on, and to perform the functions assigned to it under this Act. (2) The State Information Commission shall consist of— (a) the State Chief Information Commissioner; and (b) such number of State Information Commissioners, not exceeding ten, as may be deemed necessary. (3) The State Chief Information Commissioner and the State Information Commissioners shall be appointed by the Governor on the recommendation of a committee consisting of— (i) the Chief Minister, who shall be the Chairperson of the committee; (ii) the Leader of Opposition in the Legislative Assembly; and (iii) a Cabinet Minister to be nominated by the Chief Minister. Explanation.—Where the Leader of Opposition in the Legislative Assembly has not been recognised as such, the Leader of the single largest group in opposition of the Government in the Legislative Assembly shall be deemed to be the Leader of Opposition. (4) The general superintendence, direction, and management of the affairs of the State Information Commission shall vest in the State Chief Information Commissioner who shall be assisted by the State Information Commissioners and may exercise all such powers and do all such acts and things which may be exercised or done by the State Information Commission autonomously without being subjected to directions by any other authority under this Act. (5) The State Chief Information Commissioner and the State Information Commissioners shall be persons of eminence in public life with wide knowledge and experience in law, science and technology, social service, management, journalism, mass media, or administration and governance. (6) The State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner shall not be a Member of Parliament or Member of the Legislature of any State or Union territory, or hold any other office of profit, or be connected with any political party, or carry on any business or pursue any profession. (7) The headquarters of the State Information Commission shall be at such place in the State as the State Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, specify, and the State Information Commission may, with the previous approval of the State Government, establish offices at other places in the State.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 16
content: (1) The State Chief Information Commissioner shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office and shall not be eligible for reappointment: Provided that no State Chief Information Commissioner shall hold office as such after he has attained the age of sixty-five years. (2) Every State Information Commissioner shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office or till he attains the age of sixty-five years, whichever is earlier, and shall not be eligible for reappointment as such: Provided that every State Information Commissioner shall, on vacating his office under this sub-section, be eligible for appointment as the State Chief Information Commissioner in the manner specified in sub-section (3) of section 15: Provided further that where the State Information Commissioner is appointed as the State Chief Information Commissioner, his term of office shall not be more than five years in aggregate as the State Information Commissioner and the State Chief Information Commissioner. (3) The State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner shall, before he enters upon his office, make and subscribe before the Governor or some other person appointed by him an oath or affirmation according to the form set out in the First Schedule. (4) The State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner may, at any time, by writing under his hand addressed to the Governor, resign from his office: Provided that the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner may be removed in the manner specified under section 17. (5) The salaries and allowances payable to and other terms and conditions of service of— (a) the State Chief Information Commissioner shall be the same as that of an Election Commissioner; (b) the State Information Commissioner shall be the same as that of the Chief Secretary to the State Government: Provided that if they are in receipt of a pension or retirement benefits from previous service, their salary shall be reduced by the amount of such benefits, as specified in this section: Provided also that the salaries, allowances, and other conditions of service of the State Chief Information Commissioner and the State Information Commissioners shall not be varied to their disadvantage after appointment. (6) The State Government shall provide the State Chief Information Commissioner and the State Information Commissioners with such officers and employees as may be necessary for the efficient performance of their functions under this Act, and the salaries, allowances and service conditions of such officers and employees shall be as prescribed.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 17
content: (1) Subject to sub-section (3), the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner shall be removed from office only by order of the Governor on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity after the Supreme Court, on a reference made by the Governor, has on inquiry reported that the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner ought to be removed. (2) The Governor may suspend from office, and if deemed necessary prohibit from attending the office during inquiry, the State Chief Information Commissioner or any State Information Commissioner in respect of whom a reference has been made to the Supreme Court under sub-section (1) until the Governor has passed orders on receipt of the report of the Supreme Court. (3) Notwithstanding sub-section (1), the Governor may by order remove from office the State Chief Information Commissioner or any State Information Commissioner if he— (a) is adjudged an insolvent; or (b) has been convicted of an offence which, in the opinion of the Governor, involves moral turpitude; or (c) engages during his term of office in any paid employment outside the duties of his office; or (d) is, in the opinion of the Governor, unfit to continue in office by reason of infirmity of mind or body; or (e) has acquired such financial or other interest as is likely to prejudicially affect his functions as the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner. (4) If the State Chief Information Commissioner or a State Information Commissioner is in any way concerned or interested in any contract or agreement made by or on behalf of the Government of the State or participates in any profit or benefit arising therefrom otherwise than as a member in common with the other members of an incorporated company, he shall, for the purposes of sub-section (1), be deemed guilty of misbehaviour.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 18
content: (1) Subject to the provisions of this Act, it shall be the duty of the Central Information Commission or State Information Commission, as the case may be, to receive and inquire into a complaint from any person— (a) who has been unable to submit a request to a Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, either because no such officer has been appointed under this Act or because the Central Assistant Public Information Officer or State Assistant Public Information Officer, as the case may be, has refused to accept his or her application for information or appeal under this Act for forwarding the same to the appropriate officer or Commission; (b) who has been refused access to any information requested under this Act; (c) who has not been given a response to a request for information or access to information within the time limit specified under this Act; (d) who has been required to pay an amount of fee which he or she considers unreasonable; (e) who believes that he or she has been given incomplete, misleading, or false information under this Act; and (f) in respect of any other matter relating to requesting or obtaining access to records under this Act. (2) Where the Commission is satisfied there are reasonable grounds to inquire into the matter, it may initiate an inquiry. (3) The Commission, while inquiring into any matter under this section, shall have the same powers as vested in a civil court under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, in respect of— (a) summoning and enforcing the attendance of persons and compelling them to give evidence or produce documents; (b) requiring the discovery and inspection of documents; (c) receiving evidence on affidavit; (d) requisitioning any public record or copies from any court or office; (e) issuing summons for examination of witnesses or documents; and (f) any other matter as may be prescribed. (4) Notwithstanding anything inconsistent in any other law, the Commission may, during the inquiry of any complaint, examine any record to which this Act applies that is under the control of a public authority, and no such record may be withheld from it on any grounds.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 19
content: (1) Any person who does not receive a decision within the time specified in section 7(1) or 7(3)(a), or is aggrieved by a decision of the Central or State Public Information Officer, may, within thirty days from expiry of such period or from receipt of the decision, prefer an appeal to such officer senior in rank to the Public Information Officer in that public authority: Provided that such officer may admit the appeal after thirty days if satisfied that the appellant was prevented by sufficient cause from filing on time. (2) For appeals against an order under section 11 to disclose third party information, the concerned third party may appeal within thirty days from the order. (3) A second appeal shall lie within ninety days from the date the decision should have been made or was received, with the Central or State Information Commission: Provided that the Commission may admit an appeal after ninety days if satisfied there was sufficient cause for delay. (4) If the appeal concerns third party information, the Commission shall give the third party a reasonable opportunity of being heard. (5) In appeals, the onus to justify denial is on the Public Information Officer who denied the request. (6) Appeals under (1) or (2) shall be disposed of within thirty days, or within a maximum of forty-five days for reasons recorded in writing. (7) The decision of the Commission shall be binding. (8) In its decision, the Commission may— (a) require the public authority to take steps to secure compliance, including: (i) providing access in a particular form; (ii) appointing a Public Information Officer; (iii) publishing certain information; (iv) making changes to records management practices; (v) enhancing training provision on right to information; (vi) providing an annual report in compliance with section 4(1)(b); (b) require the public authority to compensate the complainant; (c) impose penalties under this Act; or (d) reject the application. (9) The Commission shall give notice of its decision, including appeal rights, to the complainant and public authority. (10) The appeal shall be decided in accordance with prescribed procedure.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 20
content: (1) Where the Commission, at the time of deciding any complaint or appeal, is of the opinion that the Public Information Officer has, without reasonable cause, refused to receive an application, not furnished information within the specified time, malafidely denied the request, knowingly given incorrect, incomplete or misleading information, destroyed information, or obstructed furnishing of information, it shall impose a penalty of two hundred and fifty rupees per day till the application is received or information furnished, subject to a maximum of twenty-five thousand rupees: Provided that the officer shall be given a reasonable opportunity of being heard before imposition of penalty: Provided further that the burden of proving reasonableness and diligence is on the officer. (2) Where the Commission is of the opinion that the officer has, without reasonable cause and persistently, failed to receive applications, not furnished information in time, malafidely denied requests, knowingly given incorrect, incomplete or misleading information, destroyed information, or obstructed furnishing of information, it shall recommend disciplinary action under the applicable service rules.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 21
content: No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall lie against any person for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done under this Act or any rule made thereunder.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 22
content: The provisions of this Act shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in the Official Secrets Act, 1923, and any other law for the time being in force or in any instrument having effect by virtue of any law other than this Act.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 23
content: No court shall entertain any suit, application or other proceeding in respect of any order made under this Act and no such order shall be called in question otherwise than by way of an appeal under this Act.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 24
content: (1) Nothing contained in this Act shall apply to the intelligence and security organisations specified in the Second Schedule, being organisations established by the Central Government, or to any information furnished by such organisations to that Government: Provided that information pertaining to allegations of corruption and human rights violations shall not be excluded: Provided further that in the case of allegations of human rights violations, the information shall only be provided after approval of the Central Information Commission, and notwithstanding section 7, such information shall be provided within forty-five days of the request. (2) The Central Government may, by notification, amend the Schedule by adding or removing any organisation, and such changes take effect upon publication. (3) Every such notification shall be laid before each House of Parliament. (4) Nothing contained in this Act shall apply to such intelligence and security organisations established by the State Government, as specified by notification in the Official Gazette: Provided that information on allegations of corruption and human rights violations shall not be excluded: Provided further that in the case of human rights violations, the information shall only be provided after approval of the State Information Commission and within forty-five days. (5) Every such notification shall be laid before the State Legislature.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 25
content: (1) The Central Information Commission or State Information Commission, as the case may be, shall prepare an annual report on the implementation of the provisions of this Act and forward it to the appropriate Government. (2) Each Ministry or Department shall collect and provide such information to the Commission as required to prepare the report. (3) The report shall include— (a) number of requests made; (b) number of decisions denying access and the provisions invoked; (c) number and nature of appeals and outcomes; (d) disciplinary actions taken; (e) charges collected; (f) facts indicating efforts to implement the Act; (g) recommendations for reform. (4) The appropriate Government shall lay the report before Parliament or the State Legislature, as applicable. (5) If the Commission finds a public authority's practices non-conforming with the Act, it may recommend steps to promote conformity.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 26
content: (1) The appropriate Government may, within available resources, (a) develop and organise educational programmes to advance public understanding, especially for disadvantaged communities, on exercising rights under the Act; (b) encourage public authorities to participate in or undertake such programmes; (c) promote timely dissemination of accurate information; and (d) train Public Information Officers and produce training materials. (2) Within eighteen months from commencement of the Act, the appropriate Government shall compile in its official language a guide containing easily comprehensible information needed to exercise rights under the Act. (3) Such guidelines shall be updated and published regularly and shall include: the objects of the Act; contact details of Public Information Officers; the manner and form of requests; duties of officers; assistance from the Commissions; legal remedies; provisions for voluntary disclosure; fee notices; and any additional relevant regulations or circulars. (4) The guidelines must be updated and published regularly.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 27
content: (1) The appropriate Government may make rules to carry out the provisions of this Act. (2) Such rules may provide for: (a) cost of medium or print cost price under section 4(4); (b) fee payable under section 6(1); (c) fee payable under section 7(1) and 7(5); (d) salaries, allowances, and service conditions under section 13(6) and section 16(6); (e) procedures for appeals under section 19(10); and (f) any other matter to be prescribed.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 28
content: (1) The competent authority may make rules to carry out the provisions of this Act. (2) Such rules may provide for: (i) cost of the medium or print cost price under section 4(4); (ii) fee payable under section 6(1); (iii) fee payable under section 7(1); and (iv) any other matter to be prescribed.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 29
content: (1) Every rule made by the Central Government shall be laid before each House of Parliament for a total period of thirty days, which may be comprised in one or more sessions, and is subject to modification or annulment by both Houses without affecting prior validity. (2) Every rule made by a State Government shall be laid before the State Legislature.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 30
content: (1) If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Act, the Central Government may, by order in the Official Gazette, make provisions not inconsistent with the Act for removing the difficulty, provided that no such order is made after two years from commencement. (2) Every such order shall be laid before each House of Parliament.

title: Right to Information Act, 2005 - Section 31
content: The Freedom of Information Act, 2002 is hereby repealed.

title: Repeal of Bengal Regulation XIV of 1807, Section 11, Clause 5
content: Repealed by the Amending Act, 1891 (12 of 1891).

title: Sarai Act - Section 2. Interpretation-clause
content: In this Act, unless there is something repugnant in the subject or context: "Sarai" means any building used for the shelter and accommodation of travellers, and includes, in any case in which only part of a building is used as a sarai, the part so used of such building. It also includes a purao so far as the provisions of this Act are applicable thereto. "Keeper of a sarai" includes the owner and any person having or acting in the care or management thereof. "Magistrate of the District" means the chief officer charged with the executive administration of a district in criminal matters, whatever may be his designation.

title: Sarai Act - Section 3. Notice of this Act to be given to keepers of Sarais
content: Within six months after this Act comes into operation, the Magistrate of the District in which any sarai to which this Act applies may be situated shall, and from time to time thereafter may, give to the keeper of every such sarai notice in writing of this Act, by leaving such notice for the keeper. By such notice, the Magistrate shall require the keeper to register the sarai as provided by this Act. Such notice may be in the form in the Schedule to this Act or to the like effect.

title: Sarai Act - Section 4. Registers of Sarais to be kept
content: The Magistrate of the District shall keep a register in which shall be entered, by such Magistrate or any person appointed by him for this purpose, the names and residences of the keepers of all sarais within his jurisdiction, and the situation of every such sarai. No charge shall be made for making any such entry.

title: Sarai Act - Section 5. Lodgers, etc., not to be received in Sarais until registered
content: After one month from the giving of such notice to register as provided by this Act, the keeper of any sarai or any other person shall not receive any lodger, or allow any person, cattle, sheep, elephant, camel, or other animal, or any vehicle, to halt or be placed in such sarai until the sarai and the name and residence of the keeper thereof have been registered as provided by this Act.

title: Sarai Act - Section 6. Magistrate may refuse to register keeper not producing certificate of character
content: The Magistrate of the District may, if he thinks fit, refuse to register as the keeper of a sarai any person who does not produce a certificate of character in such form and signed by such persons as the State Government may from time to time direct.

title: Sarai Act - Section 7. Duties of keepers of Sarais
content: The keeper of a sarai shall be bound: (1) When any person in such sarai is ill of any infectious or contagious disease, or dies of such disease, to give immediate notice thereof to the nearest police station; (2) At all times, when required by any Magistrate or other person duly authorized by the Magistrate of the District, to give such person free access to the sarai and allow inspection of it or any part thereof; (3) To thoroughly cleanse the rooms, verandahs, and drains of the sarai, and the wells, tanks, or other sources from which water is obtained for persons or animals using it, to the satisfaction of and as often as shall be required by the Magistrate of the District or his authorized representative; (4) To remove all noxious vegetation on or near the sarai, and all trees or branches that could allow thieves to enter or leave the sarai; (5) To keep the gates, walls, fences, roofs, and drains of the sarai in repair; (6) To provide such number of watchmen as may, in the opinion of the Magistrate of the District and in accordance with State Government rules, be necessary for the safety and protection of persons, animals, or vehicles lodging in or halting at the sarai; (7) To exhibit a list of charges for the use of the sarai at such place and in such form and languages as the Magistrate of the District shall from time to time direct.

title: Sarai Act - Section 8. Power to order reports from keepers of Sarais
content: The keeper of a sarai shall, if required by order of the Magistrate of the District served upon him, report—either orally or in writing as directed—to such Magistrate or person appointed by him, every person who resorted to such sarai during the preceding day or night. If written reports are required for a period exceeding one day or night, schedules shall be furnished by the Magistrate to the keeper, who shall fill them with the required information and transmit them in the manner and at the intervals directed by the Magistrate.

title: Sarai Act - Section 9. Power to shut up, secure, clear and clean deserted Sarais
content: If any sarai, by reason of abandonment or disputed ownership, remains untenanted and becomes a resort of idle or disorderly persons, or becomes filthy or unwholesome, or is complained of by two or more neighbors as a nuisance, the Magistrate of the District, after inquiry, may cause written notice to be given to the owner (if known and resident within the district) and also post such notice conspicuously on the sarai, requiring those concerned to secure, enclose, clean, or clear it. If the requisition is not complied with within eight days, the Magistrate may cause the necessary work to be executed, the expenses of which shall be paid by the owner and recoverable like penalties, or in the case of abandonment or disputed ownership, recovered by sale of any material found in the sarai.

title: Sarai Act - Section 10. Taking down or repairing ruinous Sarais
content: If a sarai or part thereof is deemed by the Magistrate of the District to be ruinous, likely to fall, or dangerous to persons or animals lodging in or halting at it, he shall give written notice to the keeper requiring him to take down, repair, or secure it as needed. If the keeper does not begin the work within three days of notice and complete it diligently, the Magistrate may cause the requisite work to be done, and the expenses shall be paid by the keeper and recoverable as provided under this Act.

title: Sarai Act - Section 11. Sale of materials of ruinous Sarais
content: If any sarai or part thereof is taken down under Section 10, the Magistrate of the District may sell the materials taken down, apply the proceeds to cover expenses incurred, restore any surplus to the owner upon demand, and recover any deficiency as if it were a penalty under this Act.

title: Sarai Act - Section 12. Penalty for permitting Sarais to be filthy or overgrown
content: Any keeper of a sarai who allows it to be in a filthy or unwholesome state, or overgrown with vegetation, or fails to cleanse or clear it within two days of receiving written notice from the Magistrate, or after conviction allows it to remain in such a state, shall be liable to the penalties in Section 14. The Magistrate may, instead of enforcing a daily penalty, cleanse or clear the sarai and recover expenses from the keeper as provided for penalties in this Act.

title: Sarai Act - Section 13. Power for State Government to make regulations
content: The State Government may make regulations to better attain the objects of this Act, provided such rules are not inconsistent with this Act or other laws in force. It may repeal, alter, or add to such regulations, and all changes shall be published in the Official Gazette.

title: Sarai Act - Section 14. Penalty for infringing Act or regulations
content: If the keeper of a sarai violates any provision of this Act or regulations made under it, he shall be liable on conviction before any Magistrate to a penalty not exceeding twenty rupees, and a further penalty not exceeding one rupee per day for every day during which the offence continues. This Act does not exempt any person from other penalties or liabilities to which they are subject under other laws. All penalties under this Act may be recovered in the same manner as fines under Section 61 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1861.

title: Sarai Act - Section 15. Conviction for third offence to disqualify persons from keeping Sarais
content: If a keeper of a sarai is convicted of a third offence under this Act, he shall not thereafter act as a keeper without the written licence of the Magistrate of the District, who may withhold or grant the licence on such terms and conditions as he thinks fit.

title: Sarai Act - Section 16. Nothing in Act to apply to certain Sarais
content: No part of this Act, except Section 8, applies to any sarai under the direct management of the State Government or of any Municipal Committee.

title: Sarai Act - Section 17. Extent of Act
content: This Act shall initially extend only to the territories under the Government of the Lieutenant-Governor of the North-Western Provinces of the Presidency of Fort William in Bengal. The State Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, extend this Act, with necessary modifications, to any other part of its territories, except the towns of Calcutta, Madras, and Bombay.

title: Sarai Act - Section 18. Short title
content: This Act may be called the Sarais Act, 1867.

title: Sarai Act - Schedule. Form of Notice
content: FORM OF NOTICE: Take notice that on the ______ day of ___________ 1867, an Act called the Sarais Act, 1867 was passed, and that before the day of ________ 20____, you, being keeper of a sarai [or purao] within [here state the district of the Magistrate giving the notice], must have your sarai [or purao] registered. The register is to be kept at [here state where the register is kept]. If you fail to register, you will be liable to a penalty not exceeding twenty rupees, and a further penalty not exceeding one rupee a day for every day during which the offence continues. On applying to [here give name and address of the person to keep the register], your sarai [or purao] will be registered free of charge. Dated the ____ day of _______ 20____.

title: Single-use Plastic (Regulation) Act, 2022 - Section 1. Short title, extent and commencement
content: (1) This Act may be called the Single-use Plastic (Regulation) Act, 2022. (2) It extends to the whole of India. (3) It shall come into force on such date as the Central Government may, by notification in the Gazette, appoint.

title: Single-use Plastic (Regulation) Act, 2022 - Section 2. Definitions
content: In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires: (a) “appropriate Government” means in the case of a State, the Government of that State and in all other cases, the Central Government; (b) “higher education institution” includes institutions imparting education on completion of senior secondary level; (c) “plastic” means material which contains as an essential ingredient a high polymer such as polyethylene terephthalate, high density polyethylene, Vinyl, low density polyethylene, polypropylene, polystyrene resins or multimaterials like acrylonitrile butadiene styrene, polyepthylene oxide, polycarbonate or polybutylene terephthalate; (d) “plastic packaging” means all products which are — (i) used for the containment, protection, handling, delivery and presentation of goods; and (ii) partly or wholly composed of plastic; (e) “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Act; (f) “recycle” means the reprocessing in a production process of the waste materials of a plastic product for the original purpose or for other purposes; (g) “reuse” means any operation by which a plastic product, which has been conceived and designed to accomplish within its life cycle a minimum number of trips or rotations, is refilled or used for the same purpose for which it was conceived; and (h) “single-use plastic” means any disposable plastic item which is designed to be used only once before it is thrown out or recycled and includes plastic forks and knives, plastic shopping bags, plastic coffee cups, lids, plastic water bottles, styrofoam, plastic take-out containers and plastic straws.

title: Single-use Plastic (Regulation) Act, 2022 - Section 3. Duties of Central Government
content: The Central Government shall, within six months from the commencement of this Act,— (a) prescribe a target of complete elimination of plastic waste in accordance with international obligations; (b) specify the year 2022 target year to implement a complete ban on single-use plastic and the proportion of reduction of single-use plastic during each year following the date of fixing of target year 2022; and (c) formulate and implement a National Plastic Control Policy for carrying out the purposes of this Act.

title: Single-use Plastic (Regulation) Act, 2022 - Section 4. Duties of Appropriate Government
content: The appropriate Government shall take necessary measures to promote sustainable alternatives to single-use plastic including,— (a) research by higher education institutions and others into sustainable alternatives to plastic packaging; and (b) the use of sustainable alternatives to plastic packaging.

title: Single-use Plastic (Regulation) Act, 2022 - Section 5. Measures by Appropriate Government
content: The appropriate Government shall take measures to ensure— (a) elimination of the production and use of plastics; (b) increase in recycling, reuse and other forms of waste recovery in relation to plastics; and (c) removing plastics already in the environment for the purpose of recycling, reusing or applying another form of waste recovery to the plastics.

title: Single-use Plastic (Regulation) Act, 2022 - Section 6. Prohibition on single-use plastic items after target year
content: Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, no person shall, after the target year 2022, use, stock, distribute, manufacture, sell or trade in any single-use plastic item.

title: Single-use Plastic (Regulation) Act, 2022 - Section 7. Penalty for violation
content: Whoever violates the provision of this Act shall be punished with a fine which shall not be less than rupees one lakh but which may extend upto five lakhs.

title: Single-use Plastic (Regulation) Act, 2022 - Section 8. Fund allocation
content: The Central Government shall, after due appropriation made by Parliament by law in this behalf, provide requisite funds for carrying out the purposes of this Act.

title: Single-use Plastic (Regulation) Act, 2022 - Section 9. Power to make rules
content: (1) The Central Government may, by notification, make rules for carrying out the provisions of this Act. (2) Every rule made under this Act shall be laid, as soon as may be after it is made, before each House of Parliament, while it is in session, for a total period of thirty days which may be comprised in one session or in two or more successive sessions, and if, before the expiry of the session immediately following the session or the successive sessions aforesaid, both Houses agree in making any modification in the rule or both the Houses agree that the rule should not be made, the rule shall thereafter have effect only in such modified form or be of no effect, as the case may be; so, however, that any such modification or annulment shall be without prejudice to the validity of anything previously done under that rule.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 1. Short title, extent and commencement
content: (1) This Act may be called the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973. (2) It extends to the whole of India: Provided that the provisions of this Code, other than those relating to Chapters VIII, X and XI thereof, shall not apply— (a) to the State of Nagaland; (b) to the tribal areas; but the concerned State Government may, by notification, apply such provisions or any of them to the whole or part of the State of Nagaland or such tribal areas, as the case may be, with such supplemental, incidental or consequential modifications, as may be specified in the notification. Explanation.—In this section, 'tribal areas' means the territories which immediately before the 21st day of January, 1972, were included in the tribal areas of Assam, as referred to in paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule to the Constitution, other than those within the local limits of the municipality of Shillong. (3) It shall come into force on the 1st day of April, 1974. State Amendment (Haryana): In the Code of Criminal Procedure (Haryana Amendment) Act, 2014, in section 1, after figures '2014', the words 'as extended to the Union territory of Chandigarh' shall be inserted. [Vide Notification No. GSR 929(E) dated 16th December, 2019.]

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 2. Definitions
content: In this Code, unless the context otherwise requires: (a) 'bailable offence' means an offence which is shown as bailable in the First Schedule, or which is made bailable by any other law for the time being in force; and 'non-bailable offence' means any other offence; (b) 'charge' includes any head of charge when the charge contains more heads than one; (c) 'cognizable offence' means an offence for which, and 'cognizable case' means a case in which, a police officer may, in accordance with the First Schedule or under any other law for the time being in force, arrest without warrant; (d) 'complaint' means any allegation made orally or in writing to a Magistrate, with a view to his taking action under this Code, that some person, whether known or unknown, has committed an offence, but does not include a police report. Explanation — A report made by a police officer in a case which discloses, after investigation, the commission of a non-cognizable offence shall be deemed to be a complaint; and the police officer making the report shall be deemed to be the complainant; (e) 'High Court' means (i) in relation to any State, the High Court for that State; (ii) in relation to a Union territory to which the jurisdiction of the High Court for a State has been extended by law, that High Court; (iii) in relation to any other Union territory, the highest Court of criminal appeal for that territory other than the Supreme Court of India; (f) 'India' means the territories to which this Code extends; (g) 'inquiry' means every inquiry, other than a trial, conducted under this Code by a Magistrate or Court; (h) 'investigation' includes all the proceedings under this Code for the collection of evidence conducted by a police officer or by any person (other than a Magistrate) who is authorised by a Magistrate in this behalf; (i) 'judicial proceeding' includes any proceeding in which evidence is or may be legally taken on oath; (j) 'local jurisdiction', in relation to a Court or Magistrate, means the local area within which the Court or Magistrate may exercise all or any of its powers under this Code and such local area may comprise the whole of the State, or any part thereof, as the State Government may notify; (k) 'metropolitan area' means the area declared or deemed declared under section 8 to be a metropolitan area; (l) 'non-cognizable offence' means an offence for which, and 'non-cognizable case' means a case in which, a police officer has no authority to arrest without warrant; (m) 'notification' means a notification published in the Official Gazette; (n) 'offence' means any act or omission made punishable under any law in force and includes acts in respect of which a complaint may be made under section 20 of the Cattle Trespass Act, 1871; (o) 'officer in charge of a police station' includes, when absent or unable to perform, the next-ranking police officer above the rank of constable or any other police officer so directed by the State Government; (p) 'place' includes house, building, tent, vehicle and vessel; (q) 'pleader', in relation to proceedings in any Court, means a person authorised to practise in such Court under law, and includes anyone appointed with Court’s permission; (r) 'police report' means a report forwarded under section 173(2); (s) 'police station' means any post or place declared as such by the State Government; (t) 'prescribed' means prescribed by rules under this Code; (u) 'Public Prosecutor' means any person appointed under section 24, and includes those acting under their directions; (v) 'sub-division' means a sub-division of a district; (w) 'summons-case' means a case relating to an offence other than a warrant-case; (wa) 'victim' means a person who suffered loss or injury caused by the act or omission for which the accused has been charged, including their guardian or legal heir; (x) 'warrant-case' means a case relating to an offence punishable with death, life imprisonment, or imprisonment exceeding two years; (y) words not defined herein but defined in the Indian Penal Code have the meanings assigned therein. State Amendment (Haryana): In section 2, for 'State of Haryana', substitute 'Union territory of Chandigarh'. [Vide Notification No. GSR 929(E) dated 16 December 2019.]

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 3. Construction of references
content: (1) In this Code — (a) unless the context otherwise requires, reference to a Magistrate means: (i) outside a metropolitan area — Judicial Magistrate; (ii) in a metropolitan area — Metropolitan Magistrate; (b) reference to a Magistrate of the second class means Judicial Magistrate (second class) outside metropolitan areas and Metropolitan Magistrate in metropolitan areas; (c) reference to a Magistrate of the first class means: (i) in metropolitan areas — Metropolitan Magistrate with jurisdiction there; (ii) in other areas — Judicial Magistrate (first class) with jurisdiction there; (d) reference to the Chief Judicial Magistrate means Chief Metropolitan Magistrate in metropolitan areas. (2) Reference to the Court of a Judicial Magistrate, in relation to metropolitan areas, means Court of the Metropolitan Magistrate. (3) In enactments before this Code’s commencement— (a) 'Magistrate of the first class' shall mean Judicial Magistrate (first class); (b) 'Magistrate of the second class' or 'third class' shall mean Judicial Magistrate (second class); (c) 'Presidency Magistrate' or 'Chief Presidency Magistrate' shall mean Metropolitan Magistrate or Chief Metropolitan Magistrate respectively; (d) areas included in metropolitan areas shall be construed accordingly. (4) In laws other than this Code, functions of Magistrates which involve evidence appreciation, decisions exposing a person to punishment, penalty, or detention pending inquiry/trial, or functions sending a person to trial, shall be exercised by Judicial Magistrates; while functions administrative or executive in nature, such as licensing, suspension or cancellation of licences, sanctioning or withdrawing prosecution, shall be exercised by Executive Magistrates. State Amendment (Union territories of Andaman & Nicobar Islands, Dadra & Nagar Haveli, and Lakshadweep): Insert section 3A — 'Special provision relating to Andaman and Nicobar Islands': (1) References to Chief Judicial Magistrate mean District Magistrate or, if directed, Additional District Magistrate; references to Magistrates of specified classes mean such Executive Magistrates as notified. (2) The State Government may declare cessation of this provision when adequate Judicial Magistrates are available. (3) On cessation, pending matters shall be transferred to Judicial Magistrates as specified. [Vide CrPC (Amendment) Regulation, 1974, s. 3.]

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 4. Trial of offences under the Indian Penal Code and other laws
content: (1) All offences under the Indian Penal Code shall be investigated, inquired into, tried, and dealt with according to the provisions hereinafter contained. (2) All offences under any other law shall be investigated, inquired into, tried, and dealt with according to the same provisions, subject to any law regulating the investigation, inquiry, trial or other dealing with such offences.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 5. Saving
content: Nothing in this Code shall, in the absence of a specific contrary provision, affect any special or local law in force, or any jurisdiction, power, or procedure conferred or prescribed by any other law in force.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 6. Classes of Criminal Courts
content: Besides the High Courts and Courts constituted under any other law, in every State there shall be: (i) Courts of Session; (ii) Judicial Magistrates of the first class and, in metropolitan areas, Metropolitan Magistrates; (iii) Judicial Magistrates of the second class; (iv) Executive Magistrates.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 7. Territorial divisions
content: (1) Every State shall be a sessions division or consist of sessions divisions; every sessions division shall be a district or consist of districts. Provided that every metropolitan area shall be a separate sessions division and district. (2) The State Government may, after consultation with the High Court, alter the limits or number of such divisions and districts. (3) The State Government may similarly divide any district into sub-divisions, altering their limits or number. (4) Existing sessions divisions, districts and sub-divisions at Code commencement shall be deemed formed under this section.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 8. Metropolitan areas
content: (1) The State Government may declare, by notification, that an area in the State comprising a city/town with population over one million is a metropolitan area. (2) From commencement of this Code, the Presidency-towns of Bombay, Calcutta and Madras, and the city of Ahmedabad, are deemed metropolitan areas. (3) The State Government may alter limits of a metropolitan area but shall not reduce population below one million. (4) If population falls below one million, the Government may by notification cease its metropolitan status; pending cases shall continue unaffected. (5) Reduction/alteration of limits shall not affect pending proceedings. Explanation: 'Population' means as per the last published census. State Amendment (Delhi): In section 8 — (a) in sub-section (1), after 'city or town', add 'or part thereof'; (b) substitute sub-section (3) to allow division into multiple metropolitan areas, provided none have below one million population; (c) insert sub-section (4A) empowering High Court to issue directions regarding pending proceedings post division. [Vide Delhi Act 9 of 2011, s. 2.]

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 9. Court of Session
content: (1) The State Government shall establish a Court of Session for every sessions division. (2) Every Court of Session shall be presided over by a Judge appointed by the High Court. (3) The High Court may appoint Additional and Assistant Sessions Judges. (4) A Sessions Judge of one division may also be appointed as Additional Sessions Judge of another. (5) If the Sessions Judge post is vacant, the High Court may authorise Additional/Assistant Sessions Judges or, if none, the Chief Judicial Magistrate, to handle urgent applications. (6) The Court of Session shall ordinarily sit at places notified by the High Court, but may sit elsewhere with prosecution and accused consent for case convenience. Explanation: 'Appointment' does not include government’s first appointment/posting/promotion of a person where required by law. State Amendment — West Bengal: Additional Sessions Judge in a sub-division (other than HQ) has all powers of Sessions Judge under specified sections, without derogating other powers. Orissa: Similar provision applies to Additional Sessions Judges in districts/sub-divisions other than HQ. [Vide respective State Acts.]

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 10. Subordination of Assistant Sessions Judges
content: (1) Assistant Sessions Judges are subordinate to the Sessions Judge. (2) The Sessions Judge may make rules for distribution of business among them. (3) The Sessions Judge may authorise an Additional/Assistant Sessions Judge or, if none, the Chief Judicial Magistrate, to deal with urgent applications in his absence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 11. Courts of Judicial Magistrates
content: (1) In every district (non-metropolitan), the State Government may, after consultation with the High Court, establish Courts of Judicial Magistrates (first and second class) as notified. Provided: Special Courts of Judicial Magistrates (first or second class) may be established for specific cases or case types in a local area, rendering other Magistrates in that area without jurisdiction over them. (2) Presiding officers are appointed by the High Court. (3) The High Court may confer Judicial Magistrate powers on members of the State Judicial Service functioning as Civil Court Judges. State Amendment (Union territories of Andaman & Nicobar Islands, Dadra & Nagar Haveli, Lakshadweep): In section 11(3), substitute 'member of judicial service of the State...' with 'any person discharging the functions of a civil court'. [Vide CrPC (Amendment) Regulation, 1974, s. 4.]

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 12. Chief Judicial Magistrate and Additional Chief Judicial Magistrate, etc.
content: (1) In every district (non-metropolitan), the High Court shall appoint a Judicial Magistrate of the first class to be the Chief Judicial Magistrate. (2) The High Court may appoint any Judicial Magistrate (first class) as Additional Chief Judicial Magistrate, with such powers of the Chief Judicial Magistrate as directed. (3) The High Court may designate any Judicial Magistrate (first class) in a sub-division as Sub-divisional Judicial Magistrate, and relieve them of such responsibilities when required. Subject to the Chief Judicial Magistrate’s control, they may supervise and control other Judicial Magistrates in the sub-division as directed by the High Court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 13. Special Judicial Magistrates
content: (1) The High Court, on Central or State Government request, may confer powers of Judicial Magistrate (first or second class) on any person who holds or has held any Government post, for specified cases or classes of cases in a non-metropolitan area, provided the person meets qualification/experience criteria prescribed by the High Court. (2) Such Magistrates are called Special Judicial Magistrates and are appointed for terms not exceeding one year at a time. (3) The High Court may empower a Special Judicial Magistrate to exercise powers of a Metropolitan Magistrate outside his local jurisdiction. State Amendment (Assam): Section 13 substituted to allow State Government to appoint Sub-divisional Magistrates. (Himachal Pradesh): In section 13(1), substitute 'in any district' with 'in any local area'. [Vide respective State Acts.]

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 14. Local jurisdiction of Judicial Magistrates
content: (1) Subject to the control of the High Court, the Chief Judicial Magistrate may define, from time to time, the local limits of the areas within which Magistrates appointed under section 11 or section 13 may exercise all or any of their respective powers under this Code. Provided that the Court of Special Judicial Magistrate may hold its sittings at any place within the local area for which it is established. (2) Except where otherwise provided by such definition, the jurisdiction and powers of every such Magistrate shall extend throughout the district. (3) Where the local jurisdiction of a Magistrate appointed under section 11, section 13, or section 18 extends to an area beyond the district or metropolitan area where he ordinarily holds Court, any reference in this Code to the Court of Session, Chief Judicial Magistrate, or Chief Metropolitan Magistrate shall, in relation to such Magistrate, be construed as a reference to the corresponding authority exercising jurisdiction in the said district or metropolitan area.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 15. Subordination of Judicial Magistrates
content: (1) Every Chief Judicial Magistrate is subordinate to the Sessions Judge; and every other Judicial Magistrate, subject to the general control of the Sessions Judge, is subordinate to the Chief Judicial Magistrate. (2) The Chief Judicial Magistrate may, from time to time, make rules or give special orders, consistent with this Code, regarding distribution of business among the Judicial Magistrates subordinate to him.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 16. Courts of Metropolitan Magistrates
content: (1) In every metropolitan area, the State Government may, after consultation with the High Court, establish as many Courts of Metropolitan Magistrates and at such places as notified. (2) Presiding officers of such Courts are appointed by the High Court. (3) Jurisdiction and powers of every Metropolitan Magistrate extend throughout the metropolitan area.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 17. Chief Metropolitan Magistrate and Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate
content: (1) The High Court shall, for every metropolitan area within its jurisdiction, appoint a Metropolitan Magistrate to be the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate. (2) The High Court may also appoint any Metropolitan Magistrate as Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, with all or any powers of the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate under this Code or any other law, as the High Court may direct.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 18. Special Metropolitan Magistrates
content: (1) The High Court, on the request of the Central or State Government, may confer upon any person who holds or has held any Government post, all or any powers of a Metropolitan Magistrate in respect of specified cases or classes of cases in any metropolitan area within its jurisdiction, provided such person meets qualifications or experience requirements in legal affairs as prescribed by High Court rules. (2) Such Magistrates are called Special Metropolitan Magistrates and are appointed for a term not exceeding one year at a time. (3) The High Court or the State Government, as the case may be, may empower any Special Metropolitan Magistrate to exercise powers of a Judicial Magistrate of the first class in any local area outside the metropolitan area.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 19. Subordination of Metropolitan Magistrates
content: (1) The Chief Metropolitan Magistrate and every Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate are subordinate to the Sessions Judge; every other Metropolitan Magistrate, subject to the general control of the Sessions Judge, is subordinate to the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate. (2) The High Court may define the extent of subordination of Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrates to the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate. (3) The Chief Metropolitan Magistrate may make rules or special orders, consistent with this Code, regarding distribution of business among Metropolitan Magistrates and allocation of business to Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrates.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 20. Executive Magistrates
content: (1) In every district and metropolitan area, the State Government may appoint as many Executive Magistrates as it deems fit, and shall appoint one as the District Magistrate. (2) The State Government may appoint any Executive Magistrate to be an Additional District Magistrate, granting such of the District Magistrate's powers as it directs. (3) If the office of District Magistrate becomes vacant and another officer assumes temporary administration of the district, that officer shall exercise all powers and perform all duties of a District Magistrate until orders of the State Government. (4) The State Government may place an Executive Magistrate in charge of a sub-division, to be called the Sub-divisional Magistrate, and may relieve him when necessary. (4A) The State Government may delegate its powers under sub-section (4) to the District Magistrate, subject to control and directions. (5) The State Government may also confer on a Commissioner of Police powers of an Executive Magistrate in relation to a metropolitan area.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 21. Special Executive Magistrates
content: The State Government may appoint Special Executive Magistrates for particular areas or specific functions, for such term as it thinks fit, conferring on them such powers of Executive Magistrates under this Code as it deems appropriate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 22. Local Jurisdiction of Executive Magistrates
content: (1) Subject to State Government control, the District Magistrate may, from time to time, define the local limits within which Executive Magistrates may exercise their powers under this Code. (2) Except as otherwise defined, every such Magistrate's jurisdiction and powers extend throughout the district.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 23. Subordination of Executive Magistrates
content: (1) All Executive Magistrates, other than Additional District Magistrates, are subordinate to the District Magistrate. Any Executive Magistrate (other than the Sub-divisional Magistrate) exercising powers in a sub-division is also subordinate to the Sub-divisional Magistrate, subject to the District Magistrate's general control. (2) The District Magistrate may make rules or special orders, consistent with this Code, regarding distribution of business among Executive Magistrates subordinate to him and allocation of business to an Additional District Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 24. Public Prosecutors
content: (1) For every High Court, the Central or State Government shall, after consultation with the High Court, appoint a Public Prosecutor and may also appoint Additional Public Prosecutors for conducting prosecutions, appeals, or other proceedings on its behalf. (2) The Central Government may appoint Public Prosecutors for any district/local area. (3) For every district, the State Government shall appoint a Public Prosecutor and may appoint Additional Public Prosecutors, who may also be appointed for another district. (4) The District Magistrate, in consultation with the Sessions Judge, shall prepare a panel of names fit to be appointed as Public Prosecutors/Additional Public Prosecutors. (5) Appointment by State Government for a district must be from the District Magistrate's panel. (6) If a regular cadre of Prosecuting Officers exists, appointments must be from that cadre, except when no suitable person is available, in which case appointments may be made from the panel. Explanation — 'Regular Cadre of Prosecuting Officers' means a cadre including Public Prosecutor posts and allowing promotion from Assistant Public Prosecutors; 'Prosecuting Officer' means any person appointed to functions of a Public Prosecutor or equivalents under this Code. (7) Eligibility for appointment as Public/Additional Public Prosecutor requires at least 7 years’ practice as an advocate. (8) Special Public Prosecutors with at least 10 years’ advocate practice may be appointed for specific cases; Courts may permit victims to engage advocates to assist under this provision. (9) Periods as a pleader or as a Prosecuting Officer count towards advocate practice. State Amendments: Karnataka — modifies sub-section (1). Maharashtra — deletes proviso to sub-section (6) and inserts (6A) permitting appointments from outside cadre with 7 years' practice. Madhya Pradesh — inserts sub-section (6A) enabling appointment outside cadre; modifies related provisions. West Bengal — amends sub-section (6) wording and removes proviso. Jammu & Kashmir and Ladakh — inserts sub-section (6A) permitting appointments without cadre consultation for High Court and District Courts.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 25. Assistant Public Prosecutors
content: (1) The State Government shall appoint in every district one or more Assistant Public Prosecutors for prosecutions in Magistrates’ Courts. (1A) The Central Government may appoint for any case or class of cases in Magistrates’ Courts. (2) No police officer shall be eligible for appointment as Assistant Public Prosecutor, except as provided in (3). (3) If no Assistant Public Prosecutor is available for a case, the District Magistrate may appoint another person, but not a police officer who (a) took part in investigation of the offence, or (b) is below Inspector rank. State Amendment (Orissa): Inserts proviso in sub-section (2) stating that nothing prohibits State Government from exercising control over Assistant Public Prosecutors through police officers.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 - Section 25A. Directorate of Prosecution
content: (1) The State Government may establish a Directorate of Prosecution with a Director of Prosecution and as many Deputy Directors as it thinks fit. (2) Director/Deputy Directors must have at least ten years’ practice as advocates and be appointed with concurrence of the Chief Justice of the High Court. (3) The Director heads the Directorate under administrative control of the State Home Department. (4) Every Deputy Director is subordinate to the Director. (5) Public Prosecutors, Additional Public Prosecutors, and Special Public Prosecutors appointed for the High Court are subordinate to the Director. (6) Those appointed for District Courts and Assistant Public Prosecutors are subordinate to the Deputy Director. (7) Powers, functions, and area jurisdiction of the Director and Deputy Directors are as specified by notification. (8) This section does not apply to the Advocate General when functioning as Public Prosecutor. State Amendments: Karnataka — substitutes sub-sections (2), (5), and modifies (6) terminology; Madhya Pradesh — substitutes entire section adding Additional, Joint, and Assistant Directors; modifies subordination details; Jammu & Kashmir and Ladakh — substitutes subsections to provide for a Director General of Prosecution with control and functions as per rules framed by the UT Government.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 26. Courts by which offences are triable
content: Subject to the other provisions of this Code: (a) Any offence under the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860) may be tried by: (i) the High Court, or (ii) the Court of Session, or (iii) any other Court by which such offence is shown in the First Schedule to be triable. Provided that any offence under section 376, section 376A, section 376AB, section 376B, section 376C, section 376D, section 376DA, section 376DB or section 376E of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860) shall be tried, as far as practicable, by a Court presided over by a woman.
