(b) Any offence under any other law shall, when any Court is mentioned in this behalf in such law, be tried by such Court; and when no Court is so mentioned, may be tried by: (i) the High Court, or (ii) any other Court by which such offence is shown in the First Schedule to be triable.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 27. Jurisdiction in the case of juveniles
content: Any offence not punishable with death or imprisonment for life, committed by any person who, at the date when he appears or is brought before the Court, is under the age of sixteen years, may be tried by the Court of a Chief Judicial Magistrate, or by any Court specially empowered under the Children Act, 1960 (60 of 1960), or any other law for the time being in force providing for the treatment, training, and rehabilitation of youthful offenders.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 28. Sentences which High Courts and Sessions Judges may pass
content: (1) A High Court may pass any sentence authorised by law. (2) A Sessions Judge or Additional Sessions Judge may pass any sentence authorised by law; but any sentence of death passed by any such Judge shall be subject to confirmation by the High Court. (3) An Assistant Sessions Judge may pass any sentence authorised by law except a sentence of death or of imprisonment for life or of imprisonment for a term exceeding ten years.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 29. Sentences which Magistrates may pass
content: (1) The Court of a Chief Judicial Magistrate may pass any sentence authorised by law except a sentence of death or of imprisonment for life or of imprisonment for a term exceeding seven years. (2) The Court of a Magistrate of the first class may pass a sentence of imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years, or of fine not exceeding ten thousand rupees, or of both. (3) The Court of a Magistrate of the second class may pass a sentence of imprisonment for a term not exceeding one year, or of fine not exceeding five thousand rupees, or of both. (4) The Court of a Chief Metropolitan Magistrate shall have the powers of the Court of a Chief Judicial Magistrate and that of a Metropolitan Magistrate, the powers of the Court of a Magistrate of the first class.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 30. Sentence of imprisonment in default of fine
content: (1) The Court of a Magistrate may award such term of imprisonment in default of payment of fine as is authorised by law: Provided that the term— (a) is not in excess of the powers of the Magistrate under section 29; (b) shall not, where imprisonment has been awarded as part of the substantive sentence, exceed one-fourth of the term of imprisonment which the Magistrate is competent to inflict as punishment for the offence otherwise than as imprisonment in default of payment of the fine. (2) The imprisonment awarded under this section may be in addition to a substantive sentence of imprisonment for the maximum term awardable by the Magistrate under section 29.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 31. Sentence in cases of conviction of several offences at one trial
content: (1) When a person is convicted at one trial of two or more offences, the Court may, subject to the provisions of section 71 of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860), sentence him for such offences to the several punishments prescribed therefor which such Court is competent to inflict. Such punishments, when consisting of imprisonment, shall commence one after the expiration of the other in such order as the Court may direct, unless the Court directs that such punishments shall run concurrently. (2) In the case of consecutive sentences, it shall not be necessary for the Court, by reason only of the aggregate punishment for the several offences being in excess of the punishment which it is competent to inflict on conviction of a single offence, to send the offender for trial before a higher Court: Provided that— (a) in no case shall such person be sentenced to imprisonment for a longer period than fourteen years; and (b) the aggregate punishment shall not exceed twice the amount of punishment which the Court is competent to inflict for a single offence. (3) For the purpose of appeal by a convicted person, the aggregate of the consecutive sentences passed against him under this section shall be deemed to be a single sentence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 32. Mode of conferring powers
content: (1) In conferring powers under this Code, the High Court or the State Government, as the case may be, may, by order, empower persons specially by name or in virtue of their offices, or classes of officials generally, by their official titles. (2) Every such order shall take effect from the date on which it is communicated to the person so empowered.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 33. Powers of officers appointed
content: Whenever any person holding an office in the service of Government, who has been invested by the High Court or the State Government with any powers under this Code throughout any local area, is appointed to an equal or higher office of the same nature within a like local area under the same State Government, he shall, unless the High Court or the State Government, as the case may be, otherwise directs, or has otherwise directed, exercise the same powers in the local area in which he is so appointed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 34. Withdrawal of powers
content: (1) The High Court or the State Government, as the case may be, may withdraw all or any of the powers conferred by it under this Code on any person or by any officer subordinate to it. (2) Any powers conferred by the Chief Judicial Magistrate or by the District Magistrate may be withdrawn by the respective Magistrate by whom such powers were conferred.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 35. Powers of Judges and Magistrates exercisable by their successors-in-office
content: (1) Subject to the other provisions of this Code, the powers and duties of a Judge or Magistrate may be exercised or performed by his successor-in-office. (2) When there is any doubt as to who is the successor-in-office of any Additional or Assistant Sessions Judge, the Sessions Judge shall determine by order in writing the Judge who shall, for the purposes of this Code or of any proceedings or order thereunder, be deemed to be the successor-in-office of such Additional or Assistant Sessions Judge. (3) When there is any doubt as to who is the successor-in-office of any Magistrate, the Chief Judicial Magistrate, or the District Magistrate, as the case may be, shall determine by order in writing the Magistrate who shall, for the purpose of this Code or of any proceedings or order thereunder, be deemed to be the successor-in-office of such Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 36. Powers of superior officers of police
content: Police officers superior in rank to an officer in charge of a police station may exercise the same powers, throughout the local area to which they are appointed, as may be exercised by such officer within the limits of his station.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 37. Public when to assist Magistrates and police
content: Every person is bound to assist a Magistrate or police officer reasonably demanding his aid: (a) in the taking or preventing the escape of any other person whom such Magistrate or police officer is authorised to arrest; or (b) in the prevention or suppression of a breach of the peace; or (c) in the prevention of any injury attempted to be committed to any railway, canal, telegraph or public property.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 38. Aid to person, other than police officer, executing warrant
content: When a warrant is directed to a person other than a police officer, any other person may aid in the execution of such warrant if the person to whom the warrant is directed be near at hand and acting in the execution of the warrant.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 39. Public to give information of certain offences
content: (1) Every person, aware of the commission of, or of the intention of any other person to commit, any offence punishable under any of the following sections of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860): (i) sections 121 to 126, both inclusive, and section 130 (offences against the State specified in Chapter VI); (ii) sections 143, 144, 145, 147 and 148 (offences against the public tranquillity specified in Chapter VIII); (iii) sections 161 to 165A, both inclusive (offences relating to illegal gratification); (iv) sections 272 to 278, both inclusive (offences relating to adulteration of food and drugs, etc.); (v) sections 302, 303 and 304 (offences affecting life); (va) section 364A (kidnapping for ransom, etc.); (vi) section 382 (theft after preparation made for causing death, hurt or restraint); (vii) sections 392 to 399, both inclusive, and section 402 (robbery and dacoity); (viii) section 409 (criminal breach of trust by public servant, etc.); (ix) sections 431 and 439, both inclusive (mischief against property); (x) sections 449 and 450 (house trespass); (xi) sections 456 to 460, both inclusive (lurking house trespass); and (xii) sections 489A to 489E, both inclusive (offences relating to currency notes and bank notes), shall, in the absence of any reasonable excuse (the burden of proving which excuse shall lie upon the person so aware), forthwith give information to the nearest Magistrate or police officer of such commission or intention. (2) For the purposes of this section, the term 'offence' includes any act committed at any place out of India which would constitute an offence if committed in India.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 40. Duty of officers employed in connection with the affairs of a village to make certain report
content: (1) Every officer employed in connection with the affairs of a village and every person residing in a village shall forthwith communicate to the nearest Magistrate or to the officer in charge of the nearest police station, whichever is nearer, any information which he may possess respecting: (a) the permanent or temporary residence of any notorious receiver or vendor of stolen property in or near such village; (b) the resort to any place within, or the passage through, such village of any person whom he knows, or reasonably suspects, to be a thug, robber, escaped convict or proclaimed offender; (c) the commission of, or intention to commit, in or near such village any non-bailable offence or any offence punishable under section 143, section 144, section 145, section 147, or section 148 of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860); (d) the occurrence in or near such village of any sudden or unnatural death or of any death under suspicious circumstances or the discovery in or near such village of any corpse or part of a corpse, in circumstances which lead to a reasonable suspicion that such a death has occurred, or the disappearance from such village of any person in such circumstances which lead to a reasonable suspicion that a non-bailable offence has been committed in respect of such person; (e) the commission of, or intention to commit, at any place out of India near such village any act which, if committed in India, would be an offence punishable under any of the following sections of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860), namely, 231 to 238 (inclusive), 302, 304, 382, 392 to 399 (inclusive), 402, 435, 436, 449, 450, 457 to 460 (inclusive), 489A, 489B, 489C and 489D; (f) any matter likely to affect the maintenance of order, prevention of crime, or safety of person or property respecting which the District Magistrate, by general or special order made with the previous sanction of the State Government, has directed him to communicate information. (2) In this section: (i) 'village' includes village-lands; (ii) 'proclaimed offender' includes any person proclaimed as an offender by any Court or authority in any territory in India to which this Code does not extend, in respect of any act which, if committed in the territories to which this Code extends, would be an offence punishable under sections 302, 304, 382, 392 to 399 (inclusive), 402, 435, 436, 449, 450 and 457 to 460 (inclusive); (iii) 'officer employed in connection with the affairs of the village' means a member of the panchayat of the village and includes the headman and every officer or other person appointed to perform any function connected with the administration of the village.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 41. When police may arrest without warrant
content: (1) Any police officer may, without an order from a Magistrate and without a warrant, arrest any person: (a) who commits, in the presence of a police officer, a cognizable offence; (b) against whom a reasonable complaint has been made, or credible information has been received, or a reasonable suspicion exists that he has committed a cognizable offence punishable with imprisonment for a term which may be less than seven years or which may extend to seven years whether with or without fine, if the following conditions are satisfied: (i) the police officer has reason to believe on the basis of such complaint, information, or suspicion that such person has committed the said offence; and (ii) the police officer is satisfied that such arrest is necessary to prevent such person from committing further offence; for proper investigation; to prevent tampering with evidence; to dissuade such person from influencing witnesses; or to ensure his presence in court. The police officer shall record reasons in writing for making such arrest. Provided that where arrest is not required, the police officer shall record reasons for not making the arrest. (ba) against whom credible information has been received that he has committed a cognizable offence punishable with imprisonment exceeding seven years or death and the police officer has reason to believe it; (c) who has been proclaimed as an offender under this Code or State Government order; (d) in whose possession stolen property is found and who may reasonably be suspected of an offence relating to it; (e) who obstructs a police officer in duty, or has escaped or attempts escape from lawful custody; (f) suspected deserter from the Armed Forces; (g) involved in any act committed outside India which would be an offence if committed in India and is liable to arrest under extradition or other laws; (h) released convict committing breach of rules under section 356(5); (i) requisition from another police officer with details of person and offence, and conditions for lawful arrest are met. (2) No person concerned in a non-cognizable offence shall be arrested without warrant, subject to section 42.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 41A. Notice of appearance before police officer
content: (1) Where arrest of a person is not required under section 41(1), the police officer shall issue a notice to such person to appear before him or at a specified place. (2) It is the duty of the person to comply with the notice. (3) Where the person complies, he shall not be arrested unless the police officer records reasons for arrest. (4) If the person fails to comply or is unwilling to identify himself, the police officer may arrest him, subject to court orders.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 41B. Procedure of arrest and duties of officer making arrest
content: Every police officer making an arrest shall: (a) bear visible identification of his name; (b) prepare a memorandum of arrest attested by a witness (family member of the arrested or respectable local resident) and countersigned by the arrested person; (c) inform the arrested person, unless the witness is a family member, of his right to have a relative or friend informed of his arrest.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 41C. Control room at districts
content: (1) The State Government shall establish a police control room in every district and at State level. (2) The names and addresses of arrested persons and details of arresting officers shall be displayed on the notice board at district control rooms. (3) The State-level control room shall maintain a public database of arrested persons, offence details, and arresting officers.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 41D. Right of arrested person to meet an advocate during interrogation
content: An arrested person is entitled to meet an advocate of his choice during interrogation, though not throughout the interrogation.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 42. Arrest on refusal to give name and residence
content: (1) If a person accused of committing a non-cognizable offence in presence of a police officer refuses to give his name and residence or gives false information, he may be arrested to ascertain it. (2) Upon ascertaining the true details, he shall be released on executing a bond to appear before a Magistrate if required, with surety if not resident in India. (3) If details are not ascertained within 24 hours or bond not executed, he shall be produced before Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 43. Arrest by private person and procedure
content: (1) Any private person may arrest one committing a non-bailable, cognizable offence or proclaimed offender in his presence, and hand him over to police or nearest station. (2) Police shall re-arrest if section 41 applies. (3) For non-cognizable offences with refusal to give correct name/residence, section 42 applies; otherwise, release him.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 44. Arrest by Magistrate
content: (1) A Magistrate witnessing an offence within jurisdiction may arrest or order arrest and commit to custody, subject to bail provisions. (2) A Magistrate may arrest or order arrest of any person he is competent to issue a warrant against.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 45. Protection of Armed Forces from arrest
content: (1) No member of the Armed Forces shall be arrested for acts done in official duty without consent of Central Government. (2) State Government may extend this protection to certain forces maintaining public order, substituting 'State Government' for 'Central Government'.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 46. Arrest how made
content: (1) The person making an arrest shall physically touch or confine the person unless there is submission by word or action. Provided that in case of a woman, her submission on oral intimation is presumed unless circumstances require otherwise; male officers shall not touch her unless necessary or they are female officers. (2) If arrested person resists or attempts to escape, force may be used as necessary. (3) No right to cause death unless the person is accused of an offence punishable with death or life imprisonment. (4) No woman shall be arrested after sunset and before sunrise except in exceptional circumstances, with written permission from Judicial Magistrate first class.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 47. Search of place entered by person sought to be arrested
content: (1) If the person to be arrested is believed to be in any place, the resident or person in charge shall allow entry and facilitate search. (2) If entry is refused, lawful breaking open of doors/windows is allowed after notification, except for certain female-occupied apartments, requiring notice and withdrawal for privacy before entry. (3) Officers may break open to free themselves or others lawfully inside who are restrained.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 48. Pursuit of offenders into other jurisdictions
content: A police officer may pursue and arrest in any place in India any person he is authorised to arrest without warrant.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 49. No unnecessary restraint
content: An arrested person shall not be subjected to more restraint than necessary to prevent escape.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 50. Person arrested to be informed of grounds of arrest and right to bail
content: (1) Any person arrested without warrant shall be informed of full particulars of the offence or grounds of arrest. (2) If arrested for a bailable offence, he shall be informed of his right to bail and allowed to arrange sureties.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 50A. Obligation to inform nominated person of arrest
content: (1) The arresting officer shall inform a friend, relative or nominated person about the arrest and place of detention. (2) The arrested person shall be informed of this right upon arrival at the police station. (3) An entry shall be made in a prescribed book showing who was informed. (4) The Magistrate shall ensure compliance with (2) and (3).

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 51. Search of arrested person
content: (1) The arresting officer may search the arrested person, safeguarding items except necessary clothing, and give a receipt for seized articles. If arrested by private person, police do this upon handover. (2) Searches of females must be conducted by another female with strict regard to decency.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 52. Power to seize offensive weapons
content: The arresting authority may take offensive weapons from the arrested person and deliver them to the Court or officer where the person is to be produced.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 53. Examination of accused by medical practitioner at the request of police
content: (1) A registered medical practitioner, on police request (rank not below sub-inspector), may examine an arrested person if such examination may afford evidence as to an offence, using necessary force if needed. (2) Female examinations only by or under supervision of female practitioners. Explanation: 'Examination' includes testing of blood, semen, swabs, sputum, sweat, hair, fingernail clippings, DNA profiling, and other necessary tests. 'Registered medical practitioner' means one with qualifications under the Indian Medical Council Act, 1956, listed in a State Medical Register.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 53A. Examination of person accused of rape
content: (1) Where a person is arrested for rape or attempted rape, a Government/local authority hospital's registered medical practitioner (or other practitioner within 16 km if unavailable) may examine him at request of police officer (not below sub-inspector) and use necessary force. (2) The report shall state: (i) accused's name/address and escorting officer; (ii) age; (iii) injuries; (iv) samples for DNA profiling; (v) other material particulars. (3) Reasons for conclusions shall be stated. (4) Time of commencement and completion shall be recorded. (5) Report shall be sent promptly to the investigating officer, who forwards it to the Magistrate under section 173.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 54. Examination of arrested person by medical officer
content: (1) Arrested persons shall be examined soon after arrest by a Government medical officer or, if unavailable, a registered medical practitioner. Females only by or under supervision of female officers/practitioners. (2) The examiner shall record injuries or marks of violence and likely time of infliction. (3) A copy of the report shall be furnished to the arrested or person nominated by him.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 54A. Identification of person arrested
content: Where identification by witnesses is necessary during investigation, the Court may, on request of the officer in charge, direct the arrested person to subject himself to identification proceedings. Provided that, if the identifying person is mentally or physically disabled, the process shall be supervised by a Judicial Magistrate ensuring comfortable methods and videography.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 55. Procedure when police officer deputes subordinate to arrest without warrant
content: (1) The superior officer shall give a written order to the subordinate specifying the person and offence/reason for arrest. The subordinate must inform the arrestee of the substance of the order and show it if required. (2) This does not affect arrest powers under section 41.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 55A. Health and safety of arrested person
content: The custodian of an accused must take reasonable care of his health and safety.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 56. Person arrested to be taken before Magistrate or officer in charge of police station
content: A person arrested without warrant shall be taken without unnecessary delay before a Magistrate having jurisdiction or officer in charge of a police station, subject to bail provisions.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 57. Person arrested not to be detained more than twenty-four hours
content: No person arrested without warrant shall be detained for more than 24 hours (exclusive of travel time to court) without a Magistrate's special order under section 167.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 58. Police to report apprehensions
content: Station officers shall report to the District Magistrate or Sub-divisional Magistrate (if directed) all cases of arrests without warrant within their jurisdiction, including cases where bail is granted.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 59. Discharge of person apprehended
content: No person arrested by a police officer shall be discharged except on his own bond, on bail, or under special order of a Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 60. Power, on escape, to pursue and retake
content: (1) If a person in lawful custody escapes or is rescued, the custodian may pursue and arrest him anywhere in India. (2) Section 47 provisions apply even if the arresting person is not acting under a warrant or is not a police officer.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 60A. Arrest to be made strictly according to the Code
content: No arrest shall be made except in accordance with the provisions of this Code or any other law in force providing for arrest.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 61. Form of summons
content: Every summons issued by a Court under this Code shall be in writing, in duplicate, signed by the presiding officer of such Court or by such other officer as the High Court may direct by rule, and shall bear the seal of the Court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 62. Summons how served
content: (1) Every summons shall be served by a police officer, or as per State Government rules, by an officer of the Court issuing it or other public servant. (2) The summons shall, if practicable, be served personally by delivering or tendering one duplicate to the person summoned. (3) The person served shall, if required, sign a receipt on the back of the other duplicate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 63. Service of summons on corporate bodies and societies
content: Service on a corporation may be effected by serving it on the secretary, local manager or other principal officer, or by registered post to the chief officer in India. Service is deemed effected when the letter would arrive in the ordinary course of post. 'Corporation' includes companies and societies registered under the Societies Registration Act, 1860.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 64. Service when persons summoned cannot be found
content: If the person summoned cannot be found with due diligence, service may be made by leaving one duplicate with an adult male family member residing with him, who shall sign a receipt on the other duplicate if required. A servant is not deemed a family member under this section.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 65. Procedure when service cannot be effected as before provided
content: If service under sections 62, 63 or 64 cannot be effected with due diligence, the serving officer shall affix one duplicate of the summons to a conspicuous part of the house or homestead where the person resides. The Court may, after inquiry, declare service duly effected or order fresh service.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 66. Service on Government servant
content: (1) Where the person summoned is in active Government service, the summons shall ordinarily be sent in duplicate to the head of the office, who shall cause it to be served as per section 62 and return it to the Court with signature and endorsement. (2) Such signature is evidence of due service.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 67. Service of summons outside local limits
content: When service is to be effected outside local jurisdiction, the Court shall send the summons in duplicate to a Magistrate within whose jurisdiction the person resides or is present.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 68. Proof of service in such cases and when serving officer not present
content: (1) When summons are served outside jurisdiction or when the serving officer is not present at hearing, an affidavit before a Magistrate stating service, with an endorsed duplicate, is admissible as evidence and deemed correct unless proved otherwise. (2) The affidavit may be attached to the duplicate and returned to the Court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 69. Service of summons on witness by post
content: (1) A Court may, along with a summons to a witness, send a copy by registered post to his ordinary residence, place of business, or place of work. (2) If acknowledgement by the witness or postal endorsement of refusal is received, the Court may declare service duly effected. In the Andaman & Nicobar Islands and Lakshadweep, service may also be by wireless message, with endorsement for refusal.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 70. Form of warrant of arrest and duration
content: (1) Every warrant of arrest shall be in writing, signed by the presiding officer of the Court, and bear its seal. (2) It remains in force until cancelled by the issuing Court or executed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 71. Power to direct security to be taken
content: (1) The Court issuing a warrant may endorse it for release on bail upon security. (2) The endorsement shall state number of sureties, amounts, and appearance time. (3) The executing officer shall forward the bond to Court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 72. Warrants to whom directed
content: (1) Warrants are ordinarily directed to police officers, but if no police officer is immediately available and urgent execution is needed, they may be directed to any other person(s). (2) When directed to multiple officers/persons, it may be executed by any or all of them.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 73. Warrant may be directed to any person
content: (1) The Chief Judicial Magistrate or Magistrate of first class may direct a warrant to any person within jurisdiction for arrest of an escaped convict, proclaimed offender, or accused of a non-bailable offence evading arrest. (2) Such person shall acknowledge receipt and execute it if the arrestee is on property under his charge. (3) The arrested shall be handed over to police for production before the competent Magistrate unless security under section 71 is taken.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 74. Warrant directed to police officer
content: A warrant directed to a police officer may be executed by another police officer whose name is endorsed on it by the officer to whom it is directed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 75. Notification of substance of warrant
content: The executing officer shall notify the substance of the warrant to the person to be arrested and, if required, show him the warrant.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 76. Person arrested to be brought before Court without delay
content: Subject to section 71, the arrested person shall be brought without unnecessary delay before the Court concerned, and the delay shall not exceed twenty-four hours (excluding travel time).

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 77. Where warrant may be executed
content: A warrant of arrest may be executed anywhere in India.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 78. Warrant forwarded for execution outside jurisdiction
content: (1) When a warrant is to be executed outside jurisdiction, the Court may forward it to an Executive Magistrate, District Superintendent of Police, or Commissioner of Police there. (2) It shall be accompanied by substance of the information and relevant documents for bail consideration under section 81.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 79. Warrant directed to police officer for execution outside jurisdiction
content: (1) A police officer executing a warrant outside jurisdiction shall have it endorsed by a local Magistrate or officer in charge. (2) The endorsement authorises execution and the local police shall assist. (3) Immediate execution without endorsement is permissible if delay would prevent execution.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 80. Procedure on arrest of person against whom warrant issued
content: If arrested outside issuing district, the arrestee shall be brought before the nearest Magistrate/District Superintendent of Police/Commissioner unless the issuing Court is nearer, within 30 km, or security under section 71 is taken.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 81. Procedure by Magistrate before whom such person arrested is brought
content: (1) The Magistrate or officer shall verify identity and direct removal to the issuing Court. If bailable and security is offered, take bail/security and forward bond. (2) Police may take security under section 71.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 82. Proclamation for person absconding
content: (1) If a Court believes a person against whom a warrant exists is absconding or concealing himself, it may publish a written proclamation requiring attendance at a specified place and time (at least 30 days later). (2) Proclamation shall be read and affixed publicly at residence/locality and at the Court-house, and may be published in a newspaper. (3) Written statement by the Court of due publication is conclusive evidence. (4) If accused of certain serious IPC offences and fails to attend, Court may declare him proclaimed offender. (5) Publication requirements apply to such declarations.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 83. Attachment of property of person absconding
content: (1) The Court issuing a proclamation under section 82 may order attachment of property of the proclaimed person, with reasons recorded. (2) Attachment covers property within district and outside with District Magistrate's endorsement. (3) Movable property may be attached by seizure, receiver appointment, or prohibition orders. (4) Immovable property by possession, receiver, or prohibition orders. (5) Perishable property may be sold immediately. (6) Receiver's powers as under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 84. Claims and objections to attachment
content: (1) Claims/objections to attachment within 6 months may be made by anyone other than proclaimed person, claiming interest in property. (2) Such claims may be made in issuing Court or Chief Judicial Magistrate's Court if attachment under section 83(2). (3) Court shall inquire and may allow/disallow claims. (4) If disallowed, claimant may within one year file a civil suit.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 85. Release, sale and restoration of attached property
content: (1) If proclaimed person appears in time, property is released. (2) If not, property vests in State after 6 months and disposal of claims, with some exceptions for decay or beneficial sale. (3) Within 2 years, appearance and proof of no intent to abscond may restore property or sale proceeds after expenses.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 86. Appeal from order rejecting application for restoration of attached property
content: A person aggrieved by refusal to return property or proceeds under section 85(3) may appeal to the appellate Court competent to hear appeals from the ordering Court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 87. Issue of warrant in lieu of, or in addition to, summons
content: A Court empowered to issue summons may issue a warrant instead if it believes the person will abscond or fail to obey, or if he fails to appear without reasonable excuse despite due service.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 88. Power to take bond for appearance
content: A Court may require a person present before it, whose appearance it may compel, to execute a bond with or without sureties.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 89. Arrest on breach of bond for appearance
content: If a person bound by bond to appear fails to do so, the Court may issue a warrant for his arrest.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 90. Provisions of this Chapter generally applicable to summonses and warrants of arrest
content: Provisions relating to summonses and warrants and their issue, service, and execution apply to all such processes issued under this Code.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 91. Summons to produce document or other thing
content: (1) Whenever production of any document or thing is necessary for proceedings under this Code, the Court or officer in charge of a police station may order the person possessing it to produce it. (2) Compliance may be by sending the item without personal appearance. (3) This does not affect certain Evidence Act provisions or apply to postal/telegraph custody.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 92. Procedure as to letters and telegrams
content: (1) Certain Magistrates or superior Courts may require postal/telegraph authorities to deliver documents/parcels wanted for proceedings. (2) Other Magistrates or senior police may require search/detention pending order of higher authority.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 93. When search-warrant may be issued
content: (1) Court may issue search warrant if: (a) a person will not produce documents as ordered under section 91/92; (b) item is not known to be in possession of any person; or (c) a general search is needed. (2) Warrant may limit search to specified place/part. (3) Only certain Magistrates may issue search warrants for postal/telegraph items.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 94. Search of place suspected to contain stolen property, forged documents, etc.
content: (1) Certain Magistrates may authorise entry, search, seizure, guarding, or custody for places used for deposit/sale of stolen or objectionable articles. (2) Objectionable articles include counterfeit coins, illegal metal tokens, counterfeit currency/stamps, forged documents, false seals, obscene items, and instruments for making such items.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 95. Power to declare certain publications forfeited and to issue search-warrants for the same
content: (1) State Government may declare certain publications forfeited if they contain matter punishable under specified IPC sections, and authorise police search and seizure. (2) 'Newspaper' and 'book' have meanings under the Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867; 'document' includes visual representations. (3) Orders/actions under this section are challengeable only as per section 96.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 96. Application to High Court to set aside declaration of forfeiture
content: (1) Persons with interest in forfeited publications under section 95 may apply to High Court within 2 months to set aside the declaration. (2) Special Bench of 3 Judges (or all Judges if less than 3) hears it. (3) Copies of the publication may be evidence. (4) If the court is not satisfied of the prohibited content, it shall set aside the declaration. (5) Decision by majority.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 97. Search for persons wrongfully confined
content: If certain Magistrates have reason to believe that a person is confined illegally, they may issue a search warrant, have the person produced before a Magistrate, and make appropriate orders.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 98. Power to compel restoration of abducted females
content: On sworn complaint of abduction or unlawful detention of a woman or a female under 18 years for unlawful purposes, certain Magistrates may order immediate restoration to liberty or to lawful guardian and use force to ensure compliance.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 99. Direction, etc., of search-warrants
content: Sections 38, 70, 72, 74, 77, 78, and 79 apply, as far as possible, to search-warrants under sections 93, 94, 95, or 97.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 100. Persons in charge of closed place to allow search
content: (1) Occupants shall allow entry for search upon warrant production. (2) If entry refused, section 47(2) applies. (3) Persons suspected of concealing items may be searched; females only by females with decency. (4)-(5) Two or more respectable local witnesses shall attend and sign seized items list. (6) Occupant or representative may attend; receives copy of list. (7) Persons searched receive list of seized items. (8) Refusal to witness without cause is an offence under section 187 IPC.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 101. Disposal of things found in search beyond jurisdiction
content: Things seized outside local jurisdiction with warrant shall be taken to issuing Court, unless nearer to local Magistrate, who may order them sent to the issuing Court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 102. Power of police officer to seize certain property
content: (1) Police may seize property alleged/suspected to be stolen or related to an offence. (2) Subordinate officers must report to officer in charge. (3) Seizures must be reported to Magistrate; property may be left on bond if transport/storage difficult or custody unnecessary. Perishables under Rs. 500, if unclaimed, may be auctioned with proceeds handled as per sections 457 and 458.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 103. Magistrate may direct search in his presence
content: A Magistrate may direct and witness a search of any place for which he may issue a search warrant.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 104. Power to impound document, etc., produced
content: A Court may impound any document or thing produced before it under this Code.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105. Reciprocal arrangements regarding processes
content: (1) Where a Court in the territories to which this Code extends desires that: (a) a summons to an accused person; or (b) a warrant for arrest of an accused person; or (c) a summons to any person requiring attendance and production of a document or thing; or (d) a search-warrant, issued by it, be served or executed at any place: (i) within the local jurisdiction of a Court in any State or area in India outside the said territories, it may send such summons or warrant in duplicate to the presiding officer of that Court for service or execution; section 68 applies as if such presiding officer were a Magistrate in the said territories; (ii) in a country outside India with which the Central Government has an arrangement for such service or execution (contracting State), it may send such summons or warrant in duplicate in prescribed form to a Court, Judge or Magistrate, through an authority specified by notification. (2) Where a Court in the said territories receives for service or execution a summons, warrant or search-warrant issued by a Court outside the said territories or in a contracting State, it shall cause it to be served/executed as if received from another Court in the said territories. Execution of arrest warrants follows sections 80 and 81; execution of search-warrants follows section 101. Proviso: In case of execution from a contracting State, documents or things obtained shall be forwarded to the issuing Court through the authority notified by the Central Government.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105A. Definitions (Chapter VIIA)
content: In this Chapter: (a) 'contracting State' means a country or place outside India with which the Central Government has made arrangements through treaty or otherwise; (b) 'identifying' includes proving that property was derived from, or used in, the commission of an offence; (c) 'proceeds of crime' means any property derived or obtained directly or indirectly by any person as a result of criminal activity, including the value thereof; (d) 'property' means all property and assets of any description, corporeal or incorporeal, movable or immovable, tangible or intangible, and deeds/instruments evidencing title or interest, including that obtained through proceeds of crime; (e) 'tracing' means determining nature, source, disposition, movement, title or ownership of property.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105B. Assistance in securing transfer of persons
content: (1) Where a Court in India desires a warrant for arrest of a person to be executed in a contracting State, it shall send it in duplicate to a Court, Judge or Magistrate there through an authority notified by the Central Government; such authority shall cause it to be executed. (2) During investigation/inquiry, if attendance of a person in a contracting State is required, the Court may issue a summons or warrant to be served/executed there. (3) Warrants from contracting States are executed as if from another Court in India. (4) Where a person is transferred to a contracting State from India and is a prisoner, the Court or Central Government may impose conditions. (5) Where a person transferred to India is a prisoner in a contracting State, the Court in India shall ensure compliance with transfer conditions and custody directions of the Central Government.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105C. Assistance in relation to orders of attachment or forfeiture of property
content: (1) If a Court in India has reasonable grounds to believe property is derived from an offence, it may order attachment or forfeiture under sections 105D to 105J. (2) If such property is suspected to be in a contracting State, the Court may issue a letter of request to that State for execution. (3) Letters of request from contracting States for attachment/forfeiture in India may be forwarded by the Central Government to the appropriate Court for execution under sections 105D to 105J or other applicable law.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105D. Identifying unlawfully acquired property
content: (1) The Court shall, on its own or on receiving a letter of request under section 105C(3), direct a police officer not below Sub-Inspector to take steps to trace and identify such property. (2) Steps may include inquiry, investigation, or survey of persons, places, property, assets, bank accounts, and relevant matters. (3) Such inquiries must follow Court directions.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105E. Seizure or attachment of property
content: (1) If an officer under section 105D believes property may be concealed, transferred or dealt with to prevent recovery, he may seize it or, if impracticable, order that it not be transferred/dealt with without permission. Copy of order served on concerned person. (2) Such order lapses unless confirmed by the Court within 30 days.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105F. Management of properties seized or forfeited
content: (1) The Court may appoint the District Magistrate or another nominated officer as Administrator. (2) The Administrator shall receive and manage property attached or forfeited as directed by the Central Government. (3) The Administrator shall dispose of forfeited property as directed by the Central Government.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105G. Notice of forfeiture of property
content: (1) If after inquiry under section 105D the Court believes property is proceeds of crime, it may serve notice to the affected person to explain the source within 30 days and show cause why it should not be forfeited. (2) If held on behalf by another, a copy shall be served on that person.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105H. Forfeiture of property in certain cases
content: (1) After considering the explanation to notice under section 105G and hearing affected persons, the Court shall decide if property is proceeds of crime; failure to appear allows ex parte decision. (2) If certain proceeds cannot be specifically identified, the Court may specify them to the best of its judgment. (3) Property found as proceeds stands forfeited to the Central Government free of encumbrances. (4) Forfeited company shares shall be transferred to the Government by the company.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105-I. Fine in lieu of forfeiture
content: (1) Where only part of property’s source is unproved, the Court may allow payment of a fine equal to its market value instead of forfeiture. (2) The affected person must be heard before imposing fine. (3) On payment within allowed time, forfeiture is revoked and property released.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105J. Certain transfers to be null and void
content: Any transfer of property after order under section 105E or notice under section 105G is to be ignored; if forfeited under section 105H, such transfers are void.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105K. Procedure in respect of letter of request
content: Every letter of request, summons or warrant to/from a contracting State under this Chapter shall be transmitted in such form and manner as the Central Government notifies.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 105L. Application of this Chapter
content: The Central Government may, by notification, apply this Chapter to a contracting State subject to specified conditions, exceptions or qualifications.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 106. Security for keeping the peace on conviction
content: (1) On convicting for offences in subsection (2), a Court may order the person to execute a bond, with/without sureties, to keep the peace up to three years. (2) Offences include: (a) offences under Chapter VIII IPC excluding sections 153A, 153B, 154; (b) offences involving assault, criminal force or mischief; (c) criminal intimidation; (d) other offences causing/likely to cause breach of peace. (3) If conviction is set aside, bond is void. (4) Appellate/Revision Courts may also make such orders.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 107. Security for keeping the peace in other cases
content: (1) An Executive Magistrate with sufficient grounds may require a person likely to cause breach of peace or disturb public tranquillity to show cause why he should not execute a bond (with/without sureties) for up to one year. (2) Jurisdiction exists if the place of apprehended breach is within the Magistrate’s local jurisdiction or such person is within it.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 108. Security for good behaviour from persons disseminating seditious matters
content: (1) An Executive Magistrate may act if a person intentionally disseminates, attempts to disseminate or abets dissemination of: (a) matter punishable under sections 124A, 153A, 153B, 295A IPC; (b) matter concerning a Judge amounting to criminal intimidation or defamation; or produces, keeps for sale, distributes or exhibits obscene matter under section 292 IPC. The Magistrate may require a bond (with/without sureties) for up to one year. (2) No proceedings against registered publication editors, proprietors, printers or publishers without State Government authority.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 109. Security for good behaviour from suspected persons
content: If an Executive Magistrate receives information about a person concealing his presence with intent to commit a cognizable offence, he may require a bond (with/without sureties) for good behaviour for up to one year.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 110. Security for good behaviour from habitual offenders
content: If an Executive Magistrate is informed of a person who is habitually a robber, house-breaker, forger, receiver of stolen property, protector of thieves, commits specified offences (kidnapping, extortion, cheating, mischief, IPC Chapter XII, currency offences), or habitually breaches peace, commits offences under listed Acts (Drugs & Cosmetics, FERA, EPF, Prevention of Food Adulteration, Essential Commodities, Untouchability (Offences), Customs, Foreigners), laws against hoarding, profiteering, adulteration, corruption, or is so dangerous as to require security, he may order a bond with sureties for up to three years.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 111. Order to be made
content: When acting under sections 107-110, the Magistrate shall make a written order stating the substance of the information, bond amount, term, and number/class of sureties required.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 112. Procedure in respect of person present in Court
content: If the person is present, the order under section 111 shall be read to him or explained if he wishes.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 113. Summons or warrant in case of person not so present
content: If the person is absent, the Magistrate shall issue a summons, or if in custody, a warrant to bring him. Proviso: If breach of peace is feared and immediate arrest is necessary, the Magistrate may issue a warrant at any time.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 114. Copy of order to accompany summons or warrant
content: Every summons or warrant under section 113 shall be accompanied by a copy of the section 111 order, to be delivered to the person served/arrested.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 115. Power to dispense with personal attendance
content: The Magistrate may dispense with personal attendance and permit appearance by pleader for persons required to show cause regarding security.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 116. Inquiry as to truth of information
content: (1) After an order under section 111, the Magistrate shall inquire into the truth of the information and take evidence. (2) Inquiry to follow summons-case trial procedure. (3) Before completion, the Magistrate may require interim bond for peace/good behaviour if immediate measures are needed; may detain until bond executed. Proviso: (a) No bond for good behaviour from persons not under sections 108-110; (b) Bond conditions not harsher than section 111 order. (4) Habitual offender/desperate person status may be proved by general repute or otherwise. (5) Multiple persons may be dealt with jointly or separately. (6) Inquiry to be completed within six months, else terminate unless special reasons recorded; detention cases terminate after six months. (7) Sessions Judge may vacate extension if without valid special reason.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 117. Order to give security
content: If proved necessary after inquiry, the Magistrate shall order execution of bond with/without sureties as per section 111. Bond amount to be reasonable. Minors' bonds executed only by sureties.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 118. Discharge of person informed against
content: If not proved necessary to require security, the Magistrate shall record this and discharge the person, releasing him if in custody solely for the inquiry.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 119. Commencement of period for which security is required
content: (1) If the person is serving a sentence when order made under section 106 or 117, the security period starts after sentence expiry. (2) In other cases, it starts on order date unless later date fixed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 120. Contents of bond
content: Bond binds the person to keep peace or good behaviour; for good behaviour, committing, attempting, or abetting any imprisonable offence anywhere breaches the bond.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 121. Power to reject sureties
content: (1) Magistrate may refuse/reject surety as unfit, after inquiry on oath. (2) Notice of inquiry to surety and proposer; evidence recorded. (3) If found unfit, order with reasons to refuse/reject. Before rejecting an accepted surety, issue summons/warrant to the bound person.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 122. Imprisonment in default of security
content: (1)(a) If ordered to give security under section 106 or 117 and fails, commit/detain in prison until period expires or security given; (b) If person bound to peace breaches bond, may be arrested/detained until term expires, in addition to other penalties. (2) If security period exceeds one year and not given, refer to Sessions Judge; he may decide case. (3) Sessions Court may call for more evidence, hear the person, and decide; detention not over three years. (4) Joint proceedings may be referred together. (5) Sessions Judge may transfer to Additional/Assistant Sessions Judge. (6) If security tendered to jail officer, refer to issuing Court/Magistrate. (7) Prison for default in security for peace is simple. (8) Default in security for good behaviour under section 108 is simple; under sections 109 or 110, rigorous or simple as directed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 123. Power to release persons imprisoned for failing to give security
content: (1) The District Magistrate (for orders by an Executive Magistrate under section 117) or the Chief Judicial Magistrate (in other cases) may order the release of a person imprisoned for failing to give security, if satisfied release poses no hazard to the community or others. (2) The High Court, Court of Session, District Magistrate (for section 117 orders), or Chief Judicial Magistrate (in other cases) may reduce the amount, number of sureties, or time of security. (3) Discharge may be unconditional or on conditions accepted by the person; conditions cease when the security period expires. (4) State Government may prescribe conditions for conditional discharge. (5) If conditions are not fulfilled, the District Magistrate/Chief Judicial Magistrate may cancel discharge. (6) On cancellation, the person may be arrested without warrant and brought before the relevant Magistrate. (7) Unless security is given for the unexpired period, the Magistrate may remand the person to prison for that period. (8) Such person may be released anytime on giving security for the unexpired period to the original Court or its successor. (9) The High Court, Court of Session, or relevant Magistrate may cancel any bond executed under this Chapter. (10) A surety may apply to cancel a bond; in such case the Court shall summon or produce the bound person before it.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 124. Security for unexpired period of bond
content: (1) When a person appears or is brought before the Magistrate or Court under section 121(3) proviso or section 123(10), the bond executed by him shall be cancelled, and he shall be ordered to give fresh security of the same description for the unexpired term. (2) Such order is deemed to be under section 106 or section 117 for sections 120–123 purposes.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 125. Order for maintenance of wives, children and parents
content: (1) If a person with sufficient means neglects or refuses to maintain: (a) his wife unable to maintain herself; (b) his legitimate or illegitimate minor child unable to maintain itself (married or not); (c) his legitimate or illegitimate child (not a married daughter) who has attained majority but cannot maintain itself due to physical/mental abnormality or injury; (d) his father or mother unable to maintain themselves; a Magistrate of the first class may order such person to make a monthly allowance at a rate deemed fit. Provisos allow orders for minor female child until majority if husband lacks means; allow interim maintenance and expenses during proceedings; such applications should be disposed of within 60 days of service. Explanation: 'minor' as per Indian Majority Act, 1875; 'wife' includes divorced but unmarried women. (2) Allowance is payable from order date or, if ordered, from application date. (3) Failure to comply without sufficient cause permits issuing warrant to levy amount as fine and possible imprisonment up to one month for each month's unpaid sum. Recovery must be applied for within one year of due date. Grounds for wife's refusal to live with husband may be considered. Husband's remarriage or mistress is just ground for refusal to live. (4) No maintenance if wife in adultery, refuses to live with husband without sufficient cause, or by mutual consent. (5) Order may be cancelled if wife in adultery, refuses without cause, or they agree to live separately. State amendments: Madhya Pradesh — limit increased to Rs. 3000, includes grandparents; West Bengal — limit increased to Rs. 1500, added immediate relief provision (later limit proviso omitted).

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 126. Procedure
content: (1) Proceedings under section 125 may be taken in any district: (a) where the person is; (b) where he or his wife resides; or (c) where he last resided with his wife or mother of illegitimate child. (2) Evidence to be taken in presence of the person (or pleader), recorded as in summons-cases. Proviso: if person avoids service or neglects to attend, case may be heard ex parte; ex parte order may be set aside for good cause within three months, with possible cost terms. (3) Court may make orders as to costs.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 127. Alteration in allowance
content: (1) On proof of change in circumstances, Magistrate may alter maintenance or interim maintenance ordered under section 125. (2) If a Civil Court decision warrants cancellation/variation, Magistrate shall do so. (3) For orders in favour of divorced women: (a) remarriage — cancel from date of remarriage; (b) sum payable on divorce fully received — cancel from date of order or expiry of paid period; (c) voluntary surrender of rights — cancel from date of surrender. (4) When decreeing maintenance or dowry, Civil Court shall account for amounts paid under section 125. State amendments: MP — includes grandparents; WB — raised limit to Rs. 1500 then removed limit proviso.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 128. Enforcement of order of maintenance
content: A copy of the maintenance/interim maintenance order shall be given free to the beneficiary or guardian. It may be enforced by any Magistrate where the liable person is found, on being satisfied about identity and non-payment.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 129. Dispersal of assembly by use of civil force
content: (1) Executive Magistrate, officer in charge of police station, or sub-inspector (if OIC absent) may command unlawful assembly or assembly of 5+ persons likely to disturb peace to disperse. Members must comply. (2) If they do not disperse, or show determination not to, the authority may disperse by force and seek assistance of any male person (not armed forces member acting as such) to disperse and/or arrest/confine members for dispersal or punishment.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 130. Use of armed forces to disperse assembly
content: (1) If assembly cannot otherwise be dispersed and public security requires, the highest-ranking Executive Magistrate present may cause it to be dispersed by armed forces. (2) Magistrate may require armed forces officer to disperse and arrest/confine persons as needed. (3) Armed forces officer shall comply, using minimal necessary force and injury.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 131. Power of certain armed force officers to disperse assembly
content: If public security is endangered by an assembly and no Executive Magistrate is available, a commissioned/gazetted armed forces officer may disperse it and arrest members. Upon contacting a Magistrate, he must follow that Magistrate’s instructions.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 132. Protection against prosecution for acts done under preceding sections
content: (1) No prosecution for acts under sections 129–131 without: (a) Central Government sanction for armed forces; (b) State Government sanction otherwise. (2) Protection applies to Executive Magistrates, police, persons assisting under 129–130, armed forces officers under 131, and members obeying lawful orders, if acting in good faith. (3) Definitions: 'armed forces' includes military, naval, air, and other Union armed forces operating as land forces; 'officer' includes commissioned, gazetted, in-pay officers, JCOs, warrant, petty, NCOs, non-gazetted officers; 'member' means armed forces personnel other than officers.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 133. Conditional order for removal of nuisance
content: (1) Certain Magistrates, on report/info and evidence, may order removal of unlawful obstruction/nuisance in public places/ways, regulate or remove injurious trades/goods, prevent dangerous construction/disposal, remove dangerous structures/trees, fence dangerous tanks/wells, destroy/confine dangerous animals, or require appearance to show cause. (2) Such orders cannot be questioned in Civil Court. Explanation: 'public place' includes State property, camping grounds, sanitary or recreational grounds.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 134. Service or notification of order
content: (1) Serve on the person per summons service method. (2) If not practicable, notify by proclamation as per State Government rules and post copies in suitable places.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 135. Person to whom order is addressed to obey or show cause
content: Person against whom order is made shall either perform act within specified time/manner or appear and show cause.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 136. Consequences of failing to do so
content: If the person does not perform or appear and show cause, he is liable under section 188 IPC and the order is made absolute.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 137. Procedure where existence of public right is denied
content: (1) In section 133 cases regarding public use of way/river/channel/place, Magistrate shall ask respondent if public right is denied. If so, inquire into matter before section 138 proceedings. (2) If reliable evidence supports denial, stay proceedings until competent Court decides; if none, proceed under section 138. (3) Failure to deny when questioned, or failure to prove denial, bars later denial.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 138. Procedure where person appears to show cause
content: (1) If person appears and shows cause, Magistrate takes evidence as in summons-cases. (2) If satisfied the order is reasonable/proper, make absolute (with/without modifications). (3) If not satisfied, close proceedings.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 139. Power of Magistrate to direct local investigation and examination of an expert
content: For inquiries under sections 137–138, Magistrate may order local investigation by suitable person or summon/examine an expert.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 140. Power of Magistrate to furnish written instructions, etc.
content: (1) Magistrate may provide written instructions and determine cost liability for local investigations under section 139. (2) Such report may be read as evidence. (3) For experts, Magistrate may direct cost liability.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 141. Procedure on order being made absolute and consequences of disobedience
content: (1) On order being absolute, Magistrate notifies the person and requires compliance within time, warning of section 188 IPC penalty. (2) On non-compliance, Magistrate may perform act and recover costs via sale of removed items or distress/sale of other movables (even outside jurisdiction with endorsement). (3) No suit lies for good-faith acts under this section.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 142. Injunction pending inquiry
content: (1) If urgent action needed to prevent serious public danger/injury, Magistrate may issue injunction pending determination. (2) On default, Magistrate may take measures to prevent danger/injury. (3) No suit for good-faith actions under this section.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 143. Magistrate may prohibit repetition or continuance of public nuisance
content: A DM, SDM, or other empowered Executive Magistrate may prohibit repetition/continuance of a public nuisance as defined in IPC or special/local law.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 144. Power to issue order in urgent cases of nuisance or apprehended danger
content: (1) A DM, SDM, or specially empowered Executive Magistrate, if immediate prevention/speedy remedy desirable, may by written order (stating facts) direct any person to abstain from certain acts or regulate property use to prevent obstruction, annoyance, danger to life/health/safety, disturbance of public tranquillity, riot or affray. (2) May be passed ex parte in emergencies or if notice service impracticable. (3) May be directed to individuals, residents of area, or public frequenting place/area. (4) Valid for max 2 months unless extended by State Government for up to 6 months. (5) Magistrate may rescind/alter own order or that of subordinate/predecessor on own motion or application. (6) State Government may rescind/alter its orders. (7) Applicant must be given early hearing opportunity; rejections must be reasoned.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 144A. Power to prohibit carrying arms in procession or mass drill or mass training with arms
content: (1) DM may prohibit carrying arms in procession or organising/participating in mass drill/training with arms in public place to preserve peace/safety/order. (2) May be directed to specific persons or groups. (3) Valid for max 3 months. (4) State Government may extend up to 6 months. (5) State Government may delegate extension power to DMs. Explanation: 'arms' has meaning under section 153AA IPC.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 145. Procedure where dispute concerning land or water is likely to cause breach of peace
content: (1) If satisfied on police/information report of dispute likely to cause breach of peace over land/water within jurisdiction, Executive Magistrate shall order parties to attend and file written statements of possession claims. (2) 'Land or water' includes buildings, markets, fisheries, crops, produce, and rental/profits. (3) Copy of order served per summons procedure and posted near dispute site. (4) Without considering title merits, Magistrate hears parties, takes evidence, and decides possession as of order date; may treat recent forcible dispossession as possession. (5) Parties may show no dispute exists; if so, order is cancelled and proceedings stayed; otherwise, order under (1) is final. (6)(a) If one party is found in possession (or deemed under (4) proviso), declare their entitlement and forbid disturbance until eviction by law; may restore possession if wrongfully dispossessed. (b) Order served/published as in (3). (7) On death of party, legal representatives are substituted; disputes over such status result in all claimants being made parties. (8) Magistrate may order custody or sale of perishable produce and dispose accordingly post-inquiry. (9) Magistrate may summon witnesses/documents. (10) Powers here are without prejudice to section 107 proceedings.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 146. Power to attach subject of dispute and to appoint receiver
content: (1) After making an order under section 145(1), if the Magistrate considers the case one of emergency, or finds none of the parties in possession, or cannot decide possession, he may attach the subject of dispute until a competent Court determines rights to possession. Attachment may be withdrawn if no longer likely to cause breach of peace. (2) On attachment, if no Civil Court receiver exists, the Magistrate may make arrangements for the property or appoint a receiver with powers as per the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908. If a Civil Court later appoints a receiver: (a) the Magistrate's receiver must hand over possession; (b) the Magistrate may make incidental or consequential orders.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 147. Dispute concerning right of use of land or water
content: (1) If satisfied from police report or information that a dispute likely to cause breach of peace exists on alleged right of user of land or water within jurisdiction, the Executive Magistrate shall order parties to attend and file written claims. 'Land or water' as per section 145(2). (2) Magistrate hears parties, takes evidence, and applies section 145 provisions as far as possible to decide if such right exists. (3) If such right exists, Magistrate may prohibit interference, including removing obstruction, provided such right has been exercised recently as per proviso conditions. (4) Proceedings under section 145 can be continued under this section if dispute is about right of user, and vice versa, with reasons recorded.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 148. Local inquiry
content: (1) For purposes of sections 145, 146, or 147, a DM or SDM may depute a subordinate Magistrate to conduct a local inquiry, give written instructions, and decide cost liability. (2) The deputed person's report is admissible as evidence. (3) Decision-making Magistrate may order costs, including witness expenses and pleader's fees, to be paid by any party, in whole or in part, as reasonable.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 149. Police to prevent cognizable offences
content: Every police officer may and shall, to the best of his ability, prevent the commission of any cognizable offence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 150. Information of design to commit cognizable offences
content: A police officer receiving information of a design to commit a cognizable offence shall inform his superior and any officer whose duty it is to prevent or take cognizance of such offence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 151. Arrest to prevent the commission of cognizable offences
content: (1) A police officer aware of a design to commit a cognizable offence may, without warrant or Magistrate's order, arrest the person if necessary to prevent the offence. (2) Such person cannot be detained over 24 hours unless further detention is authorised under law.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 152. Prevention of injury to public property
content: A police officer may act on his own to prevent injury to public property or to prevent removal or injury of public landmarks, buoys, or navigation marks in his view.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 153. Inspection of weights and measures
content: (1) An officer in charge may, without warrant, enter a place within station limits to inspect or search for false weights, measures, or weighing instruments if he has reason to believe such exist. (2) If found, he may seize them and must promptly inform a Magistrate with jurisdiction.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 154. Information in cognizable cases
content: (1) Information on a cognizable offence given orally to the OIC must be reduced to writing, read over, signed by informant, and entered in the prescribed book. Provisos: if victim is a woman for IPC sections 326A, 326B, 354 series, 376 series, 509, etc., statement must be recorded by a woman officer; special provisions for disabled victims include home recording, interpreter, videography, and prompt Magistrate recording. (2) Copy of recorded information given free to informant. (3) If OIC refuses to record, aggrieved may send written info to SP, who may investigate or direct a subordinate to do so. Chhattisgarh amendment adds sections 509A and 509B to list in proviso.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 155. Information as to non-cognizable cases and investigation of such cases
content: (1) On receiving info about a non-cognizable offence, OIC shall record summary and refer informant to Magistrate. (2) No investigation without Magistrate's order. (3) With order, officer may investigate with powers of OIC in cognizable case except arrest without warrant. (4) If case involves both cognizable and non-cognizable offences, treat as cognizable.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 156. Police officer’s power to investigate cognizable case
content: (1) OIC may investigate any cognizable case within his Court's jurisdiction without Magistrate's order. (2) Such actions cannot be challenged for lack of empowerment. (3) Magistrate under section 190 may order investigation. Maharashtra amendment: no Magistrate may order investigation against a public servant for acts in official duty without prior sanction; sanction decision must be made within 90 days or deemed granted.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 157. Procedure for investigation
content: (1) If OIC suspects offence he may investigate, report to Magistrate, visit spot, investigate facts, arrest offender if needed. Provisos: (a) may skip visiting personally in non-serious named-accused cases; (b) may not investigate if no sufficient ground. Further proviso for rape cases: victim's statement at her residence/place of choice, preferably by woman officer, in presence of relatives/social worker. (2) In such clause (a) or (b) cases, reasons to be recorded in report, and in (b) cases, inform informant of decision not to investigate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 158. Report how submitted
content: (1) Reports under section 157 shall be submitted through superior police officer if State directs. (2) Superior may give instructions, record them on the report, and forward promptly to Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 159. Power to hold investigation or preliminary inquiry
content: Magistrate receiving a section 157 report may direct investigation or conduct/assign a preliminary inquiry, or otherwise dispose of the case per this Code.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 160. Police officer’s power to require attendance of witnesses
content: (1) Police officer investigating may order attendance of persons within same or adjoining station limits acquainted with case facts; persons must attend. Proviso: men under 15 or over 65, women, or mentally/physically disabled cannot be required to attend outside their residence. (2) State may provide by rules for payment of reasonable expenses for such attendance away from residence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 161. Examination of witnesses by police
content: (1) Investigating police officer may orally examine persons acquainted with case facts. (2) Such persons must answer truly except to self-incriminating questions. (3) Officer may write statements, keeping separate records for each. Provisos: may record via audio-video means; women victims of specified sexual offences must be interviewed by woman officer. Chhattisgarh amendment expands offences list and mandates AV recording, identity protection.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 162. Statements to police not to be signed: Use of statements in evidence
content: (1) Statements to police during investigation not to be signed or used in evidence, except as provided; may be used to contradict prosecution witness per Indian Evidence Act section 145, with re-examination permitted to explain contradictions.
