title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 326. Conviction or commitment on evidence partly recorded by one Magistrate and partly by another
content: (1) Successor Judge/Magistrate may act on evidence recorded by predecessor, or partly by each; may re-summon witness if further examination needed. (2) Transfer cases treated as ceasing before transferor and succeeding before transferee. (3) Not applicable to summary trials, stayed proceedings under s.322, or submitted under s.325.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 327. Court to be open
content: (1) Criminal courts open to public, subject to space and presiding officer's orders to restrict access. (2) Trials of rape/IPC s.376 series offences in camera; presiding judge may allow specific persons; as far as practicable by woman judge/magistrate. (3) Ban on publication of such proceedings without court permission; may lift for rape trials if party identities kept confidential. State amendment (Chhattisgarh) expands list to various sexual offences and related IPC sections.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 328. Procedure in case of accused being lunatic
content: (1) If Magistrate believes accused of unsound mind and incapable of defence, he shall inquire, have civil surgeon/other directed medical officer examine, and examine that officer on oath. (1A) If surgeon finds unsound mind, refer to psychiatrist/clinical psychologist for diagnosis/treatment/prognosis; report if unsoundness or mental retardation; accused may appeal finding to designated Medical Board. (2) Pending exam/inquiry, Magistrate may act per s.330. (3) If unsoundness renders incapable of defence and no prima facie case, discharge and act per s.330; if prima facie case, postpone proceedings for treatment. (4) For mental retardation, determine capability; if incapable, close inquiry and act per s.330.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 329. Procedure in case of person of unsound mind tried before Court
content: (1) If during trial accused appears of unsound mind and incapable of defence, court first tries that issue; if satisfied, records finding and postpones trial. (1A) Refer to psychiatrist/clinical psychologist for care/treatment; report finding; accused may appeal to Medical Board. (2) If incapable and no prima facie case, discharge and act per s.330; if prima facie case, postpone for treatment. (3) For mental retardation with prima facie case, no trial; act per s.330.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 330. Release of person of unsound mind pending investigation or trial
content: (1) If found incapable under s.328/329, court shall order bail if no inpatient care needed and relative/friend undertakes treatment and prevention of harm. (2) If bail inappropriate or undertaking lacking, order psychiatric treatment in suitable place and inform State Govt; lunatic asylum detention only under Mental Health Act rules. (3) Court to determine if release can be ordered; may discharge under s.328/329 with security; else transfer to residential facility for care/education/training.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 331. Resumption of inquiry or trial
content: If inquiry/trial postponed under s.328/329, court may resume once accused recovers and is fit; if released under s.330, sureties produce him with certificate of officer that he is capable of defence, admissible in evidence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 332. Procedure on accused appearing before Magistrate or Court
content: (1) If accused now capable, proceed with inquiry/trial. (2) If still incapable, act under s.328 or s.329; if unsound, act under s.330.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 333. When accused appears to have been of sound mind
content: If accused appears sound at trial but evidence shows at offence time he was of unsound mind and incapable of knowing nature/wrongness, Magistrate proceeds; if triable by Sessions, commits case accordingly.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 334. Judgment of acquittal on ground of unsoundness of mind
content: When acquitting for incapacity at time of act, finding must state specifically whether accused committed the act or not.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 335. Person acquitted on such ground to be detained in safe custody
content: (1) If finding shows act committed but for incapacity would be an offence, court may: (a) order safe custody; or (b) deliver to relative/friend. (2) Asylum detention per Lunacy Act rules. (3) Delivery to relative/friend only on application, with security to care, prevent harm, and produce for inspection as State directs. (4) Court reports action to State Government.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 336. Power of State Government to empower officer-in-charge to discharge
content: State Govt may empower jail OIC detaining persons under s.330 or s.335 to discharge functions of IG Prisons under s.337 or s.338.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 337. Procedure where lunatic prisoner is reported capable of making his defence
content: If person detained under s.330(2) certified by IG Prisons (or asylum visitors) fit for defence, produce before court to act as per s.332; certificate admissible evidence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 338. Procedure where lunatic detained is declared fit to be released
content: (1) If person detained under s.330(2) or s.335 certified safe for release, State Govt may order release, continued custody, or asylum transfer. (2) For asylum transfer, Commission (judicial + 2 medical officers) must inquire and report; State may order as fit.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 339. Delivery of lunatic to care of relative or friend
content: (1) Relative/friend may apply to State Govt for custody of person detained under s.330/s.335, giving security for care, prevention of harm, inspections, and production for trial if ordered. (2) If accused’s trial postponed for incapacity, and inspecting officer later certifies capability, court to require production and proceed per s.332; certificate admissible.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 340. Procedure in cases mentioned in section 195
content: (1) If court opines it expedient in interests of justice to inquire into an offence under s.195(1)(b) IPC sections alleged in/relating to proceedings in that court, it may conduct preliminary inquiry, then: (a) record finding; (b) make written complaint; (c) send to first-class Magistrate with jurisdiction; (d) take security; (e) bind over witnesses. (2) Subordinate court’s powers may be exercised by superior court if no complaint made or application rejected. (3) Complaint signed by HC-appointed officer or presiding officer/authorised officer. (4) 'Court' has same meaning as in s.195.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 341. Appeal
content: (1) Person whose application for complaint under s.340 is refused by non-HC court, or against whom complaint made, may appeal to superior court per s.195(4) hierarchy; superior court may order withdrawal or making of complaint. (2) Orders under this or s.340 are final, not revisable.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 342. Power to order costs
content: Court hearing s.340 application or s.341 appeal may order just costs.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 343. Procedure of Magistrate taking cognizance
content: (1) Magistrate with complaint under s.340/341 proceeds as if case on police report. (2) Magistrate aware of pending appeal in underlying proceeding may adjourn trial until appeal decided.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 344. Summary procedure for trial for giving false evidence
content: (1) If at judgment delivery court opines a witness gave/fabricated false evidence in that proceeding, and trial is necessary in interests of justice, it may try summarily after show cause, imposing up to 3 months' imprisonment or ₹500 fine. (2) Procedure of summary trials to apply. (3) Does not affect power to proceed under s.340 instead. (4) If appeal/revision filed against judgment containing such opinion, proceedings under this section stayed pending outcome.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 345. Procedure in certain cases of contempt
content: (1) If offences under IPC ss.175, 178, 179, 180, 228 committed in presence of civil/criminal/revenue court, it may detain, try the same day, and punish with up to ₹200 fine or 1 month's simple imprisonment. (2) Court must record facts, offender’s statement, finding, and sentence. (3) For s.228 IPC, record nature/stage of proceeding, and nature of insult/interruption.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 346. Procedure where Court considers that case should not be dealt with under section 345
content: (1) If court considers imprisonment beyond default fine term, fine >₹200, or other reason to avoid s.345, it may, after recording facts and offender's statement, forward case to competent Magistrate, taking security or remanding. (2) Magistrate proceeds as in police report case.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 347. When Registrar or Sub-Registrar to be deemed a Civil Court
content: State Govt may declare Registrars or Sub-Registrars under Registration Act, 1908, to be civil courts for purposes of ss.345–346.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 348. Discharge of offender on submission of apology
content: Court punishing under s.345 or forwarding under s.346 may discharge offender or remit punishment on compliance with order/requisition or satisfactory apology.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 349. Imprisonment or committal of person refusing to answer or produce document
content: Witness/person refusing to answer or produce as required, without reasonable excuse, after opportunity, may be sentenced to simple imprisonment or committed to custody up to 7 days, unless compliance sooner; if persists, may be dealt with under s.345 or s.346.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 350. Summary procedure for punishment for non-attendance by a witness in obedience to summons
content: (1) Witness neglecting/refusing to attend or leaving early without excuse, and court satisfied summary trial expedient, may after show cause fine up to ₹100. (2) Apply summary trial procedure.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 351. Appeals from convictions under sections 344, 345, 349 and 350
content: (1) Person convicted under these sections by non-HC court may appeal to ordinary appellate court for that court's orders. (2) Ch.XXIX appeal provisions apply; appellate court may alter/reverse finding/sentence. (3) Appeals from Small Causes Court convictions lie to Sessions Court. (4) Appeals from Registrar/Sub-Registrar (per s.347) convictions lie to Sessions Court of that office’s division.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 352. Certain Judges and Magistrates not to try certain offences when committed before themselves
content: Except under ss.344, 345, 349, 350, no judge (other than HC judge) or magistrate shall try offences under s.195 when committed before him, in his contempt, or brought to his notice during proceedings.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 353. Judgment
content: (1) Judgment in every trial on original jurisdiction must be pronounced in open court promptly after trial or at notified later date: (a) by delivering whole judgment; or (b) reading whole judgment; or (c) reading operative part and explaining substance in language understood by accused/pleader. (2) If delivered under (a), presiding officer to transcribe in shorthand, sign each page, date delivery. (3) If read under (b) or (c), sign and date in open court, sign each page if not in own hand. (4) In (c) cases, full judgment/copy to be made available to parties free. (5) Accused in custody must be present to hear judgment. (6) Accused not in custody to attend unless personal attendance dispensed and sentence fine only or acquitted; proviso allows pronouncement even if some co‑accused absent. (7) Judgment not invalid merely for absence of party/pleader or notice defects. (8) Section subject to s.465.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 354. Language and contents of judgment
content: (1) Judgments under s.353 shall: (a) be in court language; (b) state points for determination, decisions and reasons; (c) specify offence, law section, and punishment; (d) in acquittal, specify offence and direct release. (2) If doubt exists under which of two sections/parts conviction falls, express both and pass alternative judgment. (3) For punishments of death/imprisonment for life/years, state reasons; for death, special reasons. (4) For convictions punishable with ≥1 year but sentence <3 months, record reasons unless sentence is till rising of court or case tried summarily. (5) Death sentence to direct hanging by neck till dead. (6) Certain final orders (e.g., under ss.117,138(2),125,145,147) also to contain points, decisions, reasons.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 355. Metropolitan Magistrate's judgment
content: May record specified particulars instead of full judgment: case serial, date of offence, complainant name, accused details, offence complained/proved, plea and examination, final order, date thereof, and brief reasons if appealable under s.373 or s.374(3).

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 356. Order for notifying address of previously convicted offender
content: (1) On second conviction for specified IPC offences (ss.215, 489A-D, 506 (7‑year intimidation), or Chapters XII/XVI/XVII offences punishable ≥3 years), courts other than 2nd class Magistrates may order residence notification for up to 5 years after release. (2) Applies also to conspiracy, abetment, attempts. (3) Order void if conviction set aside. (4) May also be made by appellate/revisional courts. (5) State Govt may make notification rules. (6) Rules may provide punishment for breach, tried by competent Magistrate where last notified address situated.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 357. Order to pay compensation
content: (1) When imposing sentence with fine, court may (shall in certain SC/ST cases per state amendments) order fine applied in: (a) prosecution expenses; (b) compensation for loss/injury recoverable civilly; (c) compensation to dependents in death cases; (d) compensation to bona fide purchasers of stolen property when restored. (2) In appealable cases, payment delayed till appeal period or disposal. (3) When sentence without fine, court may (shall in some SC/ST cases) order compensation to victim. (4) Appellate/revisional courts may also order. (5) Civil court to account for amounts paid under this section. State amendments in Karnataka, MP, WB mandate compensation in SC/ST victim cases.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 357A. Victim compensation scheme
content: (1) States with Centre to prepare scheme for compensating/rehabilitating crime victims. (2) On court's recommendation, District/State Legal Services Authority decides amount. (3) If trial court finds s.357 compensation inadequate or case ended in acquittal/discharge with rehabilitation need, may recommend. (4) Victims may apply if offender not traced/identified and no trial. (5) Authority to award adequate compensation within 2 months after enquiry. (6) May order emergency aid/treatment free on police/Magistrate certificate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 357B. Compensation to be in addition to fine
content: Compensation under s.357A by State Govt is in addition to fines under IPC s.326A, s.376AB, s.376D, s.376DA, s.376DB.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 357C. Treatment of victims
content: All hospitals, public or private, must immediately provide free first aid/medical treatment to victims of offences under IPC s.326A, 376, 376A, 376AB, 376B, 376C, 376D, 376DA, 376DB, 376E, and inform police immediately.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 358. Compensation to persons groundlessly arrested
content: (1) If police arrest caused without sufficient ground, Magistrate may award compensation up to ₹1000 from person causing arrest. (2) If multiple arrested, may award each up to ₹1000. (3) Recovery as fine; default punishable with up to 30 days’ simple imprisonment.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 359. Order to pay costs in non-cognizable cases
content: (1) On convicting in non-cognizable case complaint, court may order accused to pay prosecution costs (process-fees, witnesses, pleader’s fees) wholly/partially, with up to 30 days’ simple imprisonment in default. (2) May also be ordered by appellate/revisional courts.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 360. Order to release on probation of good conduct or after admonition
content: (1) First offenders meeting age/offence criteria may be released on probation bond (≤3 years) instead of sentencing, having regard to circumstances. (2) If 2nd class Magistrate not specially empowered, case to be sent to 1st class Magistrate. (3) Certain petty first offences may merit release after due admonition. (4)-(5) Orders may be made/set aside by appellate/revisional courts within limits. (6) Surety provisions apply. (7) Court must be satisfied accused/surety has fixed abode/occupation. (8)-(9) Breach of conditions may lead to arrest and sentencing. (10) Not affecting Probation of Offenders Act, Children Act or similar.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 361. Special reasons to be recorded in certain cases
content: Where eligible accused/youthful offenders could be dealt with under s.360, Probation of Offenders Act, Children Act, etc., but are not, court must record special reasons in judgment.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 362. Court not to alter judgment
content: Court cannot alter/review signed judgment/final order except to correct clerical/arithmetic errors, unless otherwise provided by law.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 363. Copy of judgment to be given to the accused and other persons
content: (1) If sentenced to imprisonment, give accused free copy immediately. (2) On request, give certified copy/translation without delay; free if appealable. Proviso: death sentence judgments to be given free immediately. (3) Applies to s.117 orders. (4) Death sentence convicts to be informed of appeal time. (5) Any person affected may get copy/order/record on payment, unless court gives free for special reason. (6) HCs may make rules for granting copies to non-parties. Karnataka amendment: free copy to Prosecuting Officer on application.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 364. Judgment when to be translated
content: Original judgment filed with record; if in different language from court and accused requires, translate into court language and attach.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 365. Court of Session to send copy of finding and sentence to District Magistrate
content: Sessions Court/CJM to send copy of finding and sentence to DM where trial held.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 366. Sentence of death to be submitted by Court of Session for confirmation
content: (1) Death sentences by Sessions Court to be submitted to HC for confirmation before execution. (2) Convict committed to jail custody under warrant.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 367. Power to direct further inquiry or additional evidence
content: (1) On submission of death sentence proceedings, HC may order further inquiry/additional evidence itself or via Sessions Court. (2) Presence of convict may be dispensed with unless otherwise directed. (3) Results of non-HC inquiries/evidence to be certified back.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 368. Power of High Court to confirm sentence or annul conviction
content: HC may: (a) confirm sentence or pass lawful alternative; (b) annul conviction, convict of other offence, order retrial; (c) acquit. No confirmation until appeal period expires or appeal disposed if filed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 369. Confirmation or new sentence to be signed by two Judges
content: In HC benches of 2+, confirmation/new sentence/order must be made, passed, signed by at least two judges.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 370. Procedure in case of difference of opinion
content: If HC bench judges equally divided in death sentence confirmation case, decide per s.392 procedures.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 371. Procedure in cases submitted to High Court for confirmation
content: On HC confirmation/other order, proper officer to send certified copy under seal/signature to Sessions Court without delay.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 372. No appeal to lie unless otherwise provided
content: No criminal appeal except as provided by Code/other laws. Proviso: victim may appeal acquittal, conviction for lesser offence, or inadequate compensation to court where conviction appeal ordinarily lies.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 373. Appeal from orders requiring security or refusal to accept/rejecting surety
content: Persons ordered under s.117 to give security for peace/good behaviour, or aggrieved by refusal/rejection of surety under s.121, may appeal to Sessions Court. Not applicable to those under s.122(2)/(4) orders.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 374. Appeals from convictions
content: (1) Convicted by HC in extraordinary original criminal jurisdiction may appeal to SC. (2) Convicted by Sessions/Additional Sessions Judge or other court imposing >7 years' imprisonment (to self or co‑accused) may appeal to HC. (3) Others convicted by lower courts, sentenced under s.325, or subject to s.360 order, may appeal to Sessions Court. (4) Appeals against sentences under IPC s.376 series to be disposed within 6 months. State amendment (Assam) expands (3)(a) to include Executive Magistrates.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 375. No appeal in certain cases when accused pleads guilty
content: No appeal where conviction on guilty plea: (a) if by HC; (b) if by Sessions, Metropolitan Magistrate, or Magistrate of 1st/2nd class, except as to extent/legality of sentence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 376. No appeal in petty cases
content: No appeal where: (a) HC sentence ≤6 months' imprisonment or ≤₹1000 fine; (b) Sessions/Metropolitan Magistrate sentence ≤3 months or ≤₹200 fine; (c) Magistrate 1st class fine ≤₹100; (d) summary case fine ≤₹200 by s.260‑empowered Magistrate. Appeal allowed if other punishment combined; not appealable merely for peace‑bond, imprisonment in default, or multiple fines within above total.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 377. Appeal by the State Government against sentence
content: (1) State Govt may appeal inadequate sentence: (a) to Sessions if passed by Magistrate; (b) to HC if by other court. (2) In certain central agency‑investigated cases, Centre may also appeal similarly. (3) Enhancement only after giving accused chance to show cause; accused may argue acquittal/reduction. (4) Appeals against IPC s.376 series sentences to be disposed within 6 months.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 378. Appeal in case of acquittal
content: (1) DM may appeal to Sessions from acquittal by Magistrate in cognizable, non‑bailable cases; State Govt may appeal to HC from other acquittals/orders. (2) In central agency‑investigated cases, Centre may direct appeal to Sessions or HC accordingly. (3) HC leave required for HC appeals under (1)/(2). (4) In complaint cases, HC may grant complainant special leave to appeal. (5) Application for special leave must be within 6 months (public servant complainant) or 60 days (others) from acquittal. (6) If special leave refused, no appeal by State/Centre lies.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 379. Appeal against conviction by High Court in certain cases
content: If HC reverses acquittal on appeal and convicts imposing death, life, or ≥10 years' imprisonment, appeal lies to SC.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 380. Special right of appeal in certain cases
content: If multiple convicted in one trial and any has appealable judgment/order, all or any convicted at that trial have right of appeal.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 381. Appeal to Court of Session how heard
content: (1) Appeals to Sessions Court to be heard by Sessions Judge or Additional Sessions Judge. Proviso: appeal from conviction by 2nd class Magistrate may be heard/disposed by Assistant Sessions Judge or CJM. (2) Additional/Assistant Sessions Judge or CJM hear only such appeals as Sessions Judge assigns by order or as HC directs.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 382. Petition of appeal
content: Every appeal via written petition by appellant or pleader; accompanied by copy of judgment/order unless appellate court otherwise directs. Provisos (UTs reg.): if not practicable to present to appellate court, may present to Administrator or Executive Magistrate (≥Sub‑Divisional rank) who forwards; may exercise temporary s.389(1) powers for suspension of sentence/bail till appellate court order. Explanation defines 'Administrator'. (2) Appeals presented to Administrator/Executive Magistrate deemed presented to proper appellate court for limitation and other purposes.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 383. Procedure when appellant in jail
content: Appellant in jail may present petition/copies to jail OIC who forwards to appellate court. State amendment (UTs) allows forwarding to Administrator/Exec. Magistrate (≥Sub‑Divisional) if weather/transport etc. prevent direct forwarding; they date‑stamp and forward to appellate court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 384. Summary dismissal of appeal
content: (1) Appellate court may summarily dismiss appeal if no sufficient ground, with provisos: (a) s.382 appeals—appellant/pleader given reasonable opportunity to be heard; (b) s.383 appeals—same, unless appeal frivolous or producing accused in custody involves disproportionate inconvenience; (c) s.383 appeals—no summary dismissal before limitation period expiry. (2) Court may call for record before dismissal. (3) Sessions/CJM must record reasons for dismissal. (4) If after summary dismissal of s.383 appeal, another s.382 appeal on same appellant exists and was not considered, court may, notwithstanding s.393, hear and dispose of it.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 385. Procedure for hearing appeals not dismissed summarily
content: (1) If not dismissed summarily, appellate court to give notice of hearing to appellant/pleader, appointed officer, complainant (if from complaint conviction), accused (if under ss.377/378), and furnish grounds of appeal. (2) Court to call for record unless available; may dispose without record if only about sentence extent/legality. (3) If only ground is severity of sentence, no other argument allowed without leave.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 386. Powers of the Appellate Court
content: After hearing parties, appellate court may: (a) in appeal from acquittal—reverse, order further inquiry, retrial, committal, or convict and sentence; (b) in appeal from conviction—reverse finding/sentence and acquit/discharge/order retrial/committal; alter finding keeping sentence; or alter nature/extent of sentence without enhancing; (c) in appeal for enhancement—reverse and acquit/discharge/order retrial; alter finding keeping sentence; or alter to enhance/reduce; (d) in appeal from other order—alter/reverse; (e) make amendments/consequential orders. Sentence cannot be enhanced without hearing accused; cannot impose greater punishment than trial court could.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 387. Judgments of Subordinate Appellate Court
content: Chapter XXVII judgment rules for original jurisdiction apply to Sessions/CJM appeals; unless directed, accused need not attend for delivery.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 388. Order of High Court on appeal to be certified to lower Court
content: (1) On deciding appeal, HC certifies judgment/order to original court; if JM not CJM, via CJM; if Executive Magistrate, via DM. (2) Receiving court makes orders conformable to HC decision; amend record as needed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 389. Suspension of sentence pending the appeal; release of appellant on bail
content: (1) Appellate court may suspend sentence/order and release on bail/bond; for death/life/≥10 years' imprisonment, PP to be heard before release; PP may seek bail cancellation. (2) HC may exercise same for appeal to subordinate court. (3) Trial court may grant interim bail pending appeal filing in some cases; sentence deemed suspended. (4) Bail period excluded from sentence term.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 390. Arrest of accused in appeal from acquittal
content: On s.378 appeal, HC may issue arrest warrant; court before which accused brought may commit to prison pending appeal or grant bail.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 391. Appellate Court may take further evidence or direct it to be taken
content: (1) Appellate court may record reasons to take additional evidence itself or direct Magistrate/Sessions Court to take it. (2) Such court certifies evidence to appellate court. (3) Accused/pleader has right to be present. (4) Evidence-taking subject to Ch.XXIII provisions.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 392. Procedure where Judges of Court of Appeal are equally divided
content: If HC bench equally divided, appeal placed before another judge; his opinion decides case. If required by any such judge, re‑hearing by larger bench.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 393. Finality of judgments and orders on appeal
content: Appellate orders are final except as per ss.377, 378, 384(4) or Ch.XXX. Proviso: despite appeal disposal, may hear related s.378 appeal against acquittal or s.377 appeal for enhancement from same case.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 394. Abatement of appeals
content: (1) s.377 or s.378 appeals abate on accused's death. (2) Other appeals (except fine‑only sentence) abate on appellant's death; proviso allows near relatives (parent, spouse, lineal descendant, sibling) 30 days to seek leave to continue appeal in conviction with death/imprisonment sentence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 395. Reference to High Court
content: (1) If court considers an Act/Ordinance/Regulation provision invalid and necessary to decide case, and not yet declared by HC/SC, it shall refer question to HC with reasons. Explanation defines 'Regulation'. (2) Sessions/Metropolitan Magistrate may also refer legal questions. (3) Court may remand or bail accused pending HC decision.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 396. Disposal of case according to decision of High Court
content: (1) HC passes order on reference and sends copy to referring court for conformable disposal. (2) HC may direct who pays costs.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 397. Calling for records to exercise powers of revision
content: (1) HC or Sessions Judge may call/examine records of inferior criminal courts for correctness/legality/propriety of findings, sentences, or orders, and regularity; may suspend execution and bail accused. Explanation defines inferior courts for Sessions Judge. (2) No revision for interlocutory orders. (3) Once revision application made to HC or Sessions, no second application by same person to other.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 398. Power to order inquiry
content: HC or Sessions Judge may direct CJM (or subordinate magistrate via CJM) to inquire further into dismissed complaints (s.203/204(4)) or into cases where accused discharged; must hear such person before ordering against them.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 399. Sessions Judge's powers of revision
content: (1) Sessions Judge has same revision powers as HC in cases where record called himself. (2) s.401(2)-(5) provisions apply mutatis mutandis. (3) Decision final for that person; no HC/other revision at that instance.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 400. Power of Additional Sessions Judge
content: Additional Sessions Judge may exercise Sessions Judge's Ch.XXX powers in cases transferred to him by Sessions Judge order.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 401. High Court's powers of revision
content: (1) HC in revision may exercise appellate ss.386,389,390,391 powers or s.307 powers; if equally divided, apply s.392. (2) No prejudicial order without hearing person. (3) Cannot convert acquittal to conviction. (4) No revision at instance of party who could have appealed but did not. (5) If appeal lay but revision filed in error, HC may treat as appeal if just.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 402. Power of High Court to withdraw or transfer revision cases
content: (1) If co‑convicts file revisions in HC and others in Sessions, HC decides which court to dispose; may transfer accordingly. (2) Cases transferred to HC treated as made there. (3) Cases to Sessions treated as made there. (4) Once disposed by Sessions after transfer, no further revision to HC/other court by same persons.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 403. Option of Court to hear parties
content: Except as provided in Code, no party has right to be heard in revision; court may choose to hear personally/by pleader.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 404. Statement by Metropolitan Magistrate of grounds of his decision to be considered by High Court
content: When HC/Sessions calls record of trial by Metropolitan Magistrate under s.397, magistrate may submit statement of grounds/facts; must be considered before overruling/setting aside decision.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 405. High Court's order to be certified to lower Court
content: When HC/Sessions revises a case, it/he certifies decision to original court per s.388; receiving court makes conformable orders and amends record if needed.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 406. Power of Supreme Court to transfer cases and appeals
content: (1) SC may transfer case/appeal between HCs or subordinate criminal courts for ends of justice. (2) Application by Attorney‑General or interested party; other than AG/Advocate‑General must be by motion with affidavit/affirmation. (3) If dismissed as frivolous/vexatious, SC may award up to ₹1000 compensation to opponent.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 407. Power of High Court to transfer cases and appeals
content: (1) HC may order transfer in interests of justice for fair trial, difficult legal question, statutory requirement, convenience, or to try before itself; options include: transfer between competent courts, commit to Sessions, or try itself. (2) HC may act on lower court report, party application, or suo motu; proviso limits intra‑division transfers unless Sessions application refused. (3) Applications by motion with affidavit unless by Advocate‑General. (4) HC may require accused applicant to bond for compensation. (5) Accused applicant must notify PP with grounds 24 hrs before hearing. (6) HC may stay subordinate proceedings pending transfer. (7) If application dismissed and frivolous/vexatious, up to ₹1000 compensation. (8) If HC tries case, uses same procedure as original court. (9) Does not affect s.197 Govt orders.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 408. Power of Sessions Judge to transfer cases and appeals
content: (1) SJ may transfer case within division for ends of justice. (2) May act on lower court report, party application, or own motion. (3) s.407(3),(4),(5),(6),(7),(9) apply with ₹250 limit in (7). Kerala amendment substitutes 'Magistrate of 1st class' for 'any Magistrate' phrasing.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 409. Withdrawal of cases and appeals by Session Judge
content: (1) SJ may withdraw/recall case/appeal made over to Assistant Sessions Judge or CJM. (2) Prior to start before Additional Sessions Judge, may recall. (3) On withdrawal/recall, may try/hear himself or make over appropriately. Kerala amendment substitutes new section re: appeals hearing jurisdictions.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 410. Withdrawal of cases by Judicial Magistrate
content: (1) CJM may withdraw/recall case made over to subordinate Magistrate, and try/inquire himself or refer to competent other. (2) Judicial Magistrate may recall case made over under s.192(2) and try/inquire himself.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 411. Making over or withdrawal of cases by Executive Magistrates
content: DM/SDM may make over ongoing proceedings to subordinate Magistrate; withdraw/recall cases made over and dispose himself or refer to another Magistrate.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 412. Reasons to be recorded
content: SJ or Magistrate making transfer/withdrawal orders under ss.408–411 must record reasons.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 413. Execution of order passed under section 368
content: In death sentence confirmation cases, Sessions Court executes HC order via warrant or other steps.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 414. Execution of sentence of death passed by High Court
content: When HC imposes death in appeal/revision, Sessions Court executes on receiving order via warrant.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 415. Postponement of execution of sentence of death in case of appeal to Supreme Court
content: (1) If HC death sentence appeal lies to SC under Const. Art.134(1)(a)/(b), HC postpones execution till appeal period or disposal. (2) If application for certificate under Arts.132/134(1)(c), postpone till disposal and expiry of appeal period if granted. (3) If intending Art.136 SLP, HC may postpone for sufficient period to apply.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 416. Postponement of capital sentence on pregnant woman
content: If woman sentenced to death is found pregnant, HC shall commute to life imprisonment.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 417. Power to appoint place of imprisonment
content: (1) State Govt may direct confinement place of any person imprisoned/committed under Code unless law otherwise provides. (2) If confined in civil jail, court/magistrate may order removal to criminal jail. (3) On release from criminal jail, return to civil jail unless three years have elapsed or original civil jail court certifies release entitlement.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 418. Execution of sentence of imprisonment
content: (1) For life/term sentences (other than s.413), court forwards warrant to jail; forward convict if not already there; proviso allows confinement in other place if till rising of court. (2) If convict absent, issue arrest warrant; sentence starts on arrest date.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 419. Direction of warrant for execution
content: Warrant for imprisonment directed to OIC of jail/place of confinement.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 420. Warrant with whom to be lodged
content: If prisoner to be confined in jail, warrant lodged with jailor.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 421. Warrant for levy of fine
content: (1) Court may recover fine by: (a) warrant attaching/selling offender's movables; (b) warrant to Collector to realise as land revenue from offender's property. Proviso: if whole default imprisonment served, no warrant unless special reasons or order for expenses/compensation under s.357. (2) State Govt may make rules on (a) execution and claim resolution. (3) Collector executes (b) as per land revenue recovery law; no arrest/detention for execution of such warrant.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 422. Effect of such warrant
content: Warrant under s.421(1)(a) executable within issuing court's jurisdiction; authorises attachment/sale outside jurisdiction when endorsed by DM where property is found.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 423. Warrant for levy of fine issued by a Court in any territory to which this Code does not extend
content: If an offender is sentenced to pay a fine by a criminal court in a territory where the Code does not extend, and the court issues a warrant to a Collector within Code territory to recover it as land revenue, the warrant is deemed issued under s.421(1)(b) by a court in Code territory; s.421(3) execution provisions apply.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 424. Suspension of execution of sentence of imprisonment
content: (1) Where sentence is fine only with imprisonment in default and fine not paid forthwith, court may: (a) allow payment in full within ≤30 days or in 2–3 instalments with ≤30‑day intervals; (b) suspend default imprisonment and release on bond with/without sureties conditioned on appearance for payment; non‑payment triggers immediate imprisonment. (2) Also applies to any money order where imprisonment may follow on non‑payment; if bond not executed, immediate imprisonment may be ordered.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 425. Who may issue warrant
content: Execution warrant for sentence may be issued by judge/magistrate who passed sentence or successor‑in‑office.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 426. Sentence on escaped convict when to take effect
content: (1) Death/life/fine sentence on escaped convict takes effect immediately. (2) For term imprisonment: (a) if severer than sentence at escape, takes effect immediately; (b) if not severer, starts after serving period equal to remaining unexpired term at escape. (3) Rigorous imprisonment is deemed severer than simple.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 427. Sentence on offender already sentenced for another offence
content: (1) Subsequent imprisonment/life sentence generally runs consecutively to existing sentence unless directed concurrent; proviso: imprisonment under s.122 default runs immediately if subsequent offence committed prior to s.122 order. (2) If already serving life sentence, subsequent term/life runs concurrently.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 428. Period of detention undergone by the accused to be set off against the sentence
content: Term imprisonment (not default) reduced by pre‑conviction detention during investigation/inquiry/trial of same case; limited to remainder of sentence. Proviso: in s.433A cases, detention set off against 14‑year period.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 429. Saving
content: (1) Nothing in ss.426–427 excuses any part of punishment for former/subsequent conviction. (2) Where imprisonment in default of fine is annexed to substantive sentence and further substantive sentence(s) follow, default imprisonment is served after all substantive sentences.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 430. Return of warrant on execution of sentence
content: When sentence fully executed, executing officer returns warrant to issuing court with endorsement certifying manner of execution.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 431. Money ordered to be paid recoverable as a fine
content: Money (other than fine) payable under Code order, if recovery method not otherwise provided, is recoverable as fine; s.421 proviso applies with added reference to s.359 cost orders.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 432. Power to suspend or remit sentences
content: (1) Appropriate Govt may at any time suspend execution or remit whole/part punishment, with/without conditions accepted by offender. (2) Govt may seek trial/confirming judge's opinion and record copy. (3) If conditions not fulfilled, suspension/remission may be cancelled; offender may be arrested without warrant to serve remainder. (4) Condition may depend on offender or be independent. (5) Govt may direct general/special rules for suspension petitions; proviso restricts petitions for male offenders >18 to be made through jail OIC or with declaration of custody. (6) Provisions apply to any criminal order restricting liberty/imposing liability. (7) 'Appropriate Government': (a) Centre if Union subject offence/order; (b) State in other cases.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 433. Power to commute sentence
content: Appropriate Govt may commute without offender's consent: (a) death → other IPC punishment; (b) life → term ≤14 years or fine; (c) rigorous → simple for any term or fine; (d) simple → fine.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 433A. Restriction on remission or commutation in certain cases
content: Notwithstanding s.432, life sentence for an offence punishable with death, or commuted death to life, cannot end until at least 14 years served.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 434. Concurrent power of Central Government in case of death sentences
content: Centre may also exercise s.432 and s.433 powers for death sentences.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 435. State Government to act after consultation with Central Government in certain cases
content: (1) State cannot remit/commute under ss.432,433 without Centre's consultation if offence: (a) investigated by DSPE/Central agency; (b) involved misappropriation/destruction/damage of Central Govt property; (c) committed by Central Govt servant in official duty. (2) Where offences include both Union and other matters with concurrent sentences, no State order effective unless Centre also orders remission/commutation for Union offences.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 436. In what cases bail to be taken
content: (1) Person not accused of non‑bailable offence, if under arrest/detained without warrant or appearing before court, and ready to give bail, must be released; proviso allows release on bond without sureties if indigent (presumed if bail not furnished within 1 week). Second proviso saves s.116(3)/s.446A. (2) If bail‑bond conditions breached, court may refuse bail on later appearance without prejudice to s.446 penalty recovery.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 436A. Maximum period for which an undertrial prisoner can be detained
content: If undertrial (non‑capital offence) has spent half of max imprisonment as detention during investigation/inquiry/trial, must be released on personal bond with/without sureties; court may order continued detention beyond half‑term or bail after hearing PP with reasons. In no case detention exceeds max imprisonment term. Explanation: exclude delay caused by accused in computing period.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 437. When bail may be taken in case of non-bailable offence
content: (1) For non-bailable offences, court/police may grant bail unless: (i) reasonable grounds to believe offence punishable with death or life imprisonment; (ii) cognizable offence with prior conviction for death/life/≥7 years, or prior 2+ convictions for cognizable offences punishable 3–7 years. Provisos: bail allowed if under 16, woman, sick/infirm; special reasons for (ii); witness identification need not bar bail if undertaking given; no bail for death/life/≥7 yrs without hearing PP. (2) If insufficient grounds for belief of guilt but sufficient for further inquiry, release on bail/own bond pending inquiry, subject to s.446A. (3) For offences punishable with ≥7 years or under IPC Ch.VI/XVI/XVII or related attempt/abetment/conspiracy, bail must include conditions: attend as required, not commit similar offence, not tamper/threaten, plus other necessary conditions. (4) Reasons/special reasons for bail to be recorded. (5) Bail may be revoked and custody ordered. (6) In Magistrate-triable non-bailable cases, if trial not concluded within 60 days from first evidence date, in-custody accused to be released on bail unless otherwise directed with reasons. (7) After trial but before judgment, if grounds to believe accused not guilty, release on bond without sureties.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 437A. Bail to require accused to appear before next appellate Court
content: (1) Before trial conclusion and appeal disposal, trial/appellate court to require accused to execute bail bonds with sureties to appear before higher court if notice issued re any appeal/petition; bonds valid 6 months. (2) Failure to appear forfeits bond; s.446 applies.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 438. Direction for grant of bail to person apprehending arrest
content: (1) Person anticipating arrest for non-bailable offence may apply to HC or Sessions for direction to be released on bail if arrested. (2) Direction may impose conditions: appear for interrogation when required; no inducement/threat/promise to witnesses; not leave India without permission; other s.437(3)-type conditions. (3) If arrested thereafter and ready to give bail, release; if Magistrate issues warrant, must be bailable in conformity. (4) Does not apply to cases under IPC s.376(3), 376AB, 376DA, 376DB. State amendments (WB/Orissa) add notice requirements before final orders in serious offences and timelines for disposal.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 439. Special powers of High Court or Court of Session regarding bail
content: (1) HC/Sessions may: (a) grant bail to accused in custody; for s.437(3) offences, impose necessary conditions; (b) set aside/modify Magistrate's bail conditions. Proviso: for offences triable only by Sessions or punishable with life, give PP notice unless not practicable. Further proviso: for IPC s.376(3), 376AB, 376DA, 376DB, notify PP within 15 days; (1A) informant/person authorised must be present at bail hearing in such cases. (2) HC/Sessions may order arrest/commit to custody of person already on bail. State amendment (Assam) inserts s.439A with restrictions on bail for enumerated serious offences except on listed grounds.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 440. Amount of bond and reduction thereof
content: (1) Bond amounts to be fixed considering case circumstances; not excessive. (2) HC/Sessions may order police/Magistrate bail amount reduced.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 441. Bond of accused and sureties
content: (1) Before release on bail/own bond, accused to execute bond for sum fixed, and for bail, one or more sufficient sureties to ensure attendance until directed otherwise. (2) Bond must include imposed conditions. (3) May also bind person to appear before appellate court(s) when called. (4) Court may verify surety sufficiency/fitness via affidavits or inquiry by itself/subordinate Magistrate. State amendment (AP) adds provision for fine in surety bond if surety fails to produce accused in serious offences.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 441A. Declaration by sureties
content: Surety must declare before court the number of persons he has stood surety for, including accused, with relevant particulars.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 442. Discharge from custody
content: (1) Once bond executed, accused released; if in jail, release order issued to jail OIC. (2) Does not require release if liable to be detained in other matters.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 443. Power to order sufficient bail when first taken is insufficient
content: If sureties accepted are insufficient or later become so, court may issue arrest warrant, require sufficient sureties, and if none given, commit to jail.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 444. Discharge of sureties
content: (1) Sureties may apply to Magistrate to discharge bond wholly/partially. (2) Magistrate issues arrest warrant for accused. (3) On appearance/surrender, bond discharged as per application; accused to find fresh sureties or be committed to jail. West Bengal amendment: adds ‘on showing sufficient cause’, allows inquiry into reasons before discharge, and modifies (2).

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 445. Deposit instead of recognizance
content: When bond required (except for good behaviour), court/officer may permit deposit of money or Govt promissory notes in lieu. West Bengal amendment removes 'with or without sureties' and substitutes 'permit' with 'direct'.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 446. Procedure when bond has been forfeited
content: (1) On proof of bond forfeiture, court records grounds and calls on bound person to pay penalty or show cause. Explanation: appearance/production conditions cover transfers to other courts. (2) If no cause/penalty unpaid, recover as fine; proviso: if unrecoverable, surety may be imprisoned in civil jail up to 6 months. (3) Court may remit part penalty for reasons. (4) Surety's estate discharged if he dies before forfeiture. (5) Copy of conviction judgment for breach of bond may be used as evidence against surety, with presumption unless rebutted.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 446A. Cancellation of bond and bail bond
content: If appearance bond forfeited for breach, both personal and surety bonds are cancelled; person cannot be released on own bond in that case unless fresh bonds given, unless sufficient cause for breach shown.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 447. Procedure in case of insolvency or death of surety or when a bond is forfeited
content: If surety becomes insolvent/dies or bond forfeited, court/Magistrate may order fresh securities; failure treated as default of original order.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 448. Bond required from minor
content: If person required to execute bond is minor, court/officer may accept bond from surety/sureties only.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 449. Appeal from orders under section 446
content: Orders under s.446 appealable: (i) by Magistrate—to Sessions; (ii) by Sessions Court—to higher appellate court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 450. Power to direct levy of amount due on certain recognizances
content: HC or Sessions may direct Magistrate to levy amount due on appearance/attendance bond for such courts.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 451. Order for custody and disposal of property pending trial
content: During inquiry/trial, court may order proper custody of property produced; if perishable or expedient, may order sale/disposal after recording necessary evidence. 'Property' includes property/documents produced or in court's custody or related to offence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 452. Order for disposal of property at conclusion of trial
content: (1) On conclusion, court may order disposal (destruction/confiscation/delivery/other) of property/documents produced or in custody or related to offence. (2) Delivery may be unconditional or on bond to restore if order modified/set aside. (3) Sessions may direct CJM to handle under ss.457–459. (4) Except for livestock/perishables/bond goods, execution delayed 2 months or pending appeal. (5) 'Property' includes converted/exchanged property and proceeds.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 453. Payment to innocent purchaser of money found on accused
content: If conviction for theft/receiving stolen property and an innocent purchaser bought stolen goods unknowingly, and money was found on accused, court may, on application and restitution of goods, order repayment up to purchase price from such money.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 454. Appeal against orders under section 452 or 453
content: (1) Aggrieved may appeal to appropriate appellate court. (2) Appellate court may stay order, modify/alter/annul, or make other just orders. (3) Same powers exercisable in appeal/confirmation/revision of related case.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 455. Destruction of libellous and other matter
content: (1) On IPC s.292,293,501,502 conviction, court may order destruction of offending copies in custody or with convict. (2) On IPC s.272–275 conviction, may order destruction of related food/drink/drug/medical preparation.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 456. Power to restore possession of immovable property
content: (1) On conviction for offence with criminal force/show or intimidation causing dispossession from immovable property, court may order restoration within 1 month of conviction. (2) Appellate/confirmation/revision court may also order restoration if trial court did not. (3) s.454 appeal provisions apply. (4) Does not prejudice civil property rights.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 457. Procedure by police upon seizure of property
content: (1) On police reporting seizure of property not produced in court, Magistrate may order its disposal/delivery to entitled person or, if unknown, order custody/production. (2) If entitled known, may order delivery with conditions; if unknown, detain and issue proclamation for claims within 6 months.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 458. Procedure where no claimant appears within six months
content: (1) If no claim in 6 months and possessor cannot show legal acquisition, Magistrate may order property to State Government for disposal/sale; proceeds per rules. (2) Order appealable to usual appellate court.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 459. Power to sell perishable property
content: If entitled person unknown/absent and property perishable, or value < ₹500, or sale benefits owner, Magistrate may direct sale; apply ss.457–458 to proceeds.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 460. Irregularities which do not vitiate proceedings
content: If Magistrate without empowerment in good faith does listed acts (e.g., issue search warrant, order investigation, hold inquest, issue process for outside offender, take cognizance under s.190(1)(a)/(b), make over case, tender pardon, recall case, sell property under s.458/459), proceedings not set aside merely for lack of power.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 461. Irregularities which vitiate proceedings
content: If Magistrate without empowerment does listed acts (e.g., attach/sell under s.83, postal/telegraph search-warrant, demand security, make maintenance order, try offender, pass sentence under s.325 on another's record, decide appeal, call for/revise proceedings), proceedings are void.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 462. Proceedings in wrong place
content: Finding/sentence/order not set aside just for being in wrong jurisdiction unless failure of justice occurred.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 463. Non-compliance with provisions of section 164 or section 281
content: (1) If confession/statement under s.164/s.281 non-compliant, court may take evidence on non-compliance and, if satisfied no prejudice and statement genuine, admit it. (2) Applies also to appellate/reference/revisional courts.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 464. Effect of omission to frame, or absence of, or error in, charge
content: (1) No finding/sentence/order invalid merely for no charge or charge error/omission/misjoinder unless appellate/confirmation/revision court thinks failure of justice occurred. (2) If so, may order charge to be framed and trial recommenced after framing; or direct new trial with corrected charge. Proviso: if no valid charge possible on facts, quash conviction.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 465. Finding or sentence when reversible by reason of error, omission or irregularity
content: (1) No finding/sentence/order reversed/altered for error/omission/irregularity in proceedings/sanction unless, in court's opinion, failure of justice occurred. (2) In deciding, court to consider if objection could/should have been raised earlier.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 466. Defect or error not to make attachment unlawful
content: Attachment not unlawful nor officer trespasser merely for defect/want of form in related process.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 467. Definitions
content: 'Period of limitation' means period in s.468 for taking cognizance.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 468. Bar to taking cognizance after lapse of the period of limitation
content: (1) Except otherwise provided, no cognizance after limitation in (2). (2) Period: (a) 6 months—fine only offences; (b) 1 year—max imprisonment ≤1 year; (c) 3 years—imprisonment >1 year ≤3 years. (3) For offences tried together, limitation determined by most severe punishment offence.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 469. Commencement of the period of limitation
content: (1) Limitation starts: (a) on offence date; (b) if offence not known to victim/police, on first day it becomes known; (c) if offender identity not known, on first day identity known to victim/police. (2) Exclude starting day in computation.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 470. Exclusion of time in certain cases
content: (1) In computing limitation, exclude time during which prosecution of same facts in another court was being pursued with due diligence and in good faith but failed for want of jurisdiction/like cause. (2) Exclude period during which prosecution stayed by injunction/order, including issue/withdrawal days. (3) Exclude period of required notice before prosecution or time to obtain prior consent/sanction, excluding dates of application and receipt. (4) Exclude time offender was (a) outside India or Union‑administered territory, or (b) absconding/concealing to avoid arrest.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 471. Exclusion of date on which Court is closed
content: If limitation expires when court closed, cognizance may be taken on reopening day. Explanation: Court deemed closed if shut during normal hours on that day.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 472. Continuing offence
content: For continuing offences, fresh limitation period starts at every moment the offence continues.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 473. Extension of period of limitation in certain cases
content: Court may take cognizance after expiry of limitation if delay properly explained or required in interests of justice.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 474. Trials before High Courts
content: When HC tries offence otherwise than under s.407 transfer, it follows Sessions Court trial procedure.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 475. Delivery to commanding officers of persons liable to be tried by Court-martial
content: (1) Central Govt may make rules with service Acts on when persons subject to military/naval/air force/other armed forces law are tried by civilian court or court-martial. Magistrates must have regard to rules and in proper cases deliver accused to commanding officer with offence details for court‑martial. Explanation: 'Unit' includes regiment, corps, ship, etc.; 'Court-martial' includes any similar tribunal. (2) Magistrate must assist CO's written request to apprehend such accused. (3) HC may direct prisoner in State jail be brought before court‑martial for trial/examination.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 476. Forms
content: Forms in Second Schedule, with variations, may be used; if used, deemed sufficient for purposes mentioned.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 477. Power of High Court to make rules
content: (1) HC may, with State Govt approval, make rules: (a) on petition‑writers in subordinate criminal courts; (b) licensing, conduct, fee scales; (c) penalties for contravention and authority/procedure; (d) other prescribed matters. (2) Rules to be published in Official Gazette.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 478. Power to alter functions allocated to Executive Magistrate in certain cases
content: If State Legislative Assembly so resolves, State Govt may, after HC consultation, notify that references in ss.108, 109, 110, 145, 147 to Executive Magistrate be read as Judicial Magistrate 1st class. UT amendment (A&N Islands, Dadra & Nagar Haveli, Lakshadweep) omits requirement of Assembly resolution.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 479. Case in which Judge or Magistrate is personally interested
content: Judge/Magistrate cannot try/commit case where he is party/personally interested, without permission of appellate court; nor hear appeal from his own judgment/order. Explanation: not deemed interested if involved only in public capacity, site visit, or related inquiry.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 480. Practising pleader not to sit as Magistrate in certain Courts
content: No pleader practising in a Magistrate's court shall sit as Magistrate in that court or within its jurisdiction.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 480A (Karnataka). Other powers of Magistrate
content: Inserted by Karnataka: Any Judicial/Executive Magistrate may attest, verify, authenticate documents brought before him for such purposes and affix seals as prescribed by law.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 481. Public servant concerned in sale not to purchase or bid for property
content: Public servant with duty in property sale under Code cannot purchase or bid for that property.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 482. Saving of inherent powers of High Court
content: Nothing limits HC's inherent power to pass orders to give effect to Code orders, prevent abuse of process, or secure ends of justice.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 483. Duty of High Court to exercise continuous superintendence over Courts of Judicial Magistrates
content: HC to continually supervise subordinate Judicial Magistrates to ensure expeditious and proper disposal of cases.

title: Code of Criminal Procedure - Section 484. Repeal and savings
content: (1) CrPC 1898 repealed. (2) Despite repeal: (a) pending matters disposed per old Code, as if new Code not in force, except pending Ch.XVIII inquiries to follow new Code; (b) notifications, orders, rules, etc. under old Code continue as if under new; (c) sanctions/consents under old Code where no proceeding commenced deemed under new Code; (d) old Code applies to prosecutions against Rulers under Art.363. (3) If period for application/proceeding under old Code expired before commencement, new provisions do not revive it.

title: Constitution of India - Article 14 (Equality Before Law)
content: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India. Article 14 consists of two parts: (1) equality before law — a negative concept prohibiting special privileges and discrimination, and (2) equal protection of laws — a positive obligation requiring the State to treat differently situated persons differently to achieve substantive equality. Equals should be treated equally; unequals unequally. This Article applies to both citizens and non-citizens. Judicial interpretation has established that Article 14 guarantees fairness, reasonableness, and non-arbitrariness in State action. It forms the foundation for the scheme of equality under the Constitution, and Articles 15 and 16 are specific applications of its principle.

title: Constitution of India - Article 15 (Prohibition of Discrimination)
content:
(1) The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. (2) No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them, be subject to any disability, liability, restriction, or condition with regard to: (a) access to shops, public restaurants, hotels and public entertainment places; or (b) use of wells, tanks, bathing ghats, roads and places of public resort maintained wholly or partly out of State funds or dedicated to the use of the general public. (3) Nothing in this Article prevents the State from making special provisions for women and children. (4) Nothing in this Article or in Article 29(2) prevents the State from making special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, or for the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. (5) Nothing in this Article or in Article 19(1)(g) prevents the State from making any special provision, by law, for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes or for the Scheduled Castes or Scheduled Tribes in relation to admission to educational institutions, including private institutions (aided or unaided), other than minority institutions under Article 30(1).

Judicial commentary: Article 15 is a specific application of Article 14 (Dasaratha v. State of A.P., AIR 1961 SC 564). Equality means treating equals equally and unequals unequally, enabling positive discrimination for SCs and STs. In E.V. Chinnaiah v. State of A.P. (2005) 1 SCC 394, it was held that legislation designed to give effect to Articles 15 and 16 is not violative of Article 14 if the differentiation is reasonable. In Preeti Srivastava v. State of M.P. (1999) 7 SCC 120, Article 15(3) was described as protective discrimination for women and children, and Article 15(4) extended similar benefits to SC/STs and backward classes. Special provisions must be reasonable, advance equality, and cannot undermine other public interests.

title: Constitution of India - Article 16 (Equality of Opportunity in Public Employment)
content:
(1) There shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State. (2) No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence or any of them, be ineligible for or discriminated against in State employment. (3) Parliament may prescribe residence requirements for certain classes of employment within a State or Union territory. (4) The State may reserve appointments/posts for any backward class of citizens not adequately represented in State services. (4A) The State may reserve posts in matters of promotion, with consequential seniority, for SCs and STs not adequately represented. (4B) The State may treat unfilled reserved vacancies of a year as a separate class, to be carried forward, exempt from the 50% ceiling on reservations. (5) This Article does not affect laws requiring that holders of offices in religious or denominational institutions belong to that religion or denomination.

Judicial commentary: Article 16, like Article 15, is an application of Article 14's equality principle. In the Thomas case (State of Kerala v. N.M. Thomas), the Supreme Court held that equality of opportunity includes compensatory measures to place SCs/STs on par with others, and that reservation could be permissible even under Article 16(1) to achieve real equality in results. Efficiency in administration (Article 335) remains a constitutional consideration. Affirmative measures, including reservations in promotions, are valid tools to achieve substantive equality in employment.

title: Constitution of India - Article 17 (Abolition of Untouchability)
content: Untouchability is abolished and its practice in any form is forbidden. Enforcement of any disability arising from untouchability is an offence punishable in accordance with law. The Untouchability Offences Act, 1955, renamed the Protection of Civil Rights Act in 1976, prescribes penalties for acts such as preventing a person from entering a place of worship or from accessing public water sources. Article 17 is self-executing and, read with Article 39(a)(ii), makes clear that untouchability is permanently outlawed. Though addressed mainly to private conduct, it also binds the State.

title: Constitution of India - Article 18 (Abolition of Titles)
content: (1) No title, not being a military or academic distinction, shall be conferred by the State. (2) No citizen of India shall accept any title from any foreign State. (3) No non-citizen holding any office of profit or trust under the State shall accept any title from a foreign State without the President's consent. (4) No person holding any office of profit or trust under the State shall, without the President's consent, accept any present, emolument, or office of any kind from or under any foreign State. This provision prevents the creation or perpetuation of titles that could undermine equality and democratic republican values.

title: Articles 19-22: Right to Freedom - Overview and Golden Triangle Doctrine
content: Article 19(1) of the Constitution guarantees to all citizens certain freedoms: (a) freedom of speech and expression; (b) to assemble peaceably and without arms; (c) to form associations or unions; (d) to move freely throughout the territory of India; (e) to reside and settle in any part of the territory of India; (f) omitted; (g) to practise any profession or to carry on any occupation, trade or business. Articles 19(2) to 19(6) impose reasonable restrictions on these freedoms in the interests of sovereignty, integrity, security, public order, decency, morality, or other specified grounds. The inter-relationship between Articles 14, 19, and 21 was examined in Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India (1978) 1 SCC 248, holding that Article 21 does not exclude Article 19; laws depriving personal liberty must meet the tests of Articles 14 and 19. In Minerva Mills v. Union of India (1980) 3 SCC 625, the Court described Articles 14, 19, and 21 as the 'Golden Triangle.' Bachan Singh v. State of Punjab (1982) 3 SCC 24 reaffirmed their vital role in the rule of law. T.R. Kothandaraman v. TN Water Supply Board (1994) 6 SCC 282 described the trinity as paving the path to liberty, equality and fraternity. The right to information, though not originally explicit, has been recognised under Article 19(1)(a) in cases like State of U.P. v. Raj Narain (1975) 4 SCC 428 and S.P. Gupta v. Union of India (1981 Supp SCC 87), emphasising open government.

title: Article 20 - Protection in Respect of Conviction for Offences
content: Article 20 contains three safeguards: (1) No person shall be convicted except for a violation of a law in force at the time of the act, nor subjected to a penalty greater than what was applicable at that time (protection against ex post facto laws). (2) No person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once (double jeopardy). (3) No person accused of any offence shall be compelled to be a witness against himself (protection against self-incrimination). In Kalpnath Rai v. State (1997) 8 SCC 732, the Court applied Article 20(1) to offences under the amended TADA Act. Maqbool Hussain v. State of Bombay, AIR 1953 SC 325, discussed Art. 20(2). Article 20(3) has been described as 'humane' and consistent with the requirement of just and fair trials under Article 21.

title: Article 21 - Protection of Life and Personal Liberty
content: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' Initially interpreted narrowly in A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras, AIR 1950 SC 27, where the freedoms under Articles 19, 21, 22, and 31 were seen as exclusive. This view was overturned in R.C. Cooper v. Union of India (1970) where the Court held that detention law must satisfy both Articles 21 and 19. In Kharak Singh v. State of UP, AIR 1963 SC 1295, 'personal liberty' was expansively defined. Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India (1978) held that any deprivation of liberty must meet the triple test: (i) valid law; (ii) conformity with applicable Article 19 freedoms; and (iii) compliance with Article 14. The law must be just, fair, reasonable—not arbitrary. Judicial interpretation has expanded Article 21 to include rights such as legal counsel, protection from bonded labour, livelihood, immediate medical aid, free legal aid, and education (Article 21A). The Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009, implements Article 21A.

title: Article 22 - Protection in Cases of Arrest and Detention
content: Article 22(1) and (2) grant arrested individuals the rights to be informed of grounds of arrest, consult a legal practitioner, and be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours; no further detention is permitted without magistrate approval. Articles 22(3)–(7) address preventive detention: allowing it under stringent safeguards, with maximum detention without Advisory Board opinion limited to three months. Parliament may prescribe circumstances and maximum periods of such detention. In Pankaj Kumar Chakrabarty v. State of W.B. (1969), preventive detention was seen as a 'necessary evil' subject to safeguards. In Alka Subhash Gadia (1992), the Court stressed that action under Article 22 must meet the constitutional tests of Articles 14, 19, and 21. Preventive and punitive detention are both permitted if authorised by valid law and procedure.

title: Article 23 - Prohibition of Traffic in Human Beings and Forced Labour
content: Article 23(1) prohibits traffic in human beings, begar (forced unpaid labour), and all similar forms of forced labour. Any contravention is an offence punishable by law. Article 23(2) allows the State to impose compulsory service for public purposes, but without discrimination based on religion, race, caste, or class. This right applies against both the State and private individuals. It covers human trafficking for immoral purposes, bonded labour, and any compulsion depriving a person of free choice to work. In People's Union for Democratic Rights v. Union of India (1982), the Supreme Court explained that this Article was included to provide immediate enforceable protection against exploitation, given the socio-economic conditions post-independence. The object was to eradicate bonded and forced labour, which were relics of feudal society and incompatible with an egalitarian order. In Gaurav Jain v. Union of India (1997), the Court noted that Article 23 also protects the rights of vulnerable women and children. Violation can be prosecuted under laws such as the Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act.

title: Article 24 - Prohibition of Employment of Children in Factories, etc.
content: Article 24 prohibits the employment of children below 14 years of age in any factory, mine, or other hazardous employment. This is a fundamental right enforceable against the State and private employers. The Supreme Court in M.C. Mehta v. State of Tamil Nadu (1996) took note of widespread child labour in hazardous industries and directed measures for abolition, including compulsory education, health check-ups, nutritional support, and responsibility sharing between industries and State governments. In Bandhua Mukti Morcha v. Union of India (1997), the Court ordered policy formulation for eradicating child labour and ensuring welfare of affected children. Article 24 is complemented by Article 21-A, introduced by the 86th Constitutional Amendment, which mandates free and compulsory education for children aged 6–14 years, and by the Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009.

title: Article 25 - Freedom of Conscience and Free Profession, Practice and Propagation of Religion
content: Article 25(1) guarantees all persons freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practise, and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality, health, and other provisions of Part III. Article 25(2) permits the State to regulate or restrict any secular activity associated with religious practice, and to enact laws for social welfare and reform, including throwing open Hindu religious institutions of a public character to all classes and sections of Hindus. Explanation I specifies that wearing and carrying kirpans is part of the Sikh religion. Explanation II clarifies that references to Hindus include Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists. Supreme Court rulings such as M. Ismail Faruqui v. Union of India (1994) affirm secularism as part of equality and the constitutional scheme; Commissioner of Police v.
