Acharya Jagadishwarananda Avadhuta (2004) links religious freedom with Article 14’s anti-discrimination principles. In Sri Venkataramana Devaru v. State of Mysore (1958), the Court applied the rule of harmonious construction, holding that denominational rights under Article 26(b) are subject to laws under Article 25(2)(b).

title: Article 26 - Freedom to Manage Religious Affairs
content: Subject to public order, morality, and health, every religious denomination or any section thereof has the right to establish and maintain institutions for religious and charitable purposes, manage its own affairs in matters of religion, own and acquire property, and administer such property according to law. The Supreme Court has applied these rights in contexts where denominational autonomy may intersect with State reforms, emphasising that in case of overlap, harmonious interpretation with Article 25(2)(b) ensures both community management and social reform objectives.

title: Article 27 - Freedom from Taxation for Promotion of a Religion
content: No person shall be compelled to pay taxes, the proceeds of which are specifically appropriated for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion or religious denomination. This provision upholds secularism by ensuring that State-collected taxes are not used to favour or finance religious activities of any specific faith.

title: Article 28 - Freedom as to Attendance at Religious Instruction or Religious Worship in Certain Educational Institutions
content: Article 28(1) prohibits religious instruction in educational institutions wholly maintained by State funds. Article 28(2) provides that this does not apply to institutions administered by the State but established under endowment or trust requiring religious instruction. Article 28(3) ensures that no person attending any State-recognised or State-aided institution shall be required to take part in religious instruction or worship without consent, or, in the case of minors, the guardian’s consent. This Article safeguards individual choice in religious participation within publicly supported educational contexts.

title: Article 29 - Protection of Interests of Minorities
content: Article 29(1) grants any section of the citizens residing in India or any part thereof, having a distinct language, script, or culture of its own, the right to conserve the same. Article 29(2) prohibits denial of admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving State aid on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language, or any of them. This protection applies to all citizens, whether majority or minority, and is linked to preserving linguistic, cultural, and script-based diversity. In T.M.A. Pai Foundation v. State of Karnataka (2002), the Supreme Court clarified that Article 29(1) is not religion-specific; it covers any section with distinct language, script, or culture. State-aided or State-maintained institutions—irrespective of who established them—cannot deny admission on grounds prohibited by Article 29(2). Article 29 operates alongside Article 30, fortifying minority rights to conserve identity through education while ensuring non-discrimination in public educational admissions.

title: Article 30 - Right of Minorities to Establish and Administer Educational Institutions
content: Article 30(1) grants all minorities, whether based on religion or language, the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice. Article 30(1A) provides that in laws for compulsory acquisition of property of a minority institution, compensation must not restrict or abrogate the Article 30(1) right. Article 30(2) prohibits the State from discriminating in granting aid to educational institutions on the ground that they are managed by a minority. In Sidhajbhai Sabbai v. State of Gujarat (1963), the Court held Article 30(1) as an absolute right, subject only to reasonable regulations regarding efficiency, discipline, health, sanitation, morality, and public order. In State of Kerala v. Very Rev. Mother Provincial (1970), it was emphasised that minority institutions must maintain standards of excellence and follow the general education pattern while retaining management rights. Ahmedabad St. Xavier’s College Society v. State of Gujarat (1974) underscored equality between majority and minority institutions in the right to education. St. Stephen’s College v. University of Delhi (1992) addressed balancing Article 30(1) with Article 29(2), holding that minority management must coexist with State powers to regulate education standards. T.M.A. Pai Foundation (2002) held Articles 29 and 30 essential to secularism and equality, ensuring minority protection without reverse discrimination. P.A. Inamdar v. State of Maharashtra (2005) affirmed that the right to establish and administer is unfettered if no State aid or recognition is sought, but general laws on public safety, national integrity, and prevention of exploitation still apply.

title: Article 32 - Remedies for Enforcement of Rights Conferred by this Part
content: Article 32(1) guarantees the right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for enforcement of the rights conferred by Part III (Fundamental Rights). Article 32(2) empowers the Supreme Court to issue directions, orders, or writs, including habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto, and certiorari, for enforcement of any of these rights. Clause (3) allows Parliament to empower other courts to exercise similar powers within their jurisdiction. Clause (4) states that the right under Article 32 shall not be suspended, except as provided by the Constitution, such as during a state of emergency under Article 359. Dr. B. R. Ambedkar called Article 32 the "heart and soul" of the Constitution, as it ensures guaranteed access to enforce fundamental rights. Alongside Article 32, Article 226 grants High Courts the power to issue writs for enforcing Fundamental Rights and for any other purpose, extending broader jurisdiction than Article 32, which is confined to Fundamental Rights enforcement.

title: Article 33 - Power of Parliament to Modify Rights in Relation to Certain Classes
content: Parliament may, by law, determine to what extent any of the rights conferred by Part III shall, in their application to: (a) members of the Armed Forces; (b) members of forces charged with the maintenance of public order; (c) persons employed in State-established organisations for intelligence or counter-intelligence; (d) persons employed in connection with telecommunications systems set up for such forces or organisations — be restricted or abrogated to ensure proper discharge of duties and maintenance of discipline. This provision recognises that full enjoyment of certain Fundamental Rights may be inconsistent with discipline required in security and defence services.

title: Article 34 - Restriction on Rights While Martial Law is in Force in Any Area
content: Article 34 allows Parliament to indemnify any person in the service of the Union, a State, or any other person for acts done in connection with maintenance or restoration of order in an area where martial law was in force. It also enables Parliament to validate sentences passed, punishments inflicted, forfeitures ordered, or other acts done under martial law in such an area. This provision ensures legal protection for actions taken during extraordinary situations involving martial law.

title: Article 35 - Legislation to Give Effect to Provisions of Part III
content: Notwithstanding anything in the Constitution, Parliament has the exclusive power to make laws with respect to: (i) matters under Article 16(3), Article 32(3), Article 33, and Article 34; and (ii) prescribing punishment for offences declared to be so under this Part. Parliament must make such laws as soon as possible after commencement of the Constitution. Clause (b) continues pre-Constitution laws relating to these matters until altered, repealed, or amended by Parliament. The Explanation adopts the meaning of 'law in force' from Article 372. Article 35 centralises law-making in sensitive areas relating to Fundamental Rights to maintain uniformity across India.
